abstract: The bank raised rates half a point to the highest level since 2008, but softened its tone on future increases.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England raised interest rates for a 10th consecutive time on Thursday, by half a percentage point, as policymakers kept up their vigilant stance against inflationary pressures.

headline: Jimmy Fallon Jokes That President Biden’s Document Drama Is a ‘Humblebrag’
abstract: “First, they searched near Biden’s Corvette, now they’re searching his beach house,” Fallon said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Cheering
abstract: What do you think this image is saying?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? Why do you think The Times published it this week? For what kind of article might it have served as the art? Can you relate to anything in it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: A Film Critic Who Embraces His Role as a Guide
abstract: Rescuing movie viewers from endless browsing — and introducing them to hidden gems — is satisfying to a Times critic.
lead_paragraph: The phrase “service journalism” is a loaded one, particularly among arts critics, who are constantly worrying that their thoughtful and nuanced criticism is being reduced to a yes or no binary — fresh or rotten fruit, if you will. Am I contributing to the cultural conversation, we worry, or merely serving as a consumer guide? But as the writer who curates the New York Times lists of the best movies to watch on Netflix and on Amazon Prime Video, and the best movies and TV shows to see on Hulu, I’ve come not only to accept the label of service journalism, but to embrace it.

headline: After Jacinda Ardern, Politics Will Never Look the Same
abstract: For once, a politician who wasn’t afraid of fashion.
lead_paragraph: Last September, Jacinda Ardern, the prime minister of New Zealand who announced recently that she was stepping down after almost six years in power, did something government leaders rarely do. She modeled in a fashion show.

headline: A U.S. Ambassador Finds Himself on Hostile Ground in Hungary
abstract: David Pressman, a gay human rights lawyer, has been accused by pro-government media in Hungary of undermining traditional values, violating diplomatic conventions and meddling in the judiciary.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — David Pressman, a gay human rights lawyer, knew he was in for a rough time even before he arrived in Hungary with his husband and two children to take up a new job in September as the United States’ ambassador to Europe’s self-declared citadel of traditional Christian values and friend of the Kremlin.

headline: A Primer on U.S.-Philippine Military Ties
abstract: The United States and the Philippines have announced a plan to broaden American military access. The alliance is complicated by colonial history and rising tensions over Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: The United States and the Philippines announced a deal on Thursday that will give U.S. forces access to four more military sites in the Southeast Asian country, creating the largest American military presence there in decades.

headline: Top E.U. officials arrive in Kyiv for a summit with Zelensky.
abstract: The European Union’s top officials arrived in Ukraine on Thursday before a summit with President Volodymyr Zelensky to discuss issues including Ukraine’s reconstruction and its candidacy for membership in the bloc.
lead_paragraph: The European Union’s top officials arrived in Ukraine on Thursday before a summit with President Volodymyr Zelensky to discuss issues including Ukraine’s reconstruction and its candidacy for membership in the bloc.

headline: 36 Hours in Bangkok
abstract: A secret garden, a bicycle ride across city and paddy farms, and a world-class cocktail scene in Thailand’s capital.
lead_paragraph: A secret garden, a bicycle ride across city and paddy farms, and a world-class cocktail scene in Thailand’s capital.

headline: How to Forge Shells for Ukraine's Artillery
abstract: At factories in Pennsylvania and Iowa, steel shells are formed in 2,000-degree furnaces and filled with explosives — offering Kyiv a lifeline of ammunition.
lead_paragraph: At factories in Pennsylvania and Iowa, steel shells are formed in 2,000-degree furnaces and filled with explosives — offering Kyiv a lifeline of ammunition.

headline: She Became a Broker to Buy Her Own House Near Washington, D.C. Which Did She Choose?
abstract: Aiming to be her ‘own advocate’ and save on commission fees, a schoolteacher dived into the real estate game and emerged with her first single-family home. Here’s how she did it.
lead_paragraph: Aiming to be her ‘own advocate’ and save on commission fees, a schoolteacher dived into the real estate game and emerged with her first single-family home. Here’s how she did it.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on ‘The Price Is Right’ Strategies
abstract: A family is divided on the controversial “dollaring” of an opponent.
lead_paragraph: Abbey writes: My mother-in-law has a strong moral stance against “dollaring” on “The Price Is Right” — or bidding one dollar higher than your opponent. But I like to root for contestants who “dollar” others: It’s good strategy. Please tell my mother-in-law to hate the game, not the player.

headline: Poem: Birthday
abstract: Wonder needs no ornaments, only an invitation, and to have been born at all.
lead_paragraph: The fatal clichés in life are not those of the soul, or love, or nature — they are, instead, the tired accusations made against these things by the awe-starved know-it-alls of the world. What cynics call clichés are, in fact, poetry’s ancient obsessions, and Ana Božičević’s “Birthday” is a cunning defense of poetry’s work. This poem meets cynicism with determined simplicity, the form making its own argument via a spare and elegant use of repetition and surprise. Wonder needs no ornaments, only an invitation, and to have been born at all, “Birthday” reminds us, is a good enough reason for a party. Selected by Anne Boyer

headline: The Teenager Leading the Smartphone Liberation Movement
abstract: Logan Lane gave up her smartphone. That changed her life.
lead_paragraph: How many hours do you spend on your phone each day? Probably more than you’d like. In our technology-saturated world, we rely on our devices for what feels like an endless list of daily tasks — everything from staying up-to-date on Twitter to killing time at the post office. The idea of reclaiming any degree of independence from our smartphones can often feel impossible.

headline: New York Pays $121 Million for Police Misconduct, the Most in 5 Years
abstract: The total was driven up by a small group of very expensive cases, including a settlement with a man wrongly accused of assassinating Malcolm X.
lead_paragraph: Police misconduct settlements in New York City last year were driven to their highest level since 2018 by six payouts over $10 million, including one for Muhammad A. Aziz, whose conviction in the assassination of Malcolm X was thrown out after he spent two decades in prison.

headline: They Crossed Paths in Second Grade. Now They’re Best Sellers.
abstract: When “Master Slave Husband Wife” came out last month, Ilyon Woo teamed up with her old friend Imani Perry for her first book event.
lead_paragraph: “I saw a little school report from back then and it said, ‘Ilyon likes to play with Imani,’” Ilyon Woo said in a phone interview about her second book, “Master Slave Husband Wife,” which debuted at No. 7 on the hardcover nonfiction list. “We were both pigtailed back then.”

headline: What Slang Words Do You Use?
abstract: A new vocabulary called “algospeak” has emerged on TikTok. Does it change the way you talk and write?
lead_paragraph: Today’s featured article begins:

headline: The Trillion-Dollar Question: Could a Coin Save the Day?
abstract: The latest standoff over raising the nation’s debt ceiling is giving new life to an old theory about how to avoid a default.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The debt limit standoff between Republicans and Democrats has elevated questions about creative solutions for averting a crisis, including one that at first blush might seem unthinkable: Could minting a $1 trillion platinum coin make the whole problem go away?

headline: Alex Prud’homme Wishes He Was in the Room Where It Happened
abstract: “That toothsome meal arguably saved the Republic,” says the journalist, whose new book is “Dinner With the President: Food, Politics, and a History of Breaking Bread at the White House,” of Thomas Jefferson’s so-called Dinner Table Bargain. “The debate at Jefferson’s reverberates today.”
lead_paragraph: I have a colorful pile of books that is slowly accreting by my bed, and occasionally sets off a landslide. At the moment the stratum includes: George Saunders’s “A Swim in a Pond in the Rain,” Geoff Dyer’s “The Last Days of Roger Federer,” Toni Tipton-Martin’s “Jubilee” cookbook, Patti Smith’s “M Train,” Mark Strand’s “Hopper,” Mark Rozzo’s “Everybody Thought We Were Crazy,” Ian Fleming’s “Thrilling Cities” (a 1963 travelogue picked up for 10 cents), Sally Mann’s “Hold Still” and a substrate of magazines and catalogs. I dip in and out of these books before sleep, or when I’m procrastinating, and will eventually finish them all. Or not.

headline: A Century On, the Search for the Real Franz Kafka Continues
abstract: Translating Kafka’s diaries revealed a writer even more alive than English-language readers previously knew.
lead_paragraph: The first time Franz Kafka’s voice entered my head, I was 15. Two new friends I’d made through our shared interest in literature had introduced me to his fiction, and we took turns reading the Willa and Edwin Muir translations to each other in the high school library. I distinctly recall the three of us reading “The Judgment” aloud and bursting out laughing at the passage when the protagonist discovers his father’s underwear is unclean and again when his father stands up on the bed to berate him.

headline: The Secret to a Better Workout Is Probably Already in Your Kitchen
abstract: Used correctly, caffeine can help you lift more, run faster and cycle farther.
lead_paragraph: For two years, Steph Gaudreau gave up her daily cup of coffee. She switched to large mugs of herbal tea — not because caffeine was affecting her sleep or making her anxious, but to gain an edge in cross-country mountain bike racing.

headline: Who Should Get a Covid Booster Now? New Data Offers Some Clarity.
abstract: If you are high-risk, the answer is straightforward. If you are low-risk, there is less consensus.
lead_paragraph: Three years into the pandemic, it has become evident that Covid-19 isn’t going anywhere, and neither are vaccine boosters.

headline: Five Years Ago, I Wrote a Fictional Disaster That Is Now Playing Out in Real Time
abstract: The battle over South River Forest has turned violent.
lead_paragraph: What could make a person die for trees?

headline: Senator Calls on Apple and Google to Ban TikTok in App Stores
abstract: Michael F. Bennet, a Colorado Democrat, cited national security, adding to bipartisan pressure on the Chinese-owned video app.
lead_paragraph: Senator Michael Bennet, Democrat of Colorado, called on Apple and Google Thursday to remove TikTok from their app stores because of national security concerns, as bipartisan pressure on the Chinese-owned company escalates.

headline: For the Conductor Charles Munch, Virtuosity Meant Taking Risks
abstract: This 20th-century maestro could be extreme at the podium, but he also believed in the “beauty, joy and goodness” of an artist’s calling.
lead_paragraph: When Charles Munch started work as the conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra in the fall of 1949, he gave a speech.

headline: They Outlasted the Dinosaurs. Can They Survive Us?
abstract: Sturgeon are disappearing from North American rivers where they thrived for millions of years. And the quest to save them is exposing the limits of the Endangered Species Act.

headline: An Enduring Commitment, Wedding Ring or Not
abstract: One woman’s quest to find a replacement for the too-small gold band she has had for more than four decades.
lead_paragraph: I don’t wear my wedding ring anymore. I haven’t for the last 20 or so years. I’m not divorced, nor do I plan to be anytime soon. After 47 years, I haven’t outgrown my marriage but I have outgrown my ring.

headline: Falling Mortgage Rates Bring Some Home Buyers Back to Market
abstract: The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell to 6.09 percent this week, the lowest in five months. Buyers are returning, but experts say the state of the economy will drive the market’s next moves.
lead_paragraph: Earlier in the pandemic, when many urbanites were leaving New York to work remotely in far-flung locations, Molly Parker Wade instead moved from the West Coast to Brooklyn to be closer to her family.

headline: At This Popular Restaurant, Proposals Are Their Specialty
abstract: One if by Land, Two if by Sea in Greenwich Village, which offers the perfect setting for romantic engagements, expects to see a jump in proposals in February.
lead_paragraph: Synonymous with love as it is with Old World charm, One if by Land, Two if by Sea, located at 17 Barrow Street in Manhattan’s Greenwich Village neighborhood, is a restaurant that is not only a fine dining landmark, but also the perfect setting for a romantic proposal.

headline: Power to Punish LIV Golfers Faces a Legal Test in Europe
abstract: An arbitration panel will meet next week to weigh whether the European Tour may penalize the men who played on the Saudi-backed circuit.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — Many of the golfers had wandered away one afternoon last week, seeking lunch or refuge from the Emirati sun or something besides the monotony of a driving range.

headline: Education Firms That Serve Hasidic Schools Are Barred Amid Fraud Inquiry
abstract: New York City education officials will block payments for some companies that have billed the government to provide special education, primarily for students in yeshivas.
lead_paragraph: New York City education officials have stopped doing business with 20 companies that provide education services in private schools amid concerns about fraud in the industry.

headline: Over 75,000 Job Openings in Iowa Alone. Millions of Refugees Seeking Work. Make the Connection.
abstract: Immigration reform is hard. Here are three ideas that could help.
lead_paragraph: Across the globe, 32.5 million refugees are seeking safety, many of them adults in search of work. At the same time, severe labor shortages in the United States and many other high-income countries have left businesses clamoring for workers.

headline: Wallpaper Everywhere All at Once
abstract: The current maximalist movement does not spare the ceiling.
lead_paragraph: When Ryia Jose decorated her daughters’ bedroom, she felt there was only one way to approach a room with a slanted ceiling: Cover it in wallpaper, the ceiling included.

headline: Nebraskans Are Sitting on Strategic Metals. Is Mining a Patriotic Duty?
abstract: One county has a wealth of minerals essential to defense and the green economy. Mining would transform the community, yet many say they feel a patriotic obligation to dig.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Forget Pandemic Puppies. Meet the Inflation Chicken.
abstract: People are snapping up chickens that are “heavy layers” in response to egg inflation. The chick situation holds lessons about the broader economy.
lead_paragraph: Which shortage came first: the chicks or the eggs?

headline: She Took On Atlanta’s Gangs. Now She May Be Coming for Trump.
abstract: Fani Willis’s aggressive tactics have sparked criticism — and won over voters. What do they tell us about how she might prosecute the former president?
lead_paragraph: Late on the first Sunday of 2021, news broke of President Donald J. Trump’s call with Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger of Georgia, asking him to “find 11,780 votes” to help contest the 2020 election. The next morning — Monday, Jan. 4 — was Fani Willis’s first day in the office as the district attorney for Fulton County, which encompasses most of Atlanta, as well as suburbs like Sandy Springs, East Point and Alpharetta. “Not the second day,” she told me when I met with her in November. “My very first day in this office — in that conference room, it’s all over the TV.” She found herself hoping that the secretary of state might have been “in another county when it happened,” she said, laughing darkly. He was not. And so, Willis said, “I’m stuck with it.”

headline: A Revolution in How Democrats Pick a President
abstract: A plan spearheaded by President Biden could see Iowa replaced as the first state to vote in the party’s primaries.
lead_paragraph: For the past 50 years, the race to become the Democratic Party’s presidential nominee has been shaped by the where the contest begins: Iowa.

headline: Encouraging Economic Signs
abstract: New data suggests a promising possibility for the economy — that the U.S. avoids big job losses.
lead_paragraph: American workers are getting smaller raises. Counterintuitively, that may be good news for the economy, and for hopes that the United States can avoid a recession.

headline: Shell’s Profit Soared to $42 Billion Last Year
abstract: The record haul, pushed by high energy prices and a hunger for liquefied natural gas, came as a new chief signaled a more “balanced approach” to renewable energy.
lead_paragraph: Shell, Europe’s largest energy company, reported a bumper profit for 2022 on Thursday: $42.3 billion, more than double its 2021 total and probably a record for any British company.

headline: ‘A Lot of Nothing’ Review: The Cop Next Door
abstract: Mo McRae’s feature debut, about a well-off Black couple and their white neighbor, is more of a trauma drama than a satirical thriller.
lead_paragraph: In “A Lot of Nothing,” James and Vanessa, a Black couple, are watching television on the couch in their well-appointed Los Angeles home when a news flash alerts them to “another officer-involved shooting.” James (Y’lan Noel), a corporate lawyer, and Vanessa (Cleopatra Coleman), who works in finance, are rattled and furious. Then they learn that the cop is their white neighbor, Brian (Justin Hartley), with whom Vanessa has already had words — following his contemptuous use of “you people.”

headline: ‘Pathaan’ Review: Fighting the Good (and Long) Fight
abstract: Filled to the brim with action set pieces, “Pathaan” stars Shah Rukh Khan as a secret agent saving India from havoc unleashed by a vengeful former operative.
lead_paragraph: The all-out action movie of the sort honed by Hollywood is not as prevalent in Bollywood. But “Pathaan,” a record-setting addition to a series of spy adventures, rolls out a flaming dessert cart of chugging guns, midair melees and ceaseless showdowns.

headline: ‘True Spirit’ Review: Around the World in 210 Days
abstract: Nothing rocks the boat for long in this can-do drama based on the true story of Jessica Watson, an Australian teenager who sailed the globe.
lead_paragraph: The soft-rock bard Christopher Cross once sang, “Sailing takes me away.” For one gutsy Aussie, Jessica Watson, “away” meant circling the globe at age 16. “True Spirit” streamlines and sanitizes her impressive real-life feat, which began in October 2009, into pure inspo fuel, recounting Watson’s maritime journey without ever turning grim for long.

headline: ‘The Amazing Maurice’ Review: A Cool Cat and His Band of Merry Rodents
abstract: Hugh Laurie voices a quippy, self-referential cat in this animated adaptation of a popular Terry Pratchett book.
lead_paragraph: “You know, in many ways, I don’t think the plot of this adventure has been properly structured,” observes the droll Malicia Grim (voiced by Emilia Clarke) during a brief lull in the middle of “The Amazing Maurice.”

headline: ‘Body Parts’ Review: Even Sex Scenes Have Rules
abstract: The documentary features performers and filmmakers discussing onscreen nudity and sex, but offers little on the subject of sexual exploitation.
lead_paragraph: Cinema’s first kiss was recorded in 1896, and the American film industry has been obsessed with desire and sex ever since. The documentary “Body Parts” is an attempt to account for cinema’s prurient interests. The documentarian Kristy Guevara-Flanagan interviews performers and filmmakers — including familiar faces like Jane Fonda and Karyn Kusama — on the topic of onscreen nudity and sex. Their stories of exploitation and negotiations are supported by archival clips from Hollywood movies of the present and past.

headline: ‘Love in the Time of Fentanyl’ Review: Heartbreak, Death and Hope in Vancouver
abstract: To combat the overdose crisis, a group that includes former and current users open a safe consumption site where shooting up does not have to mean death.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, in response to record high overdose deaths in Vancouver, a group of artists, activists, and current and former drug users in the Downtown Eastside neighborhood came together to form the Overdose Prevention Society, a renegade safe consumption site where drug users could safely consume drugs. The O.P.S. staff tests the drugs for fentanyl, provides clean needles and has Narcan on hand in case of an overdose. “Love in the Time of Fentanyl,” directed by Colin Askey, tenderly documents this community’s lifesaving efforts.

headline: ‘The Locksmith’ Review: A Botched Job
abstract: Ryan Phillippe plays a lock picker trying to escape his past in this clunky, clichéd crime thriller.
lead_paragraph: In the world of crime capers and thrillers, the “one last job” narrative framework has been used enough that it’s less of a trope than its very own genre — films of all stripes can play in the fun house, so long as they find a way to keep it fresh or winsome. Nicolas Harvard’s directorial debut “The Locksmith,” though, mostly takes stock characters and narrative turns and throws them into its basket, unable to fill the rest in with much color or nuance.

headline: Those Window Stickers to Prevent Bird Strikes? There’s a Catch.
abstract: Every year, hundreds of millions of birds die in the United States from flying into glass. New research shows how to prevent some of those deaths.
lead_paragraph: A thump on the window, if you’re around to hear it. A dead songbird below. Many people seek to prevent this sorrowful scenario by warning birds away with decals or film applied to windows of homes and office buildings. But there’s a big catch, a new study suggests: These products only work if affixed to the outside of the glass.

headline: ‘Full Time’ Review: No Rest for the Working Girl
abstract: A breathlessly tense portrait of modern labor, this French drama stars Laure Calamy as a single mother who hits her breaking point during a nationwide strike.
lead_paragraph: “Full Time,” the second feature by Éric Gravel, begins with a womblike moment of rest before pushing the pedal to the floor and launching us into the chaotic workweek of Julie (Laure Calamy), a single mother and the lead chambermaid of a 5-star hotel in Paris.

headline: Is Chelsea Setting the Market, or Breaking It?
abstract: The Premier League club’s American owners have splashed roughly $750 million on new players since last year. Puzzled rivals can’t see a strategy behind the spending.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the last few hours of the January transfer window ticked by, and as a small group of Chelsea executives were painstakingly trying to piece together the $131 million deal that would make Enzo Fernández, the 21-year-old Argentine midfielder, the most expensive player ever signed by an English team, Todd Boehly, the most high-profile of Chelsea’s new owners, was on the phone, trying to sign someone else.

headline: Investors Cheer Meta’s Slimmed-Down Ambitions
abstract: Meta’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, called 2023 the “year of efficiency,” a pronouncement that is reassuring investors and sparking a wider rally in tech stocks.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of a mammoth day for tech earnings, investors already like what they see.

headline: Single Women Own More Homes Than Single Men
abstract: A look at where the ownership gap is greatest and smallest across the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Single women own and occupy more homes than single men in the United States, despite earning only about 83 cents for every dollar that men earn, according to a new study.

headline: European Central Bank Raises Rates Again but Markets See an End to Escalation
abstract: The bank raised rates by half a point and said it expected to do the same in March, but traders are betting there will not be many more increases after that.
lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank kept up its aggressive efforts to fight inflation on Thursday, raising rates by half a percentage point to the highest since 2008 and all but promising another half-point increase in March.

headline: 60 Seconds With Elise Corbin
abstract: A chat with one of the New York Times Crossword constructors.
lead_paragraph: I’m very curious about the world around me and I enjoy learning about all the little interesting ways in which it works, and I like to think of crossword puzzles as a supplement to that. They’re a way for me to take an idea or a concept and have a little fun with it. With each puzzle, I try to push the boundaries of what I’ve seen before, and my goal is to make solvers go, “Wow, I didn’t know that was possible!” while also having learned something new and interesting.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
abstract: This week’s properties are on the Upper West Side, in the Flatiron district and in Astoria.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom, two-bath, 1,200-square-foot prewar apartment with French doors and built-in bookshelves in the living room; a windowed eat-in kitchen with a double oven and a Brazilian quartzite island countertop; a primary bedroom with pocket doors and an en suite bath with marble counters; two customized closets in the second bedroom; a windowed second bathroom; and two pantry closets, one large enough for a washer dryer with board approval; on the 13th floor of a 16-story 1925 landmark Neo-Georgian building with a doorman, live-in resident manager, extra storage, laundry room and bike room. Daniella Schlisser, Brown Harris Stevens, 212-906-9348; bhsusa.com

headline: Homes for Sale in New Jersey and New York
abstract: This week’s properties are a six-bedroom house in Frenchtown, N.J., and a three-bedroom house in Locust Valley, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A six-bedroom, seven-and-a-half-bath, three-story Victorian house built in 1878 and currently operating as a bed-and-breakfast, with a family room, living room, large updated kitchen, first-floor bedroom suite, pocket doors, stained-glass windows, three fireplaces, a lower-level caretaker’s suite, two patio areas, a detached two-car garage, additional parking and a separate cottage, on 0.27 acres. Sue Havens and Cynthia Shoemaker-Zerrer, Callaway Henderson Sotheby’s International Realty, 609-731-6089 or 609-915-8399; sothebysrealty.com

headline: California Will End Its Covid State of Emergency This Month
abstract: The orders that give the governor wider powers to fight the virus are set to expire on Feb. 28.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you heard the announcement this week that President Biden plans to end the nation’s Covid public health emergency in May, signaling that the pandemic has moved into a less dire phase.

headline: It’s Beyoncé’s Time to Shine at the Grammys … Right?
abstract: With a dominant new album, “Renaissance,” and the chance to become the most awarded artist in Grammy history, all eyes are on the pop superstar ahead of Sunday’s show. What could go wrong?
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé enters the 65th annual Grammy Awards on Sunday in rarefied air — a pop deity festooned with trophies, supported by one of the music world’s most ardent fan bases and on the precipice of Grammy immortality. So why does she also feel like an underdog?

headline: Valentine’s Day 2023 Gift Guide: What T Editors Covet Most Right Now
abstract: Essentials for a romantic night at home, sophisticated sweets and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always preferred to spend Valentine’s Day at home — avoiding crowded restaurants and dressing up on freezing-cold February nights. But that doesn’t mean it should feel like any other night. When I was growing up, my mother would serve what she called a “red dinner.” Beets and salmon (pink was permissible) were usually the stars, paired with cranberry juice and strawberry mousse for dessert. Now, my fiancé and I have started a new tradition of making Meera Sodha’s mushroom bao — a recipe we wouldn’t normally undertake on a weeknight. To inspire your own special night in, consider gifting your dinner companion a plant-dyed linen apron (the fuchsia-splattered Abstract pattern would be perfect for anyone planning a red dinner). Set the mood with a cocktail — those extending dry January will enjoy Amaro Falso, the newest nonalcoholic offering from the Brooklyn distillery St. Agrestis — poured into a festive glass. Maison Balzac, the Australian brand that specializes in colorful tableware, has a whimsical selection and, though it’s more suitably sized for chips or dips, I’m partial to the coupe featuring a faux pink prawn perched on its rim.

headline: ‘Dionne Warwick: Don’t Make Me Over’ Review: A Trailblazer Gets Her Flowers
abstract: This documentary tries to do justice to a six-decade career in 95 minutes, which proves challenging.
lead_paragraph: Before a late-career revival as a Twitter powerhouse, Dionne Warwick cultivated a music career that changed the game for Black people in America. Her influence as a crossover artist is brought to light in the new documentary, “Dionne Warwick: Don’t Make Me Over.”

headline: 2 Lawmakers Stripped of Immunity in Brussels Graft Inquiry
abstract: The European Parliament’s move is likely to prompt the arrest of Marc Tarabella of Belgium and Andrea Cozzolino of Italy in connection with claims of influence-peddling involving Qatar and Morocco.
lead_paragraph: European Union lawmakers revoked the immunity of two of their peers on Thursday, opening the door to more arrests by the Belgian authorities in the latest twist of a sweeping investigation into allegations of corruption of the bloc’s Parliament by Qatar and Morocco.

headline: New Jersey Councilwoman Is Fatally Shot, Officials Say
abstract: Eunice K. Dwumfour, 30, was found dead in her car with multiple gunshot wounds on Wednesday night. She was serving her first term on the Sayreville Borough Council.
lead_paragraph: SAYREVILLE, N.J. — Eunice K. Dwumfour, a 30-year-old councilwoman serving her first term in Sayreville, N.J., was fatally shot on Wednesday night, officials said.

headline: They’re Not Just Dads, They’re Congressional Dads
abstract: Male politicians who are parents of young children are wearing their fatherhood on their sleeves and their babies on their chests.
lead_paragraph: Several members of Congress, mostly men, held a news conference outside the Capitol last week — a typical sight in Washington.

headline: ‘Knock at the Cabin’ Review: Who’s There? The Apocalypse.
abstract: In M. Night Shyamalan’s latest thought experiment, Dave Bautista brings the end of the world to a peaceful country cottage.
lead_paragraph: A little girl, out collecting grasshoppers in the forest, meets someone who might be described — if this were a picture book — as a friendly giant. His huge arms are covered in tattoos, and his demeanor walks a fine line between gentle and fearsome.

headline: Deese, Top Economic Aide to Biden, Will Step Down This Month
abstract: Brian Deese, the director of the National Economic Council, played a pivotal role in negotiating economic legislation the president signed in his first two years in office.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Brian Deese, who served as President Biden’s top economic adviser and helped create and negotiate the sweeping economic legislation that Mr. Biden signed into law in his first two years in office, will leave his position in mid-February.

headline: Why Grandma’s Nutrition Drink Is So Hard to Disrupt
abstract: Upstarts have tried, and mostly failed, to compete with shakes like Ensure and Boost. They say the brands’ ties to health care providers make it tough.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, Barry Nalebuff’s 89-year-old father entered the hospital for hip surgery and came out a daily drinker of the nutritional shake Ensure, which his doctor recommended. Mr. Nalebuff, a professor at the Yale School of Management and a founder of Honest Tea, blanched when he read the back of the bottle: After water, the first two ingredients were corn maltodextrin and sugar.

headline: A Proud Ship Turned Into a Giant Recycling Problem. So Brazil Plans to Sink It.
abstract: The old aircraft carrier, once the navy’s flagship, is packed with asbestos. No country, including Brazil, will let it dock to be dismantled.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A decommissioned aircraft carrier, packed with an undetermined amount of asbestos, is being towed in circles off the coast of Brazil after it was refused permission to dock in Turkey for recycling. The problem? No government wants anything to do with it.

headline: Tortured Guantánamo Detainee Is Freed in Belize
abstract: Majid Khan, a Pakistani citizen who attended high school in Maryland, finished his sentence last year.
lead_paragraph: BELIZE CITY — A small Central American nation, known for its barrier reef and ecotourism, has taken in a former terrorist turned U.S. government informant whose tale of torture by the C.I.A. moved a military jury at Guantánamo Bay to urge the Pentagon to grant him leniency.

headline: ‘Baby Ruby’ Review: Enfant Terrible
abstract: This psychological horror movie stars Noémie Merlant as a new mother experiencing delusions and paranoia.
lead_paragraph: As moody and messy as its eponym, “Baby Ruby” aspires to demonstrate how postpartum psychosis can feel like a horror movie. It just fails to make the condition feel like a particularly convincing or cohesive horror movie.

headline: ‘Let It Be Morning’ Review: After the Wedding, the Siege
abstract: A Palestinian citizen of Israel returns to his hometown and encounters problems in this film from Eran Kolirin.
lead_paragraph: Opening titles situate “Let It Be Morning” “in a place not far from here a short while before peace breaks out.” The outlook for that tongue-in-cheek prediction only seems bleaker after the movie, set in an Arab village in Israel at the doorstep of — but not in — the West Bank.

headline: Ford Lost $2 Billion in 2022 as Some Investments Soured
abstract: The company’s financial performance was hurt by its stake in Rivian, an electric truck company, and an autonomous car business.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor said on Thursday that it lost $2.2 billion in 2022 as it wrote down the value of two big investments and struggled with high costs and supply chain problems.

headline: Israel’s Right-Wing Government Pushes Home Demolitions as Violence Surges
abstract: Israel defends its policy of leveling the family homes of Palestinians accused of attacks on its citizens as a deterrent. Critics say it is illegal and ineffective.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, Israel’s new, far-right minister of national security, Itamar Ben-Gvir, called for the immediate sealing of the family home of a Palestinian gunman who, a day earlier, had killed seven people in East Jerusalem before being shot dead by the police.

headline: ‘The Blind Man Who Did Not Want to See Titanic’ Review: Just Like the Movies
abstract: In this wry Finnish drama, a disabled man embarks on a journey to visit his girlfriend, encountering inaccessible infrastructure and evil goons along the way.
lead_paragraph: The opening scenes of Teemu Nikki’s film tell us two things about its protagonist, Jaakko (Petri Poikolainen): first, that he’s a cinephile who can’t get through a single conversation without referencing John Carpenter; second, that he is blind and uses a wheelchair.

headline: Meta Soars by Most in Decade, Adding $100 Billion in Value
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg’s company recorded its biggest daily market gain in nearly a decade, as the mood brightens among tech investors.
lead_paragraph: Meta’s stock surged on Thursday after the company reported better-than-expected earnings, said it would buy back billions of dollars in its stock, and overcame a court challenge to its ambitions in the so-called metaverse.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Social Connections
abstract: What do you notice and wonder about where people of different income levels make their friends?
lead_paragraph: These four graphs display where Americans make social connections and meet their friends. For each setting (high school, college, work and neighborhood), the y-axis shows the proportion of friends made in that setting relative to the national average for the different income groups. The data was gathered from 72.2 million active Facebook users ages 25 to 44. User information was anonymous.

headline: Something Very Important for Democrats Just Happened in Pennsylvania
abstract: Opening state jobs to more workers is a wise tweak to the party’s image.
lead_paragraph: I believe as fervently as anyone in the value of a four-year college degree not just as a path to professional opportunity but also as preparation for informed, thoughtful citizenship. I’ve written extensively about that, and I wouldn’t take back a word.

headline: Someone Called the Police on a Girl Catching Lanternflies. Then Yale Honored Her.
abstract: Bobbi Wilson, 9, was hunting for spotted lanternflies, an invasive species, in New Jersey. A neighbor called the police, but her effort has since earned recognition “from far and wide,” her mother said.
lead_paragraph: When Bobbi Wilson, 9, took it upon herself to spend hours of her summer aiming to obliterate the invasive spotted lanternflies that were ravaging her northern New Jersey community, she did not expect much attention. She just wanted to help.

headline: House Ousts Ilhan Omar From Foreign Affairs Panel as G.O.P. Exacts Revenge
abstract: In a highly politicized vote, the Republican-led chamber criticized Ms. Omar’s statements about Israel, delivering retribution for the removal of G.O.P. members when Democrats held the majority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bitterly divided House on Thursday ousted Representative Ilhan Omar of Minnesota from the Foreign Affairs Committee over past comments about Israel that were widely condemned as antisemitic, as Republicans moved to cater to the demands of right-wing members and mete out punishment to a Democrat their party has demonized for years.

headline: Avedon at Large
abstract: “Richard Avedon: Murals” fills just one gallery of the Met, but “fills” is an understatement. These in-your-face, wall-engulfing portraits are a milestone in image-making.
lead_paragraph: He had reached the heights of the fashion industry, photographing the most beautiful models each month for Alexander Liberman’s Vogue; he was shooting Bette Davis and Barbra Streisand for mink coat advertisements, and Catherine Deneuve for the cover of Life. But it wasn’t enough anymore. Not professionally, and not personally. Not after the assassination in Memphis, not after the riots in Chicago. Richard Avedon in 1968 was going through an artistic crisis. He needed a fresh start, with a new camera; he had to get out of New York; he needed to think bigger, in the most literal sense imaginable.

headline: Former High-Profile Lawyer Is Charged With Embezzling More Than $18 Million
abstract: Tom Girardi, who was part of the legal team representing the environmental activist Erin Brockovich, was indicted in two states on charges that he stole from clients, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Tom Girardi, a former high-profile trial lawyer known for winning a record settlement for the environmental activist Erin Brockovich, has been indicted by federal grand juries in Los Angeles and Chicago on charges that he embezzled more than $18 million from clients, prosecutors said on Wednesday.

headline: In Congo, a Pope and a Nation Revitalize Each Other
abstract: Francis has been slowed by age. But his enthusiastic welcome in Africa has proved a shot in the arm and provided a reminder of the papacy’s global reach.
lead_paragraph: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — Pope Francis put down his prepared remarks and instructed the stadium packed with young Catholics in Congo to make clear their opposition to the corruption that had hobbled their country with a single, rousing voice.

headline: 13 Easy Slow Cooker Chicken Recipes for the Busiest Days
abstract: A few minutes of prep in the morning means you don’t have to think about dinner again until it’s time to eat.
lead_paragraph: For some home cooks, the slow cooker is the fairy godmother of kitchen appliances. Toss a few ingredients into the crock (maybe sear the meat or sauté some veg, if you like), set the timer, go about your day and, when you come home, ta-da! Your kitchen smells like someone has been minding the stove all day, and dinner is, with the exception of a few finishing touches, done.

headline: Philomena Cunk Is Weird Enough to Take on the World
abstract: The new Netflix show “Cunk on Earth” looks like an ambitious BBC documentary. Until its fictional host, created by Charlie Brooker, starts to ask some deeply silly questions.
lead_paragraph: On her BBC show investigating the history of humanity, Philomena Cunk interviews Martin Kemp, a professor at the University of Oxford, about the Renaissance period.

headline: I Made You a Meal Plan
abstract: These three recipes (and Venn diagram!) are an exercise in strategic overlaps and substitutions.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago at the grocery store, as I was being shaken down for all I’m worth in front of the egg shelf, a woman next to me gasped as she looked at the prices. We’re all trying to combat skyrocketing costs, and meal planning can save you from impulse buying and wasting food down the road.

headline: ‘Una Vita Difficile’ Review: Life Comes at You Fast
abstract: Alberto Sordi stars as an idealistic Italian Everyman caught up in a changing postwar world in this rediscovered comedy from the ’60s.
lead_paragraph: “Una Vita Difficile” (“A Difficult Life”) slides and skitters over nearly two decades of Italian history, from the partisan battles with German occupiers after the fall of Mussolini to the economic boom of the 1960s. It’s a movie — released in Italy in 1961 and only now making its way to North American screens — about a great many wonderful and vexing things, including love, honor, money, cinema, politics and Alberto Sordi’s remarkable chin.

headline: Felix Gonzalez-Torres, a Master of Mutability
abstract: An ultra-polished survey of the artist’s works at David Zwirner — some not seen before — demonstrate how preservation and change can coexist.
lead_paragraph: My old friend Shepherd Raimi, who had some 30 years on me, used to say over and over, mantra-like — I can still hear his voice — “Everything changes. All the time.” He wasn’t offering an observation. He was delivering a life lesson, to me, to himself, to anyone listening.

headline: Review: Dancing for Themselves in an Underworld of Shadows
abstract: Cullberg, a contemporary Swedish company, makes its Joyce Theater debut with Deborah Hay’s delicate, hypnotic “Horse, the Solos.”
lead_paragraph: Seven bodies dance in the light, in the dark and in the shadowy in between. One raises a knee as a toe languidly stirs the air. A single arm dangles above the head as a leg extends behind, hovering close to the floor. Arms bend at the elbows with dripping, shimmering fingers. Deborah Hay’s hourlong “Horse, the Solos” is a hypnotic underworld: Gradually, you descend into it, and gradually, it takes hold.

headline: Ron DeSantis’s Efforts to Make Education in Florida Less ‘Woke’
abstract: The Florida governor’s influence on an A.P. Black studies course. Also: The killing of Black men; a formidable Trump; anti-boycott bills; living without plastic.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Celebrating the Roaring 2020s With a Bee’s Knees Cocktail
abstract: The Prohibition Era favorite is back on bar menus, with creative ingredients but the same inherent charm.
lead_paragraph: The Bee’s Knees cocktail — a simple sour composed of gin, lemon juice and honey that is one of the few enduring drinks to come out of the Prohibition era — is having a busy time of it.

headline: How to Clean Stainless Steel Appliances
abstract: Using vinegar isn't a good idea.
lead_paragraph: Using vinegar isn't a good idea.

headline: ‘Godland’ Review: Another of God’s Lonely Men Goes Amok (Spiritually)
abstract: In this striking drama set in the late 19th century, a Danish priest travels to Iceland and is gradually undone by a world he can’t understand.
lead_paragraph: Soon after the Danish priest at the center of “Godland” staggers onto Iceland for the first time, he falls to his knees. For the rest of this sly, brutal movie he will keep on staggering and falling, overcome by the harsh weather, the unforgiving land, his difficult venture and, most crucially, his vainglorious ego. He’s been selected to establish a new church in a small Icelandic community, but somewhere along his travels he has forgotten that crucial lesson about pride, destruction and haughty spirits.

headline: Eye Drops Are Recalled After Being Linked to Vision Loss and 1 Death
abstract: The maker of EzriCare Artificial Tears said it was recalling the eye drops after U.S. health authorities linked the product to a drug-resistant bacteria strain.
lead_paragraph: The manufacturer of a brand of over-the-counter eye drops said that it was recalling the product, EzriCare Artificial Tears, after it was linked to a drug-resistant bacteria strain that has caused at least one person’s death and vision loss in five others.

headline: Newly Published, From Climate Fiction to a Lost Congolese Princess
abstract: A selection of recently published books.
lead_paragraph: IN THE BELLY OF THE CONGO, by Blaise Ndala. Translated by Amy B. Reid. (Other Press, paperback, $18.99.) In this novel the story of what happened to a Congolese princess, who disappeared after her forced exhibition at the Brussels World’s Fair of 1958, is unearthed when her niece meets the son of one of her captors 45 years later.

headline: Facing Death, a Pianist Recorded Music of Unspeakable Emotions
abstract: Lars Vogt, for one of his final albums made before dying from cancer, turned to chamber music by Schubert with Christian and Tanja Tetzlaff.
lead_paragraph: There are recordings that are meant for the ages, that are intended to sound definitive. There are recordings that document a fleeting interpretation, that inspire or provoke, that accept the impossibility of a final word. And then there are the rare recordings whose circumstances defy the ordinary routines of an artist, that capture a high or a low moment in that person’s life and, matched to the right music, transcend it.

headline: Review: At New York City Ballet, a Too Quiet Debut
abstract: “Fortuitous Ash,” Keerati Jinakunwiphat’s first work for a ballet company, was spectral in two senses: ghostly and insubstantial.
lead_paragraph: When Kyle Abraham’s “The Runaway” had its debut at New York City Ballet nearly five years ago, it made a strong impression. His first work for a ballet company, it infused new sounds (tracks by Kanye West and Jay-Z, among others), outré costumes and ways of moving that were bold and contemporary while still drawing on the dancers’ classical technique. It wasn’t flawless. But it was fresh and exciting, and it was an immediate hit.

headline: Britain to Investigate if Deadliest Attack of Northern Ireland’s ‘Troubles’ Was Preventable
abstract: The decision is a big victory for the families of the 29 people who died in the attack in August 1998, four months after the signing of the Good Friday Agreement.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nearly 25 years after a car bomb killed 29 people in the Northern Ireland town of Omagh — the deadliest single attack of the era known as the Troubles — the British government said on Thursday that it would open an independent inquiry into whether security forces could have averted the bombing.

headline: In ‘Dear Edward,’ Connie Britton Embraces Her Inner ‘Real Housewife’
abstract: The series reunites the actor with Jason Katims, the “Friday Night Lights” showrunner. But the wealthy suburbanite she plays is “so not Tami Taylor,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2010, after she shot the final episode of “Friday Night Lights,” Connie Britton rather famously had an identity crisis.

headline: Charter School Expansion Faces Tough Fight in New York
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul wants to allow more charter schools to open in New York City. But as the public school system loses students, the effort faces strong political headwinds.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s proposal to allow dozens of new charter schools to open in New York City has set the stage for a charged battle in the coming months over the future of the city’s school system.

headline: Trump Won’t Commit to Backing the G.O.P. Nominee in 2024
abstract: The former president faces several potential Republican challengers in his bid for the White House.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump refused to say he would support the next Republican presidential nominee if it was not him, exposing a potential quagmire along the party’s path toward reclaiming the White House in 2024 and showcasing, once again, the former president’s transactional spin on political loyalty.

headline: Why Are So Many Americans Dying Right Now?
abstract: Where are the country’s quite large numbers of deaths actually coming from?
lead_paragraph: About 1.1 million Americans have officially died from Covid-19 since the start of the pandemic, a number that may be familiar by now. But here’s a less familiar one: According to one tabulation by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, more than 300,000 additional Americans have died over the past three years whom we would not have expected to in more normal times.

headline: The Juicy Secret to Stellar Baby Back Ribs
abstract: You don’t need a smoker or a grill to make sticky, tender ribs at home — just an oven and a surprising four-ingredient glaze.
lead_paragraph: In 1853, a grape varietal from the farmer Ephraim Wales Bull won first prize at an exhibition for the Boston Horticultural Society. He had been working on this particular type of grape for a decade: a sturdy, sweet-tart purple fruit that could survive the harsh winters in Concord, Mass., where he lived. These days, Concord grapes are most often sold as juice and jelly, concentrated down to their fruitiest essence.

headline: Claudia Cardinale: 6 Decades in the Movies
abstract: Ahead of a MoMA retrospective, the actress reflected on her career, which includes over 100 films and many classics of Italian cinema.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon in Rome, Claudia Cardinale recalled the many heartthrobs she worked with during her more than six-decade movie career, and let out a full-throated laugh.

headline: What Students Are Saying About ChatGPT
abstract: Is this new chatbot the end of education as we know it? Or a useful new tool for learning? Teenagers weigh in.
lead_paragraph: By now you’ve probably heard of ChatGPT, a powerful new artificial intelligence chatbot released to the public late last year that can craft jokes and working computer code, guess at medical diagnoses, and create text-based Harry Potter games.

headline: Man Killed by Memphis Police in Library Had Shot Officer, Authorities Say
abstract: The officer was taken to a hospital in “extremely critical” condition, the department said. The Memphis police have been under intense scrutiny after the death of Tyre Nichols.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — A Memphis police officer shot and killed a man in a public library on Thursday afternoon after the man shot another officer, critically wounding him, the authorities said.

headline: The Impact of Tom Brady’s Retirement Is Still Unfolding
abstract: Brady claims he is done for good, but it is unclear what that will mean for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, the Fox broadcast booth and other interested parties.
lead_paragraph: Tom Brady will not be competing on a football field next fall. That much is certain, at least if you believe his second retirement will stick.

headline: What Do You Think About the Controversy Surrounding the New A.P. Course on African American Studies?
abstract: First, Florida banned the course. Then, the College Board published the official course framework stripped down from an original draft. What’s your reaction?
lead_paragraph: Update, Feb. 13: Two new Times articles add additional reporting on this topic: “Florida Officials Had Repeated Contact With College Board Over African American Studies” and “The College Board’s Rocky Path, Through Florida, to the A.P. Black Studies Course.”

headline: It’s Winter. Let’s Go to the Farmers’ Market!
abstract: In cities like Detroit and Philadelphia, markets have become year-round destinations, offering classes, crafts and music, as well as a surprising array of fresh produce.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday morning at Eastern Market in Detroit, busking musicians filled the air with jazz as vendors finished setting up for the day’s traffic. Shoppers streamed in, sizing up winter produce, relishes and chutneys, fresh cuts of beef and more.

headline: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar Was the ‘Best Weapon in Basketball’
abstract: Everyone knew he was close to surpassing Wilt Chamberlain’s career scoring record in 1984. Opponents still couldn’t stop him.
lead_paragraph: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar was still a couple of months from breaking the N.B.A.’s career scoring record, but Mark Eaton of the Utah Jazz had been crunching the numbers, and he was worried — for himself.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: The U.S. Military Expands in the Philippines
abstract: Also, Vladimir Putin evokes Stalingrad and a contested film is a box-office hit in India.
lead_paragraph: The two countries announced an agreement that would allow the U.S. to gain access to four more sites in the Philippines. The plans for a larger U.S. military presence in the country come amid fears about a possible Chinese invasion of Taiwan.

headline: How the R&B Innovator Kelela Unlocked a New Level
abstract: In the six years since her debut, “Take Me Apart,” the 39-year-old musician has been researching, processing and preparing to make an even bolder statement.
lead_paragraph: In mid-January, Kelela Mizanekristos emailed over the document she shares with everyone who plans to work with her. It’s a syllabus for the university of her mind, a guide to help the 39-year-old R&B musician’s collaborators understand the foundation on which she builds her art: her experiences, good, bad and in-between, as a queer Black woman.

headline: Alphabet’s Profit Falls 34% Amid Ads Slowdown
abstract: Google’s parent company reported its fourth consecutive drop in quarterly profit, weeks after culling 6 percent of its work force to cut costs.
lead_paragraph: Alphabet, Google’s parent company, has settled into a period of stalled growth as economic uncertainty reverberates across Silicon Valley. Gone are the pandemic boom times, when the internet giant’s profit and employee head count soared.

headline: Mira Lehr, Artist Who Explored Nature’s Distress, Dies at 88
abstract: She helped found a gallery for women artists in Miami Beach and, influenced by an early Buckminster Fuller experiment, focused her art on ecology.
lead_paragraph: Mira Lehr, a versatile Florida artist who helped found an early cooperative gallery for women artists in Miami Beach and whose paintings, sculptures and installations often reflected her concerns about environmental degradation, died on Jan. 24 in Miami Beach. She was 88.

headline: Amazon Reports Almost No Profit and Slowing Growth
abstract: The company indicated the reduced growth and tight margins would continue in the first three months of this year.
lead_paragraph: Amazon on Thursday reported almost no profit in the latest quarter, with unexpected weakness in its big cloud computing businesses helping to slow overall sales growth to one of its lowest levels in decades.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: It’s coincidence more than divine providence that three of our recommended books this week evoke religion in their titles: Paul Harding’s novel “This Other Eden” describes the expulsion of its characters from an earthly paradise in Maine, A.E. Stallings’s collected poems in “This Afterlife” use close observation and formal structure to summon a state of everyday grace, and Jamie Kreiner’s “The Wandering Mind” explores (in its subtitle’s words) “What Medieval Monks Tell Us About Distraction.” It turns out they struggled with short attention spans too: For a headline on that review, we almost went with “Our father who art in — squirrel!”

headline: Ann McLaughlin Korologos, Former Labor Secretary, Dies at 81
abstract: Her brief tenure as only the second woman to run the department came after years of service within the Reagan administration.
lead_paragraph: Ann McLaughlin Korologos, who served as secretary of labor from 1987 to 1989, becoming only the second woman to hold the post, died on Jan. 30 in Salt Lake City. She was 81.

headline: In High-Profile Raids, Zelensky Showcases Will to Tackle Corruption
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky is eager to highlight his crackdown on corruption, ahead of E.U. accession talks and possible Western investigations of war aid.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — A leaked police video showing bundles of cash found in an official’s sofa. A tax inspector accused of fraud in issuing refunds. The dismissal of the chief of the customs service and his top deputy, as well as senior officials from a consumer protection agency and the forestry agency. And a search warrant served on a business tycoon once seen as all but untouchable for his close ties to government.

headline: Apple Revenue and Profit Down as iPhone Sales Slow
abstract: The iPhone maker said sales of its flagship product were down 8 percent as it dealt with a factory shutdown and worries about rising inflation.
lead_paragraph: When a Covid-19 outbreak in China forced a lockdown of Apple’s largest iPhone factory in November, the world’s most valuable company warned investors that it would lose sales. The question was: How much?

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Congress Expands Scrutiny of Junior R.O.T.C. Programs
abstract: Senators said they were “disturbed” by reports that schools were automatically enrolling students into the military program. Lawmakers are also examining other issues.
lead_paragraph: Congressional leaders have expanded their scrutiny of the military’s Junior Reserve Officers’ Training Corps program, asking for information about the program’s enrollment practices, curriculum and sponsor relationships with the National Rifle Association.

headline: These Extinct Elephants Were Neanderthals’ ‘Biggest Calorie Bombs’
abstract: A study of butchered bones from 125,000 years ago offers what researchers call “the first clear-cut evidence of elephant-hunting in human evolution.”
lead_paragraph: In his 1931 book, “How to Tell Your Friends From the Apes,” the American satirist Will Cuppy noted that Neanderthals had fires, caves, marrow bones, mosquitoes, love and arthritis. “What more can you ask?” he mused.

headline: Joyce Dopkeen, Barrier-Breaking News Photographer, Dies at 80
abstract: In 1973, she was the first woman hired by The New York Times to be a full-time staff photographer.
lead_paragraph: Joyce Dopkeen, who in 1973 became the first woman to be hired by The New York Times as a full-time staff photographer, beginning a 35-year career with the newspaper, died on Tuesday in Rockville, Md. She was 80.

headline: The Smell of Magic
abstract: A new crop of scents reference long-held beliefs about the connection between perfume and the supernatural.
lead_paragraph: In the third-century B.C. Greek epic poem the Argonautica, the sorceress Medea wields fragrance as a magical weapon: In order to steal the coveted Golden Fleece, which is guarded by a dragon, she lulls the creature to sleep with a scented potion, escaping unscathed.

headline: Heather Gay of ‘Real Housewives’ Knows She’s a ‘Bad Mormon’
abstract: A star of the Salt Lake City franchise details her separation from the church in a new memoir.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — For Heather Gay, becoming a cast member on “The Real Housewives of Salt Lake City” was like “drawing a line in the sand” with her identity as a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. When she joined the Bravo show in 2019, she realized her move to quietly quit the faith would become very loud.

headline: Peru’s Foreign Minister Concedes There’s No Evidence Criminals Are Behind Protests
abstract: In an interview, Foreign Minister Ana Cecilia Gervasi acknowledged “we don’t have any evidence” that weeks of protests were being driven by criminal groups, though she maintained proof would be found.
lead_paragraph: In a stark admission, Peru’s foreign minister contradicted its president about the origin of deadly protests shaking the country, saying in an interview this week “we don’t have any evidence” that the demonstrations were being driven by criminal groups.

headline: Northeast Braces for the Worst Wind Chill in Decades
abstract: Forecasters say a dangerous cold will grip parts of the region on Friday and into Saturday.
lead_paragraph: By the time New Yorkers were commuting to work on Friday morning, the wind chill made it feel like just 10 degrees. In Boston, the cold air and wind combined to make it feel like 2 degrees. In Portland, Maine, the wind chill was a bracing minus 12 degrees. And that was the good news. It was expected to get significantly colder and windier throughout the day and into Saturday.

headline: The White House says Russian Olympians should be permitted only as neutral participants.
abstract: The stance differs from the full ban demanded by Ukraine and supported by some of its allies.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said on Thursday that Russian and Belarusian athletes should compete in the 2024 Olympics in Paris only as neutral participants, but it did not weigh in on the bigger question: whether the athletes should be allowed in at all.

headline: Former Trump Executive, Already Jailed, Could Face More Fraud Charges
abstract: Manhattan prosecutors warned that they might charge Allen H. Weisselberg with insurance fraud to pressure him to cooperate in an investigation of the former president.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan prosecutors this week warned that they might file new fraud charges against Allen H. Weisselberg, a longtime top executive at Donald J. Trump’s real estate business — increasing pressure on Mr. Weisselberg to cooperate in a broader investigation into the former president, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Soaring Death Toll Gives Grim Insight Into Russian Tactics
abstract: Moscow is sending poorly trained recruits, including convicts, to the front lines in eastern Ukraine to pave the way for more seasoned fighters, U.S. and allied officials say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The number of Russian troops killed and wounded in Ukraine is approaching 200,000, a stark symbol of just how badly President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion has gone, according to American and other Western officials.

headline: Republicans and Debt: Blackmailers Without a Cause
abstract: Why this debt ceiling crisis is different from the last one.
lead_paragraph: Stop me if you’ve heard this before: Two years after a Democratic president took office and pushed ambitious policies through Congress, Republicans have regained control of the House. They don’t have the votes required to repeal the president’s achievements, but a quirk of U.S. law — which requires that Congress vote a second time to authorize the borrowing that results from already enacted spending and tax legislation — seems to give them an opportunity to engage in blackmail, threatening to create a financial crisis unless their demands are met.

headline: In the Age of A.I., Major in Being Human
abstract: How to acquire the skills no machine can have.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, a piece of artwork generated with artificial intelligence took a first prize at the Colorado State Fair. To me, the image looks like a view from the back of the stage at an opera. You see the backs of three singers, then, past them, vague squiggles and forms that may or may not be an audience, and all around, dominating everything, the fantastical Lord of the Rings-style palace where they are performing.

headline: Tech’s Biggest Companies Discover Austerity, to the Relief of Investors
abstract: After years of expansion and billions in profits, Big Tech is pulling back from its famously lavish spending as a long boom finally ends.
lead_paragraph: For much of last year, tech companies stumbled. Digital ad sales plunged. E-commerce sputtered. IPhone production stalled. And investors lost faith.

headline: Reflections on Star Quality From a Golden Age of ‘Junk TV’
abstract: In a new memoir, a longtime casting director revels in memories of a bygone Hollywood, matching actors with the roles that made them stars.
lead_paragraph: Stop to consider the movie and TV characters that are most permanently seared into the American psyche, and their impact is rarely a function of screen time. Usually, the effect on audiences is immediate: Think Tim Curry’s first appearance in “The Rocky Horror Picture Show,” or Stockard Channing breezing into Rydell High alongside her fellow Pink Ladies.

headline: Biden Aims to Deter China With Greater U.S. Military Presence in Philippines
abstract: U.S. officials say they are preparing to surge forces in the event of conflict with China, including over Taiwan, but do not intend to build up permanent bases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden and his aides have tried to reassure Chinese leaders that they do not seek to contain China in the same way the Americans did with the Soviet Union during the Cold War.

headline: As Russia Strikes Ukrainian Civilians, Putin Tells His People the War Is Just
abstract: Invoking World War II on the 80th anniversary of victory at Stalingrad, Mr. Putin repeated his false justifications for an invasion that has taken a staggering toll.
lead_paragraph: KRAMATORSK, Ukraine — While Ukrainian rescue workers searched a bombed-out apartment building for survivors of a Russian attack, President Vladimir V. Putin sought to assure his citizens on Thursday, in a speech invoking his nation’s victory over Nazi Germany, that this was another virtuous war.

headline: ‘Endgame’ Review: A Laugh at the Apocalypse?
abstract: There’s plenty of pleasure to be found at the end of the world in the Irish Repertory Theater production of Samuel Beckett’s play.
lead_paragraph: The dog is a small, stuffed toy, pathetic and adorable all at once. A sewing project in progress, he has a patchwork coat, three legs so far — and zero genitals, because those are going to be the finishing touch.

headline: Pentagon Says It Detected a Chinese Spy Balloon Hovering Over Montana
abstract: The revelation comes days before Secretary of State Antony Blinken’s visit to Beijing, where he is expected to meet with President Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: Live updates: The U.S. has shot down the Chinese spy balloon.

headline: Corrections: Feb. 3, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Feb. 3, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the hostile welcome that David Pressman, the U.S. ambassador to Hungary, received in Budapest described incorrectly the anti-L.G.B.T. message directed at him on a banner. It read, “Mr. Pressman, don’t colonize Hungary with your cult of death,” not “Mr. Pressman, don’t terrorize Hungary with your cult of death.”

headline: Report Traces Rising Prevalence of Semiautomatic Pistols in Gun Crimes
abstract: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms created a statistical portrait that law enforcement agencies can use to address new threats, which include untraceable “ghost guns.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — About two million guns linked to crimes were recovered by law enforcement officials around the country from 2017 to 2021 — many of them semiautomatic pistols modeled on Glock 9-millimeter handguns, according to the most comprehensive national accounting of crime guns in decades.

headline: Actress and Hairdresser Took $3 Million From Malibu Doctor, Prosecutors Say
abstract: They feigned friendship, moving into the ailing doctor’s beachfront home and giving him drugs, while they spent his money, according to the federal indictment. Both face a range of charges.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — An actress and a hairdresser feigned friendship with a wealthy doctor, moved into his beachfront home in Malibu, Calif., and plied him with drugs including marijuana and LSD while defrauding him of at least $3 million, according to a federal indictment unsealed this week.

headline: Finishing-Line Cry
abstract: Barb Lin makes her themeless crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Two-for-One Crossword
abstract: Derrick Niederman makes us work twice as hard on an interesting challenge.
lead_paragraph: TWO-FOR-ONE CROSSWORD — This is the latest installment of a unique puzzle that makes infrequent appearances in the variety puzzle rotation. The last time The Times published one, about two years ago, it went over well with solvers. I do think it’s on the difficult side if you’re feeling any frustration, however.

headline: Man Paid $20,000 in Bitcoin in Failed Attempt to Have 14-Year-Old Killed, U.S. Says
abstract: John Michael Musbach, 31, of Haddonfield, N.J., tried to hire a hit man to kill a child with whom he had exchanged sexually explicit photos, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey man admitted in federal court on Thursday that he had tried to hire a hit man on the dark web, paying $20,000 in Bitcoin in an effort to kill a 14-year-old who he feared would testify against him in a child pornography case, the Justice Department said.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Asia Eases Rules on Masks, but Not All Are Set to Forgo Them
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, February 3, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “They mask just like they reflexively bow their heads when seeing an elder. Without a mask on, they feel something is missing.”

headline: Court Dismisses Guilty Plea by Australian Tennis Star Nick Kyrgios in Assault Case
abstract: The guilty plea and dismissal stemmed from a confrontation Mr. Kyrgios had with his partner in 2021 when she tried to prevent him from leaving in a ride-hailing car.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The Australian tennis star Nick Kyrgios pleaded guilty on Friday to common assault during a court hearing in Canberra, the Australian capital and his hometown. But shortly after, the court dismissed the charge.

headline: Living ‘Out Loud and Proud’ in Berlin
abstract: Paula Sapion Miranda dazzled Deidre Olsen — who also lived in Germany — with colorful flowers and a line from a Pablo Neruda poem.
lead_paragraph: Paula Sapion Miranda and Deidre Lillian Olsen were both skeptical about finding love, but that began to change one blustery afternoon in April 2021 after they met for a picnic during Covid lockdown in Berlin.

headline: When His Air-Conditioner Broke Down, Things Heated Up
abstract: Harvey Starin first considered Dorine Seidman, a former president of their homeowner’s association, “stern and scary.” That changed.
lead_paragraph: In July 2019, after a committee meeting of their homeowners association, Dorine Ruth Seidman, 77, asked Harvey David Starin, 76, if he wanted to grab dinner at Papa Giuseppe’s, an Italian restaurant in Delray Beach, Fla., where both lived. Her invitation was made in a neighborly way, without a hint of romance.

headline: She Found Love in a Surprising Place: A CD Pile
abstract: It was a very Gen X love story for Niffer Desmond and Paul Petroskey. She admired his music from afar for years, but had no way of finding him. Then social media was invented.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1992, Niffer Marie Desmond and her friend Caitlyn Meeks hosted a late night radio show called “the Bucket Sisters” at University of California, Santa Cruz, where they were undergraduates. On the show, they played CDs that were stacked on a shelf in the campus studio.

headline: A Friendship Evolves, Thanks to an Unusual Date — With Grandpa
abstract: Shuo Chen and Gorick Ng were introduced in 2012 when both were in college and he was seeking some professional advice from her. They didn’t become a couple until almost 10 years later.
lead_paragraph: Gorick Ng waited nearly a decade for a date with Shuo Chen. When he finally got one, in 2021, circumstances prevented him from sweeping her off her feet like a hero in a romance novel. For the date they had arranged — bathing her grandfather — both needed their feet firmly on the ground.

headline: Two Kisses We Never Talked About
abstract: Sometimes you really have to show up for your ex. This was one of those times.
lead_paragraph: Kevin and I separated two years ago; only on paper do we remain married. With time and a lot of therapy, we managed to find our way into genuine friendship, and I know many people can’t say that. But as Americans living abroad in Vienna, we haven’t felt a need to officially end our marriage.

headline: New York Blocks Payments to 20 Firms That Serve Hasidic Schools
abstract: Amid concerns about fraud in the industry, the city has stopped doing business with the companies, which provide special education, primarily to yeshivas.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at a policy change that has stopped payments to some education firms that serve Hasidic schools. We’ll also meet two theatrical performers and producers who are opening their own space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Russian losses in the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The number of Russian troops killed and wounded in Ukraine is approaching 200,000, as the effects of fighting in and around eastern Ukraine magnify what was already a heavy toll, according to Western and American officials.

headline: The Decisive Test for Germany Is Still to Come
abstract: Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s strategy of caution surely won’t hold.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — After months of indecision, hand-wringing and uncertainty, Germany last week committed to send Leopard 2 tanks to Ukraine. The delay was a measure of the decision’s significance. For a country long wary of active military involvement in conflicts, the release of its most advanced war machine for battle with Russian troops is momentous. A taboo has been shed.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Addresses Netflix’s Plan to Charge for Shared Accounts
abstract: “I understand. You don’t like paying for TV,” Kimmel said. “So, let me just say this: My name is Jimmy and I’m free every night, no charge.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: How Gabrielle Giffords Measures Progress on Gun Safety: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Word of the Day: subtle
abstract: This word has appeared in 790 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word subtle has appeared in 790 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 26 in “The Last Holdouts” by Amy Harmon:

headline: Together
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of — or use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: The World’s Newest Country Is Broken and Forgotten. Enter Pope Francis.
abstract: The soaring hopes at South Sudan’s creation in 2011 have been cruelly dashed. Pope Francis arrived in the country on Friday and immediately offered blunt criticism of its leaders.
lead_paragraph: It is just over a decade since the steamy capital of South Sudan exploded in joy, with revelers singing and dancing through the night to mark the birth of their nation as it split from its old enemy, Sudan.

headline: A New Approach to Funding for the Arts
abstract: A new government policy, called Revive, will prioritize Indigenous arts and culture, and also provide funding for commercial arts forms, like popular music.
lead_paragraph: The arts industry in Australia breathed a sigh of relief on Monday when the Labor government announced the country’s first national arts and cultural policy in nearly a decade, with Anthony Albanese declaring the arts to be “at the heart of our national life.”

headline: Storming Normandy in 1346
abstract: “Essex Dogs,” the first novel in a projected trilogy by the historian Dan Jones, imagines a hard-bitten band of mercenaries hired to invade France on behalf of their English king.
lead_paragraph: “Essex Dogs,” a first novel by the best-selling historian Dan Jones, opens with a group of soldiers pressed together inside a landing craft approaching the coast of Normandy at dawn. They disembark on the beach, where they meet a barrage of enemy missiles and must scramble to safety as soldiers from other boats drop dead all around them.

headline: ‘The Last of Us’ Is a Very Conservative Show. Really.
