abstract: The right should love its view of masculinity, the government and what it takes to survive.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of the achingly poignant, much-discussed third episode of “The Last of Us,” HBO’s new zombie dystopia series, there’s an earnest ode to traditional masculinity. Bill, a taciturn survivalist, leaves a letter for the show’s hero, Joel, to open after his death. In it, Bill writes of his longtime love, Frank, “I saved him. Then I protected him. That’s why men like you and me are here. We have a job to do.”

headline: A Trip to TikTok, ChatGPT’s Origin Story and Kevin Systrom’s Comeback
abstract: Casey becomes a content moderator, Kevin breaks some news on OpenAI and Instagram’s co-founder reveals his new project.
lead_paragraph: TikTok is opening up a “Transparency and Accountability Center” to try to win over skeptics. Is the company’s strategy working? Then, the origin story of OpenAI’s ChatGPT and how the company kicked off an A.I. arms race.

headline: How ChatGPT Kicked Off an A.I. Arms Race
abstract: Even inside the company, the chatbot’s popularity has come as something of a shock.
lead_paragraph: One day in mid-November, workers at OpenAI got an unexpected assignment: Release a chatbot, fast.

headline: Jon Klassen Reviews the Most Complete Collection to Date of Eric Carle’s Animal Art
abstract: Klassen had been influenced by the quietly revolutionary artist before Carle made a single book for children.
lead_paragraph: When he was starting out as a commercial artist, before any books with his name on them had been published, Eric Carle made a promotional flier to send around: a picture of a solid-blue whale that folds out over several connected pages. On the first page of the foldout you can see the whale whispering, via a tiny speech bubble, “think big.” Several folded-out pages later, in the white space next to the whale’s tail, there is a tiny red ladybug yelling, via a much bigger speech bubble, “THINK SMALL.”

headline: Is Trump Way Up or Way Down?
abstract: The polls are surprisingly divided, but higher-quality surveys point to an answer.
lead_paragraph: Is Donald J. Trump the clear favorite and front-runner to win the Republican nomination? Or is he badly weakened and even an underdog against Ron DeSantis?

headline: How to Turn a Boring Speech Into Something Americans Will Actually Want to Watch
abstract: Without an evolutionary leap to bring it into the modern era, it will become a relic.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will deliver his State of the Union address on Feb. 7, and two things are guaranteed: He’ll declare the state of the union strong, and that’s all you’ll remember on Feb. 8. This has nothing to do with Mr. Biden’s oratory. The State of the Union is the last great regular communication opportunity in American politics, but its power shrivels every year because the mode of presentation is obsolete. Where else in modern life does someone try to rally people around his or her ideas with a constantly interrupted, visually desolate, 60-minute rant? Fine, the Joe Rogan podcast, but you can’t name a second.

headline: Brazil’s Lula Promised ‘More Books in Place of Guns.’ Can He Deliver?
abstract: In his first terms as president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva expanded the scope of who could get published in the country, and who could access books. His return to the presidency comes with expectations, and hurdles.
lead_paragraph: The dismantling of the Ministry of Culture. The gutting of federal funding for the arts. Proposals to tax books as luxury items. For many writers, publishers, and other literary professionals across Brazil, President Jair Bolsonaro’s conservative government felt like a yearslong assault on cultural production.

headline: Are You (Still) an Optimist? These Questions Might Help Explain Why
abstract: It may seem impossible to feel upbeat about the future, especially now. But there are common traits optimists share that can help improve anyone’s outlook.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you’re back in high school — fluorescent lights humming, hard plastic chairs, a classroom stuffy with hormones and anxiety — and you’ve just aced a test. Do you think to yourself, “I guess I got lucky today?” Or does your internal monologue say, “Damn, I’m good!”?

headline: Republicans Revive a Debate on Term Limits
abstract: Similar proposals to restrict lawmakers’ tenures that the party pushed in the 1990s went nowhere. In this new Congress, the result is likely to be the same.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In grabbing control of the House, Republicans promised a vote on a proposition that always strikes a chord with frustrated voters: imposing term limits on members of the House and Senate to finally depose those entrenched, out-of-touch lawmakers.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the dance company Cullberg's Joyce debut.
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the dance company Cullberg's Joyce debut.

headline: How to Tell If Your Brain Needs a Break
abstract: Taking a few minutes to do a puzzle — or stare into space — can allow you to return to work sharper and more creative.
lead_paragraph: It’s 1:02 p.m. Do you know what your brain is doing?

headline: There’s Already a Better Search Engine Than Google. It’s YouTube.
abstract: Silicon Valley is wondering whether ChatGPT will replace Google as the internet’s main source of information. For many topics, YouTube already has.
lead_paragraph: Will ChatGPT kill Google?

headline: Shaking Ordinary Ice (Very Hard) Transformed It Into Something Never Seen Before
abstract: The research illustrates how much scientists still have to learn about a molecule as simple as water.
lead_paragraph: Shaken and chilled — but not stirred — ordinary frozen water turns into something different: a newly discovered form of ice made of a jumble of molecules with unique properties.

headline: My Co-Worker’s Baby Photo Gallery Put Me Over the Edge
abstract: It is a shared office space. But that’s not really an excuse.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: ‘Hip Hip Hooray!’ Cheering News for Free Speech on Campus
abstract: Stanford University steps back from its list of “harmful” words and phrases.
lead_paragraph: The following is a celebration of the cancellation of the Elimination of Harmful Language Initiative, an attempt by a committee of I.T. leaders at Stanford University to ban 161 common words and phrases. Of those 161 phrases, I have taken pains to use 45 of them here. Read at your own risk.

headline: Amanda Serrano Knows Exactly Where She Belongs
abstract: Serrano, a world champion in seven weight classes, lost to her biggest rival last spring. Now, she’s sparring with men to get back to the level she demands of herself.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Serrano leaned an elbow against a wall at her boxing gym in Brooklyn after a recent workout, massaging her triceps against a lacrosse ball. Her face was flushed and her hair pulled back into a tight bun, with the sweaty proof of her work in the ring.

headline: A Song and Dance Collaboration, Straight Outta Swamplandia
abstract: The choreographer Troy Schumacher, the composer Ellis Ludwig-Leone and the novelist Karen Russell teamed up, pushing one another to new places in their mediums.
lead_paragraph: The Night Falls is a tourist trap in Florida, a beautiful grotto turned into a roadside attraction where three sisters sing in kitschy bird outfits. And then they drown and become actual birds, monstrous ones, whose seductive song, like that of the sirens in Greek myth, draws people to their doom.

headline: Big Discounts on Top Listings Push a Trend Into the New Year
abstract: Stephen M. Ross, the real estate developer and principal owner of the Miami Dolphins, sold his penthouse atop 25 Columbus Circle for $40 million, down from the $75 million list price in 2019.

headline: The Fullest View of Vermeer Still Leaves Plenty to the Imagination
abstract: A blockbuster exhibition brings together more paintings by the Dutch master than ever before. Yet he remains a mystery, despite efforts by authors, filmmakers and researchers to fill the empty space.
lead_paragraph: Sheer numbers are sure to draw many visitors to “Vermeer,” the blockbuster exhibition devoted to the Dutch Golden Age master that opens at the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam on Friday. The Dutch national museum has managed to gather 28 of Johannes Vermeer’s paintings, representing about 75 percent of his known surviving works. That’s seven more than the public could see at the last major Vermeer retrospective nearly 30 years ago.

headline: Corporate Lawyer’s Unlikely Mission: Defend and ‘Humanize’ a Hated Terrorist
abstract: Stanislas Eskenazi volunteered with Brussels’ legal aid service, typically helping petty criminals. But now he is representing Belgium’s most-wanted man.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The two men sitting in the Brussels courtroom have much in common.

headline: How Prosecutors Say a Top F.B.I. Agent Sold His Services Overseas
abstract: As the counterintelligence chief in New York, Charles McGonigal had access to sensitive American secrets. His arrest has touched off a scramble to assess the damage.
lead_paragraph: When Charles McGonigal, a former counterintelligence chief with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was accused of using his position to benefit an associate’s business in Eastern Europe, it represented a startling turn for a high-ranking official who had been entrusted with access to some of the most sensitive secrets held by the American intelligence community.

headline: Sorry, Dogs: The Lobby Is Off-Limits.
abstract: The four-legged pets are welcome, but not welcome everywhere. Their owners must carry them or use a service elevator.
lead_paragraph: Though he says he has lived in Barclay Tower, a 58-story residential building in Manhattan’s TriBeCa for over a decade, Jeno Steiner has barely lingered in its resplendent lobby. He rarely sees the striated marble floors trimmed with handcrafted stone mosaics, the cornices of French chiseled limestone, or the seating areas of Japanese tamo ash and teak.

headline: Why Chinese Companies Are Investing Billions in Mexico
abstract: Alarmed by shipping chaos and geopolitical fractures, exporters from China are setting up factories in Mexico to preserve their sales to the United States.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: One Day They’ll Say This Was the Best (and Worst) Thing I Ever Made
abstract: It started with smirk and ended with a bang, and in between it changed the media universe.
lead_paragraph: “What’s one thing that’s true about you that no one else would believe?” is a recurring prompt on Twitter. I like to respond that I started a website that made a billionaire vampire so angry, he deployed about $10 million — and a professional wrestler — to destroy it. All of this is true, except Peter Thiel is not technically a vampire.

headline: The Powerful Lobbyist Behind Kevin McCarthy
abstract: Jeff Miller is the new House speaker’s top fund-raiser and closest confidant. He is also one of Washington’s most prominent corporate lobbyists, an arrangement that is drawing scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As he waged his messy campaign to become House speaker, Representative Kevin McCarthy turned to a longtime friend, Jeff Miller, to serve as a kind of field general.

headline: In Maine, a Rare Influx of New Residents, and a Housing Crunch
abstract: New arrivals over the last few years have fueled hopes of population growth, but workers increasingly struggle to find housing in a market gone wild.
lead_paragraph: SEARSPORT, Maine — In 2019, when Celine Kelley’s daughter was born, there were 13 births and 31 deaths in the coastal town of Searsport — a familiar phenomenon in a state where deaths had outpaced births for more than a decade.

headline: Sake. Dashi. Soba Shops: Japanese Chic Takes Root in Brooklyn
abstract: In Greenpoint, new businesses are cropping up, making it a contender for Little Tokyo status.
lead_paragraph: On a cold Tuesday afternoon in January, four women made their way down Guernsey Street in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. They had just finished lunch at Acre, a Japanese cafe and shop, where they had been served bento boxes and green tea, and were headed to 50 Norman, a new warehouse space nearby that housed three other Japanese businesses.

headline: ‘My Watch Thinks I’m Dead’
abstract: Dispatchers for 911 are being inundated with false, automated distress calls from Apple devices owned by skiers who are very much alive.
lead_paragraph: FRISCO, Colo. — On a recent sunny Sunday morning, following a night of fluffy snowfall, tens of thousands of skiers flocked to the resorts of Summit County. Just minutes after the lift lines opened, sirens began blaring in the 911 emergency service center, where four staff members were taking calls and dispatching help.

headline: Where American Democracy Isn’t Very Democratic
abstract: The problem of democracy and American law enforcement goes beyond questions of accountability.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, I wrote that American policing lies largely outside of democratic control. In practice, despite the formal authority of mayors, city councilors and other elected officials, police departments can and do operate without meaningful accountability or public oversight.

headline: 582,462 and Counting
abstract: To fix a problem like homelessness in America, you need to know its scope. To do that, you need sheriffs, social workers, volunteers, flashlights and 10 days in January.
lead_paragraph: They go into the streets in search of data. Peeking behind dumpsters, shining flashlights under bridges, rustling a frosted tent to see if anyone was inside. This is what it takes to count the people in America who don’t have a place to live. To get a number, however flawed, that describes the scope of a deeply entrenched problem and the country’s progress toward fixing it.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, February 3, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: January Jobs Report Contained Hopeful and Worrying News for the Fed
abstract: The Federal Reserve is tracking incoming labor figures as it decides how high interest rates need to go and how long they should stay elevated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials have said they are looking for the labor market to cool as they assess how much more they need to do to slow the economy, and the job report on Friday underscored that policymakers may still have a ways to go.

headline: U.S. Hiring Surges With January Gain of 517,000 Jobs
abstract: The report defied expectations and underscored the challenges for the Federal Reserve, which is trying to cool the labor market to fight inflation.
lead_paragraph: Soft landing? The American labor market is still soaring.

headline: The End of the Pandemic Emergency in the U.S.
abstract: The chapter is closing on three years of special public health measures, but that doesn’t mean Covid is over.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said this week that it would end the public health emergency for Covid, a sign that federal officials believe that the pandemic has moved into a new, less dire phase.

headline: Hong Kong Tries to Repair Its Battered Image With Plane Ticket Giveaway
abstract: The city’s reputation has been hammered by protests, a harsh security law and strict Covid measures. It hopes a giveaway of 500,000 plane tickets woos back tourists.
lead_paragraph: Interested in visiting a place that still calls itself “Asia’s world city” despite mounting evidence that it’s marching toward an insular, authoritarian future?

headline: Why Eggs Cost So Much
abstract: Inflation, avian flu and war have made a food staple much more expensive.
lead_paragraph: Prices have risen for just about everything over the past couple of years. But anyone shopping for groceries recently has probably noticed the cost of one item in particular: eggs.

headline: Two Experimental Horror Directors Discuss the Thoughts Behind the Frights
abstract: Kyle Edward Ball, the filmmaker behind “Skinamarink,” and Robbie Banfitch, who made “The Outwaters,” talk about their creepy, buzzy movies.
lead_paragraph: Universal’s evil robot movie “M3gan” is one of the first big hits of 2023. But two new indie horror films are generating buzz too, even though they were made for next to nothing and are driven by distorted audio, disorienting cuts and other defiantly experimentalist techniques.

headline: Songwriter or Star? The-Dream, Muni Long and Two Paths to the Grammys.
abstract: Ahead of the first-ever Grammy Award for songwriter of the year, two musicians who have been both headliners and behind-the-scenes cogs trace their unique journeys to recognition.
lead_paragraph: While Adele, Beyoncé and Harry Styles may soak up the most attention at Sunday’s Grammy Awards, other musicians often relegated to the fine print of superstar albums will celebrate one extra chance at recognition this year. For the first time, the Recording Academy will present an award for songwriter of the year, non-classical, making background figures the focus, at least for a moment.

headline: Tech Earnings Give a Wake-Up Call to Investors
abstract: Apple, Amazon and Alphabet all reported disappointing quarterly results, as they emphasized efforts to cut costs in the face of an economic slowdown.
lead_paragraph: Shares in tech companies are in retreat after investors got sobering news on Thursday about three of the industry’s giants — Alphabet, Amazon and Apple — including slowing demand for everything from iPhones to digital ads to cloud services.

headline: Furor Over Chinese Spy Balloon Leads to a Diplomatic Crisis
abstract: The Pentagon called the object, which has flown from Montana to Kansas, an “intelligence gathering” balloon. Beijing said it was used mainly for weather research and had strayed off course.
lead_paragraph: Live updates: The U.S. has shot down the Chinese spy balloon.

headline: ‘I Am Here to Kill the Queen’: Crossbow Intruder Is Convicted of Treason
abstract: The conviction, the first on such a charge in Britain in more than 40 years, came after officers stopped a man at a gate leading to the monarch’s private quarters on Christmas Day in 2021.
lead_paragraph: An intruder wielding a crossbow who scaled a fence at Windsor Castle and threatened to kill Queen Elizabeth II on Christmas Day in 2021 pleaded guilty on Friday to treason, the first person to be convicted of such a charge in Britain in more than four decades.

headline: A Ghost Appears at the Marc Jacobs Show
abstract: Upside-down jackets, punk gestures — Vivienne Westwood is still present in fashion.
lead_paragraph: “Fashion is life-enhancing. And I think it’s a lovely, generous thing to do for other people.”

headline: Value Stocks? Growth Stocks? Markets Last Year Turned Everything Topsy-Turvy.
abstract: With the exception of Apple, eight tech giants are no longer “pure growth” stocks, while Exxon and Chevron are, a new study says. Our columnist says: Buyer, beware.
lead_paragraph: It is impossible even to talk about the long bull market that ended in January 2022 without saying high-growth tech stocks propelled the market higher.

headline: Many Banks Pay High Rates on Savings. So Why Aren’t You Moving Your Money?
abstract: Some online banks offer yields of 3.3 percent or more, but savers may be reluctant to open one because they think it will be a hassle.
lead_paragraph: If you are keeping a good amount of spare cash in a basic savings account at a big bank, you are missing out.

headline: Readers Share Their Favorite California Travel Tips
abstract: Perhaps they’ll provide inspiration for your next trip.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, we’ve been asking you for tips on exploring the Golden State — and you’ve been delivering.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: What to do for 36 hours in Bangkok. Also, how Barnes & Noble came back from near death, and senior housing that seniors actually like.
lead_paragraph: What to do for 36 hours in Bangkok. Also, how Barnes & Noble came back from near death, and senior housing that seniors actually like.

headline: Ukraine Renews Threat to Boycott Olympics if Russians Compete
abstract: Ukraine’s sports minister said his country was marshaling allies to press the International Olympic Committee to bar Russian and Belarusian athletes.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s sports minister on Friday renewed the country’s threat to boycott next summer’s Paris Olympics if Russian and Belarusian athletes are allowed to compete, and said his country would continue to marshal like-minded allies to add weight to a threat that represents a serious crisis for the Olympic movement.

headline: Ford Partners With Red Bull in Return to Formula One
abstract: The automaker and the drinks manufacturer are joining forces on a high-powered team in the world’s most popular motorsports series.
lead_paragraph: The whispers of a merger between Ford and Red Bull had been the talk of Formula One for months, an intriguing story line in a competition that knows the value of drama.

headline: Germany adds older Leopard 1s to the list of tank for Ukraine.
abstract: An older model than the already approved Leopard 2, the tanks will need refurbishment and could face ammunition shortages.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany has agreed to allow the export of its Leopard 1 battle tanks to Ukraine, a government spokesman said on Friday, creating an opportunity for increased tank transfers to Ukraine as battles intensify in the country’s east.

headline: The 19th-Century Cult That Gave Rise to an Incel Assassin
abstract: Susan Wels’s “An Assassin in Utopia” links President Garfield’s killer to the atmosphere of free love and religious fervor that gripped Oneida, N.Y., in the late 1800s.
lead_paragraph: What do an experiment in free love, a renowned newspaper editor with a penchant for the occult, and a dour — then murdered — president have in common?

headline: Court Upholds Charges Against Ex-Louvre Chief in Art Trafficking Case
abstract: Jean-Luc Martinez, who led the museum from 2013 to 2021, is fighting charges of complicity in fraud and money laundering, part of an inquiry into the illegal sale of Egyptian artifacts.
lead_paragraph: The Paris appeals court upheld charges of complicity in fraud and money laundering against the former president of the Louvre on Friday, in a case involving trafficked Egyptian artifacts that shocked the art world when it embroiled the man who used to lead France’s most famous museum.

headline: What Is Literary Criticism For?
abstract: John Guillory’s “Cultural Capital,” published amid the 1990s canon wars, became a classic. In a follow-up, “Professing Criticism,” he takes on his field’s deep funk.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, it was common to pick up a newspaper or a magazine and read about high drama in university literature departments. Star professors were either master thinkers introducing new rigor and glamour into a tweedy profession gone stale, or theory-addled tenured radicals taking a hatchet to the masterpieces of Western culture.

headline: What Times Readers Would Change About Their Doctors’ Offices
abstract: These small tweaks could go a long way toward improving patients’ overall experience.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks ago, I wrote a newsletter about an Indiana urogynecologist who had crowdsourced ideas to redesign his practice from the ground up. I also spoke to other practitioners who are thinking about patients’ experiences at their own offices, and asked what changes you would most like to see.

headline: Job Growth Is a Boost for Biden as He Bets on a Lasting Turnaround
abstract: President Biden has for months pointed to solid hiring trends as evidence that his agenda has rebuilt the economy after the pandemic shutdowns.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — President Biden on Friday seized on what he called “strikingly good news” about the economy, hailing the addition of a half-million jobs and capping a week of presidential swagger about the direction of the country.

headline: ‘One Gut Punch After Another’: The Case of the Missing Dallas Zoo Animals
abstract: The brazenness of the thefts brought international attention and a range of whodunit theories. The police charged a 24-year-old local man in connection with the disappearances.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The first missing animal at the Dallas Zoo, taken or allowed to escape through a hole cut in the heavy metal mesh of her enclosure, was Nova, a 25-pound clouded leopard.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our critic recommends checking out a show about pasta, a French political comedy and a potent new true-crime documentary.
lead_paragraph: ‘Shape of Pasta’When to watch: Now, on the Roku Channel.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The hosts had plenty of news to pick through this week, including former President Trump returning to the campaign trail, Tom Brady retiring from football (again), and Netflix cracking down on password sharing.
lead_paragraph: The hosts had plenty of news to pick through this week, including former President Trump returning to the campaign trail, Tom Brady retiring from football (again), and Netflix cracking down on password sharing.

headline: Italian Mobster, 16 Years on the Lam, Is Found Working at a Pizzeria
abstract: Edgardo Greco, 63, was arrested as he was about to start a night shift at a restaurant in France. Investigators identified him through online photographs.
lead_paragraph: After the arrest of Matteo Messina Denaro, 60, the police found that, while on the run, Italy’s most wanted mobster had expensive tastes, dressing in designer duds and favoring expensive perfumes. When he was taken into custody at a clinic in Palermo, Sicily, he was wearing a watch estimated to cost about $35,000, prosecutors later said.

headline: The Danger Lurking Behind the Premier League’s Wealth
abstract: Teams that can’t match England’s spending now face a choice: Accept that they can no longer compete for the best talent, or risk everything to try.
lead_paragraph: The precise nature of the hierarchy is, in truth, a little confusing. The job titles are, in isolation, grand and impressive, but taken together, all of those capital letters become somehow vague and a little meaningless. There were, for a while, two Technical Directors, one Director of Global Talent and Transfers, and a Co-Director of Recruitment and Talent.

headline: Ozempic Can Cause Major Weight Loss. What Happens if You Stop Taking It?
abstract: As more patients turn to diabetes medications for other uses, a shortage has taken hold. But doctors say going off these drugs can take a toll.
lead_paragraph: Teri Parris Ford felt awful on her Ozempic medication. Two years ago, her doctor had prescribed it to treat Ms. Ford’s pre-diabetes, for which it was effective. Ms. Ford, a 57-year-old art teacher, experienced a drop in her A1C (a measure of average blood sugar) and lost 20 pounds in six months.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Take on Eric Kim’s sweet-and-sour ribs as a practice run for Super Bowl Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The Super Bowl is next weekend, and if you’re having folks over to watch the game, the last thing you want to be doing is cooking something for the very first time. (You think Patrick Mahomes won’t practice this weekend?) Don’t leave things to chance. Plan out what you want to make in the next few days, and if it includes a recipe you haven’t attempted before, make it now. Doing so will pay dividends come the 12th when you have a full living room.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a pandemic-inspired killer, a trance-induced massacre and a bloodthirsty little boy.
lead_paragraph: It’s 2020, and Covid-19 has most of America under quarantine. Miri (Beth Million) takes coronavirus precautions seriously, but her college bestie Parker (Gideon Adlon) has virus fatigue, something her Instafriends witness when she posts a video of herself making out with a guy at a party.

headline: A ‘Preventable Tragedy’: Dying for Lack of an Organ Donor
abstract: Readers urge action to improve the organ donation system and save lives. Also: Budget misinformation; making bread; foie gras; against gambling.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Look Ahead at the Season’s Big Books
abstract: Gilbert Cruz and Tina Jordan discuss the upcoming books they’re most excited to read in the next few months.
lead_paragraph: How do you define a “big book”? It might be a new offering from a beloved author or a deep dive into a timely subject or a story that has generated unusual enthusiasm among editors and other early readers: One way or another, these are the books that build “buzz” and create momentum in the weeks and months before their publication. On this week’s podcast, the Book Review’s editor, Gilbert Cruz, talks with Tina Jordan, the deputy editor, about the books they’re most looking forward to this season, including new fiction from Salman Rushdie, Eleanor Catton and Victor LaValle, and nonfiction from Matthew Desmond, Claire Dederer and David Grann.

headline: At Czech Spa Town, ‘Russia for Us Is the Past, and It Was Not Pleasant’
abstract: Since the 18th century, Russians have flocked to the healing waters of Karlovy Vary. Now, the Czech government has barred them from visiting the country, and the town must reinvent itself.
lead_paragraph: James Bond, poisoned by a villain in the film “Casino Royale,” almost died in the forecourt of the Grandhotel Pupp, a majestic reinvention of what, under Communism, was called the Grand Hotel Moskva, a shabby lodge popular with members of the Czech and Soviet nomenklatura.

headline: The Ecstatic, Elusive Art of Ming Smith
abstract: The artist was the first Black woman photographer to have her work acquired by MoMA. Now, decades later, as she returns for a solo show, she reflects on her singular career.
lead_paragraph: In 1979, the artist Ming Smith arrived at New York’s Museum of Modern Art with a portfolio of her photographs. She had been living in the city for a few years, nurturing her obsession with photography, when she heard that the museum had announced an open call for submissions. As Smith walked into the building, prints in tow, the receptionist thought she was a messenger. A few days later, the department of photography’s then chief curator, John Szarkowski, and assistant curator Susan Kismaric bought two of Smith’s pieces, making her the first Black woman photographer to have her works acquired by the museum.

headline: 3 New Chocolate Desserts for Everyone You Love
abstract: Preparing a special dinner can be intimidating, but these make-ahead sweets will be hits no matter how much time or kitchen confidence you have.
lead_paragraph: Chocolate is an easy choice for homemade Valentine’s Day desserts and this trio of recipes has something for everyone. Like relationships, they range in commitment: simple hot fudge sundaes get some help from store-bought ice cream; a dramatic soufflé cake takes about an hour but is big enough to serve a group; aspirational Earl Grey crème brûlée for two requires a little patience for a dish that feels luxurious.

headline: How to Get Government Aid to Ditch Fossil Fuels
abstract: Americans can get tax credits to go electric, but only if they have cash upfront. Other countries have programs, too.
lead_paragraph: Ready for the climate version of HGTV?

headline: High-Altitude Balloon Spotted Flying Over Montana
abstract: A high-altitude balloon was filmed by a resident in Billings, Mont. The Pentagon has not confirmed that the balloon seen in the video is the one it identified as being from China.
lead_paragraph: A high-altitude balloon was filmed by a resident in Billings, Mont. The Pentagon has not confirmed that the balloon seen in the video is the one it identified as being from China.

headline: Karol G and Romeo Santos’s Sensual Goodbye, and 12 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Morgan Wallen, Yves Tumor, Lankum and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: How to Turn a Good Cry Into Good Cinema
abstract: Bringing a great crying scene to the big screen requires a combination of craft and empathy. This is how three recent movies — “Close,” “Babylon” and “The Woman King” — pulled it off.
lead_paragraph: Before the sniffles, before the sharp inhales and heavy swallows — before, in other words, any of the typical sounds of crying — you hear the muted pitter-patter of a child’s tears making landfall on his T-shirt.

headline: Reader Tips for a Better Frozen (or Homemade) Pizza
abstract: A recent look at the state of premium frozen pizza, and an accompanying taste test, brought out big opinions. “Pizza,” as one reader notes, “is a big tent.”
lead_paragraph: Want to start an argument? Just bring up pizza: how it’s made, what fits the definition, which style is supreme. All are up for debate.

headline: Retirees Are Losing Their Life Savings to Romance Scams. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: Con artists are using dating sites to prey on lonely people, particularly older ones, in a pattern that accelerated during the isolation of the pandemic, federal data show.
lead_paragraph: Con artists are using dating apps to prey on lonely people, and older ones are a growing target. In a pattern that accelerated during the isolation of the coronavirus pandemic, romance scams claimed $139 million from adults age 60 and older in 2020, according to data from the Federal Trade Commission, up from $84 million the year before.

headline: How BMG Secretly Signed a Rapper Dropped for Antisemitic Lyrics
abstract: Though the music label ultimately backed out, the deal illustrates the temptations and risks faced by corporations seeking to capitalize on the notoriety of pop-culture figures.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: This roundup includes titles by Fintan O’Toole, Xochitl Gonzalez and more.
lead_paragraph: This roundup includes titles by Fintan O’Toole, Xochitl Gonzalez and more.

headline: New York City’s Most Romantic Restaurants
abstract: Times writers and editors share where they like to dine on Valentine's Day.
lead_paragraph: Times writers and editors share where they like to dine on Valentine's Day.

headline: ‘We Are in Trauma’: Memphis Reels From the Latest of Many Blows
abstract: Tyre Nichols’s fatal beating took its place on a roster of traumatic events that have helped shape the story of Memphis as much as its world-famous musical innovations.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Across the Northeast, Officials Warn of a Dangerous Arctic Blast
abstract: Cold temperatures and fierce winds are intensifying, and conditions are expected to grow worse on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Temperatures across the Northeast plummeted and wind speeds crept upward on Friday, as the region prepared for some of the coldest wind chills in decades.

headline: An Even Deadlier Pandemic Could Soon Be Here
abstract: Bird flu has spread widely among animals. Unless we act now, it soon could do the same among humans.
lead_paragraph: As the world is just beginning to recover from the devastation of Covid-19, it is facing the possibility of a pandemic of a far more deadly pathogen.

headline: Gary Glitter Is Released From Prison After Serving Half of His Sentence
abstract: The disgraced former glam rock singer was found guilty in 2015 of sexually abusing three young girls in the 1970s. He had been given a 16-year sentence.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The former glam rock singer Gary Glitter has been released from prison after serving half of a 16-year sentence for sexually abusing three young girls decades ago, Britain’s Ministry of Justice said on Friday.

headline: Raye, Tired of Music’s Waiting Game, Releases an Album at Last
abstract: The British musician spent years writing for other artists. After speaking her truths about the industry, she shares personal revelations on her debut.
lead_paragraph: When the British artist Raye performed “Ice Cream Man.” during a January concert at the cavernous Utilita Arena in Birmingham, England, many of the young women in the audience began to cry.

headline: Review: At 95, a Conductor Is Still Showing New Facets
abstract: Herbert Blomstedt introduced the New York Philharmonic to a piece he premiered in Stockholm 59 years ago.
lead_paragraph: At 95, the conductor Herbert Blomstedt is still showing new sides of himself to the New York Philharmonic.

headline: A Little Night Chopping
abstract: Let dicing ingredients be a welcome interlude between work and dinner.
lead_paragraph: Hello, everyone. I’m a senior editor on the Food desk, and I’m filling in for Emily Weinstein this week.

headline: Trump Needs a Confrontation. His G.O.P. Rivals Don’t Have to Give Him One.
abstract: For now, allowing the former president to fade is wiser than attacking him.
lead_paragraph: Just before Christmas, I wrote a column warning about the disappointment many may feel if Donald Trump exits the political stage with a relative whimper — by losing a Republican presidential primary to a figure like Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and then simply dimming, the way ex-presidents normally do, instead of going out with a supernova’s spectacle.

headline: Eliot Spitzer and an Elite Co-op Board Fight Over a Ditch
abstract: The former governor of New York faces a lawsuit from a cooperative board that could upend his plans to build condos on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: On a coveted stretch of Fifth Avenue, steps away from Central Park, the shareholders of an Upper East Side cooperative are fighting for an unusual prize: the ownership of a grimy concrete ditch behind their luxury apartment building.

headline: Fears of Russian Nuclear Weapons Use Have Diminished, but Could Re-emerge
abstract: Nearly a year into the war in Ukraine, U.S. policymakers and intelligence analysts have more confidence that they understand at least some of President Vladimir V. Putin’s red lines.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last fall, tensions in Washington reached a crescendo as Moscow made persistent nuclear threats and U.S. intelligence reported discussions among Russian military leaders about the use of such weapons.

headline: Brooklyn Museum Celebrates 25 Years of First Saturdays
abstract: During that time, the museum has welcomed more than 1.5 million visitors to live performances by a diverse group of artists.
lead_paragraph: Yaya Bey’s memories of her frequent visits to the Brooklyn Museum are vivid: the glee on the children’s faces as she guided field trips to exhibits like Jean-Michel Basquiat’s skull painting, and especially First Saturdays, when every floor boiled over with art, dance and music performed by a diverse group of artists.

headline: Lit Trivia: Can You Identify These Novels by Their First Sentences?
abstract: Some books grab you right from the author’s first sentence and stick with you long after the last page. Can you match these five opening lines to their titles?
lead_paragraph: Some books grab you right from the author’s first sentence and stick with you long after the last page. Can you match these five opening lines to their titles?

headline: Metal Detector Hobbyist Finds a 500-Year-Old Pendant Linked to Henry VIII
abstract: Researchers say the jewelry, found in a field outside Birmingham, England, is an extraordinary piece of treasure.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Charlie Clarke, a 34-year-old cafe owner in Birmingham, England, was feeling down about losing his dog to cancer, so he went over to a friend’s place in the countryside to take a stroll and get some fresh air. He brought his metal detector with him, gear for the new hobby he had picked up six months earlier.

headline: Sex Lives of Hudson, N.Y., Bohemians
abstract: In Jen Beagin’s “Big Swiss,” a sex therapist’s transcriptionist fantasizes about sleeping with a married female patient, who also happens to go to her dog park.
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of women I know who’ve only dated men, Flavia — the titular neurotic blonde in Jen Beagin’s new novel, “Big Swiss” — would make an exception for Detective Olivia Benson. Luckily, but also unluckily (Flavia is married, after all), there is a Mariska Hargitay look-alike at her local dog park, and like the “Law & Order: S.V.U.” siren, this stranger is not the type to beat around the bush. No, Greta goes straight to the bush. “You must get this a lot,” she says, “but would you mind taking a quick look at this thing on my labia?”

headline: Chinese Spy Balloon or ‘Civilian Device’?
abstract: Here is what we know about the balloon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration shot down a Chinese spy balloon on Saturday, prompting a diplomatic drama and raising questions about the next stage of an already tense relationship between the world’s two superpowers.

headline: Wonking Out: Is the Dollar’s Dominance Under Threat?
abstract: And does it matter for anything real?
lead_paragraph: Is the U.S. dollar at risk of losing its position of international dominance? I’ve been seeing some breathless speculation to that effect over the past few weeks; I’ll talk about the sources of that speculation in a minute. But let me first note that this isn’t a new question. Indeed, I wrote about it at length a few years back.

headline: Love Letter: A Friend, Not a Wife
abstract: Plus: an unusual date — with grandpa.
lead_paragraph: Alessandra Ranelli had been separated from her husband for about a year when he found out he had Stage 3B colon cancer.

headline: Democrats, Seeing a Weaker Trump, Are Falling in Line Behind Biden
abstract: Concerns about the president’s age are being overcome by enthusiasm about his record so far, optimism about the G.O.P. field — and the absence of better options.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Nine months ago, amid sky-high gas prices and legislative gridlock, anxious Democrats routinely offered the same assessments of President Biden as a candidate for re-election: too frail, too politically weak, too much of a throwback.

headline: Trump Likened to Mob Boss John Gotti in Ex-Prosecutor’s New Book
abstract: Mark F. Pomerantz, who resigned from the Manhattan district attorney’s office last year, wrote that he had pursued a racketeering case against the former president.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump grew his business, fortune and fame “through a pattern of criminal activity,” according to a new book by a veteran prosecutor, who reveals that the Manhattan district attorney’s office once considered charging the former president with racketeering, a law often used against the Mafia.

headline: Review: From Lil Buck, History and a Chance to Flash Some Brilliance
abstract: “Memphis Jookin’: The Show,” which presents jookin “in the world it comes from,” is sincere entertainment, packed with talent and heart.
lead_paragraph: “This is going to be very educational for a lot of y’all,” Lil Buck said at Lincoln Center’s Rose Theater on Thursday.

headline: A Brief History of Spying With Balloons
abstract: A Chinese balloon seen floating over the northwestern United States this week was a reminder of how governments have used balloons for reconnaissance for more than a century.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese balloon seen hovering over Montana this week has been described as an “intelligence-gathering” airship by the Pentagon and a stray civilian research airship by China.

headline: Kyrie Irving Asks the Nets to Trade Him
abstract: The Nets guard, who will be a free agent this summer, wants out of Brooklyn just months after he caused an uproar by linking to an antisemitic film on social media.
lead_paragraph: Kyrie Irving has asked the Nets to trade him before the N.B.A.’s trading deadline on Thursday, according to a person familiar with the request who was not authorized to discuss it publicly.

headline: Paco Rabanne, Couturier of the Space Age, Dies at 88
abstract: He burst onto the French fashion scene in 1966 and, with dresses made from metal, plastic and paper, changed the definition of couture.
lead_paragraph: Paco Rabanne, the Spanish designer whose futuristic creations gave shape to the dreams of the space age and redefined couture, died on Friday in Portsall, France. He was 88.

headline: Do Handouts Work?
abstract: A debate rages over how much the poor benefit from straight cash donations.
lead_paragraph: Josephy Amosi Kamanga, who lives in Malawi, couldn’t afford to pay the examination fee for his eldest child, so she dropped out of school two years ago. She later got pregnant and is living at home. The fee that changed his daughter’s life? Just $4.98.

headline: Linda Pastan, Poet Who Plumbed the Ordinary, Dies at 90
abstract: In 15 collections, beginning in the early 1970s, she wrote of family, nature, loss and sometimes dogs.
lead_paragraph: Linda Pastan, whose elegantly simple poems found beauty and, sometimes, pain in the ordinary sights and moments of life, died on Jan. 30 at her home in Chevy Chase, Md. She was 90.

headline: Biden Weighs State of the Union Focus on His Unfinished Agenda
abstract: As the president prepares for his national address, his aides debate an emphasis on his still-unrealized plans for child care, prekindergarten and more.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s top economic aides have battled for weeks over a key decision for his State of the Union address on Tuesday: how much to talk about child care, prekindergarten, paid leave and other new spending proposals that the president failed to secure in the flurry of economic legislation he signed in his first two years in office.

headline: Seeing Myself in the Work of an Artist I Never Met
abstract: I never met Kimowan Metchewais, but I feel a kinship with him and his work.
lead_paragraph: There’s a basic understanding that Native people who straddle life inside and outside the reservation share: We can carry our culture with us where ever we go, but also have perspective outside of it.

headline: Jury Rules for Elon Musk and Tesla in Investor Lawsuit Over Tweets
abstract: The case centered on whether investors lost money because they believed Mr. Musk’s social media posts about taking Tesla private in 2018.
lead_paragraph: A jury decided Friday that Elon Musk was not liable for losses suffered by investors after he posted messages on Twitter saying he had secured the funding to take Tesla private in 2018.

headline: U.S. Considers Lifting Protections for Grizzly Bears Near Two National Parks
abstract: Federal wildlife officials will begin a yearlong study in response to “substantial information” showing that grizzly populations had improved.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is taking a step toward lifting federal protections for grizzly bears in the northern Rocky Mountains, which could open the door to hunting in Montana, Wyoming and Idaho in the future, wildlife officials said.

headline: Bodies of 3 Men Are Found After They Disappeared in Detroit
abstract: They were discovered at an abandoned building 12 days after the men were supposed to meet at a rap show. The police called their deaths homicides but said the cause and motive were still unknown.
lead_paragraph: The bodies of three Michigan men who disappeared on Jan. 21 after a canceled rap show in Detroit were found on Thursday at an abandoned apartment building in nearby Highland Park, Mich., the state police said on Friday.

headline: What Weapons Is Ukraine Getting, and Will They Arrive in Time?
abstract: Kyiv has been promised scores of tanks and other armor, and the longest range munitions yet. But with a looming Russian offensive, a race is on to get the matériel to the battlefield.
lead_paragraph: The latest American weapons package for Ukraine, unveiled on Friday, includes the longest range weapons yet to push back Russian troops and strike logistical targets well behind enemy lines. But they come with a hitch: They will be deployed on the battlefield too late to be used against a broad assault by Moscow that seemingly has begun to unfurl in eastern Ukraine.

headline: Blinken Says Chinese Spy Balloon Is a ‘Violation of U.S. Sovereignty’
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken canceled a weekend trip to Beijing after a Chinese high-altitude balloon was detected floating over the United States this week.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken canceled a weekend trip to Beijing after a Chinese high-altitude balloon was detected floating over the United States this week.

headline: I Saw Ammunition Being Made for Ukraine
abstract: The U.S. has given Ukraine more than a million American-made artillery shells, and Ukrainians are shooting thousands of them at Russian troops each day. I decided to take a closer look at where the artillery ammunition is made.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. has given Ukraine more than a million American-made artillery shells, and Ukrainians are shooting thousands of them at Russian troops each day. I decided to take a closer look at where the artillery ammunition is made.

headline: What Will It Take to Trust M. Night Shyamalan?
abstract: The director, whose latest is “Knock at the Cabin,” has been working to regain audience faith, one B-movie at a time.
lead_paragraph: A man enters a dark room and faces a suspicious audience. Within these four walls, he explains, he’s going to tell captive strangers a tale with life-or-death stakes. But first, he needs something crucial from them: their trust.

headline: Agriculture Dept. Proposes Limits on Sugar and Salt in School Meals
abstract: The proposed guidelines are part of the Biden administration’s push to address childhood obesity, diabetes and other diet-related diseases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Friday proposed updated nutrition guidelines for school meals as part of its push to address childhood obesity, diabetes and other diseases.

headline: Kari Lake, Still Refusing to Accept Defeat in One Race, Teases Arizona Senate Run
abstract: Ms. Lake, a Republican who lost to Katie Hobbs in the state’s governor’s race, previewed opening salvos against Senator Kyrsten Sinema and Ruben Gallego.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kari Lake, the fiery former news anchor who narrowly lost a race for governor of Arizona last year, said in an interview that she is considering a Republican campaign for the U.S. Senate in Arizona next year.

headline: Officers Will Not Face Charges in Fatal Ohio Shooting, Prosecutor Says
abstract: Relatives of Joe Frasure Jr. said he had been cleaning out his grandmother’s apartment when officers responded to a burglary call.
lead_paragraph: A prosecutor in Ohio said that three officers who were responding to a burglary call will not be charged in the fatal shooting of a man his family said had been cleaning out his dead grandmother’s apartment.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: U.S. Sends Longer-Range Weapons
abstract: The latest aid package will allow Ukraine to hit targets 90 miles away.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Carol Sloane, Jazz Singer Who Found Success Early and Late, Dies at 85
abstract: After seemingly being on the verge of stardom, she languished for decades, battered by changing tastes and bad luck, before enjoying a midlife comeback.
lead_paragraph: The crowd had thinned by the time Carol Sloane, then 24, took the festival stage in Newport, R.I., in July 1961. The Saturday afternoon slot was a showcase for new talent, hence the sparse attendance. Ms. Sloane had chosen to sing “Little Girl Blue.” The pianist knew the tune but not the rarely performed introduction, so she sang it a cappella, hitting every ravishing note.

headline: Biden Says U.S. Economy is ‘Strong’ After Jobs Report
abstract: President Biden pointed to rapid job growth and falling consumer prices as evidence that his economic agenda is working.
lead_paragraph: President Biden pointed to rapid job growth and falling consumer prices as evidence that his economic agenda is working.

headline: A Giant Balloon Floats Into Town, and It’s All Anyone Can Talk About
abstract: A Chinese balloon has been raising a lot of questions for people who live under its path. “I did see it, and it should have been shot,” said a barbecue chef in Billings, Mont.
lead_paragraph: HELENA, Mont. — Larry Mayer, a newspaper photographer, pointed his camera to the sky on Wednesday and began snapping pictures of what appeared to be a mysterious white orb hanging in the sky over Billings, Mont.

headline: ‘Three-Body’ Review: A Chinese Series Beats Netflix to the Screen
abstract: A 30-episode adaptation of the celebrated science-fiction novel “The Three-Body Problem” is premiering simultaneously in China and on the American streamer Rakuten Viki.
lead_paragraph: This review contains spoilers for the novel “The Three-Body Problem” and the television series “Three-Body.” There’s no way around it.

headline: House G.O.P. Subpoenas Biden Officials for Investigating School-Related Threats
abstract: Representative Jim Jordan, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, demanded documents for an investigation into whether the government mistreated parents scrutinized after threats against school officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans on Friday issued their first subpoenas of the Biden administration since taking control of the House, demanding documents for an investigation into whether the government mistreated parents who were scrutinized after school officials endured threats and harassment over mask mandates and teaching about racism.

headline: E.U. Vows More Help for Ukraine but Tamps Down Membership Talk
abstract: European Union leaders met in Kyiv with President Volodymyr Zelensky, who said Ukraine would not give up on Bakhmut, the eastern city caught in a fierce battle with Russian forces.
lead_paragraph: European Union leaders met in Kyiv on Friday with President Volodymyr Zelensky and delivered a symbolic embrace of Ukraine as it fights for survival against Russia, but they withheld a prize Mr. Zelensky dearly wants, accelerated membership in the bloc.

headline: Two Men Arrested in Execution-Style Killings of a Family in California
abstract: The brutal nature of the mass shooting, which included the murder of an innocent young mother and her infant, shocked the nation.
lead_paragraph: Two men suspected of slaying four generations of the same family, including a 10-month-old baby, were captured on Friday near the house where the grisly crime occurred last month in the Central Valley of California, according to the authorities.

headline: E.M.T.s Provided No Care for 19 Minutes After Police Beat Tyre Nichols
abstract: The board that regulates emergency medical technicians in Tennessee on Friday voted to suspend the licenses of the two E.M.T.s who arrived at the scene and failed to render aid.
lead_paragraph: The two emergency medical technicians who first arrived to treat Tyre Nichols after he was severely beaten by Memphis police officers did not provide any care for 19 minutes after getting to the scene, a regulatory agency concluded on Friday as it voted to suspend their licenses.

headline: Brazil Says It’s Started Sinking an Old Warship, Hazardous Material and All
abstract: The navy said it had begun an operation to send the aircraft carrier São Paulo to the bottom.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Brazilian Navy said on Friday evening it had begun an operation to sink the decommissioned aircraft carrier São Paulo, packed with an undetermined amount of asbestos and other toxic materials, about 220 miles off the country’s northeastern coast.

headline: An Owl Named Flaco Is Loose in Central Park, With Vandals to Blame
abstract: After leaving his damaged Central Park Zoo enclosure the night before, a Eurasian eagle-owl was the subject of an intense rescue effort as darkness and temperatures fell on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A Eurasian eagle-owl named Flaco was the subject of an intense rescue effort late Friday after getting loose as a result of vandals having damaged his Central Park Zoo enclosure the night before, parks and zoo officials said.

headline: Owner of Construction Firm Pleads Guilty in Fatal Wall Collapse
abstract: Finbar O’Neill insisted on piling dirt against the structure at a Hudson Valley job site even after being warned against it several times, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey construction company executive has pleaded guilty to federal charges of violating safety rules at a Hudson Valley work site where a worker was killed when a concrete wall collapsed in 2017, officials said.

headline: How to Stay Safe in Extreme Cold Weather
abstract: Experts offer tips to protect against common health hazards as temperatures plummet.
lead_paragraph: As an Arctic blast bombards the Northeastern United States, temperatures have plunged, and people are bracing for extreme wind chill. Those who will be affected by the cold should stay inside as much as possible. If you have to go out, protect yourself from the risks associated with icy conditions, including falls and car accidents. The unanimous advice from experts: Exercise extreme caution.

headline: 2016 Trump Campaign to Pay $450,000 to Settle Nondisclosure Agreements Suit
abstract: The settlement with a former campaign aide who says she was the target of sexual discrimination effectively invalidates agreements hundreds of 2016 Trump campaign officials signed.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s 2016 campaign will pay $450,000 as part of a settlement of a long court fight over its use of nondisclosure agreements, according to documents filed on Friday in a New York federal court.

headline: Unconditional Condition?
abstract: Kate Hawkins presents a subtle and spirited Saturday grid.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is an all-around kindhearted grid, isn’t it? It’s not frustratingly difficult, the wordplay is good-humored, and there are upbeat terms and phrases at every turn. This is Kate Hawkins’s 11th published puzzle in The Times in a little over three years; according to her notes, however, it’s an early construction that sat in the hopper for a while. Not something I would have noticed: There’s a handful of debuts, some accessible modern trivia and plenty of fresh entries.

headline: Corrections: Feb. 4, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 4, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the lowest wind chill temperatures in decades in the Northeast misstated the location of Middlebury Snowbowl. It is in Hancock, Vt., not Middlebury.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Spa Town Favored by Russians Reinvents Itself
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 4, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Maybe I’m a bad person, but I don’t want to suffer for Ukraine.”

headline: Advisory Firm Sues Elon Musk’s Twitter, Saying It Hasn’t Been Paid
abstract: Innisfree M&A says Twitter, which Elon Musk bought last year, has not paid it $1.9 million for services it rendered for the deal.
lead_paragraph: The blockbuster technology deal that every adviser on Wall Street clamored to be a part of has proved not to have been so lucrative for at least one advisory firm that worked on it.

headline: Gautam Adani’s Rise Was Intertwined With India’s. Now It’s Unraveling.
abstract: The tycoon often said the Adani Group’s goals were in lock step with India’s needs. Now, the company’s fortunes are crashing, a collapse whose pain will be felt across the country.
lead_paragraph: Gautam Adani began the year as one of the richest men who ever lived, an upstart billionaire whose conglomerate, one of India’s largest, had surged in value by 2,500 percent in five years.

headline: Balloon Incident Highlights Fragile State of U.S.-China Relationship
abstract: Recent efforts by Beijing to mend ties with Washington were showing progress, but the balloon’s appearance over the United States illustrates lingering mistrust and growing tensions.
lead_paragraph: Live updates: The U.S. has shot down the Chinese spy balloon.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: After Gutting Youth Services, Can the U.K. Still Cut Youth Crime?
abstract: Poor neighborhoods that have been hit hardest by austerity have also seen violence among young people surge or remain stubbornly high. Residents say that’s no coincidence.
lead_paragraph: The Marcus Lipton Youth Club is the last dedicated youth center still standing in its pocket of South London. Every day, the center opens its steel security gates to an area of the city plagued by youth violence, where half the children live in poverty.

headline: Survivors of the Monterey Park Shooting Dance On
abstract: Three survivors who narrowly escaped the mass shooting at the Star Ballroom Dance Studio in Monterey Park, Calif., reflect on life after tragedy as their community returns to the dance floor.
lead_paragraph: Three survivors who narrowly escaped the mass shooting at the Star Ballroom Dance Studio in Monterey Park, Calif., reflect on life after tragedy as their community returns to the dance floor.

headline: She Grabs the Wrong Gym Bag, and Carries It Into a New Life
abstract: In “Someone Else’s Shoes,” Jojo Moyes puts a fresh spin on the classic plot where characters swap circumstances.
lead_paragraph: The British novelist Jojo Moyes is known for her terrifically funny tear-jerkers, often about women trapped in sticky situations. Very few authors have the power to make you laugh on one page and cry on the next. Moyes is one of them.

headline: As Wallace Stevens Once Put It: Hi!
abstract: Poetic beginnings — first lines, or first poems in collections — do a lot of work in setting the tone and the reader’s expectations.
lead_paragraph: Poker players have an expression for that moment when you look at your cards and discover you’ve been dealt the luckiest possible hand. It’s called “waking up with aces.” This reminds me of the way that the first lines of poems seem to come out of nowhere. It’s true for the poet, the lines just arriving, as if by dictation or angelic message — as Eliot writes in his essay on Blake, “The idea, of course, simply comes.” And it’s true for the reader, who can only have the same in medias res experience, encountering a line at the top of a page. There’s a shock to this unveiling. All the emails I get begin with some variation on “I hope this finds you well,” but a poem can begin in any kind of way. “I felt a Funeral, in my Brain.” “Thou still unravish’d bride of quietness.” There’s a Wallace Stevens poem that starts “Hi!”

headline: If the Ironman World Championship Doesn’t Happen in Kona, Did It Even Happen?
abstract: The iconic one-day world championship event has outgrown the small town on the island of Hawaii. But will triathletes follow the race outside of Kona?
lead_paragraph: The highest peak of a triathlete’s career can be found along a stretch of Ali’i Drive in Kailua-Kona, Hawaii.

headline: How Hard Is It to Hang On to Friends?
abstract: In her new memoir, “B.F.F.,” Christie Tate looks at her history of failed platonic relationships and learns something about herself.
lead_paragraph: Never trust a woman with no girlfriends, goes an old adage. But what about a woman who struggles with those girlfriend relationships, who finds them both necessary and confounding, and craves connection but finds conflict?

headline: Democrats Overhaul Party’s Primary Calendar, Upending a Political Tradition
abstract: The proposal radically reshapes the way the party picks its presidential nominees, putting more racially diverse states at the front of the line.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Upending decades of political tradition, the Democratic National Committee on Saturday approved a sweeping overhaul of the Democratic primary process, a critical step in President Biden’s effort to transform the way the party picks its presidential nominees.

headline: What Does It Mean to Be Liberal?
abstract: In his new book, “The Struggle for a Decent Politics,” the political philosopher Michael Walzer grapples with a definition.
lead_paragraph: We seem unable to live without the word “liberalism,” but can’t agree on what it means. Does it describe an ideology — or something fuzzier? If the first, Alexis de Tocqueville in 1840, William Gladstone in 1880 and Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932 would have disagreed violently about what that program was. One minimal definition, at least as it applies to liberal democracy, is that liberalism seeks to preserve political and economic liberty within a majoritarian framework. Liberals, in Isaiah Berlin’s language, care more about the “negative” principle of freedom from restraint than the positive one of forging a more just society.

headline: Bringing a Little Queerness to Acting Roles
abstract: Poppy Liu plays a blackjack dealer in “Hacks.” And has been working nonstop ever since.
lead_paragraph: Name: Poppy Liu

headline: Why New York City’s Best Won’t Be Enough to Solve the Migrant Crisis
abstract: The city has frantically sought to uphold its promise of shelter for all. But as more people arrive, services are being stretched past their capacity.
lead_paragraph: Since the governors of Texas and Florida began sending migrants northward in acts of political theater last spring, the city of New York has received close to 44,000 asylum seekers, a number greater than the populations of SoHo and TriBeCa combined. According to City Hall, there have been 12,000 new arrivals during the past month alone. While New York has welcomed great numbers of immigrants into its ecosystem each year for centuries — there are more than three million foreign-born people living in the city now, responsible for close to a quarter of the city’s gross domestic product — it has not confronted a situation where so many people have come in such rapid sequence without the traditional pathways to integration.

headline: The Mean Life of a ‘Midsize’ Model
abstract: On TikTok, a midsize movement is forming, but models like Jill Kortleve are rarely cast in glossy brand campaigns or on the catwalks. Why not?
lead_paragraph: In Paris last month, at the Chanel couture show, there was something about one model that set her apart from the others on the runway.

headline: Classified U.S. Report Highlights Foreign Power Aerial Spying With Advanced Tech
abstract: Before a Chinese spy balloon was discovered in the United States, American officials said a rival power may have used advanced technology to surveil U.S. military sites.
lead_paragraph: Live updates: The U.S. has shot down the Chinese spy balloon.

headline: Are You Switching to a Heat Pump? We Want to Hear From You.
abstract: Some people in extremely cold areas of the U.S. are switching to heat pumps from oil or gas furnaces. But others are not convinced that these devices are right for them.
lead_paragraph: As the world moves to electrify everything from cars to heating in an effort to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, heat pumps have become more popular.

headline: Selling Trump Isn’t What It Used to Be
abstract: Donald Trump has reunited with a former business partner to sell online trading cards, hoping to recreate a once-profitable mix of hype and celebrity. Initial sales hint at how difficult that will be in 2023.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump announced his foray into NFTs late last year, capitalizing on public interest in his presidential campaign to sell cartoonish virtual trading cards depicting him as a superhero, he was derided for retreating to his huckster impulses.

headline: How a Radio Producer Spends Her Sundays
abstract: KalaLea is a listener. Often, in her free time, she will tune in to a podcast, or the sounds of her neighborhood, or a friend’s story.
lead_paragraph: KalaLea has worked in video and graphic design, web production, photography and publishing. She has trained in yoga and Reiki, and she has pursued organic farming in Brazil. She has taught cooking classes, started a catering business and opened a cafe in Brooklyn. But once she found radio, it stuck.

headline: Will Pickleball Be as Fun to Watch as It Is to Play?
abstract: Pickleball had no problem attracting millions of amateur players. Now, as the sport looks to grow at the professional level, it must convince spectators that the game is as fun to watch as it is to play.
lead_paragraph: At parks, gyms and sports clubs across the country, millions of people are playing pickleball, with the sport’s explosive growth leading to battles with tennis players over court space, a push for developers to create new courts and professional athletes like LeBron James hungry to invest in the professional game.

headline: Ties to Kabul Bombing Put ISIS Leader in Somalia in U.S. Cross Hairs
abstract: Bilal al-Sudani’s financing of the ISIS branch in Afghanistan that killed 13 U.S. troops in 2021 elevated him on U.S. kill-or-capture lists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Bilal al-Sudani was no stranger to American counterterrorism officials.

headline: What’s the Correct Color of Bees? In Austria, It’s a Toxic Topic.
abstract: In the Austrian state of Carinthia, where the law favors light-colored local bees, those honey producers judged “too dark” risk eradication.
lead_paragraph: STOCKENBOI, Austria — Sandro Huter was determined to defend his bees, which were facing a looming death sentence.

headline: When It Comes to Building Its Own Defense, Europe Has Blinked
abstract: Despite expectations that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine would force Europe to bolster its military strength, it has instead reinforced dependency on U.S. leadership, intelligence and might.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is the greatest challenge to European security since the end of the Cold War, but the Europeans have missed the opportunity to step up their own defense, diplomats and experts say. Instead, the war has reinforced Europe’s military dependence on the United States.

headline: Turning Nairobi’s Public Libraries Into ‘Palaces for the People’
abstract: A Kenyan nonprofit is restoring iconic public libraries, leaving behind a segregated past and turning them into inclusive spaces.
lead_paragraph: In 1931, the first library in Kenya’s capital, Nairobi, opened its doors — to white patrons only.

headline: The Pentagon Saw a Warship Boondoggle. Congress Saw Jobs.
abstract: After years of crippling problems and a changing mission, the Navy pushed to retire nine of its newest ships. Then the lobbying started.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — The 387-foot-long warships tied up at the Jacksonville Navy base were acclaimed as some of the most modern in the United States fleet: nimble, superfast vessels designed to operate in coastal waters and hunt down enemy submarines, destroy anti-ship mines and repel attacks from small boats, like those often operated by Iran.

headline: Muscle Cars, Balaclavas and Fists: How the Scorpions Rolled Through Memphis
abstract: Residents say the street crime unit was an intimidating and sometimes violent presence in the city. Five Scorpion officers are charged with murdering Tyre Nichols during an arrest.
lead_paragraph: For 14 months, officers from the high-profile Scorpion unit of the Memphis Police Department patrolled city streets with an air of menace, zooming up on targets, jumping out of their Dodge Chargers at a dead run, shouting at people to get out of their vehicles, lie down on the ground.

headline: Harry Styles Ate Here. His Fans Will Now Eat Here Forever.
abstract: A stray lyric by the pop star radically changed the clientele — and fortunes — of a Los Angeles cafe.
lead_paragraph: At 9:30 a.m. on a Thursday, the Harrys began to arrive at Beachwood Cafe. Young women with neon hair extensions, colorful crocheted cardigans and shirts illustrated with cherries, sunflowers and the word “Pleasing” piled out of rental cars and Ubers. They were trailed by their mothers and filming on their phones. By 10:30, the mom-and pop eatery, which has been around since the 1970s in the heart of Beachwood Canyon, Los Angeles, had a 30-minute wait, and a swarm of teenage girls taking photos in front of its blue door.

headline: In Big Sur, Living With Nature’s Beauty but Trapped by Its Fury
abstract: The succession of storms last month that left some residents in that treasured region cut off from the rest of California is another reminder of the perils and adventure of Central Coast life.
lead_paragraph: BIG SUR, Calif. — Under cover of darkness, John Handy edged his Chevy Silverado as far south as he was allowed, contemplating escape.

headline: At Least 1 Is Killed in Brutal Cold Blast Across New York and New England
abstract: The wind chill atop Mount Washington in New Hampshire approached minus 110 degrees and an infant was killed when a tree fell on a car in western Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: People across the northeastern United States confronted the coldest temperatures seen in decades on Saturday, as an Arctic air mass passed over the region, accompanied by powerful winds that drove wind chills to dangerous levels.

headline: Some Homeless Encampments Can Stay, but the Underlying Issues Remain
abstract: Three court decisions have now ruled that the shelter system does not meet the needs of homeless people.
lead_paragraph: In many Canadians cities, one noticeable consequence of the pandemic has been a rise in the number of homeless people living in encampments. Now three separate court rulings in British Columbia and Ontario have upheld the right of their residents to not be removed.

headline: Just Often Enough, the Grammys Get It Right
abstract: It’s disappointing that the big awards show doesn’t reflect all of music’s immediacy and vibrancy and messiness. But the Grammys still function as a measure of change.
lead_paragraph: My teenage take on awards shows was informed by a punk rock worldview: The winners were losers. The Grammys? Isn’t that where everyone dresses like Liberace and glad-hands the press on a red carpet?

headline: Traveling and Eating Well
abstract: When you travel, is tracking down a fantastic meal just as important as seeing the sights? I have tips to help.
lead_paragraph: This year seems like a good year for a great trip. On The Times’s Food desk, where I’m an editor and also write a weekly newsletter about New York City restaurants, we’re already scouting for the year’s best restaurants, and I’m guessing many of you are planning trips with food in mind, too.

headline: Mount Washington set a record for coldest wind chill ever recorded at minus 108 degrees.
abstract: The air temperatures at the region’s highest peak went as low as minus 47 degrees, according to the National Weather Service.
lead_paragraph: Temperatures dropped precipitously and wind speeds rose across the Northeast early on Saturday, but no area could compete with the frigid conditions atop Mount Washington in New Hampshire.

headline: Watching the Watchmen
abstract: The government must match continued investments in policing with reforms that make police more accountable to the communities that they serve.
lead_paragraph: American communities need robust law enforcement, and the vast majority of police officers are public servants performing dangerous work with dedication. The footage of Memphis police officers killing Tyre Nichols in early January, however, is all the more unbearable because Americans have seen the likes of it so many times before. Too many Americans today live in fear that they may suffer abuse or excessive force at the hands of police officers who are sworn to protect them.

headline: Microsoft’s Activision Deal Tests a New Global Alignment on Antitrust
abstract: Until recently, antitrust regulators in Europe and the United States took different approaches. Now, they’re on the same page — which some experts say makes closing deals harder.
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft announced its $70 billion acquisition of the video game maker Activision Blizzard last year, almost everyone involved expected antitrust inquiries from officials in the European Union and Britain, and many thought regulators there would try to block the deal. What U.S. enforcers would do, however, was less clear.

headline: Russia Pushes to Take Ukrainian Town Near a Vital Supply Line
abstract: Ukraine has used the strategic town of Vuhledar to launch attacks disrupting transit on a critical rail link between the war’s southern and eastern fronts.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Moscow is deploying thousands of soldiers to southeastern Ukraine as it renews an assault on a strategically important town that Ukrainian forces have used to harass shipments on a critical Russian supply line that runs from the eastern Donbas region to Crimea.

headline: Maybe We Should Convince Men That Paid Leave Is Their Idea
abstract: The Family and Medical Leave Act turns 30 this year. Time for an upgrade.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Reisman spent her career pushing for a better system of child care in America. She was the executive director of the (now defunct) Child Care Action Campaign from 1986 to 1997. If you want to see her in action, you can watch her on C-SPAN speaking at hearings for the Act for Better Child Care Services of 1988 — if nothing else, the grainy footage is a powerful reminder that our foremothers were fighting the good fight on child care when I was, well, still a child.

headline: Erasing Black History Is Not the Role of the College Board
abstract: The way forward is confronting this history, not wishing it away.
lead_paragraph: In the nation’s capital, blocks from the White House, scores of sharply dressed Americans mingled Thursday night over cocktails and collard greens, a glittering coming-out party for the College Board’s first advanced placement course in African American studies.

headline: Attacks on Electrical Substations Raise Alarm
