abstract: The White House has embraced signs that the economy is strong. For the Fed, that strength could prolong its fight against inflation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, underscored that the central bank has more work to do when it comes to slowing the economy and that officials remain determined to wrestle rapid inflation under control, even if that means pushing rates higher than expected.

headline: A Tech Race Begins as Microsoft Adds A.I. to Its Search Engine
abstract: Amid the tech industry’s worst slump in decades, industry leaders are predicting an era built on new chatbots and other types of artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a rough few months for the tech industry. There have been tens of thousands of layoffs, hundreds of billions in value lost on Wall Street and a high-profile scandal at a crypto company that has shaken faith in that young market.

headline: How Much to See a Movie at AMC? It Will Soon Depend Where You Sit.
abstract: By the end of 2023, the movie theater chain will offer tickets at three different price tiers, with middle seats costing the most. You’ll pay less if you like the front row.
lead_paragraph: Some middle seats at AMC movie theaters will be more expensive than others as part of the company’s new ticket-pricing strategy, announced this week.

headline: An Army Brat Returns Home to a Korea He No Longer Recognizes
abstract: In Heinz Insu Fenkl’s autobiographical novel “Skull Water,” a 1970s teenager suffers a grief that connects him to his forebears.
lead_paragraph: Insu, the 14-year-old narrator of Heinz Insu Fenkl’s autobiographical novel, “Skull Water,” is mourning the Korea of his memory. The son of a Korean mother and a German father — a sergeant in the U.S. Army — he has just returned with his family to the Seoul region after a year in Germany, where his father had been stationed after service in the Vietnam War. Back in his native country, Insu feels a “profound disappointment” in its “new density,” noticing “the summer sweat on my flesh sticking with a different thickness.” His gaze remains this specific and melancholic throughout the novel.

headline: David Harris, Leader of Vietnam Draft Resistance Movement, Dies at 76
abstract: An activist who went to jail for refusing to serve in the military, he teamed with and married Joan Baez and later became a journalist.
lead_paragraph: David Harris, an activist and journalist who in the late 1960s became a national figure for encouraging young men to resist being drafted to serve in the Vietnam War — and who went to jail after refusing the draft himself — died on Monday at his home in Mill Valley, Calif. He was 76.

headline: Lesson Plan: The Devastating Earthquake in Turkey and Syria
abstract: Ways to help students understand the crisis and how they can make a difference.
lead_paragraph: A 7.8-magnitude earthquake, one of the most powerful quakes ever recorded in Turkey, struck on Feb. 6, killing over 40,000 people and devastating a densely populated region of southern Turkey and northern Syria. The rescue effort has been complicated by the location of the quake zone, in a region already burdened by a war and a refugee crisis, and straddling government- and opposition-controlled lands in Syria.

headline: Months Before Hamlin’s Collapse, Bills’ Co-Owner Also Suffered Cardiac Arrest
abstract: In an essay, Jessica Pegula, a top-ranked tennis player, described the health ordeal of her mother, Kim Pegula, president of the Buffalo Bills. Hamlin, a defensive back, went into cardiac arrest at a Jan. 2 game.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Pegula, the professional tennis player, has revealed details for the first time about the health of her mother, Kim Pegula, a co-owner and president of the Buffalo Bills and the Buffalo Sabres, describing how she went into cardiac arrest last year and is still struggling to recover.

headline: BP, in a Reversal, Says It Will Produce More Oil and Gas
abstract: The company said global concerns about energy security had prompted the change, as it reported record profits for 2022.
lead_paragraph: BP’s chief executive, Bernard Looney, said on Tuesday that the company would pare back its plans to reduce oil and gas production in the coming years, a move that would result in higher-than-expected carbon emissions.

headline: Ex-Coinbase Employee Pleads Guilty to Insider Trading
abstract: The case was part of a crackdown on an old-school financial crime in the crypto world.
lead_paragraph: A former employee of the Coinbase cryptocurrency exchange pleaded guilty on Tuesday to insider trading, the first time a crypto industry insider has admitted to trying to profit from confidential information.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘My Parents Fought a Lot’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: No church wants a pastor without a wife. Not in the 1960s, anyway. A year from graduating with a masters in theology, my father visited his school library and placed a book on each study table. He planned to return later, see who caught his fancy and then join her table as he claimed his book. But it was the student librarian who smiled at him when he returned. She despised the patriarchy, loved to gossip and preferred jokes to piety. My father asked her out, and my mother said yes. — Sari Fordham

headline: Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the Queen of Having It Both Ways
abstract: The Arkansas governor perfectly reflects the moral compromises of her party.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: Police Brutality Is Not Always About Race
abstract: The killing of Tyre Nichols is a reminder that even the most horrific injustices are often complicated.
lead_paragraph: The brutal killing of Tyre Nichols by Memphis cops horrified and infuriated many Americans, not least because it was another in what has been an endless litany of Black men and boys killed by police officers in America: George Floyd, Eric Garner, Philando Castile, Tamir Rice, Michael Brown and literally thousands of names less well known. There is one confounding detail in Nichols’s death, however. The five policemen who mercilessly beat the life out of him were all Black.

headline: Regulation, Productivity and the Meaning of Life
abstract: Safety and environmental rules may reduce gross domestic product. But maybe that’s OK.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago The Times published a very interesting column by my colleague Ezra Klein about America’s peculiar lack of progress in the art of building things. Drawing on a recent paper by Austan Goolsbee and Chad Syverson, he noted that at least according to official statistics, we’ve gone a half century without any rise whatsoever, and maybe even a decline, in construction productivity — basically the number of person-hours it takes to build a house or other structure of a given size.

headline: As Sunak Tries to Move Ahead, He’s Haunted by Prime Ministers Past
abstract: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain made moves to recharge his government, but he is being harried by Liz Truss and Boris Johnson, who are not fading away.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Rishi Sunak tried to recharge Britain’s beleaguered government on Tuesday, shuffling cabinet ministers and creating new departments to focus on science, technology and energy policy. But even as he moves forward, Mr. Sunak is haunted by his two ousted predecessors, Liz Truss and Boris Johnson, both of whom are mounting noisy rehabilitation campaigns, potentially at his expense.

headline: Restaurant Review: Le Bernardin Holds On to Its Craft (and Its Four Stars)
abstract: Eric Ripert and his team have emerged from the pandemic still carrying the flag for French technique, exquisitely handled seafood and pure pleasure.
lead_paragraph: When I tell people that the city’s great sushi counters are guardians of a cultural legacy, they usually know what I’m talking about. When I make the same case about Le Bernardin, the cushioned, curtained and carpeted seafood restaurant on West 51st Street, I get blank stares.

headline: Ted Bell, Adman Turned Author of Best-Selling Thrillers, Is Dead at 76
abstract: In midcareer, having worked for the biggest agencies, he quit to conjure up novels about a British spy named Alex Hawke, who was likened to James Bond.
lead_paragraph: Ted Bell, a former award-winning advertising copywriter and creative director who abandoned Madison Avenue in his early 50s to recast himself as a best-selling novelist by writing and marketing his Alex Hawke spy thrillers, died on Jan. 20 in Hartford, Conn. He was 76.

headline: Gustavo Dudamel: An Introduction in 10 Recordings
abstract: Dudamel, the New York Philharmonic’s next music director, has a varied catalog of classics and contemporary works, as well as film scores.
lead_paragraph: If Gustavo Dudamel, the 42-year-old superstar maestro who on Tuesday was announced as the next music director of the New York Philharmonic, is known for anything, it’s the sheer energy of his performances. His body moves with dancerly charisma as his baton conjures extremities of orchestral sound; the music feels alive, and so do you.

headline: Will Gustavo Dudamel Be New York’s New Bernstein?
abstract: The superstar conductor’s hiring is the New York Philharmonic’s attempt to recapture the populist glamour it enjoyed under Leonard Bernstein in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Gustavo Dudamel becoming the New York Philharmonic’s next conductor is a seismic event for the city’s cultural scene.

headline: Gustavo Dudamel, Star Maestro, to Leave L.A. for New York Philharmonic
abstract: Dudamel, a charismatic 42-year-old conductor, will take up the Philharmonic’s podium in 2026, in a major coup for the orchestra.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Gustavo Dudamel, the charismatic conductor of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, whose fiery baton and bouncy curls have made him one of classical music’s most recognizable figures, will leave his post in 2026 to become the music director of the New York Philharmonic, both orchestras announced on Tuesday.

headline: Zoom Joins Tech Giants in Announcing Layoffs
abstract: The company is cutting 15 percent of its work force, or about 1,300 jobs, citing “the uncertainty of the global economy.”
lead_paragraph: Zoom, the videoconferencing giant that grew rapidly during the pandemic, said on Tuesday that it was laying off 15 percent of its work force, or about 1,300 employees, becoming the latest tech company to cut back amid looming concerns about the economy.

headline: At Cooper Union, a Russian Design Show Caught in a Political Crossfire
abstract: After indefinitely postponing a modest student exhibit about the Russian equivalent to the Bauhaus, the school received protests from 750 academics. On Monday, it reinstated the show.
lead_paragraph: Since the Russian invasion of Ukraine there have been cancellations of concerts, exhibitions and performances, often involving high-profile Russian artists with ties to the government of President Vladimir V. Putin. But the latest event to be postponed and debated was somewhat different: an architecture exhibition at the Cooper Union in New York.

headline: Where to Find Sicilian Specialties, and More Reader Questions
abstract: Eating outdoors in the winter? No problem.
lead_paragraph: I’d like to start this week’s newsletter with a very heartfelt thank you to the folks here at The Times who contributed to last week’s Valentine’s Day dining newsletter. They are some of the busiest people on staff, and I appreciate their taking the time to share such thoughtful recommendations. We will definitely do that again!

headline: Where #Vanlife Meets #Skibum
abstract: In the Pacific Northwest, ski resorts set aside spots in their parking lots for vans and R.V.s, creating overnight communities of skiers and riders. One writer toured three Oregon resorts to test the scene.
lead_paragraph: When you spend the night in a ski area parking lot during a snowstorm, there’s a point in the early morning hours when the soundscape inside the van shifts. The quiet huff of snow and wind is broken by the distant thunder of avalanche bombs, and the beep and scrape of snowplows.

headline: Biden’s approval ratings last year were some of the worst for a second-year president.
abstract: The economy has helped drag down the president’s numbers, with a low point coming amid record high gas prices.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans disapprove of the job President Biden is doing, with his approval rating hovering around 42 percent for months after recovering from a dip into the mid-30s over the summer.

headline: How Eagles Coach Nick Sirianni Got That Philadelphia Swagger
abstract: After surviving a disastrous introductory news conference, an ill-chosen flower analogy and his “Beat Dallas” motivational shirt, Sirianni has transformed the Eagles and maybe himself.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the Super Bowl between Philadelphia and Kansas City.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing: Quake’s Death Toll Soars
abstract: Also, China’s balloon spin and Russia’s mounting losses.
lead_paragraph: As the death toll from the earthquake in Turkey and Syria rose to at least 7,100, the window for finding survivors was beginning to narrow. Rescue workers were digging through debris in freezing conditions. The World Health Organization said the death toll was expected to increase by the thousands.

headline: Grammys 2023: Hip-Hop Wins, Beyoncé Wins (Sort of)
abstract: Does respect from music’s premier awards show still carry weight?
lead_paragraph: The major awards at this year’s Grammys were split: Harry Styles won album of the year, Lizzo took record of the year and Bonnie Raitt received song of the year. Beyoncé, nominated in each of those categories, won none of them.

headline: Sarah Huckabee Sanders plans a Republican response that pushes for younger leaders.
abstract: Ms. Sanders, 40, the newly elected governor of Arkansas, is expected to highlight the age difference between her and President Biden, 80.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders of Arkansas, one of the relatively few high-profile Trump administration officials who bolstered their careers through the experience, will step into the national spotlight again on Tuesday night when she delivers the Republican response to President Biden’s State of the Union address.

headline: Rescuers Pull Survivors from Collapsed Apartment in Turkey
abstract: Dozens of volunteers joined a rescue effort to save a family trapped inside the wreckage of a six-floor apartment building in Gaziantep, Turkey.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of volunteers joined a rescue effort to save a family trapped inside the wreckage of a six-floor apartment building in Gaziantep, Turkey.

headline: Amid Quake’s Frosty Wreckage, a Remarkable but Bittersweet Rescue
abstract: In the hard-hit Turkish city of Gaziantep, a collapsed apartment building spared few of its residents. But one man heard his brother’s voice from beneath the debris.
lead_paragraph: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — At first glance, there was little reason to expect that anyone was still alive in the ruins of the apartment building on Tuesday. The powerful earthquake that struck southern Turkey the day before had reduced its six floors to a hulking pile of concrete rubble.

headline: Fact-Checking Biden Before the State of the Union
abstract: We examined the president’s recent statements.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a preview of his State of the Union address on Tuesday, President Biden has toured the country promoting his legislative accomplishments and economic progress — and flubbed some facts along the way.

headline: Battery Fire Forces Plane to Return to San Diego After Takeoff
abstract: Four people were treated at a hospital for smoke inhalation after a passenger’s external battery pack caught fire in the cabin of a New Jersey-bound flight, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A battery pack caught fire in the cabin of a New Jersey-bound flight from California on Tuesday, forcing the plane to return to San Diego International Airport shortly after takeoff, officials said.

headline: House G.O.P. Leads Constitution Read-Aloud, Seeking an Edge on Patriotism
abstract: A 43-minute recitation of the document fulfilled a promise Republicans made last year, and followed several acts of performative patriotism since they assumed control of the House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Kevin McCarthy vowed during his party’s campaign to win control of the House that things would be different when Republicans took over, with new policies on the agenda, new people in charge and “something that hasn’t been done in years”: a new ritual of reading every single word of the Constitution aloud from the floor on Day 1.

headline: Investment Firm Backs Bed Bath & Beyond’s Stock Offering
abstract: Hudson Bay Capital has essentially agreed to make sure the troubled retailer will sell roughly $1 billion in shares as it tries to avoid bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: Bed Bath & Beyond’s plan to use a public stock offering as a way to raise more than $1 billion and avoid bankruptcy will be backed by the investment firm Hudson Bay Capital Management, two people familiar with the situation said, speaking on the condition of anonymity because the terms of the deal have not been made public.

headline: Memphis Officer Texted Photo of Tyre Nichols After Beating, New Documents Show
abstract: The revelation came in Memphis police documents related to the firing of five officers who have been charged with murder in Mr. Nichols’s death.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — As Tyre Nichols sat propped against a police car, bloodied, dazed and handcuffed after being beaten by a group of Memphis police officers, one of those officers took a picture of him and sent it to at least five people, the Memphis Police Department said in documents released by the state on Tuesday.

headline: Rescue Teams Fight ‘Weather and the Earthquake’ as Toll Surpasses 7,700 Dead
abstract: Shoveling snow and rubble, emergency crews worked across hundreds of miles in Turkey and Syria to save people in the aftermath of the most powerful quake in the region in decades.
lead_paragraph: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — Rescue workers dug through rubble on Tuesday to find survivors of the most powerful and deadly earthquake to hit Turkey and Syria in decades, toiling in a vast and desperate search complicated by geography and geopolitics, freezing weather and the sheer scope of the disaster.

headline: Alec Baldwin’s Lawyers Say ‘Rust’ Prosecutor Should Be Disqualified
abstract: Lawyers for Mr. Baldwin, who was charged with involuntary manslaughter, say the fact that the special prosecutor is also a state legislator violates the New Mexico Constitution.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the actor Alec Baldwin filed a motion on Tuesday seeking to disqualify the special prosecutor who was part of the team that brought involuntary manslaughter charges against him for the fatal shooting of the cinematographer on the “Rust” movie set.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Mukarram Jah, Heir to an Opulent Throne He Abandoned, Dies at 89
abstract: He descended from famed Islamic royalty in India and Turkey, but later fled to Australia and became a sheep farmer.
lead_paragraph: On April 6, 1967, Mukarram Jah was fabulously, and unhappily, thrust into the past.

headline: From a baby born in the rubble to a trapped teenager, many earthquake victims are children.
abstract: Harrowing images have emerged of some of the millions of children caught in the catastrophic earthquake in Turkey and Syria.
lead_paragraph: A baby born under the rubble and rescued, alive, hours later. Two little girls lying flat in the wreckage of a collapsed building. A boy dangling from a roof, reciting the Muslim prayer of death. A teenage boy recording himself under the ruins of his home, wondering if he will live or die.

headline: Russia Pays a Bloody Price for Small Gains on Eastern Front
abstract: Russia is relying on masses of troops to overrun Ukrainian positions, producing heavy casualties and incremental gains.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — As Russia makes slow, bloody gains in a renewed push to capture more of eastern Ukraine, it is pouring ever more conscripts and military supplies into the battle, Ukrainian officials say. Still it remains far from clear that Moscow can mobilize enough forces to sustain a prolonged offensive.

headline: Charles Silverstein, 87, Dies; Helped Destigmatize Homosexuality
abstract: He was at the forefront in persuading the American Psychiatric Association to reassess its classification of homosexuality as a mental disorder.
lead_paragraph: In February 1973, when it was his turn to speak before an American Psychiatric Association panel on why it should stop classifying homosexuality as a mental disorder, Charles Silverstein chose an unexpected tool for his response: humor.

headline: Former Mexican President Accused of Supporting Sinaloa Cartel
abstract: The accusation, which was quickly denied, was made by a former Mexican official at the trial in Brooklyn of Mexico’s former top security chief.
lead_paragraph: A former Mexican official convicted of drug trafficking testified in a New York court on Tuesday that he had been told that Felipe Calderón, the onetime president of Mexico, had instructed government officials to support the Sinaloa drug cartel as it battled its rivals.

headline: China Isn’t Ready to Pick Up Phone After Balloon Incident
abstract: Chinese officials rejected a request from the U.S. defense secretary to speak with his counterpart after an American fighter jet shot down a Chinese spy balloon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon said on Tuesday that China had rejected a request from Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III to speak with his Chinese counterpart on Saturday soon after an American fighter jet shot down a Chinese spy balloon off the coast of South Carolina.

headline: How Earthquakes Test Our Souls and Our Governments
abstract: What I lived through as a boy in Mexico City and what it could foretell for Turkey and Syria.
lead_paragraph: In every life there are a few indelible dates: the birth of a child, the death of a parent, a national tragedy such as 9/11.

headline: New York City’s Social Services Commissioner Will Resign
abstract: Gary Jenkins, who has been criticized for his handling of the homeless crisis, said he would step down in a television interview Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s embattled social services commissioner, who has faced criticism over his handling of the city’s homelessness crisis, said in a television interview on Tuesday that he is resigning.

headline: Kyrie Irving Says He Wants to Change His Narrative in Dallas
abstract: After his first practice with the Dallas Mavericks since being traded from the Nets, Kyrie Irving said he felt nothing but “genuine love” from his new team.
lead_paragraph: After practicing with the Dallas Mavericks for the first time, Kyrie Irving sat in front of a team-themed backdrop on Tuesday afternoon to express his excitement and criticize his former employer.

headline: Read the Decertification Documents
abstract: Memphis police officials detailed the actions taken by five fired officers that led to Tyre Nichols’s death.
lead_paragraph: Memphis police officials detailed the actions taken by five fired officers that led to Tyre Nichols’s death.

headline: Officers Manhandled and Beat Tyre Nichols. We Tracked Each One’s Role.
abstract: The Times found that each of the six officers we tracked immediately used physical force, escalating even as Nichols became increasingly incapacitated and incoherent.
lead_paragraph: The Times found that each of the six officers we tracked immediately used physical force, escalating even as Nichols became increasingly incapacitated and incoherent.

headline: Biden plans to warn Republicans not to use the debt limit as a bargaining chip.
abstract: Economists roundly agree that it would be catastrophic for the economy if the United States did not pay its bills and defaulted on its debt by failing to make required payments to U.S. bondholders.
lead_paragraph: President Biden plans to offer a wish list of Democratic policy proposals during his State of the Union address on Tuesday night, but the most pressing item on his agenda this year will require the cooperation of Republicans: raising the debt limit.

headline: Videos Show Desperate Search for Survivors Near Quake’s Epicenter
abstract: Hatay Province had Turkey’s highest-known death toll from Monday’s earthquake.
lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — As dawn broke on Tuesday, rescuers scrambled to use whatever they could — shovels, bare hands, random tools found on the street — to dig for survivors after the worst earthquake to hit Turkey in decades.

headline: After spy balloon clash, U.S.-China tensions loom over Biden’s speech.
abstract: The president has taken steps meant to limit China’s technological advancement and bolster military forces in the Asia-Pacific region.
lead_paragraph: While Russia’s war in Ukraine presents a more urgent day-to-day foreign policy issue for President Biden and his aides, they have said repeatedly that China is the greatest long-term challenger to American power — even as the two countries maintain robust trade ties.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Officer Dies After Being Shot in Robbery While Off Duty
abstract: Adeed Fayaz, 26, had been shot on Saturday as he tried to buy a car in Brooklyn in response to a Facebook Marketplace post.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer died from his injuries on Tuesday after he was shot while off duty during a robbery attempt as he tried to buy a car in Brooklyn, police officials said.

headline: New York Hails Maestro as a ‘Monstruo’ and a Boon to Young Musicians
abstract: The naming of Gustavo Dudamel to lead the New York Philharmonic elicited national pride among Venezuelans and excitement among those who provide music training to children.
lead_paragraph: Eduardo Cordova, a bartender at the Venezuelan restaurant Casa Ora in Brooklyn, greeted the naming of Gustavo Dudamel as the New York Philharmonic’s next music director and its first Hispanic leader with high praise.

headline: On a Streak
abstract: Solve Chase Dittrich’s puzzle with or without help from the Wordplay column.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Sweep in 3 Special Elections Gives Democrats Control of Pennsylvania House
abstract: Three Democratic victories flipped the House for the first time in a dozen years by a single seat in the battleground state.
lead_paragraph: Democrats swept three special elections in solidly blue House districts in western Pennsylvania on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, putting the party in the majority by a single seat and breaking a Republican legislative monopoly that has recently focused on election restrictions and anti-abortion bills.

headline: Biden Officials Tell Supreme Court That Title 42 Case Will Soon Be Moot
abstract: The justices are set to hear arguments on March 1 on whether Republican-led states may seek to keep in place the immigration measure, which was justified by the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration urged the Supreme Court on Tuesday to dismiss a challenge to ending the pandemic-era immigration measure known as Title 42, saying that the government’s announcement that the health emergency would expire on May 11 would make the case moot.

headline: For a President Who Spends His Days Confronting Russia and China, a Domestic Focus
abstract: Mr. Biden is proud of reshaping foreign policy to focus on superpower conflict, but knows it is jobs and energy prices that voters want to hear about.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Biden delivered his State of the Union address a year ago, war had broken out in Europe just days before and it appeared inevitable that Vladimir V. Putin would quickly take control of Ukraine. China, the Pentagon kept repeating, was America’s “pacing” challenge, a long-term technological and financial competitor, but not likely to pose an imminent challenge to Taiwan or the United States.

headline: 7 Takeaways From Biden’s State of the Union Address
abstract: The president’s speech presented no big new proposals, but he offered to work with Republicans even as he parried hecklers and sought to allay Democratic concerns about his vigor heading into 2024.
lead_paragraph: President Biden delivered a plea to Republicans on Tuesday for unity in his second State of the Union address, but vowed not to back off his economic agenda and offered no far-reaching, new ideas in a speech filled with a familiar litany of exhortations from more than four decades in political life.

headline: LeBron James Breaks Kareem Abdul-Jabbar’s N.B.A. Scoring Record
abstract: James, the Los Angeles Lakers star, scored the record-breaking 38,388th point that had eluded generations of superstars.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One of the most extraordinary records in N.B.A. history had stood for nearly 39 years, until LeBron James grabbed it for himself.

headline: How LeBron James Outscored Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and All the N.B.A. Greats
abstract: LeBron James now has the N.B.A.’s career scoring record. See how he got there, and how he overtook the other great scorers in league history.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James now has the N.B.A.’s career scoring record. See how he got there, and how he overtook the other great scorers in league history.

headline: The Story of LeBron James’s 38,390 Points, by Those Who Were There
abstract: Teammates. Competitors. Victims of his memes. They each have a story about James’s road to breaking the N.B.A. career scoring record.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Curry’s favorite memory of playing against LeBron James isn’t from any of the three championships he won with the Golden State Warriors against James’s teams. It was from his 2009-10 rookie season, when James was in his seventh year with the Cleveland Cavaliers.

headline: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar Is Greater Than Any Basketball Record
abstract: His N.B.A. career scoring record has been broken, but his legacy of activism and his expansion of Black athlete identity endure.
lead_paragraph: Some athletes live swaddled in their greatness, and that is enough. Others not only master their sport but also expand the possibilities — in competition and away from it — for generations to come. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar did just that, including for LeBron James, who has laid claim to the N.B.A. career scoring record that Abdul-Jabbar had held so tight for nearly 39 years.

headline: Biden’s Message: What Trump Promised, I’m Delivering
abstract: But there were also reminders of the forces that can’t be mastered by infrastructure spending, China bashing and appropriations of populist themes.
lead_paragraph: In 2016 Donald Trump ran for president against his fellow Republicans and then against Hillary Clinton by promising economic nationalism: a break with the bipartisan enthusiasm for globalization, an end to outsourcing, a manufacturing revival, new infrastructure spending, frank competition with China instead of friendly integration.

headline: A Milestone for Black N.F.L. Hires, but Not on the Sidelines
abstract: Five Black presidents have been hired to lead N.F.L. teams, an influx some hope could provide a blueprint for diversifying leadership even as the league struggles to improve head coaching searches.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the Super Bowl between Philadelphia and Kansas City.

headline: The Many Ways LeBron James Can Score
abstract: The Los Angeles Lakers star’s game has evolved over the past 20 years, making him a threat from all over the court — no matter how old he gets.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Lakers star’s game has evolved over the past 20 years, making him a threat from all over the court — no matter how old he gets.

headline: A Teenage Poet, Onstage at Town Hall
abstract: A poetry slam will feature Cameron Dada, one of the winners of a Black History Month poetry competition.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll preview a poetry slam for middle and high school students that’s planned for today. We’ll also look at swimmers who survive winter by swimming — and not in a heated pool.

headline: After Shouts of ‘Liar’ and Worse, Biden Takes on His Detractors in Real Time
abstract: His State of the Union address was not exactly a celebration of a unity agenda. But the president seemed to relish the scrimmage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden was about midway through a speech of about 7,218 words on Tuesday when a Republican lawmaker tried to shut him down with a single one: “Liar!”

headline: Corrections: Feb. 8, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Feb. 8, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about the flight of a Chinese surveillance balloon across the United States and what it reveals about China’s surveillance of the United States misstated the military rank of Michael Rogers, a former director of the National Security Agency. He is a retired admiral, not a general.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Rescuers Battle Fierce Weather as Toll Grows
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, February 8, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “People are driving bodies to us in their personal cars.”

headline: Trump stages his own ‘State of the Union’ speech.
abstract: The former president excoriated President Biden in a two-minute videotaped message from his South Florida home.
lead_paragraph: Eager to burnish his 2024 bona fides as some Republicans raise doubts about his third bid for the White House, former President Donald J. Trump stood Tuesday between two American flags — in his signature blue suit and red tie — and offered his own assessment of the nation.

headline: Times Columnists Respond to the State of the Union
abstract: Welcome to Opinion’s commentary on the State of the Union. Here’s what several of our writers thought of President Biden’s speech.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Opinion’s commentary on the State of the Union. Here’s what several of our writers thought of President Biden’s speech.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: The rising death toll in Turkey and Syria from the earthquake.
lead_paragraph: Rescue workers dug through rubble yesterday to find survivors of the most powerful and deadly earthquake to hit Turkey and Syria in decades, toiling in a vast and desperate search complicated by geography and geopolitics, freezing weather and the sheer scope of the disaster. At least 7,700 people were reported dead, and the toll is expect to climb, officials said.

headline: Sarah Huckabee Sanders, in G.O.P. response, criticizes Biden agenda as ‘woke fantasies.’
abstract: Ms. Sanders is the first Arkansan to deliver a State of the Union response since Bill Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders of Arkansas delivered a scorching admonition of President Biden’s State of the Union address on Tuesday, casting him as the head of a failed administration hijacked by a “radical left” agenda that has delivered high gasoline prices and empty grocery shelves while teaching children to “hate one another on account of their race.”

headline: Fact-Checking Biden’s State of the Union Address
abstract: The president’s speech contained no outright falsehoods, but at times omitted crucial context or exaggerated the facts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden praised the economy as well as his legislative accomplishments and record on the world stage in his State of the Union address on Tuesday night.

headline: Germany Has a Problem
abstract: A reckoning with the far right is long overdue.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In the heat of debate about Germany sending tanks to Ukraine, it’s easy to forget that just two months ago, the authorities arrested 25 people for planning a radical right-wing coup to overthrow the German government.

headline: Full Transcript of Biden’s State of the Union Address
abstract: In his first State of the Union speech under a divided Congress, President Biden highlighted his economic record and appealed to Republicans to work with him.
lead_paragraph: President Biden delivered his annual State of the Union address on Tuesday to a joint session of Congress. The following is a transcript of his remarks, as recorded by The New York Times.

headline: Jimmy Fallon Sounds Off on State of the Union Applause
abstract: “It was a tough night for all of Biden’s staffers watching from the White House, because every time people clapped, the lights went on and off,” Fallon said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Inside the tense exchange between Romney and Santos.
abstract: Senator Mitt Romney of Utah admonished Representative George Santos, a fellow Republican and New York freshman, telling him he “shouldn’t have been there.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It began on the floor of the House, in an impromptu but strikingly testy exchange just before the State of the Union address.

headline: Planning and Working
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A Grieving Turkish Diaspora Rallies Together
abstract: In Melbourne, Australia, dozens of volunteers in the parking lot behind a halal butcher shop packed three shipping containers with cardboard boxes full of new tents, blankets and sleeping bags.
lead_paragraph: As they reckon with shocking images on social media and the long wait for news from home, the world’s Turkish diaspora, which includes some 20 million people, has rallied to provide support to one another and send aid to their family members far away.

headline: Zelensky thanks Britain during his second overseas trip since Russia’s invasion.
abstract: LONDON — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine made a surprise visit to Britain on Wednesday morning, welcomed with a hug at Stansted Airport by Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, who announced plans to expand British military support for Ukraine to include training its pilots in NATO fighter jets.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine made a surprise visit to Britain on Wednesday morning, welcomed with a hug at Stansted Airport by Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, who announced plans to expand British military support for Ukraine to include training its pilots in NATO fighter jets.

headline: Syrian Refugees Who Died in Earthquake Are Returned Home
abstract: Millions fled the war in Syria for the safety of neighboring Turkey. “We want them to be buried among their family,” said a man waiting for the body of a young relative coming from Turkey.
lead_paragraph: In the first days after Monday’s earthquake, no humanitarian aid was entering northwestern Syria. Only victims’ bodies.

headline: 2023 Oscar Nominations: Full Ballot
abstract: Here’s every nominee. Cast your vote and predict the winners.
lead_paragraph: Here’s every nominee. Cast your vote and predict the winners.

headline: The Trouble With Reboot TV
abstract: The reboot that changes nothing will be uncanny and lifeless; the one that thinks itself more clever than its predecessor will turn out cynical and sour.
lead_paragraph: In life, you rarely get a second chance to do something right — so goes the shopworn cliché. Contemporary Hollywood is a different matter. If a property was even glancingly popular in the 1980s or ’90s, it seems, it’s either in the process of being resuscitated or has been already. “Reboot” is one of those coinages that burrows into the lexicon without ever being fully explained (at least to me), but it has clearly supplanted “remake,” migrating over from the language of computing such that you now imagine the entertainment industry pulling every last item from its junk drawer and plugging it in to see if it still works. So startlingly large is the number of rebooted series that the phenomenon has even inspired an original show: Hulu’s very funny “Reboot,” about a fictional garbage ’80s sitcom being brought back to life.

headline: This Soup Can Be Many Things, but It’s Always Delicious
abstract: The warmth and richness of menudo is a fortifying ritual to finish up the week — or start a new one.
lead_paragraph: Menudo is magic in a bowl — a very particular alchemical assemblage. Sporting tripe, a deeply spiced broth and the choice of many different seasonings, this Mexican soup is a gift at the beginning of a slow morning, or the end of a too-long night. Whatever the scenario, menudo can mean community, and menudo can mean tradition, and menudo can mean family, in any iteration of that word that feels right for you. But no matter the context: Menudo is simply delicious. It’s a ritual and a history and a balm inside your bowl.

headline: $370,000 Homes in Indiana, Vermont and Georgia
abstract: A three-bedroom home in Indianapolis, a two-bedroom condominium in Waitsfield and an early 19th-century farmhouse in Washington.
lead_paragraph: This house is in the St. Clair Place neighborhood, a bustling section of Indianapolis with an active community association. The area’s main thoroughfare, 10th Street, is a few blocks away, putting this home within easy walking or biking distance of several pubs, a brewery and a community center.

headline: With One More Title, the Eagles Would Finally Match the A’s
abstract: Despite having left town in 1954, the Athletics, with five championships, are still Philadelphia’s most decorated team. The Eagles could tie things up on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the Super Bowl between Philadelphia and Kansas City.

headline: When the Government Goes Top Secret, Who Can Write Its History?
abstract: In “The Declassification Engine,” Matthew Connelly traces the evolution of America’s obsession with secrecy and the alarming implications for our understanding of the past.
lead_paragraph: It’s no secret that government secrecy has gone haywire. Classified documents have turned up in the homes of President Biden and former Vice President Mike Pence, where they were perhaps inadvertently stashed. That’s a far cry from the case of former President Donald Trump, who, it appears, deliberately concealed top-secret records at his Florida estate, unlawfully keeping them from their rightful owners: the National Archives and, ultimately, the people of the United States.

headline: The Prophet of Urban Doom Says New York Still Has a Chance
abstract: The business professor who warned that the city might be caught in a ‘doom loop’ suddenly finds himself famous.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: A Cockeyed Optimist: Oscar Hammerstein Was No Stephen Sondheim
abstract: Laurie Winer’s new book, “Oscar Hammerstein II and the Invention of the Musical,” takes the measure of Sondheim’s mentor and spiritual godfather.
lead_paragraph: When I read in Laurie Winer’s new book that she’d gone 22 times to the original production of Stephen Sondheim’s “Sweeney Todd,” I wasn’t surprised. A charming, out-of-control passion animates her “Oscar Hammerstein II and the Invention of the Musical.” The book arrives as a handsome, sobersided production from Yale University Press, and it displays a reasoned and discerning tone throughout. Yet there’s no mistaking, underneath, an author drunk on Broadway’s blazonry.

headline: What Acts of Kindness Have You Witnessed or Participated In?
abstract: A farmer secretly paid for his neighbors’ prescriptions for years. Would you give this way to others — even if you wouldn’t receive any public recognition or reward?
lead_paragraph: When was the last time someone did something particularly kind, generous or selfless for you?

headline: Does Your Home Have Backup Power? We Want to Hear From You.
abstract: Sales of generators and home batteries are up as people look to protect themselves from power outages, which are becoming more common.
lead_paragraph: The system that provides electricity to our homes is getting less reliable. Outages are more frequent and last for longer. More severe weather is likely to make the problem worse.

headline: Madonna’s New Face Is a Brilliant Provocation
abstract: Some fans cheered, others scowled, but the queen of reinvention may have laughed last.
lead_paragraph: With blond braids looped over her ears, dressed in a long black skirt and black jacket accessorized with a riding crop, one of the best-selling female recording artists of all time stepped into the spotlight at the 65th annual Grammy Awards Sunday night. Madonna was there to introduce Sam Smith and Kim Petras, a nonbinary performer and a trans woman. She began by referring to her four decades in the music industry, and praised the rebels “forging a new path and taking the heat for all of it.”

headline: Would You Have Four Kids if It Meant Never Paying Taxes Again?
abstract: Countries around the world are trying to raise fertility rates. Will anything work?
lead_paragraph: Eagle-eyed readers may notice we’re dropping “On Parenting” from this newsletter’s title. Don’t worry: I’ll still be analyzing the health, economics and culture of the American family. I’m just expanding my coverage area to include adjacent topics about the way we live now that don’t always involve parenting, like health, wellness, celebrity and internet culture, evolving ideas about etiquette, shifting workplace norms and, as we approach a presidential election cycle, a few thoughts on politics. (As always, if you have questions, topics or ideas you want explored, drop me a line here.)

headline: Politicians of Asian Descent Rise in Latino-Majority San Antonio
abstract: With the election of a Japanese American as leader of the county government, San Antonio now has politicians of Asian descent in its two top positions.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Peter Sakai, a second-generation Japanese American, was serving as a family court judge in San Antonio, which is largely Hispanic, when he was reminded of how much he stood out.

headline: The World’s Biggest Democracy Is Jettisoning Freedom and Tolerance
abstract: The soul of a majestic nation is at stake.
lead_paragraph: When I moved to New Delhi in 2009 to work as a foreign correspondent, there was already a decade’s worth of magazine covers heralding the inevitable, just-around-the-corner but not-quite-yet-here rise of India to the top table of the global order and its role as a democratic counterweight to China. Usually they included an elephant or perhaps a tiger or a woman in a shimmering sari. The messy problems of multiethnic democracy, a tangled bureaucracy shot through with corruption, the great difficulty of dragging hundreds of millions of people out of poverty — these would all be overcome through ingenuity, technology and India’s relentless spirit of progress. The cyclical nature of these magazine covers brought to mind the famous quip about Brazil: India was the country of the future and always would be.

headline: A Troubled Mother Faces Murder Charges in Her Young Children’s Deaths
abstract: Chilling details emerged at an arraignment of Lindsay Clancy, accused of strangling her three children. Her lawyer argued she was mentally ill, but prosecutors outlined methodical planning leading to the deaths.
lead_paragraph: DUXBURY, Mass. — Lindsay Clancy lay paralyzed in a hospital bed on Tuesday afternoon, occasionally blinking or shutting her eyes, unable to do anything but listen as lawyers told two narratives about how she had strangled her three children.

headline: Meet the People Working on Getting Us to Hate One Another Less
abstract: As the threat to democratic norms and procedures mounts, there has been an explosion of research aimed at lowering the political temperature.
lead_paragraph: Affective polarization — “a poisonous cocktail of othering, aversion and moralization” — has prompted an explosion of research as the threat to democratic norms and procedures mounts.

headline: Whitney Houston’s Enduring Legacy: Lifting Up Other Black Women
abstract: The singer was intimately familiar with how punishing the spotlight could be. Instead of only guiding others toward greater visibility, she worked to ensure they would survive it.
lead_paragraph: THERE ARE, STRANGELY, a lot of other women in Whitney Houston’s 1993 video for the song “I’m Every Woman,” that can-do anthem powered by Houston’s unparalleled midrange pipes. “It’s all in me,” she sings of a spellbinding force that would seem to make others unnecessary. Yet there alongside her we find the funk powerhouse Chaka Khan, who first recorded the song in 1978; the song’s co-composer Valerie Simpson; Houston’s mother and mentor, Cissy Houston; a dance team of young Black girls; and the trio TLC. Houston recorded “I’m Every Woman” for the soundtrack of “The Bodyguard” (1992), which she co-executive produced, and which secured her megastardom such that “the wonderment of her talent and her career impacted everyone,” as her sister-in-law and estate executor, Pat Houston, puts it. The open secret of this video is that Houston had a hand in that influence: She deliberately used her status as an icon to light up a whole network of Black female forebears and creative descendants.

headline: The Future of Balenciaga Is on the Line
abstract: And everything else you need to know to hold forth on fashion month at a cocktail party.
lead_paragraph: Get ready. Your feeds are about to be crammed full of color, sparkle, celebrities and opinion. Fashion month is upon us: hundreds of shows in four cities vying not just for your wardrobes, but for your eyeballs and even sense of outrage.

headline: For a Stable, Strong Core, Forget About Crunches
abstract: If the goal of your workout is to walk away with a chiseled six-pack, you’re missing the point.
lead_paragraph: To perform well at virtually any sport, you need a strong core. This is a no-brainer for rowing, golf and dancing, but it’s also true for less obvious activities: Your core gives you the stability you need to play darts, for example, and the power you need to play Ping-Pong.

headline: What a Bird Flu Outbreak Among Mink Could Mean for Humans
abstract: A new variant of avian influenza appears capable of spreading among mammals, highlighting the need for more proactive surveillance, experts said.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: An Artist With Roots in Nairobi and New York Imagines a New Destiny
abstract: With sculptures that blend evolutionary history and science fiction, Wangechi Mutu draws on her bicontinental life for an ambitious New Museum survey.
lead_paragraph: “It’s the difference between a plant with one root and one with a network of roots,” the artist Wangechi Mutu said. She was speaking in the clear light of her expansive, white-walled and wood-beamed studio, on the outskirts of Nairobi, about her decision in 2015 to begin dividing her time between New York — where she had been living and working since the mid-1990s — and Kenya, the country of her birth.

headline: China’s Bid to Improve Food Production? Giant Towers of Pigs.
abstract: High-rise hog farms have sprung up nationwide as part of Beijing’s drive to enhance its agricultural competitiveness and reduce its dependence on imports.
lead_paragraph: The first sows arrived in late September at the hulking, 26-story high-rise towering above a rural village in central China. The female pigs were whisked away dozens at a time in industrial elevators to the higher floors where the hogs would reside from insemination to maturity.

headline: SZA’s Ruination Brought Her Everything
abstract: Her moody, enigmatic music made her a megastar. Can she learn to live with success?
lead_paragraph: If you’re footloose and floating up Pacific Coast Highway, a blink beyond the emerald front lawn of Pepperdine University, you’ll sense a sharp rise above sea level. The world’s deepest ocean appears on your left, a vast and breathing GIF. Moons charm bloodstreams, and dolphins model fortitude. Hawks plunge for fat mackerel, and riptides drag fools far out and forever under waves that from the shore look like peace and possibility.

headline: Hip-Hop, Still Fly at 50
abstract: A museum exhibition and book kick off the anniversary of a genre incubated in the Bronx and exported to the world.
lead_paragraph: “Everything is a flashback,” Syreeta Gates said last week. “That’s the way it always is with our culture. Black folks are going to see what’s out there, take it and remix it for themselves and transform it into something else.”

headline: How to Prepare for a Lost, Stolen or Broken Smartphone
abstract: You may never have to deal with a missing device, but planning ahead with a few simple steps can make it easier if disaster strikes.
lead_paragraph: The average smartphone contains so much of one’s personal life — photos, list of contacts, calendar, email, digital wallet — that the loss of that handy slab of glass and metal can be highly disruptive and disorienting. You may never have to face this situation, but you would be wise to plan for it, especially if you have children with their own phones.

headline: In Rural Ukraine, Medicine and Hope Roll In on a Truck
abstract: A mobile clinic is trying to restore medical services to villages once occupied by Russian forces as fighting rages nearby. “They’ll never beat our people,” a specialist with the team said.
lead_paragraph: Young mothers gather with baby carriages in the morning chill and exchange village gossip while waiting to visit a health clinic on a truck. The vehicle’s arrival is a big event.

headline: The Police Unit That Was Supposed to Keep Memphis Safe
abstract: A Times investigation into the team of officers accused of killing Tyre Nichols reveals the challenges of preventing policing brutality.
lead_paragraph: This episode contains descriptions of violence.

headline: State of Uncertainty
abstract: What Biden said, and didn’t, in his State of the Union speech.
lead_paragraph: President Biden used his State of the Union speech to portray the U.S. as a country in recovery, and he is right that there has been a lot of good news lately.

headline: Uber Reports Record Revenue as It Defies the Economic Downturn
abstract: The company, which was hit hard in the early stages of the pandemic, saw revenue jump 49 percent from the same period a year ago.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber indicated on Wednesday that it had staved off the downturn that hit many technology companies while posting what Dara Khosrowshahi, Uber’s chief executive, called the company’s “strongest quarter ever.”

headline: The Lethal Beauty of the Gloriosa Lily
abstract: Regal and otherworldly, it has enchanted florists with its flamelike form and incendiary colors. But the bloom is every bit as dangerous as it looks.
lead_paragraph: IN THE REALM of flowers, there are the known quantities: staid white lilies for funerals; red roses for traditional expressions of romantic love; fusty carnations for prom boutonnieres. But there are also those more complex blossoms whose symbolism and aesthetic character are altogether less familiar, and it’s to this latter group that the gloriosa lily belongs. At once delicate and flamboyant, beautiful but somewhat creepy, the gloriosa lily, a.k.a. Gloriosa superba — which is not a true lily at all but a species of the autumn crocus family Colchicaceae — adds a showy, if vaguely menacing, glamour to floral arrangements and gardens. Bright and dramatic, the blooms are what Gary Page, a partner in the New York Flower Group, a wholesale flower purveyor (of which his longstanding namesake company is now a division), calls “visually stimulating,” and have accordingly found favor with avant-garde floral designers catering to our moment’s taste for wild, imaginative assemblages.

headline: The Times Reports 11% Increase in Revenue as Digital Subscriptions Climb
abstract: The company said it added more than a million digital subscribers in 2022, bringing its total number of paying subscribers to 9.6 million.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company said on Wednesday that it gained more than one million digital-only subscribers last year, helping to lift revenue from the year before despite headwinds facing the media industry.

headline: Biden Makes His Business Case in the State of the Union
abstract: The president took credit for strong job growth and his legislative agenda that’s boosted investment in infrastructure and clean energy projects.
lead_paragraph: President Biden delivered a State of the Union address to Congress on Tuesday night that was filled with dramatic moments, meant in part to jump start his 2024 re-election campaign.

headline: California County Agrees to Pay $4.5 Million in Death of Man Stunned With Taser
abstract: The man, Chinedu V. Okobi, 36, died in 2018 after a deputy repeatedly used a Taser on him in a struggle that began when law enforcement officers saw him jaywalking in Millbrae, Calif.
lead_paragraph: San Mateo County, Calif., has agreed to pay $4.5 million to the family of a Black man who died in 2018 after a sheriff’s deputy repeatedly used a Taser on him during a struggle that began when law enforcement officers saw the man jaywalking on a busy street, the county confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: This Winter, More Than Ever, We’re Skiing Straight to Hell
abstract: Will I deny my child the pleasure of a winter sport in what could be its final seasons?
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When I saw news photos of the bare slopes of the Alps’ storied ski resorts a few weeks ago, I felt relief. The green and brown mountains of Garmisch-Partenkirchen in Bavaria, where my family has skied at the Garmisch Classic ski resort for years, were a dismal sight, yes. But the snowless scene also warmed my heart: I had an excuse not to take my 12-year-old son downhill skiing during his school break.

headline: Understanding the Massacre in Goshen
abstract: A conversation about the gun violence that killed a family, including a 10-month-old baby, in a small San Joaquin Valley town last month.
lead_paragraph: Gang violence is common across the Central Valley. Three of its counties had the highest homicide rates in California in 2021, with Tulare County ranked third.

headline: How Can I Convince My Wife That She Cheated Her Siblings?
abstract: While dividing up her late mother’s belongings, a woman claimed an extremely valuable artwork for herself, purposely hiding its worth from her fellow heirs.
lead_paragraph: After my wife’s mother died, we learned she had divided the value of her home and accounts equally among her three children. She made a few specific bequests of larger items. But for most of her stuff, she directed the kids to take turns choosing things for themselves. Unbeknown to any of them (including my mother-in-law, apparently), she owned an extremely valuable piece of art — probably worth more than all the specific bequests combined. My wife didn’t tell her siblings, though. She waited for her turn to choose an item, chose the picture and brought it home. I think this was terrible behavior, but my wife disagrees: She doesn’t believe she had any duty to educate her siblings about the value of anything. What do you think?

headline: A New Marvel Hero Battles Supervillains and Teen Angst
abstract: In the animated series “Marvel’s Moon Girl and Devil Dinosaur,” the superhero exploits are based in relatable teenage emotions and concerns.
lead_paragraph: “One girl can make a difference.”

headline: Rihanna: Since She’s Been Gone
abstract: On Sunday, one of pop’s most reliable hitmakers returns at the Super Bowl halftime show. During her hiatus from music her mystique — and the stakes for her return — have only grown.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Spring Fashion That Lights Up the Night
abstract: Mirrored paillettes, iridescent beads and eye-catching chain mail shine bright after dark.

headline: At the State of the Union, Republicans Give Biden the Gift of Heckling
abstract: A presidency that’s been short on galvanizing TV gets an infusion of energy from a feisty speech.
lead_paragraph: It’s a rare speech where you go onstage hoping to get booed.

headline: Simone Forti’s Experiments Transcribing Bodies in Motion
abstract: Best known for her work as a choreographer, the artist is the subject of a wide-ranging show at MOCA in Los Angeles — and a recipient of the Venice Biennale’s lifetime achievement award.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the mid-1970s, Simone Forti, already established as a dancer and choreographer, experimented with creating holograms — miniature images of her body that would spring into motion as you walked around them. The holograms offer one answer to a vexing question for museums interested in the ephemeral art of dance: how to collect or exhibit it.

headline: How ‘Some Like It Hot’ Tunes In to the Jazz Age
abstract: From the set design to the wig styles, the Broadway musical creates a richly detailed vision of the 1920s and ’30s. Its creators share their inspirations.
lead_paragraph: During the 1920s and well into the next decade, there was an explosion of creativity in artistic expression and popular entertainment.

headline: Twitter Was Blocked in Turkey, Internet-Monitoring Group Says
abstract: The service was blocked in what appeared to be a coordinated way.
lead_paragraph: Twitter was blocked on several networks inside Turkey, according to NetBlocks, a group that tracks internet outages — taking out a key communication channel for coordinating relief efforts after Monday’s devastating earthquake.

headline: ‘Troubling’ Race Disparity Is Found in U.K. Prosecution Decisions
abstract: Black and biracial people in England and Wales are significantly more likely to be prosecuted than white people who have been arrested on comparable charges, according to a major study.
lead_paragraph: Black people and those from other minority groups are significantly more likely to be prosecuted in England and Wales than white people who have been arrested on comparable charges, according to a major new study that the Crown Prosecution Service called “troubling.”

headline: What’s a Japanese Mobster to Do in Retirement? Join a Softball Team.
abstract: The members of the Ryuyukai have done nearly 100 years of hard time. Now they’re just looking to stay out of trouble.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Volodymyr Zelensky Meets King Charles III in a Sweatshirt
abstract: The Ukrainian president continues to weaponize his wardrobe.
lead_paragraph: In October 2020, just over a year after he was elected president of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky and his wife, Olena Zelenska, took an official trip to Britain that included a visit to Buckingham Palace to meet with Prince William and his wife Catherine, now Princess of Wales. At the time, the Ukrainian President, like the Prince, wore the uniform of a peace time leader: a dark suit and tie and black shoes polished to a pristine glow.

headline: John Cleese to Reboot ‘Fawlty Towers’
abstract: Mr. Cleese will write and act alongside his daughter Camilla Cleese in a revival of the renowned BBC comedy.
lead_paragraph: “Fawlty Towers,” the renowned 1970s British sitcom that starred John Cleese as a surly and snobbish hotel owner, will be rebooted with Mr. Cleese returning alongside his daughter Camilla Cleese, Castle Rock Entertainment announced on Tuesday.

headline: The Harrowing Personal Story France’s Prime Minister Rarely Tells
abstract: The daughter of an Auschwitz survivor, Élisabeth Borne has avoided bringing her past into politics, even when it might be appropriate.
lead_paragraph: France’s prime minister, Élisabeth Borne, sat on a recent, rainy evening in a dim room at a Red Cross shelter, listening to young women recount their personal stories of poverty, fractured homes and schooling struggles.

headline: Chocolate and Fire for Valentine’s Day
abstract: Three new desserts from Yossy Arefi and a chance to flambé.
lead_paragraph: Next Tuesday is Valentine’s Day, which many love birds might celebrate with flowers, Champagne and, of course, chocolate galore.

headline: Orca Moms Pay a High Price to Feed Large Adult Sons
abstract: A maternal preference for sons in a group of killer whales that swim off the Pacific Northwest may contribute to its endangered status.
lead_paragraph: A fully grown male orca is one of the planet’s fiercest hunters. He’s a wily, streamlined torpedo who can weigh as much as 11 tons. No other animal preys on him. Yet in at least one population, these apex predators struggle to survive without their moms, who catch their food and even cut it up for them.

headline: Investigators say Putin likely approved the supply of the missile system that brought down Flight MH17.
abstract: A Dutch-led team made the assessment, but said it had suspended its investigation because of insufficient evidence and rules that prevent new prosecutions.
lead_paragraph: There are “strong indications” that President Vladimir V. Putin decided to supply the antiaircraft missile system that Russia-backed separatists used to shoot down a Malaysia Airlines passenger jet above eastern Ukraine in 2014, a Dutch-led international team found.

headline: World Championships and World Cups, Mikaela Shiffrin Keeps Making Her Mark
abstract: A silver medal in super-G gave Shiffrin her 12th career medal at the world Alpine skiing championships and made her the first woman in the modern era to accumulate that many.
lead_paragraph: It’s becoming difficult to keep track of all the records Mikaela Shiffrin is breaking.

headline: Hermès Wins MetaBirkins Lawsuit; Jurors Not Convinced NFTs Are Art
abstract: The verdict means First Amendment protections did not apply to a digital project blurring the line between art and business.
lead_paragraph: Perturbed when an artist made a digital version of its coveted Birkin handbag with a reproduction of a mature fetus inside it, the luxury fashion brand Hermès watched in shock as other iterations popped up online. A Birkin with mammoth tusks affixed to it. One sporting the Grinch’s shaggy green fur. Others stamped with van Gogh’s “Starry Night” or populated by smiley emojis.

headline: The Biggest Penguin That Ever Existed Was a ‘Monster Bird’
abstract: Fossils found in New Zealand highlight an era after the dinosaurs when giant flightless birds prowled the seas for prey.
lead_paragraph: New Zealand has been a haven for earthbound birds for eons. The absence of terrestrial predators allowed flightless parrots, kiwis and moas to thrive. Now researchers are adding two prehistoric penguins to this grounded aviary. One species is a beefy behemoth that waddled along the New Zealand coastline nearly 60 million years ago. At almost 350 pounds, it weighed as much as an adult gorilla and is the heaviest penguin known to science.

headline: Disinformation Researchers Raise Alarms About A.I. Chatbots
abstract: Researchers used ChatGPT to produce clean, convincing text that repeated conspiracy theories and misleading narratives.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Lost Letters by Mary, Queen of Scots, Uncovered by Amateur Code Breakers
abstract: The messages, written while she was imprisoned by her cousin Queen Elizabeth I, were mistakenly listed as Italian texts in France’s national library.
lead_paragraph: Deep in the archives of France’s national library, an assortment of coded letters listed as Italian texts lay untouched for more than 400 years. But when three code breakers — a German pianist, an Israeli computer scientist and a Japanese physicist — stumbled upon them, they discovered something remarkable.

headline: President Biden Is Not Backing Off His Big-Government Agenda
abstract: In his first appearance before a Republican House, the president renewed calls for large new economic programs and offered no concessions on federal spending.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There were no economic pivots in President Biden’s first State of the Union address to a Republican House. He did not pare back his push to raise taxes on high earners or to spend big on new government programs. He offered no olive branches to conservatives who have accused him of running the country into crisis with government borrowing.

headline: There’s a Ring Around This Dwarf Planet. It Shouldn’t Be There.
abstract: Quaoar, which orbits the sun in the distant Kuiper belt, is the latest small object shown to have a ring like the ones around Saturn.
lead_paragraph: A small icy world far beyond Neptune possesses a ring like the ones around Saturn. Perplexingly, the ring is at a distance where simple gravitational calculations suggest there should be none.

headline: Biden Aims to Win Back White Working-Class Voters Through Their Wallets
abstract: In his State of the Union address, the president signaled the opening of a yearslong push to persuade white working-class voters to return to the Democratic fold. Winning them over on cultural issues may be more difficult.
lead_paragraph: With his call for a “blue-collar blueprint to rebuild America,” President Biden on Tuesday night acknowledged rhetorically what Democrats have been preparing for two years: a fierce campaign to win back white working-class voters through the creation of hundreds of thousands of well-paid jobs that do not require a college degree.

headline: Grieving Turks and Syrians Abroad Rally to Help Quake Victims in Their Homelands
abstract: An outpouring of donations is flowing from around the world, as communities struggle to ease feelings of helplessness — and the agony of waiting for loved ones who have not called.
lead_paragraph: In Berlin, roads are blocked by boxes and people frantically unloading trucks of baby formula. In Melbourne, Australia, a halal-butcher shop hosts distraught expatriates, packing tents and sharing their grief. And in London, volunteers spend their mornings shuttling vans full of donations to the airport.

headline: The State of the Union Is … Feisty
abstract: Readers react to President Biden’s speech and the Republican heckling. Also: A national police commission; knitting and politics; the secret donor.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bing (Yes, Bing) Just Made Search Interesting Again
abstract: Google has stiff competition now, after Microsoft integrated powerful A.I. technology into its search engine.
lead_paragraph: Read the latest from Kevin Roose on his conversation with the chatbot built into Microsoft’s search engine.

headline: 4.9 Million Fabuloso Bottles Recalled for Bacteria Risk
abstract: Colgate-Palmolive, the manufacturer of the multipurpose cleaner, said recalled bottles had been made with “inadequate” amounts of a preservative meant to curb bacteria growth.
lead_paragraph: About 4.9 million bottles of the multipurpose cleaning product Fabuloso have been recalled because they may contain bacteria that can cause a serious infection in people with weakened immune systems and others with health risks, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said on Wednesday.

headline: China Sends Spy Balloons Over Military Sites Worldwide, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: The balloons have some advantages over the satellites that orbit the earth in regular patterns. They fly closer to earth and can evade radar.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American intelligence agencies have assessed that China’s spy balloon program is part of a global surveillance effort that is designed to collect information on the military capabilities of countries around the world, according to three American officials.

headline: In L.A., Dudamel’s Influence Extends Beyond the Concert Hall
abstract: The news that Gustavo Dudamel is leaving the Los Angeles Philharmonic for New York was a blow to a city where he has been much more than a conductor.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For more than 13 years, Gustavo Dudamel has been the public face of an orchestra that became the envy of the nation and the pride of this city.

headline: Why New York City Is Buying Bus Tickets for Migrants Headed to Canada
abstract: Some of the migrants who were bused to New York City are now seeking asylum in Canada, where they hope to have an easier time getting work permits and health insurance.
lead_paragraph: New York officials, who once condemned Texas leaders for busing migrants from the southern border, calling the treatment inhumane, are buying bus tickets for newcomers who want to go north and seek asylum in Canada.

headline: The Paradox of Prosecuting Domestic Terrorism
abstract: The U.S. prosecuted Brian Lemley for threats, not violence. Is that what it takes to fight extremism?
lead_paragraph: The U.S. prosecuted Brian Lemley for threats, not violence. Is that what it takes to fight extremism?

headline: ‘Lucy’ Review: There’s Something About the Babysitter
abstract: A workplace comedy set at home, this cleverly detailed production explores child care as both labor and primal instinct.
lead_paragraph: Hiring a babysitter is a high-stakes leap of faith. How well can you really know someone before trusting them with your kids? And what’s going to happen when you’re not at home? Maybe she won’t quite be Mary Poppins, but let’s hope the glint in her eye doesn’t remind you of the unassuming villain in a psychological thriller.

headline: 2 Children Killed After Bus Driver Crashes Into Day Care Near Montreal
abstract: The police in Laval, Quebec, said that six other children were injured and that the driver had been charged with first-degree murder.
lead_paragraph: A bus driver has been charged with first-degree murder after he plowed a large bus into a day care center outside Montreal, killing two children on Wednesday morning, the police said.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? Australian Rock and More
abstract: I'm a senior video editor and reporter. Here are five things I've been enjoying lately.
lead_paragraph: I'm a senior video editor and reporter. Here are five things I've been enjoying lately.

headline: Review: A Hip-Hop Take on Shakespeare’s Star-Crossed Lovers
abstract: “Rome & Jewels,” revived at the Joyce Theater, established Rennie Harris as a gifted and canny choreographer of street styles for the concert stage.
lead_paragraph: Hip-hop is now established enough to get an all-star 50th-birthday celebration at the Grammys. Hip-hop concert dance isn’t quite that old, but it can look back a few decades, as with the revival of Rennie Harris’s “Rome & Jewels” at the Joyce Theater this week.

headline: What Can Hypnosis Do for Your Health?
abstract: This 200-year-old treatment can be effective for a variety of conditions, but it does take work.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Bob Orben, One-Man Gag Factory and Speechwriter, Dies at 95
abstract: He wrote tens of thousands of jokes in his career — told by, among others, Dick Gregory, Jack Paar, Red Skelton and, for a while, President Gerald R. Ford.
lead_paragraph: Bob Orben, who after writing jokes for Dick Gregory, Jack Paar, Red Skelton and others in the 1960s found a new avenue for his wit when he became a speechwriter for President Gerald R. Ford in 1974, died on Feb. 2 in Alexandria, Va. He was 95.

headline: A ‘$10 Quintillion’ Asteroid
abstract: NASA plans to explore Psyche, an asteroid made of iron, nickel and we don’t know what else.
lead_paragraph: Lindy Elkins-Tanton is leading a NASA mission to explore an asteroid rich with metals  supposedly worth $10 quintillion that’s orbiting the sun between Mars and Jupiter. The asteroid’s name is Psyche, after the Greek goddess of the soul.

headline: Greta Thunberg: ‘The World Is Getting More Grim by the Day’
abstract: Why the world’s most prominent climate activist remains disappointed with people in power.
lead_paragraph: There is genuinely no precedent in the modern history of geopolitics for the climate activist Greta Thunberg.

headline: When Athletes Go Hollywood
abstract: With Tom Brady appearing in the comedy “80 for Brady,” a look at other sports figures who have made their way to the big screen.
lead_paragraph: When is a famous athlete not a famous athlete? When they’re appearing as themselves in a Hollywood movie — then they’re a movie star. Or are they? Despite more than a century of sports legends appearing in films, very few have brought the stardust of their exploits on the field to the very different arena of the big screen. The latest to try is the football godhead Tom Brady.

headline: Many of Biden’s Goals on Police Reform Are Still Incomplete
abstract: President Biden said in his annual address to Congress that it was time to “finish the job” on police reform, even as many of his most ambitious goals are stalled.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One year after President Biden used the State of the Union address to celebrate billions in federal funds for police departments, the president struck a different tone this week after yet another person was killed at the hands of law enforcement.

headline: Marjorie Taylor Greene Shouts “Liar” at Biden During State of the Union
abstract: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, Republican of Georgia, called President Biden a ‘liar’ after he said that Republicans wanted to end entitlement programs like Social Security.
lead_paragraph: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, Republican of Georgia, called President Biden a ‘liar’ after he said that Republicans wanted to end entitlement programs like Social Security.

headline: Footage Shows Devastation in Turkey Following Earthquake
abstract: In the city of Kahramanmaras, many apartment buildings had entirely collapsed, leaving hundreds of families displaced.
lead_paragraph: In the city of Kahramanmaras, many apartment buildings had entirely collapsed, leaving hundreds of families displaced.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: Frustration Mounts in Turkey
abstract: Also, Volodymyr Zelensky visits Britain and LeBron James breaks a record.
lead_paragraph: During his first visit to the disaster zone, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey tried to reassure survivors of the devastating earthquake that the situation was under control. But as people wait for aid, their anger is mounting.
