headline: 11 Easy Salmon Recipes for the Most Demanding Days
abstract: The quick-cooking fish is the ideal weeknight dinner centerpiece.
lead_paragraph: Nutrient-rich salmon is beloved for a reason — in fact, many reasons. It’s easy to come by, it’s delicious and it can cook in the time it takes you to read this article. Its richness plays incredibly well with tangy sauces, sweet-and-salty glazes and spicy oils, so there’s no limit to flavor. Below are some of New York Times Cooking’s best salmon offerings.

headline: Greece Moves to Block Far-Right Party as Election Nears
abstract: A new law targets a party founded by an imprisoned former official of the neo-Nazi group Golden Dawn. But critics say its reach could be wider.
lead_paragraph: Greece’s government has moved to block from Parliament an extreme-right party seen as a successor to the neo-Nazi group Golden Dawn, which shot to prominence a decade ago but was effectively banned after being declared a criminal organization.

headline: What the Winter Storms in California Mean for Travel
abstract: Ski resorts and wineries may ultimately benefit, but in many areas, impassable stretches of highway and major wind and water damage will take weeks or months to repair.
lead_paragraph: The first months of California’s winter can be described in a word that’s eluded the state for several drought-parched years: wet. Thanks to a back-to-back stream of atmospheric rivers dousing the state in record rain and snow, residents have dealt with flooding, power outages, downed trees, evacuation warnings and more than 20 weather-related deaths. Among the places that have been hit hardest: Sacramento, which has experienced major flooding; parts of coastal Highway 1; and the Central Coast, in particular, Santa Cruz County, which is still recuperating from serious flooding and erosion.

headline: I Promised God It Was the Last Time
abstract: After years of suppressing her gay desires, an ultra-Orthodox Jewish woman reaches her breaking point.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in an ultra-Orthodox Hasidic community, Sara Glass was used to following strict rules — including what to wear, when to get married and whom to love. “I had strong feelings that I really should be with a woman and not with a man,” she told our host, Anna Martin. “But I wanted to do what God said was right.”

headline: Searching for Streaming Profit, Disney Cuts $5.5 Billion in Costs
abstract: In the company’s first earnings report since Bob Iger returned as C.E.O., it exceeded Wall Street’s expectations. But about 7,000 jobs are expected to be cut.
lead_paragraph: Robert A. Iger gave Disney’s corporate critics the equivalent of a punch in the mouth on Wednesday.

headline: The Oscars’ Andrea Riseborough Controversy, Thoroughly Explained
abstract: You’ve got questions about the surprise best-actress nominee, and our awards columnist has the answers (and a few more questions).
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Soul Told Black Musicians’ Stories. Its Archives Are Going Digital.
abstract: The newspaper, which started in 1966 with a focus on R&B, funk and disco, shut down in 1982. But one of its founders’ grandsons is devoted to finding it a new online audience.
lead_paragraph: The rock ’n’ roll bible Rolling Stone was founded in 1967. The renegade music magazine Creem started in 1969. But another publication predated them both: Soul.

headline: Ronald Blythe, Scribe of the English Countryside, Dies at 100
abstract: He was best known for his 1969 book “Akenfield,” but he was also beloved for his many essays and columns about rural life in his native Suffolk.
lead_paragraph: Ronald Blythe, an English writer who rarely ventured far from his birthplace in rural Suffolk, but who rose to international literary fame with his 1969 book “Akenfield: Portrait of an English Country Village,” an oral history of the quickly vanishing world he knew so well, died on Jan. 14 at his home near the village of Wormingford, about 75 miles northeast of London. He was 100.

headline: Biden’s Vision About How to Heal America
abstract: Standing up to China is about addressing domestic pathologies, not pulverizing a balloon.
lead_paragraph: Just a few days ago, the United States was in a national tizzy about a balloon.

headline: A Can’t-Miss Opportunity for LeBron James Fans, No Matter the Distance
abstract: Fans of James, the N.B.A.’s biggest star, came from all over the world to see his record-breaking performance Tuesday. “I’m not going to regret the money that was spent. I would have regretted missing it,” one said.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Joe Burwick, a 40-year-old accountant, was standing outside Crypto.com Arena several hours before Tuesday night’s Los Angeles Lakers game and wearing a LeBron James jersey. He made the impulsive decision just days before to fly from Buffalo to attend the game. His ticket cost $1,000.

headline: Man Pleads Guilty to Hate Crimes in El Paso Massacre That Killed 23
abstract: Patrick Crusius, 24, agreed to plead guilty to federal charges after prosecutors said they would not seek the death penalty. But he still faces a state trial in which he could be sentenced to death.
lead_paragraph: A Texas man who fatally shot 23 people and injured dozens more at a Walmart store in El Paso in 2019 pleaded guilty on Wednesday to federal hate crimes and weapons charges in connection with the deadliest anti-Latino attack in modern United States history.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Romney-Santos Confrontation Reflects a Broader Clash Within the G.O.P.
abstract: The run-in between the senator from Utah, an institutionalist who prizes decorum, and the newly elected, embattled congressman from New York encapsulated the tension inside the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitt Romney, Republican of Utah, was not expecting to see Representative George Santos, the embattled first-term Republican from New York, perched near the aisle of the House chamber at the State of the Union on Tuesday night, close enough to reach out for a presidential handshake.

headline: It’s Time to Answer Your Questions About Super Bowl LVII
abstract: When is the kickoff? What time will Rihanna perform? Who are the players to watch? Cheesesteak or barbecue? We have answers.
lead_paragraph: When is the kickoff? What time will Rihanna perform? Who are the players to watch? Cheesesteak or barbecue? We have answers.

headline: ‘Magic Mike’s Last Dance’ Review: Stripping Down to Bare Essentials
abstract: Channing Tatum returns as Florida’s favorite male exotic dancer, romancing a restless socialite played by Salma Hayek Pinault.
lead_paragraph: “What does a woman want?” Sigmund Freud famously confessed that he had spent most of his career flummoxed by that question. In the 21st century it seems that the director Steven Soderbergh, the screenwriter Reid Carolin and the heterodox psychoanalytic theorist Channing Tatum have come up with an answer that Freud would never have dreamed of: Magic Mike.

headline: Why the Odds Are Stacked Against a Promising New Covid Drug
abstract: A new drug quashes all coronavirus variants. But regulatory hurdles and a lack of funding make it unlikely to reach the U.S. market anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, America’s arsenal of Covid treatments has shrunk as new variants of the coronavirus have eroded the potency of drug after drug. Many patients are now left with a single option, Paxlovid. While highly effective, it poses problems for many people who need it because of dangerous interactions with other medications.

headline: Soccer Player Christian Atsu Remains Missing in Turkey Despite Earlier Reports, Team Officials Say
abstract: It was unclear whether Mr. Atsu, a Ghanaian national, was still trapped underneath the rubble in Hatay Province, Turkey, or whether he had been removed but could not be located in the region’s overwhelmed hospitals.
lead_paragraph: The whereabouts of Christian Atsu, a professional soccer player for the Turkish club Hatayspor, remained unknown on Wednesday, club officials said, despite their earlier statements that he had been rescued from the rubble of the earthquake that hit Turkey and Syria and was receiving medical treatment.

headline: Twitter Glitches Pile Up as Key Features Fail
abstract: Many users said they could not post tweets or message one another on Wednesday as the #TwitterDown hashtag began trending.
lead_paragraph: Twitter users around the world reported that they could no longer post messages or send messages to one another on Wednesday, the latest in a series of glitches at the social media service owned by Elon Musk.

headline: Five Takeaways From the House G.O.P. Hearing With Former Twitter Executives
abstract: The Oversight Committee called the session to scrutinize whether the social media platform has censored the right, but it yielded new revelations about the company’s permissive approach.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans on Wednesday summoned former Twitter executives to answer to accusations that the social media platform has tried to silence voices on the right, but the hourslong hearing yielded new revelations about how the company failed to limit hateful speech or material that could incite violence, sometimes altering its own rules to avoid doing so.

headline: Congress Is Investing in Alternatives to Police. Can They Work?
abstract: With both violent crime and police brutality on Americans’ minds, there is a hunger for alternative approaches to public safety.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.

headline: Zelensky Brings a Shopping List to Britain, With Fighter Planes at the Top
abstract: In a surprise visit that started a two-day blitz of Western allies, the Ukrainian president implored Britain to provide planes he said would represent “wings of freedom.’’
lead_paragraph: LONDON — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine pleaded with Britain on Wednesday to supply his country with fighter jets, making his dramatic appeal during a surprise visit to London that began a two-day diplomatic blitz of Ukraine’s Western allies.

headline: N.I.H. Leader Rebuts Covid Lab Leak Theory at House Hearing
abstract: Now in the majority, House Republicans are eager to scrutinize the Biden administration’s Covid policies and the origins of the virus, as a hearing on Wednesday demonstrated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The acting director of the National Institutes of Health pushed back on Wednesday against Republicans’ assertions that a lab leak stemming from taxpayer-funded research may have caused the coronavirus pandemic, telling lawmakers that viruses being studied at a laboratory in Wuhan, China, bore no resemblance to the one that set off the worst public health crisis in a century.

headline: What Does ‘Lots of Luck in Your Senior Year’ Actually Mean? An Investigation.
abstract: In the daily Rorschach test that is modern politics, everyone saw what they wanted in the Bidenism du jour.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During a State of the Union address full of Bidenese Dictionary classics like “folks” and “I need to be crystal clear,” one entry stood out.

headline: TV Viewership Declines for Biden’s State of the Union Speech
abstract: Fox News attracted the biggest audience of the night, while CNN’s viewership fell by half from a year ago.
lead_paragraph: President Biden delivered a feisty State of the Union address on Tuesday punctuated by several ad-libbed exchanges with Republican hecklers, an unusual dose of improv for an annual broadcast that usually runs strictly to script.

headline: Dead Men at the State of the Union
abstract: The State of the Union commemorated Tyre Nichols, and attendees recalled Henry Truman, an early victim of police violence.
lead_paragraph: There were dead men at the State of the Union.

headline: Millions Suffer Cold and Grief After Catastrophic Quake, Awaiting Help
abstract: With thousands dead and many more left homeless in Turkey and Syria, people struggling to unearth victims, bury the dead and provide for millions of survivors are pleading for more aid.
lead_paragraph: KAHRAMANMARAS, Turkey — The city’s soccer stadium is packed with tents to shelter families whose homes were destroyed in this week’s earthquakes. Outside, where people huddle in cars or around small fires to ward off the bitter cold, work crews struggle to extract the living and the dead from the ruins of apartment buildings that crumbled to the ground.

headline: Heckling of Biden Reflects a New, Coarser Normal for House G.O.P.
abstract: The repeated outbursts that interrupted the State of the Union address encapsulated the ethos of the new Republican majority, which styles itself after former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House floor has been no stranger to rowdy spectacle in 2023, but the eruptions of Republican vitriol against President Biden during his State of the Union address on Tuesday night underscored a new and notably coarse normal in Congress, where members of the G.O.P. majority tossed aside rules of decorum and turned the annual speech into a showcase for partisan hostility.

headline: South Carolina Dog Breeder Is Fatally Shot at Planned Sale of French Bulldog
abstract: The attackers also stole the puppy, the authorities said. French bulldogs have become among the most expensive dog breeds in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Lonnie A. Ray of Darlington County, S.C., had bred and sold dogs for a while, and he knew what safety precautions to take when arranging a sale, according to Daniel Simon, the sheriff of Lee County.

headline: Vigil Held for Slain Councilwoman as F.B.I. Joins Hunt for Her Killer
abstract: Hundreds of people gathered Wednesday in Sayreville, N.J., to remember Eunice K. Dwumfour, the first-ever Black person elected in the small borough.
lead_paragraph: SAYREVILLE, N.J. — In the week since a New Jersey councilwoman was shot to death in a car on the street outside her house, the police have interviewed friends and family members and enlisted the help of the State Police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

headline: What Is She in France?
abstract: Alex Rosen plays a shell game with us.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Lakers Agree to Trade Russell Westbrook in a Three-Team Deal
abstract: Westbrook, a nine-time All-Star, would head to Utah after not fitting smoothly with LeBron James and Anthony Davis. Minnesota’s D’Angelo Russell will return to the Lakers, who drafted him in 2015.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Lakers have agreed to trade guard Russell Westbrook to the Utah Jazz as part of a three-team deal, according to three people familiar with the trade who were not authorized to speak about it publicly.

headline: Quality Control, Atlanta Rap Powerhouse, Sells to Scooter Braun’s Hybe
abstract: The acquisition is the famed music manager’s first major move at Hybe America — a division of the South Korean firm — since he became its sole chief executive last month.
lead_paragraph: Quality Control Music, the Atlanta rap label that is one of the hottest hit machines in contemporary music, has been acquired by Hybe America, a company led by the executive and talent manager Scooter Braun, in one of the most closely watched deals in the music business.

headline: Reporter Arrested While Covering News Conference in Ohio
abstract: The reporter was arrested after officers said he was being too loud while the Ohio governor spoke about a train derailment in the state.
lead_paragraph: A reporter who was covering a news conference on the train derailment in Ohio that led to the release of toxic fumes was arrested following a live shot on Wednesday, after officers told him to be quiet while the governor spoke, according to the cable channel where he works, NewsNation.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A.I.’s Ease at Spinning Deception Raises Alarm
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Feb. 9, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Crafting a new false narrative can now be done at dramatic scale, and much more frequently — it’s like having A.I. agents contributing to disinformation.”

headline: Corrections: Feb. 9, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Feb. 9, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about the water rescue of a man who was later charged with stealing a boat misidentified the location of Mr. Labonte’s arrest in Oregon. It is Seaside, not Astoria, Ore.

headline: Kelce Brothers Will Share the N.F.L.’s Biggest Stage
abstract: Kansas City’s Travis Kelce has built a case as the best tight end ever, while his older brother Jason ranks as one of the league’s premier linemen. One of them will win their second Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the Super Bowl between Philadelphia and Kansas City.

headline: 2023 Super Bowl Prediction: Our Pick Against the Spread
abstract: Philadelphia and Kansas City, both conference’s top seeds, are so evenly matched that injuries to Patrick Mahomes and his receivers, up against the Eagles’ turnover-forcing defense, may provide an edge.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the Super Bowl between Philadelphia and Kansas City.

headline: In Syria, a Hospital ‘Filled With Tragedy’
abstract: A subterranean hospital known as the Cave and long the destination for war wounded is now filled with casualties of the earthquake — both alive and dead.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Nehad Abdulmajeed thought he had seen the worst human suffering of his career as a surgeon in Syria. In 2016, he survived the siege of Aleppo, which left thousands dead or crippled in the midst of a civil war.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: The latest from rescue efforts in Turkey and Syria.
lead_paragraph: Two days after a devastating magnitude 7.8 earthquake killed more than 12,000 people in Turkey and Syria, families huddled under improvised tents in the cold rain, resting on bits of furniture pulled from the wreckage. On the border between the two countries, the bodies of Syrian refugees who had died in the quakes were returned home — but humanitarian aid was not allowed to enter.

headline: Can Gustavo Dudamel’s Star Power Boost the Philharmonic?
abstract: Hiring the Venezuelan maestro was a coup for the orchestra, which has also benefited from improved acoustics in its concert hall.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll find out why a bartender in Brooklyn called the conductor who was just named music and artistic director of the New York Philharmonic a “monstruo” — Spanish for “monster” — and meant it as a compliment.

headline: These 12 Transgender Americans Would Love You to Mind Your Own Business
abstract: A group of transgender Americans describes what it’s like to be trans in America today.
lead_paragraph: A group of transgender Americans describes what it’s like to be trans in America today.

headline: Nets Agree to Trade Kevin Durant, Signaling End of Star-Studded Era
abstract: Days after trading Kyrie Irving, the Nets reached a deal to send Durant to the Phoenix Suns for a package of players and first-round draft picks.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Nets’ era of superstars appears to be over.

headline: Word of the Day: forfeit
abstract: This word has appeared in 76 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word forfeit has appeared in 76 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 16 in “Free Pizza and Easy Sleep: W.N.B.A. Upgrades Travel for Finals” by Kris Rhim:

headline: Chelsea Handler Thanks Republicans for Enlivening a Dull Night
abstract: After her antics during the State of the Union address, Handler wondered when Marjorie Taylor Greene would join the cast of “The Real Housewives of Atlanta.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Zelensky presses Ukraine’s case in Brussels, the third stop in a brief but packed European tour.
abstract: BRUSSELS — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine was meeting the European Union’s 27 heads of government in Brussels on Thursday, capping a two-day tour of key European allies as he framed Russia’s invasion as an existential struggle for the continent.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine was meeting the European Union’s 27 heads of government in Brussels on Thursday, capping a two-day tour of key European allies as he framed Russia’s invasion as an existential struggle for the continent.

headline: Rebuilding Quake-Stricken Cities in Turkey and Syria May Take Decade
abstract: While intact buildings might look fine, their structural integrity might have been damaged. Some of these buildings will have to be torn down. This process alone could take years.
lead_paragraph: With thousands of buildings having been turned to rubble or half-structures across dozens of cities in Turkey and Syria by Monday’s earthquake, officials say it will be years before the streetscapes in these stricken areas bear any resemblance to their old selves.

headline: LeBron James
abstract: Which athletes do you love to watch play?
lead_paragraph: A recent Times article reports on how LeBron James’s game has evolved over the past 20 years and made him a threat from all over the court — no matter how old he gets.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Pat Field’s New Hustle
abstract: The outfitter to Lily Collins and Sarah Jessica Parker can sell you a tutu or a pink merkin. In a new memoir she spills the tea.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Field likes looking back on a lifetime in fashion as a series of snapshots. In the late 1970s the rocker Patti Smith visited Ms. Field’s shop on Eighth Street in Manhattan, a downtown mecca for club kids and outliers of varying stripes. “Her hair was disheveled, and her clothes were all wrinkled,” Ms. Field recalled, “but she had on a full-length olive green mink, looking like royalty who’d fallen on hard times”

headline: That’s Tory Burch?
abstract: Over the last few seasons a new energy has emerged at the preppy American label. Fashion insiders are taking note.
lead_paragraph: You’ll have to forgive the pair of whispering fashion writers in the second row of the Tory Burch runway show in September, or the three writers clustered at an industry party two months later, talking about the best shows of New York Fashion Week. They’re just a little confused.

headline: He Set Off Across Australia on a Toy Scooter. Then Australia Got on Board.
abstract: An improbable journey by a Japanese visitor chronicling his adventures on social media has captured the country’s imagination.
lead_paragraph: At a gas station near Bethungra, three people squabbled over who would buy him lunch. At a train station in Junee, a bearded man offered him shelter. And in small towns along Australia’s back roads, encounters with strangers have led to offers of hot showers and warm beds; beer and burgers; and heartfelt, even tearful, conversations, conducted mostly via Google Translate.

headline: Lesson Plan: The Science of Awe
abstract: New research suggests that awe is beneficial for our physical and mental well-being. In this lesson students will learn how to cultivate more of it.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “How a Bit of Awe Can Improve Your Health” by Hope Reese

headline: North Korea Urges ‘Preparedness for War’ and Displays New Missile
abstract: Analysts said the new weapon was probably a solid-fuel ICBM, which the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un, has wanted to add to his country’s growing nuclear arsenal.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — North Korea has unveiled what analysts said was a new, solid-fuel intercontinental ballistic missile during a nighttime military parade in Pyongyang on Wednesday, the latest example of the country’s effort to fill its arsenal with increasingly advanced nuclear technology.

headline: 36 Hours in New Orleans
abstract: Soak up Mardi Gras season while dive-bar hopping, dancing to brass bands and exploring history in the French Quarter.
lead_paragraph: Soak up Mardi Gras season while dive-bar hopping, dancing to brass bands and exploring history in the French Quarter.

headline: The Magic of Your First Car
abstract: For these young people in Los Angeles, a car is a portal to possibilities, a means to escape monotony and a gathering space where they can let it all go.
lead_paragraph: For these young people in Los Angeles, a car is a portal to possibilities, a means to escape monotony and a gathering space where they can let it all go.

headline: They Didn’t Need Fancy Amenities or a Garden, but Closets Would Be Nice. Which Brooklyn Condo Did They Choose?
abstract: After years of living in an apartment with no closets, a couple decided it was time to move when the rent rose to $2,800 a month. Here’s what they found.
lead_paragraph: After years of living in an apartment with no closets, a couple decided it was time to move when the rent rose to $2,800 a month. Here’s what they found.

headline: Newly Published, From Hip Hop Style to Psychic Weapons
abstract: A selection of books published this week.
lead_paragraph: MI SANGRE, by Roj Rodriguez. (Hatje Cantz, $62.) An Austin-based photographer depicts everyday aspects of Mexican life and culture, from charros and escaramuzas to Lotería iconography, as well as how they are reimagined by Mexican Americans on the other side of the border.

headline: Your Height — and Your Children’s Height — Shouldn’t Matter
abstract: It’s time to end the tyranny of tallness.
lead_paragraph: Would you be a few inches taller if you could? The answer may depend on your gender and how much you’ve dreamed of being a professional athlete. But few people would say they want to be shorter — and Mara Altman wants to know why.

headline: Jojo Moyes’s Grandmother Knew a Bookworm When She Saw One
abstract: “It wasn’t a compliment,” says the writer, whose latest novel is “Someone Else’s Shoes.” “My weekly visits to her were usually spent with my nose buried between the pages.”
lead_paragraph: “Shrines of Gaiety,” by Kate Atkinson, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie’s “We Should All Be Feminists,” “The Faber Book of Reportage,” edited by John Carey, and around 30 copies of The New Yorker.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Bird-Watching Etiquette
abstract: A couple disagrees on getting hushed during hobby time.
lead_paragraph: Alex writes: My fiancée, Edie, is a bird-watcher. Often when we’re walking, she’ll stop and demand silence to use her birding app, which identifies birds by sound. This interrupts our chats, and the app records me saying dumb things. Please order Edie to stop.

headline: What Liberals Can Learn From Ron DeSantis
abstract: Let’s not make the same mistake again.
lead_paragraph: Is there anything liberals can do about Ron DeSantis other than quietly seethe, loudly condemn him every time he makes headlines and hope that his political flaws — his distaste for glad-handing, his less-than-inspiring public speaking style, his conspicuous unlikability — will take him down before he gets anywhere close to the presidency? It would be tempting to write off DeSantis, the bombastic Republican governor of Florida, as another unelectable right-wing lunatic unfit for national office.

headline: How Do You Serve a Friend in Despair?
abstract: I learned hard lessons when my oldest friend, Pete, plunged into depression.
lead_paragraph: My friendship with Peter Marks was created around play. Starting at age 11, we played basketball, softball, capture the flag, rugby. We teased each other, pulled pranks, made fun of each other’s dance moves and pretty much everything else. We could turn eating a burger into a form of play, with elaborate smacking of lips and operatic exclamations about the excellence of the cheese. We kept it up for five decades.

headline: A Gorgeous, Dazzling Novel and a Mouthpiece for Human Darkness
abstract: “Our Share of Night,” by Mariana Enriquez, is a bewitching brew of mystery, myth, wealthy occultists and mediums who can summon “the Darkness.”
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, the artist Salvador Dalí was commissioned to create a tarot deck for the James Bond film “Live and Let Die.” The deal fell through, but Dalí continued to work on the cards, casting himself as the Magician and his wife, Gala, as the Empress. Inspired by the raw, dreamlike language of Delacroix, Duchamp and Surrealism, Dalí married the hallucinatory with the concrete, the esoteric with the commonplace and the disturbing with the beautiful to create images that feel both ethereal and visceral.

headline: Poem: Lost in America
abstract: A poem that shakes us awake, enacting and preserving the fugitive possibilities of “healing from the law.”
lead_paragraph: “Lost in America” is a poem of powerful juxtapositions. It has the appearance of prose, yet through anaphoric repetition, it creates a rhythmic experience closer to sacred and liturgical poetry. Its litany-like structure invites participation. Readers might find themselves absorbed into the poem’s pattern of thought, filling in lines or naming the repeating atrocities, banalities and insults of American life. Then, once the pattern has been set and law laid down, the poem turns away, breaks its own rules, evades expectations. No more hypnotic spell, no more filling in the blanks. The poem shakes us awake and demonstrates another, more liberatory way of getting lost, enacting and preserving the fugitive possibilities of “healing from the law.” Among becomes against. Selected by Anne Boyer

headline: What I Know About Married Bliss I Learned From My Husband’s Twin
abstract: Togetherness didn’t come naturally to me. But it can be learned.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up, my family never had much patience for “we liked it” people, those couples who use the royal “we” as though their relationship were its own fief. For instance, the husband who, when asked, “What did you think of the show?” responds, “Oh, we liked it.” The rule was that when one of these couples came to dinner, we had to contain ourselves until they were on the front walk — then my siblings and I would start in.

headline: Ahead of the Super Bowl, Short-Term Rentals Fumble in Phoenix
abstract: Homeowners and investors were banking on a big payday, but an oversaturated vacation rental market and nearly full hotels have dampened those prospects.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the Super Bowl between Philadelphia and Kansas City.

headline: The Best Cities for Minimalists
abstract: Few people can toss everything and live off the land, but a new study highlights the cities where principles of simple living are more easily practiced.
lead_paragraph: Minimalism has become a popular catchphrase in recent years. Call it that or “simple living” — the idea is that a simpler life is a happier one.

headline: She Helped Unlock the Science of the Covid Vaccine
abstract: Kizzmekia Corbett helped lead a team of scientists contributing to one of the most stunning achievements in the history of immunizations: a highly effective, easily manufactured vaccine against Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: “Transforming Spaces” is a series about women driving change in sometimes unexpected places.

headline: All Hail the ‘God of Sod,’ Groundskeeper for All 57 Super Bowls
abstract: On Sunday, George Toma’s perfectionism will be on display for hundreds of millions of people who will have no idea who he is or how he suffers for his work.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the Super Bowl between Philadelphia and Kansas City.

headline: What Is a Pickleball Dress?
abstract: As more people pick up the sport, fashion designers and apparel brands are looking to cash in on clothing them.
lead_paragraph: Like many Americans, the fashion designer Norma Kamali has often found herself in the company of people who, as she put it, are “obsessed with pickleball and do nothing but talk about pickleball.” Ms. Kamali, 77, said that some players have even tried to recruit her, so to speak. “They’ll be like, ‘Oh, you’re a designer, you should design a pickleball dress!’”

headline: Novels Rooted in History and a Sense of Place
abstract: Three new books whisk readers to days of yore in Italy, Scandinavia and Palestine.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes a novel’s setting looms so large it becomes a crucial element of the plot. That’s certainly true of the dangerous streets of World War II Rome, which Joseph O’Connor explores in his historical thriller MY FATHER’S HOUSE (Europa, 440 pp., $27), and even more so of the “neutral, independent country within Rome” known as Vatican City, where an Irish priest has organized an escape line for refugees, diplomats and Allied soldiers sought by the German forces that control northern Italy.

headline: Biden Finds a Political Foil as He Warns of Social Security and Medicare Cuts
abstract: President Biden used his visit to the University of Tampa to talk about what he says are Republican proposals to cut entitlements.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — President Biden traveled to Florida on Thursday afternoon with a political gift he had not been expecting before Tuesday night’s State of the Union speech.

headline: This Is What Happened When the Authorities Put Trump Under a Microscope
abstract: Read together, the three major investigations of his presidency tell a story.
lead_paragraph: In retrospect, the Mueller report was a cry for help.

headline: Sanctions Against Russia Ignore the Economic Challenges Facing Ukraine
abstract: Sanctions are a diversion from the economic struggle that truly matters in this conflict.
lead_paragraph: ​​In December 2021, President Biden warned President Vladimir Putin of Russia that any incursion into Ukrainian territory would entail “economic consequences like none he has ever seen.” America and its European allies followed through on this threat with the largest scale economic sanctions effort in recent history.

headline: Steve Bannon’s Podcast Is Top Misinformation Spreader, Study Says
abstract: A large podcast study found that Mr. Bannon’s “War Room” had more falsehoods and unsubstantiated claims than other political talk shows.
lead_paragraph: When Stephen K. Bannon, the White House strategist turned podcaster, was explaining the latest Covid-19 developments in 2021, he passed the microphone to a special guest: Clay Clark, an evangelist and anti-vaccine activist.

headline: When Having a Baby and Losing Your Job Collide
abstract: At tech companies that spent recent years expanding paid parental leave, parents have felt the whiplash of mass layoffs in an especially visceral way.
lead_paragraph: Alex Gable spent recent weeks in the bleary-eyed haze of new parenthood. His son was born in November and Mr. Gable powered down his laptop, deleted Slack from his phone and focused on caring for his wife while making the most of the four precious hours a day that their baby was awake — there was tummy time and time spent ogling little drawings of snowflakes.

headline: Abortion Rights Supporters See Biden Address as Missed Opportunity
abstract: While praising the administration’s actions so far, activists say the State of the Union speech could have done more to address what they view as a national health crisis.
lead_paragraph: During the midterm campaigns, Democrats spent months focused on the demise of federal abortion rights and the danger they said it posed to all Americans.

headline: U.S. Aims to Curtail Technology Investment in China
abstract: The Biden administration is preparing new rules that would restrict U.S. dollars from flowing to China.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Growing concerns about China’s military and economic ambitions have lawmakers and the White House weighing yet another effort to restrict Beijing’s access to advanced technologies that could be used in war.

headline: What Is Our Responsibility to Lab Animals?
abstract: Standard ethical guidelines encourage minimizing the use of, and harm to, animals in research. Is that enough?
lead_paragraph: Scientists use animals to learn more about diseases, develop drugs and test product safety. For example, Covid-19 vaccines were tested on mice and monkeys and developed based on decades of animal-based work on mRNA vaccine technology. The results saved an estimated 20 million lives.

headline: Do I Need to Avoid Dark Chocolate Now?
abstract: A recent report found high concentrations of cadmium and lead in dark chocolate. There’s no reason to panic, experts say, but it’s worth a closer look.
lead_paragraph: Q: There were a number of news articles about cadmium and lead in dark chocolate recently, and it made me incredibly anxious as someone who eats very dark chocolate every day — including during my pregnancy and breastfeeding! What would experts say about how much I should worry?

headline: Boring Book Events? Not for Grady Hendrix.
abstract: The author of “How to Sell a Haunted House” learned the hard way that standing at the front of a mostly empty bookstore is no fun.
lead_paragraph: Not long after Grady Hendrix’s first novel, “Horrorstör,” came out in 2014, he traveled from Manhattan to a “really lovely” bookstore in Pennsylvania, prepared to chat with readers about his tale of a haunted furniture store based on Ikea.

headline: Can China Reverse Its Population Decline? Just Ask Sweden.
abstract: Wealthy countries have been trying to boost their birthrates for decades. The results have been pretty similar.
lead_paragraph: China’s population has begun to decline, a demographic turning point for the country that has global implications. Experts had long anticipated this moment, but it arrived in 2022 several years earlier than expected, prompting hand-wringing among economists over the long-term impacts given the country’s immense economic heft and its role as the world’s manufacturer.

headline: They Were the Victim of a Bigoted Assault, but They’re the One on Trial
abstract: In Isabel Waidner’s novel “Sterling Karat Gold,” a violent attack on a nonbinary immigrant leads to a surreal, Kafkaesque tribunal.
lead_paragraph: Isabel Waidner’s third novel, “Sterling Karat Gold,” opens with Sterling Beckenbauer, a 30-something nonbinary immigrant to England, being “recruited into a bullfight without their consent” on the streets of Camden Town. Sterling survives this bigoted attack, which their assailants attempt to pass off as a sporting event, but an accusation of assault by one of the “matadors” brings Sterling to the attention of the English justice system. Soon Sterling is arrested, imprisoned and put on trial for a growing list of trumped-up “crimes.”

headline: The Art World Refashions the Cowboy
abstract: In the show “Cowboy,” a collaboration between Antwaun Sargent and Helmut Lang, artists tackle the fascination with the American West.
lead_paragraph: “I’d always wanted a pair of cowboy boots, they’re such an American staple,” Antwaun Sargent said in a phone interview.

headline: House Tour | Christian Louboutin
abstract: The designer invites T into his 350-acre vacation compound in Melides, Portugal, which includes a color-shifting party tower.
lead_paragraph: The designer invites T into his 350-acre vacation compound in Melides, Portugal, which includes a color-shifting party tower.

headline: Hogwarts Legacy Can’t Cast Aside Debate Over J.K. Rowling
abstract: The video game is the latest battleground over the “Harry Potter” author’s comments on transgender issues, with fans and gamers divided over whether they should play it at all.
lead_paragraph: The developer behind a highly anticipated video game set in the “Harry Potter” universe, but a century before the familiar story, was always going to have to confront the expectations of a zealous fandom.

headline: One State’s Effort to Keep Some Police Encounters From Turning Deadly
abstract: A program in New Jersey that pairs police officers with certified mental health screeners is expanding into 10 of the state's 21 counties, with the aim of de-escalating conflicts before they turn violent.
lead_paragraph: ROSELLE PARK, N.J. — The shift was subtle but meaningful.

headline: Inside Christian Louboutin’s Portuguese Beach Compound
abstract: The designer gives T a tour of his colorful vacation home on a secluded stretch of Atlantic coastline.
lead_paragraph: The French shoe designer Christian Louboutin, 58, has always had a flair for the dramatic. Even the act of sitting down to lunch at his home in Melides, Portugal, a quiet coastal town some 80 miles south of Lisbon, requires visitors to engage in a performance of sorts. Inset into the concrete top of his outdoor dining table are giant ceramic tarot cards arranged like place settings; guests are invited to pick the card with which they identify. “I am often the Sun or the Hermit,” Louboutin says. The Empress and the Lovers are popular choices. “But no one ever wants to be the Hanged Man,” he says with a sigh.

headline: Free Speech vs. Disinformation Comes to a Head
abstract: The outcome of a case in federal court could help decide whether the First Amendment is a barrier to virtually any government efforts to stifle disinformation.
lead_paragraph: In July 2021, as Covid-19 cases began to surge again, the surgeon general warned that misinformation had led to “avoidable illnesses and death” and urged the nation’s social media giants to do more to fight the sources of it.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom in Pound Ridge, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Norwalk, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom, four-bath, 3,114-square-foot, 1860 home with original doors, wide plank floors and wood-beamed ceilings; a living room with a double-sided fireplace; a restored kitchen with a farm sink, a Wolf stove and a pass-through; a spacious family room with a stone fireplace and deck access; a first-floor bedroom with pond views; a primary bedroom with an alcove; a fourth bedroom converted to a dressing room with built-ins; a stone patio with an enclosed porch; and a yard with an in-ground pool, wishing well, gazebo, pond and a three-car garage; on 4.24 acres. Felice Wyloge, Julia B. Fee Sotheby’s International Realty, 914-419-2104; sothebysrealty.com

headline: Oh Much More Than Bother: This Winnie the Pooh Is Terrifying
abstract: When the gentle bear fell into the public domain, a horror director pounced. Glimpses of the low-budget film have enthralled and enraged fans.
lead_paragraph: Winnie the Pooh, Piglet, Christopher Robin and other denizens of the Hundred Acre Wood will be back on the big screen this month. Just don’t expect delightful animation, whimsical songs or heartwarming themes of young innocence and imagination. The new movie is spectacularly unsuitable for children: It’s a gore-splattered, live-action sequel out of a nightmare, featuring a terrifying pair of psychopaths who commit gruesome murders.

headline: The Color-Changing Party Tower of Christian Louboutin’s Dreams
abstract: At his vacation compound on the Portuguese coast, the designer has amassed a veritable village of imaginative buildings.
lead_paragraph: HEAD SOUTH FOR 80 miles from Lisbon to the village of Melides, on the Alentejo coast, take the dirt road that borders the lagoon and leads to the Atlantic and, after a few minutes of bumpy driving, a 28-foot-tall tower emerges from a thicket of parasol pines. At first glance, it resembles a spaceship: a wide concrete cylinder with a round hole in its roof. But to its owner, the structure represents something much more whimsical. “I call it La Folie,” says the 58-year-old French shoe designer Christian Louboutin, “because it’s just for fun.”

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s properties are on the Upper East Side, in Hell’s Kitchen and Windsor Terrace.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom, two-bath, 1,000-square-foot apartment with built-in shelves and a closet in the foyer; a step-down living room with a fireplace and built-in bookcases; a windowed kitchen with a breakfast bar, dishwasher and a pass-through; a primary bedroom with two closets, including a walk-in, and a windowed en suite full bathroom; a second bedroom or home office with a Murphy bed and a windowed en suite bath with a shower stall; leaded casement windows; hardwood floors; and central air-conditioning; on the ninth floor of a 10-story prewar doorman building with a live-in superintendent, a storage room, bike room and laundry room. Sabrina Saltiel, Douglas Elliman, 212-350-2205; douglaselliman.com

headline: ‘She Won’t Be Manageable’ They Said. Now She’s in Charge.
abstract: Her father doubted her much of her career. Les Moonves launched a bid at CBS to overrule her. That was before sexual misconduct allegations came to light. Now Shari Redstone controls the media empire.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, May 13, 2018, Leslie Moonves, the chairman and chief executive of CBS, faced a difficult decision, perhaps the most agonizing of his long and celebrated media career: whether to pull the trigger on a coup against the Redstone family, which controlled CBS.

headline: How Educators Secretly Remove Students With Disabilities From School
abstract: Known as informal removals, the tactics are “off-the-book” suspensions often in violation of federal civil rights protections for those with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: ROSEBURG, Ore. — Jessica LaVigne was nervous but hopeful on a recent afternoon that the team managing her son’s special education plan at Roseburg High School would tell her something she had dreamed of for more than a decade: He would be able to attend a full day of school for the first time since second grade.

headline: Freed Former C.I.A. Prisoner Has Big Dreams for a New Life in Belize
abstract: Majid Khan, a “high-value detainee” at Guantánamo Bay, was released last week after two decades of social isolation.
lead_paragraph: BELIZE CITY — On his first day of freedom, the former Guantánamo Bay prisoner Majid Khan prayed without anyone watching him for the first time in two decades.

headline: Credit Suisse Reports Huge Loss as It Seeks to Revive Fortunes
abstract: The struggling Swiss bank recorded its biggest annual loss since the 2008 financial crisis and warned of another “substantial” loss in 2023.
lead_paragraph: Credit Suisse on Thursday reported its biggest loss since the 2008 financial crisis, and warned of another “substantial” loss this year, as the beleaguered Swiss bank struggles to revive itself by refocusing on fewer business lines.

headline: Life on the Beat for Ukraine’s Cops: The Drunk, the Disorderly and Drones
abstract: In cities dealing with bombardment and blackouts, the Patrol Police have taken a lead in trying to retain a sense of security for a traumatized public.
lead_paragraph: In another time, in another place, the call to the police in Kyiv might have been dismissed as a crank. A resident living along the river had spotted a suspicious red light in the distance and was worried.

headline: In Its Push for an Intelligence Edge, China’s Military Turned to Balloons
abstract: Chinese military scientists have been looking for ways to make them more durable, harder to detect and even to serve as platforms that fire advanced weapons.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Long before an unmanned Chinese airship floating over the United States grabbed the world’s attention, Taiwan may have glimpsed Beijing’s ambitions to turn balloons — seemingly so old-fashioned and ponderous — into elusive tools of 21st-century military power.

headline: The Most Empty Downtown in America
abstract: San Francisco has been held up as an economic success story, but the heart of the city is yet to recover from the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: For the past decade, San Francisco has worked hard to turn its downtown into a vibrant hub, providing a model that other cities in the United States looked to emulate.

headline: In ‘You’ Season 4, Joe Goldberg Is No Longer in Control
abstract: The Netflix thriller’s latest episodes have its antihero, played by Penn Badgley, on the back foot as he navigates the world of London’s ultrarich.
lead_paragraph: On a sound stage on the outskirts of London, Joe Goldberg, played by Penn Badgley, wound his way through a private club, deep in thought.

headline: A Fight Against Sludge
abstract: Why the Biden administration is trying to crack down on those sneaky fees charged by hotels, rental cars, internet providers and more.
lead_paragraph: Sneaky fees have become a big part of America’s consumer economy.

headline: ‘The Outwaters’ Review: Massacre in the Mojave
abstract: Stunning sound design, creative mood-setting and a fearless finale elevate this found-footage horror film about an ill-fated camping trip.
lead_paragraph: The found-footage genre can be catnip to young filmmakers, embracing as it does a low-budget aesthetic and the kind of incoherent crashing-about that even the most unseasoned actors can manage. There’s nothing green, though, about Robbie Banfitch, the director (as well as writer, editor, cinematographer and sound designer) of “The Outwaters,” a movie that lavishes as much attention on its setup as its payoff.

headline: ‘The Civil Dead’ Review: Spirit in Disguise
abstract: In this gentle ghost story, an aimless photographer meets an old friend with an unusual secret.
lead_paragraph: Sweet and shaggy and kind of sad, Clay Tatum’s “The Civil Dead” is a low-key buddy comedy in which only one of the buddies is alive. Even so, this isn’t a scary movie — the sole horror onscreen is the lead actor’s self-inflicted haircut — but an offbeat bromance with existentialist ambitions.

headline: ‘Cinema Sabaya’ Review: Conversations and Compassion in a Small Town in Israel
abstract: Israel’s Oscar entry is a documentary-style chamber piece about a video workshop for Arab and Jewish women whose conclusions feel, well, tired.
lead_paragraph: “Cinema Sabaya,” Israel’s international feature entry for this year’s Oscars (though not nominated), looks and feels like a behind-the-scenes documentary. It’s not — the actors aren’t playing themselves and the drama is scripted. But the film resides in the porous boundary between fiction and reality, mounting a chamber piece of sorts not unlike “Women Talking,” but enriched by naturalistic flair that eschews didacticism.

headline: ‘The Blue Caftan’ Review: Secrets of Silk
abstract: In this luscious Moroccan drama, a tailor and his wife strive to save their craft, and their unusual companionship, in the face of illness and change.
lead_paragraph: There’s something downright lustful about the opening scenes of “The Blue Caftan,” which show rustling silks being caressed in close-up by gentle hands. It’s clear right away that this Moroccan drama from Maryam Touzani, about a middle-aged couple who sell hand-sewn caftans, has something to say about desire. But who is the object of whose desire remains tantalizingly mysterious for much of the film, cloaked by the characters’ (and the camera’s) nearly erotic affection for a dying craft.

headline: ‘Attachment’ Review: Demon Lover
abstract: Mysterious behavior leads to an over-familiar reveal in this supernatural horror movie.
lead_paragraph: Shacking up soon after meeting up could strain any relationship, but “Attachment” stirs in the extra spice of demonic possession. In Gabriel Bier Gislason’s compact supernatural story, Maja (Josephine Park) and Leah (Ellie Kendrick) move into Leah’s London flat not long after a meet-cute in a Danish library. Their sole neighbor is Leah’s mother, Chana (Sofie Grabol), whose extreme protectiveness lights a slow-burning fuse of dread.

headline: ‘Consecration’ Review: Something Unholy
abstract: This unsatisfying horror film follows a woman’s search for clues after her brother’s mysterious death at a seaside convent.
lead_paragraph: “Consecration,” a new horror film from the director Christopher Smith, begins with a cryptic declaration from its protagonist, Grace (Jena Malone): “My brother used to believe I had a guardian angel. And I used to believe in nothing. Now, I’m not so sure.” During this voice-over, an older nun saunters over and points a gun at the camera, which is to say, at Grace’s face.

headline: ‘Hannah Ha Ha’ Review: Making Ends Meet
abstract: The directors Jordan Tetewsky and Joshua Pikovsky offer a warm examination of what it means to do meaningful work in a world that undervalues it.
lead_paragraph: The aimlessness of young adulthood is well-trodden ground in the world of indie cinema, but few movies offer the nuanced, lived-in portrayal seen in “Hannah Ha Ha.” The film follows the day-to-day life of Hannah (an illuminating Hannah Lee Thompson), a 25-year-old in small-town Massachusetts. She engages in odd jobs around the area, farming vegetables and teaching guitar lessons, while living with her aging father, Avram (Avram Tetewsky). Under the pressure of her rise-and-grind yuppie older brother, Paul (Roger Mancusi), who reminds her she’ll be booted off Dad’s health insurance on her impending 26th birthday, Hannah attempts to find herself a “real job,” first in the jargon-fueled tech world her brother occupies and then, after that fails, the service industry.

headline: ‘Of an Age’ Review: A Boy’s Own (Coming Out) Story
abstract: In 1999 Melbourne, a teenage outsider meets a young man who’s smart, kind, sensitive and looks mighty fine in a tight black T-shirt.
lead_paragraph: One of the trickier hurdles that romantic movies need to clear is convincing the viewer to swoon, too. That bar proves insurmountably high in “Of an Age,” a confident if unpersuasive story about a quintessentially alienated teenager falling for guy in his mid-20s who checks all the heartthrob boxes: He’s kind, good looking, has a nice smile and seems to like the attention directed at him. Yet why this object of desire, an ostensibly serious thinker en route to grad school, would fall for our charisma-challenged protagonist remains thoroughly mystifying.

headline: What Happens on Page 76 of This Season’s Books?
abstract: The artist Caleb Hahne Quintana envisions new releases by Ayòbámi Adébáyò, Eleanor Catton and more.
lead_paragraph: “‘What’s with the pose, Hida?’

headline: First Significant Aid Delivery Arrives in Northwestern Syria After Earthquake
abstract: The U.N. convoy was carrying shelter material and non-food items to the opposition-held region.
lead_paragraph: Six humanitarian aid trucks carrying shelter material and non-food items entered the opposition-held region of northwestern Syria on Thursday, a spokesman for the U.N. Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs said, three days after a devastating earthquake struck the region.

headline: 2 Charged With Murder in 1975 Killing of an Indiana Teenager
abstract: Laurel Jean Mitchell was found dead after she left a church camp to meet with friends and never made it. Her case had remained unsolved until DNA testing revealed a match.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of Aug. 6, 1975, Laurel Jean Mitchell left the Epworth Forest church camp in North Webster, Ind., where she worked at the snack bar, to meet friends at a nearby amusement park.

headline: Bob Iger’s Turnaround Plan Takes Shape
abstract: Shares jumped after the Disney chief executive unveiled plans to revamp its streaming business and cut costs, including through thousands of layoffs.
lead_paragraph: Since returning to Disney in November, Bob Iger has inspired hope among employees and investors that he could turn around the entertainment giant — and faced a tough challenge from the activist investor Nelson Peltz.

headline: Searching for Struggling Readers, One School at a Time
abstract: Two new specialized dyslexia programs will open at Brooklyn public schools as New York focuses more on children with the learning disability.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Cruz used to complain about going to school. His failing grades on reading assignments shook his confidence and made him wonder whether he was not as smart as the other children.

headline: Coping With Isolation on the Big Sur Coast
abstract: Big Sur has been cut off for weeks since the winter storms, but locals know how to live with isolation.
lead_paragraph: BIG SUR — Big Sur can be a lonely place. For decades, Camaldolese monks, Zen Buddhists and New Age humanists have found solace in its remoteness. Poets and writers like Henry Miller, Jack Kerouac and Robinson Jeffers have drawn inspiration from its steep slopes that drop into the Pacific Ocean.

headline: Off Panama’s Caribbean Coast, a New Stay Perched Above the Treetops
abstract: Plus: a brasserie designed by Luke Edward Hall, a gallery highlighting traditional Indian craftsmanship and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: I wake up in the dark, even in the summer, because we florists are very early people. It’s a little bit of a scramble to get out the door, but I can’t wake up without taking a shower. I’ll use Éminence Monoi Age Corrective Exfoliating Cleanser, followed by Dior Capture Totale Le Sérum and Dior Prestige La Crème. I try to slather myself in those, and then another big slather of Kiehl’s Avocado Eye Cream and Carmex Classic Lip Balm. I don’t wash my hair every day but, when I do, I use Alba Botanica So Smooth Gardenia Conditioner. (I don’t use shampoo.) I always scrunch Kiehl’s Creme With Silk Groom into wet hair and then wind it up with these discontinued Scunci Clips to set — I’ve resorted to buying them on eBay. I started pinning my hair up to control the curl, and now it’s become my signature. It is pretty healthy because it’s tucked away all the time but, when it starts to feel gangly, I’ll snip it myself. I almost never wear makeup because my day starts so early. If I do, I’ll do a cat eye with Stila Stay All Day Waterproof Liquid Eyeliner, Diorshow Mascara and, sometimes, Rouge Dior 999 lipstick. Other lipsticks I rotate in are Stila Stay All Day Liquid Lipstick and Clinique Almost Lipstick in Black Honey. I’ll use Weleda Gentle Cleansing Milk to wash it off at night and, sometimes, I use this Borghese Purifying Mud Mask — I’ve had a jar of that forever. I don’t get massages enough, but I need to. I threw out my back recently, and a massage at Element spa in Brooklyn helped me get back on my feet. A lot of my team has favorite hand creams that are around the studio, one being Aesop Reverence Aromatique Hand Balm, so I’ll use those. One thing I use often is this hand wash that is used to remove sap and resin. The filth if we don’t wear gloves is incredible, it just gets into your pores, and this really removes it. Working with flowers and sometimes rotting flowers, I like to be aware of smells, so I don’t wear fragrance very often. What I do love to wear is Hermès Eau d’Orange Verte. It’s very piney and not very femme. It just feels a little sharp, like me.

headline: A Puzzle Maker Aims to Unite Black Communities in 25 Squares
abstract: Juliana Pache wants to give people in different Black cultures a place to feel at home and get to know each other.
lead_paragraph: Juliana Pache is talking to me in a video interview from a sunlit room in her Queens apartment. Ms. Pache speaks thoughtfully and shares the story of how she became a crossword constructor as well as the creator of Black Crossword, a venture that launched in January.

headline: Chinese Balloon Had Tools to Collect Electronic Communications, U.S. Says
abstract: China’s surveillance balloons have flown over more than 40 countries and are directed by the Chinese military, the State Department said. The F.B.I. is studying debris.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration provided its most comprehensive description of the Chinese spy balloon that traversed the United States last week, saying on Thursday that the machine was part of a global surveillance fleet directed by China’s military and was capable of collecting electronic communications.

headline: N.F.L. Players Say They Were Shortchanged on Disability Benefits
abstract: A federal lawsuit said that Commissioner Roger Goodell and other leaders of the league’s disability plan kept players from receiving payouts for injuries sustained while playing the game.
lead_paragraph: Ten former N.F.L. players sued Commissioner Roger Goodell and the league’s disability plan and its board members on Thursday, accusing them of systematically denying benefits to the players by lying about and misinterpreting the results of their medical examinations and the plan’s guidelines.

headline: Burt Bacharach, Composer Who Added a High Gloss to the ’60s, Dies at 94
abstract: His sophisticated collaborations with the lyricist Hal David — “The Look of Love,” “Walk On By,” “Alfie” and many more hits — evoked a sleek era of airy romance.
lead_paragraph: Burt Bacharach, the debonair pop composer, arranger, conductor, record producer and occasional singer whose hit songs in the 1960s distilled that decade’s mood of romantic optimism, died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 94.

headline: Nicaragua Frees Hundreds of Political Prisoners to the United States
abstract: The authoritarian government of Daniel Ortega handed over 222 prisoners as a way to signal a desire to restart relations with the United States, according to officials.
lead_paragraph: Nicaragua released 222 political prisoners early Thursday, including an American citizen, in a deal negotiated with Washington that marks one of the biggest prisoner releases ever involving the United States, according to senior Biden administration officials.

headline: A Night in the Club, Then Early to Bed
abstract: The Before Midnight parties promise all the thrills of a hedonistic night out, but with a respectable finish time for older dance music fans.
lead_paragraph: It was Friday night, in a 2,000-person capacity nightclub in London, and the dance floor was packed. A heavy-duty sound system pounded out house music and a huge disco ball turned overhead. Only one thing was off: It was 9.30 p.m.

headline: What Can the Wife of Bath Teach Us About Misogyny Today?
abstract: A new book traces the “biography” of Geoffrey Chaucer’s most enduring character and her impact on the course of English literature.
lead_paragraph: Of all the tales Chaucer’s pilgrims tell around the table at the Tabard Inn, it is the Wife of Bath’s that has most riotously escaped the Middle Ages: inspiring Shakespeare, James Joyce, Zadie Smith and dozens of poets, playwrights, feminists and rebels in between. And no wonder. Alison of Bath is unlike any female character ever written before her, neither princess nor witch nor damsel in distress.

headline: I.R.S. Tells Millions Who Received State Rebates: Don’t File Just Yet
abstract: Tax season is underway. But the Internal Revenue Service is still figuring out whether taxpayers who received rebates last year should count them as taxable income.
lead_paragraph: If you’re one of the millions of taxpayers who received a one-time tax payment from your state last year, the Internal Revenue Service has some advice: Hold off on filing your federal income tax return.

headline: Wagner, the Russian mercenary group, says it has stopped recruiting prisoners.
abstract: Thousands of released convicts have been killed, many soon after arriving on the battlefield in Ukraine, Russian rights advocates and Ukrainian officials say.
lead_paragraph: The founder of the Kremlin-affiliated Wagner mercenary group, known for its ruthless tactics and harsh discipline, said on Thursday that it would no longer recruit fighters in Russian prisons. That would end a practice that has raised criticism from human rights groups but helped Moscow grind out advances in Ukraine’s east.

headline: Activist Disney Investor Ends Battle for Board Seat
abstract: Nelson Peltz withdrew a day after Bob Iger, the chief executive, announced a restructuring that will cut $5.5 billion in costs and roughly 7,000 jobs.
lead_paragraph: Behind the scenes at Disney on Thursday, senior executives were giddy. The activist investor Nelson Peltz, in a surprise morning phone call to CNBC, had ended his attempt to install himself or his son on Disney’s board and shake up the company.

headline: ‘Huesera: The Bone Woman’ Review: What to Dread When You’re Expecting
abstract: In Michelle Garza Cervera’s terrifying and transfixing debut feature, a pregnant woman battles visions of a demoness who threatens her body and mind.
lead_paragraph: Ever since I saw “Huesera: The Bone Woman,” the captivating horror film from the Mexican director Michelle Garza Cervera, at the Tribeca Film Festival last year, I haven’t been able to shake its images from my mind. Both a quintessential horror crowd-pleaser and an exceptionally specific deconstruction of the trials of pregnancy, the film offers a portrait of Valeria (Natalia Solián), a furniture maker in Mexico City, as she transitions into a life of domesticity.

headline: Albert Okura, ‘Chicken Man’ Who Saved a Ghost Town, Dies at 71
abstract: He built a California fast-food chain, opened a McDonald’s museum and restored a historic town on Route 66, a road that was special to him.
lead_paragraph: Albert Okura, a third-generation Japanese American, was a college dropout whose dream was to become the world’s biggest fast-food chicken salesman. He became a successful chicken restaurateur, if not the biggest, and later turned to historic preservation — and, as the song says, got his kicks on Route 66.

headline: Big Brands Keep Raising Prices, With Limited Shopper Resistance
abstract: Consumers continue to absorb significant price increases by PepsiCo, Unilever and others. The companies say prices will remain high in the months to come.
lead_paragraph: From soda to soap, consumer giants like PepsiCo and Unilever continue to raise the prices of their products significantly, passing on the higher costs they face, and consumers continue to spend, cutting back only modestly in recent months.

headline: An Artist Puts Kabul in a New Light (With Lipstick and Manicure)
abstract: The Afghan-Canadian artist Hangama Amiri fled the Taliban as a child. Her new museum show reclaims space for women with colorful textile works.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN, Conn. — At a time when  the Taliban are rolling back women’s rights in Afghanistan, the Afghan-Canadian artist Hangama Amiri has created a form of long-distance resistance through her painstakingly sewn textile artworks, now on display at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield, Conn.

headline: House Votes Unanimously to Condemn China Over Spy Balloon
abstract: The vote came after Republican leaders rebuffed a right-wing effort to formally rebuke President Biden for the episode, part of an effort to keep partisanship out of China policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday issued a bipartisan condemnation of the Chinese Communist Party for flying a spy balloon over the United States last week, unanimously approving the measure after top Republicans rebuffed a right-wing faction that had pressed to rebuke President Biden personally for how the incident was handled.

headline: How Uta Barth’s Art Illuminates
abstract: In a 40-year retrospective at the Getty Center in Los Angeles, the photographer scrutinizes subtle shifts in light and reveals what we see and don’t.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The photography of Uta Barth unites the conceptual rigor that is characteristic of Germany, where she was born, with the fascination with light and space of California, where she has lived for the last 40 years.

headline: We’re Not Being Cruel, President Biden. Just Careful.
abstract: The risk of running for re-election at the age of 80 can’t be ignored.
lead_paragraph: Messages don’t come any more mixed.

headline: ‘Somebody I Used to Know’ Review: Reigniting Old Flames
abstract: In Dave Franco’s new comedy, Alison Brie plays a reality television showrunner attempting to break up her ex-boyfriend’s engagement.
lead_paragraph: In the catalog of comedies about city strivers who decamp to their suburban hometowns to hassle former lovers, Dave Franco’s “Somebody I Used to Know” is an upbeat but minor entry, destined to recede behind the worthier stories from which it borrows. The unfortunate irony of the movie’s title — one word off from the Gotye earworm, presumably to preserve search engine optimization, if not originality — is that the film lacks the indelible details and authentic feeling necessary to encode it in long-term memory. Indeed, soon after finishing the movie, it already feels far away.

headline: Sam Bankman-Fried Needs Tighter Bail Restrictions, Judge Says
abstract: A federal judge said he was not satisfied with a plan that lawyers for the disgraced FTX founder struck with prosecutors to limit his use of encrypted messaging apps.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Thursday ordered lawyers for Sam Bankman-Fried, the disgraced founder of the bankrupt FTX cryptocurrency exchange, to create a plan with prosecutors that would ensure Mr. Bankman-Fried did not delete text messages he sent while awaiting trial on charges that he orchestrated the theft of billions of dollars in customer deposits.

headline: What Recession? Some Economists See Chances of a Growth Rebound.
abstract: The Federal Reserve has raised rates rapidly. But instead of cracking, some data point to an economy that’s thriving.
lead_paragraph: Many economists and investors had a clear narrative coming into 2023: The Federal Reserve had spent months pushing borrowing costs rapidly higher in a bid to tame inflation, and those moves were expected to slow growth and the labor market so much that the economy would be at risk of plunging into a downturn.

headline: 20 Wines Under $20: Finding Bargains Amid Inflation
abstract: The familiar names have risen in price, but great, unexplored values still abound.
lead_paragraph: Inflation may have eased in recent months, but the shelves of retail wine shops show no evidence of such economic calming.

headline: Patrick Mahomes Is Not a Kid Anymore. (He Just Plays Like One.)
abstract: Mahomes, known for his sense of fun and improvisation on the field, has become a kind of elder statesman, settled in his family life, his business endeavors and his community.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the Super Bowl between Philadelphia and Kansas City.

headline: ‘Sweetheart’ Review: A Seaside Crush
abstract: In this British coming-of-age film, a young lesbian stumbles through some important firsts.
lead_paragraph: AJ, the moody protagonist of the British coming-of-age film “Sweetheart,” exudes an angst that is recognizable to any person who has lived through adolescence.

headline: Review: No Dudamel Yet, but a Celebration at the Philharmonic
abstract: Esa-Pekka Salonen led the New York Philharmonic the day after Gustavo Dudamel was named as its next music director.
lead_paragraph: If critics ruled the world — hope springs eternal — Esa-Pekka Salonen might be the New York Philharmonic’s music director right now. A conductor and composer, incisive and dryly funny, with a broad and quirky repertory, he was favored by some of us during the process that resulted in the selection of Jaap van Zweden in 2016.

headline: The Ideal Winter Dish? It’s This Cozy Cabbage Recipe
abstract: Melissa Clark pairs that hearty vegetable with pork, herbs and bright lemon to bring out its very best.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I wrote about my expansive, ever-growing devotion to cabbages in the Cooking newsletter, casually asking readers if they were also on Team Cabbage.

headline: Finger Food Is Always a Must
abstract: Buffalo cauliflower, vegan cauliflower popcorn and dips galore for your sports-viewing needs.
lead_paragraph: Tanya McQuoid, Jennifer Coolidge’s character on HBO’s “The White Lotus,” is by no means a role model. But amid her frequent displays of cluelessness are succinct, if not odd, moments of wisdom.

headline: Smithsonian’s Hirshhorn Tries Reality TV to Find ‘the Next Great Artist’
abstract: Seven artists compete for an exhibition at the museum in a series it produced with MTV and the Smithsonian Channel.
lead_paragraph: “One of you will show your work at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden and will take home $100,000.”

headline: As Kansas City Returns to the Super Bowl, So Too Will Fans’ Chop
abstract: The tomahawk chop has long been a feature of the team’s games, but it has come under increased criticism from Native Americans.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the Super Bowl between Philadelphia and Kansas City.

headline: What’s the Biggest Story on Your Campus?
abstract: The Times wants to help you tell it.
lead_paragraph: It’s a tumultuous time to be a college student. Undergraduate campuses have become hot spots for a host of cultural issues, with politicians and thought leaders debating how best to educate the next generation. Often left out of those discussions are the very students who will be affected.

headline: Southwest Airlines Faces Tough Questions From Senators
abstract: The company canceled thousands of flights around Christmas, disrupting travel for about two million people.
lead_paragraph: Senators grilled a top Southwest Airlines executive on Thursday over the company’s holiday meltdown, which disrupted flights for as many as two million people during one of the year’s busiest periods for air travel.

headline: Is Biden Too Old to Run Again?
abstract: In her column Michelle Goldberg says yes. Readers offer their opinions. Also: What to do about the deficit; the purpose of taxes; talking to the police.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Elon Musk doesn’t want his satellites to run Ukraine’s drones.
abstract: The comments angered some leaders in Kyiv.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk’s Starlink satellite internet service has been one of the most consequential technologies for Ukraine in the war, providing a vital online link for soldiers fighting the Russian forces even in areas where digital infrastructure has been wiped out.

headline: Church of England Considers Gender-Neutral Language for God
abstract: The church said that God was neither male nor female and has asked a commission to explore how that is reflected in its services.
lead_paragraph: The Church of England is considering whether to use gender-neutral terms to refer to God, a spokesperson said on Thursday, adding that there are no plans to “to abolish or substantially revise” the existing liturgy.

headline: ‘Not Just a Silly Balloon’: Dismay and Fear Over Another U.S.-China Clash
abstract: A big white orb has pushed the rival superpowers back to diplomatic distance, showing that peace may be frighteningly fragile.
lead_paragraph: Compared with the unease from Chinese fighter jets racing over the Taiwan Strait or naval standoffs in the South China Sea, the giant Chinese balloon floating over the United States last week looked to many in Asia like a puffy trifle.

headline: Florida Officials Had Repeated Contact With College Board Over African American Studies
abstract: A letter from state officials is likely to fuel controversy over the College Board, which has been accused of stripping or minimizing concepts to please conservatives.
lead_paragraph: While the College Board was developing its first Advanced Placement course in African American studies, the group was in repeated contact with the administration of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, often discussing course concepts that the state said it found objectionable, a newly released letter shows.

headline: What an ’80s Feeling: ‘Flashdance’ Turns 40
abstract: The film helped bring breaking into the mainstream. Over the years, it also became famous for the subs and doubles of its star, Jennifer Beals.
lead_paragraph: At the climax of a strip routine, a young woman in silhouette arches back across a chair and pulls a cord. A cascade of water drenches her flexed body.

headline: A Republican Makes Jokes About an Unlikely Subject: Her Own Party
abstract: In frequently bawdy terms at a press club dinner, Representative Nancy Mace brought down the house with her barbs at fellow House members and other Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Representative Nancy Mace of South Carolina has worked hard to cultivate an image as a different sort of Republican — one willing to publicly criticize former President Donald J. Trump and the party’s embrace of the far right, even as she usually votes the party line and has come to adopt some of the same rhetoric.

headline: Dead Chicks and Rotting Meat: South Africa Declares ‘Disaster’ Over Power Cuts
abstract: President Cyril Ramaphosa, facing rising public wrath, on Thursday declared a “state of disaster” and pledged to end an energy crisis that threatens economic and political stability.
lead_paragraph: With South Africa enduring daily power outages of up to 10 hours, President Cyril Ramaphosa declared a nationwide “state of disaster” on Thursday to address an electricity crisis so dire that day-old chicks are freezing to death, supermarket owners are rushing to sell meat before it spoils and many businesses have been forced to shut down.

headline: In Southern Turkey, a Parking Lot Becomes an Open-Air Morgue
abstract: Hundreds of families searched for deceased relatives at a makeshift morgue outside a hospital in Turkey’s hardest-hit region.
lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, TURKEY — Near the epicenter of Monday’s devastating earthquake, hundreds of bodies lined the pavement of a parking lot outside a hospital in Hatay Province. The makeshift, open-air morgue was a grim reminder of the human toll of the disaster.

headline: What Students Are Saying About How Much They Share With Their Friends
abstract: “I understand that sharing any kind of thoughts can be hard, but if you’re struggling it is so worth it.”
lead_paragraph: When was the last time you shared something really personal with a friend— a problem you were struggling with, an embarrassing moment, a crush you had on someone, or anything else?

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Feb. 15, 2023
abstract: This week, LeBron James, the Los Angeles Lakers forward, became the N.B.A.’s career scoring leader. Look at the graph: What do you notice?
lead_paragraph: No one thought LeBron James would overtake Kareem Abdul-Jabbar to become the N.B.A.’s career scoring leader when he came to the league as an 18-year-old. It didn’t seem like anyone could.

headline: General Motors Reaches Deal to Ensure Its Chip Supply
abstract: GlobalFoundries will dedicate part of its semiconductor output to G.M. as the automaker offers more electric vehicles and driver-assistance systems.
lead_paragraph: General Motors has reached an agreement with a large computer chip maker to help ensure it has a steady supply of semiconductors as it ramps up production of electric vehicles and complex components that require increases in computing power.
