headline: A New Round in the Contentious Fight Over N.Y.’s Next Top Judge
abstract: A Republican state senator filed a lawsuit on Thursday seeking a full Senate hearing for Justice Hector LaSalle, Gov. Kathy Hochul’s choice for chief judge.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Gov. Kathy Hochul’s nominee to become New York State’s top judge was blocked by a Democratic-led committee in the State Senate last month, the governor has been weighing whether to sue her fellow Democrats and compel the Senate to take a full vote on her nominee.

headline: Laraaji Conjures a Baptism in Sound
abstract: The pioneer of ambient music, now 79, rediscovered some of his earliest recordings for a new four-disc set.
lead_paragraph: Laraaji, a pioneer of ambient music, barely remembers recording most of “Segue to Infinity,” a four-disc trove of his early studio sessions. In the decades since he started recording, Laraaji has made dozens of albums and cassettes, both solo and collaborative. He has played concerts, festivals, webcasts, collaborations with musicians and dancers, yoga classes, meditation gatherings and more.

headline: With Legislative Prospects Dim, Democrats to Highlight Past Bills
abstract: Senator Chuck Schumer says the party’s main priority will be to make certain that sweeping laws of the past two years are implemented — and that Democrats get credit.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With major legislation likely to be rare in a divided Congress, Senate Democrats are planning to put much of their effort over the next two years into selling the impact of laws they have already passed, heralding the benefits and making sure that tens of billions of federal dollars are spent appropriately and in a way that gives them a political advantage.

headline: Jean Anderson, 93, Exacting and Encyclopedic Cookbook Author, Dies
abstract: Her 1,300-page “Doubleday Cookbook” was a rival to “The Joy of Cooking,” and her rigorously tested recipes taught generations of home cooks.
lead_paragraph: Jean Anderson, the indefatigable and exacting Southern-born food writer and author of nearly 20 cookbooks, including “The Doubleday Cookbook”— a kitchen bible that rivaled “The Joy of Cooking” — and “The Food of Portugal,” which introduced American cooks to the lore, culture and food ways of her favorite country, died last month at her home in Chapel Hill, N.C. She was 93.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The subtitles of nonfiction books are as subject to fad and fashion as anything else in the culture: It’s a running joke in the Book Review that every history we’ve read lately is subtitled “The Reckoning That Changed Civilization Forever.” But this week our recommended books buck the trend by sticking to the facts, plain and simple. “The Wife of Bath: A Biography.” “Roald Dahl, Teller of the Unexpected: A Biography.” “Rikers: An Oral History.” These are, refreshingly, the store-brand versions of nonfiction subtitles; they tell you what you’ll get and they do it without any bells or whistles or extravagant claims. Even the one book on our list with a long subtitle — Tracy Kidder’s “Rough Sleepers: Dr. Jim O’Connell’s Urgent Mission to Bring Healing to Homeless People” — uses it to give real information about the book, not to overpromise. May these be harbingers of a new trend.

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Ethics Code as Critics Push for Change
abstract: In 2019, Justice Elena Kagan told Congress that an ethics code for the justices was in the works. Four years later, it has not emerged.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As calls for the Supreme Court to adopt an ethics code mount, the justices continue to wrestle with whether to adopt a policy similar to one that applies to all other federal judges.

headline: Roger Waters of Pink Floyd weighs in on the war in Ukraine, again.
abstract: An address at the United Nations this week is dismissed by an American ambassador.
lead_paragraph: Roger Waters, the Pink Floyd co-founder who has been roundly criticized for his views of the war in Ukraine, condemned Russia’s invasion in an address to the United Nations Security Council on Wednesday — though he added that he believed the invasion had been provoked.

headline: How Multicurrency Accounts Take the Bite Out of Spending Money Abroad
abstract: Travelers fed up with lousy exchange rates and punitive foreign transaction fees are signing up for apps that let them decide where the buck (or euro or pound) stops.
lead_paragraph: Jet lag aside, almost nothing can dull that post-vacation glow more than a huge credit card bill packed with inscrutable foreign transaction fees.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our critic recommends a cartoon about a peppy pony, a thoughtful new comedy special and a brutal Korean competition series.
lead_paragraph: ‘Pinecone & Pony’When to watch: Now, on Apple TV+.

headline: PGA Tour Payouts Soar as Saudi-Backed LIV Golf Rains Down Riches
abstract: A $20 million purse is on the line in Arizona this week — matching, for about a month, a PGA Tour regular-season record.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — After all these years — and given the ritualized rowdiness, it is impossible to say for certain — the money at the Phoenix Open might be flowing as freely as the drinks and the jeers around the 16th hole.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: 20,000 Dead in Turkey and Syria
abstract: Also, new U.S. information about China’s spy balloon and North Korea’s newest missile.
lead_paragraph: The death toll from the devastating earthquake in Turkey and Syria surpassed 20,000 as rescue efforts faltered, even as the first U.N. aid convoy reached Syria.

headline: As Aid Trickles Into Syria, Residents Say Too Little, Too Late
abstract: “Some people under ruins are sharing their wills with the team,” said one rescue worker. “They share names of their loved ones, then they die.”
lead_paragraph: The first shipment of international aid reached the exhausted residents of opposition-held northwestern Syria on Thursday, a small triumph for the hundreds of thousands who had waited days for help to dig out people buried in the rubble, find secure lodging and obtain food.

headline: SpaceX Test Fires 31 Engines on the Most Powerful Rocket Ever
abstract: The ignition of the Super Heavy booster may set up an uncrewed orbital flight test next month of Starship, the company’s prototype spacecraft.
lead_paragraph: SpaceX moved one step closer to its future on Thursday with a successful ground test of the engines of the most powerful rocket ever built.

headline: Energy Dept. Will Lend $2 Billion to a Battery Component Maker
abstract: The loan will help accelerate Redwood Materials’ plans to produce components for electric car batteries from new and recycled sources.
lead_paragraph: The Energy Department on Thursday announced a $2 billion loan to help a Nevada company step up production of critical components of electric vehicle batteries.

headline: The Absolute Vermeer, in a Show More Precious Than Pearls
abstract: This blockbuster at the Rijksmuseum, never to be repeated, pares the sphinx of Dutch art to the essence: 28 gemlike paintings.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — What is a masterpiece?

headline: When a ‘Miracle’ Drug Is Out of Reach
abstract: People in poorer countries cannot get access to a revolutionary cystic fibrosis treatment.
lead_paragraph: People in poorer countries cannot get access to a revolutionary cystic fibrosis treatment.

headline: How M&M’s ‘Trendjacked’ the Super Bowl
abstract: Mars Wrigley has parlayed a controversy over “woke” M&M’s into what amounts to free advertising for the candy maker’s new spokeswoman, Maya Rudolph.
lead_paragraph: Mars Wrigley has parlayed a controversy over “woke” M&M’s into what amounts to free advertising for the candy maker’s new spokeswoman, Maya Rudolph.

headline: Alleva Dairy, a Little Italy Cheese Shop, Will Close After 130 Years
abstract: The Grand Street store, known for its fresh ricotta and mozzarella, owed more than $600,000 in back rent to its landlord.
lead_paragraph: Alleva Dairy, a 130-year-old Little Italy cheese store known for its fresh ricotta and mozzarella, will close in March after a long battle with its landlord over back rent. It’s just the latest passing of a historic business in the Manhattan neighborhood, whose demographics have changed significantly in the past few decades.

headline: Family of ‘Rust’ Cinematographer Sues Baldwin and Other Producers
abstract: Halyna Hutchins’s husband previously agreed to settle his lawsuit regarding the fatal on-set shooting. Now her parents and sister are suing producers and crew members.
lead_paragraph: The parents and sister of Halyna Hutchins, the cinematographer who was fatally shot on the “Rust” film set, filed a lawsuit on Thursday against Alec Baldwin and other producers and crew members, accusing them of negligent behavior and lax attention to safety.

headline: A Pigeon Was Dyed. Then It Died. Now the Police Are Investigating.
abstract: The artificially pink pigeon, nicknamed Flamingo, was thought to be a victim of a gender reveal stunt gone wrong. The New York City Police Department’s animal cruelty unit has opened an inquiry.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Police Department’s Animal Cruelty Investigation Squad said Thursday it was investigating how a white king pigeon, nicknamed Flamingo, ended up dyed completely pink before being found by rescuers. The bird, which was taken to a wildlife rehabilitation organization last week, died earlier this week.

headline: Florida Sports Board Removes Menstruation Questions From Medical Form
abstract: Responding to concerns about student privacy, high school athletics officials voted to remove questions about menstruation history from a medical form.
lead_paragraph: Florida’s governing body for high school sports voted on Thursday to remove all questions about menstruation from medical forms required for student athletes, after an uproar that reflected anxieties about digital and reproductive privacy.

headline: What Were Those Flying Objects? Not Aliens, the White House Says.
abstract: Here is what we know about the objects as well as the Chinese spy balloon that were taken down this month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The U.S. government and Canada have been busy intercepting unidentified flying objects in the skies, shooting down one on Friday over Alaska, another on Saturday over the Yukon Territory and a third over Michigan on Sunday.

headline: The New York City Mixtape
abstract: From bars and clubs to parks and sidewalks, you can hear a global soundtrack, music brought by immigrants and remixed and remade, like the musicians themselves.
lead_paragraph: From bars and clubs to parks and sidewalks, you can hear a global soundtrack, music brought by immigrants and remixed and remade, like the musicians themselves.

headline: House Blocks Pair of D.C. Bills, Hinting at Discord to Come
abstract: The House, back in Republican hands, is invoking its powers to weigh in on D.C. legislation, including an overhaul of the city’s century-old criminal code.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a heady few years for the District of Columbia’s longtime aspirations of self-governance, with a statehood bill even passing in the U.S. House of Representatives in 2021, the temperature between Congress and the city it sits in has plummeted to new lows.

headline: Ron Labinski, Who Designed a Cozier Future for Stadiums, Dies at 85
abstract: An architect, he followed his hunch that teams would abandon ugly concrete multipurpose arenas for fan-friendly single-sport facilities, like Oriole Park at Camden Yards.
lead_paragraph: Ron Labinski, a visionary architect who a half-century ago foresaw a market for modern single-sport stadiums and then helped design them, replacing look-alike concrete bowls that had often inelegantly housed both baseball and football teams, died on Jan. 1 in Prairie Village, Kan. He was 85.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Marianne Mantell, Who Helped Pave the Way for Audiobooks, Dies at 93
abstract: In her early 20s she co-founded the groundbreaking spoken-word record label Caedmon, which had a hit with Dylan Thomas’s “A Child’s Christmas in Wales.”
lead_paragraph: Marianne Mantell, who in her early 20s helped start the audiobook revolution by co-founding a record company that turned recordings of countless literary giants, including Ernest Hemingway, James Joyce and Dylan Thomas, into mass-market entertainment, died on Jan. 22 at her home in Princeton, N.J. She was 93.

headline: ‘No More Antakya’: Turks Say Quake Wiped Out a City, and a Civilization
abstract: Amid scenes of utter devastation and widespread suffering in the bitter cold, residents mourned the loss of family, friends and memories.
lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — They bedded down anywhere they could: on lightless street corners, in grassy little parks, next to an elementary school, on a hillside down from one of the world’s earliest Christian churches.

headline: Investigating ‘Weaponization’ of Government, G.O.P. Airs Old Grievances
abstract: The marquee committee of the new Republican majority opened its first hearing by rehashing complaints about the treatment of former President Donald J. Trump and others. Even Fox News cut away.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When hard-right Republicans extracted concessions from Speaker Kevin McCarthy in exchange for supporting his election last month, one of their top demands was that he robustly fund and give sweeping jurisdiction to a special subcommittee to investigate their claims of pervasive bias in the federal government against conservatives.

headline: Influence Networks in Russia Misled European Users, TikTok Says
abstract: The covert and coordinated campaign was disclosed in a new report that also addressed misinformation, fake accounts and moderation struggles.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, 1,704 TikTok accounts made a coordinated and covert effort to influence public discourse about the war in Ukraine, the company said on Thursday.

headline: Pence Gets Subpoena From Special Counsel in Jan. 6 Investigation
abstract: The move by Jack Smith, the special counsel, is one of the most aggressive in his investigation of Donald Trump’s efforts to stay in power and is likely to lead to a battle over executive privilege.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence has been subpoenaed by the special counsel investigating former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to cling to office after he lost his bid for re-election, a person familiar with the matter said on Thursday.

headline: N.B.A. Power Shifts to the West With Trade Frenzy
abstract: No move was bigger than Phoenix Suns’ agreement to trade for Kevin Durant. But the Lakers and Mavericks look stronger after deals of their own.
lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be a quiet dinner with friends and family, who were there to celebrate Mat Ishbia’s big win — officially taking over as the controlling owner of the Phoenix Suns and Mercury.

headline: ‘Your Place or Mine’ Review: Try Neither
abstract: This humdrum Netflix romantic comedy features Reese Witherspoon and Ashton Kutcher as longtime friends with possibly hidden feelings for each other.
lead_paragraph: Reese Witherspoon, Ashton Kutcher and the screenwriter (and first-time director) Aline Brosh McKenna each have decades of experience making hit romantic comedies. So it’s all the more confounding that their latest, “Your Place or Mine,” is as phony and flat as a store-bought valentine forced on every kid in class. Witherspoon and Kutcher play Debbie and Peter, longtime chums who shared a sole night of passion 20 years ago before settling into a bicoastal best friendship. Why haven’t these codependent singletons gotten back together? “She’s … her and I’m … me?” he sputters. His answer sums up the hard thinking that went into this script.

headline: How to Destroy (What’s Left of) the Mainstream Media’s Credibility
abstract: Objectivity is a hard standard, but good journalism can’t do without it.
lead_paragraph: It is hardly a secret within America’s newsrooms that our profession has lost much of the public’s trust. Gallup, which has polled “Confidence in Institutions” for decades, found that, as of last summer, just 16 percent of Americans had either a “great deal” or “quite a lot” of confidence in newspapers — down from 25 percent a decade earlier and 35 percent in 2002. For TV news, the latest results were even worse. Eleven percent of Americans trust it. Fifty-three percent don’t.

headline: How Many Comics Does It Take to Joke About a Dim Bulb?
abstract: Nate Bargatze, Chase O’Donnell and the star of “Cunk on Earth” find smart nuances in pretending that they aren’t the sharpest tools in the shed.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one group of people who have been made fun of more than any other, it’s the stupid.

headline: War Is Peace, Freedom Is Slavery, Democrats Are Radicals
abstract: Who’s obsessed with culture wars? Not the Dems.
lead_paragraph: Political speeches, very much including State of the Union addresses, rarely make much difference. They can, however, be useful guides to the political landscape.

headline: In Speech to E.U. Leaders, Zelensky Links Europe to Ukraine’s Fate
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky, in only his second trip outside Ukraine since the conflict began, told European lawmakers that his country’s war against Russia was a defense of all Europe.
lead_paragraph: With his soldiers fighting over the trenches and ruined towns of eastern Ukraine, President Volodymyr Zelensky appeared for the first time in person before leaders of the European Union on Thursday and made an impassioned case that his country’s war with Russia was Europe’s battle, too.

headline: They’re Big. They’re Red. But Are They Boots?
abstract: A New York collective known for smart-alecky drops has once again captured the internet’s imagination, this time with oversize red boots that look to be pried straight off Astro Boy’s feet.
lead_paragraph: From the people who brought you cologne that smells like WD-40, “Birkinstock” sandals made from Birkin bags and Times Newer Roman, a font ever so slightly wider than Times New Roman, comes a hotly anticipated new release: the Big Red Boot.

headline: Reminiscing About Clothes That Shaped Hip-Hop
abstract: At an opening for a new exhibition at the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology, attendees embraced a musical fashion history.
lead_paragraph: A proud crowd of hip-hop style pioneers gathered at the Museum at F.I.T. on Tuesday night to toast the opening of a show that celebrates the history and evolution of hip-hop fashion. The exhibition, “Fresh, Fly, Fabulous: 50 Years of Hip Hop Style,” documents the fashion genre’s humble origins from its beginnings in the Bronx in the early 1970s to its crossover into the mainstream as a dominant and lucrative international force.

headline: Court Cases Now in Limbo in Wake of Memphis Police Abuses
abstract: The Shelby County District Attorney’s Office will review cases involving the five officers charged in the death of Tyre Nichols and could look back at hundreds of others involving its now-disbanded Scorpion unit.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — The arrest of five Memphis police officers charged with second-degree murder in the death of Tyre Nichols could lead to a cascade of criminal cases being dismissed and convictions appealed, as defense attorneys in the city weigh challenging reports and testimony brought by the now-defunct police unit of which the officers were a part.

headline: ‘This Is Our Fate’: A Syrian Family Is Displaced in Southern Turkey
abstract: Syrian refugees displaced by the earthquake in southern Turkey say they need water and more tents to keep their children warm.
lead_paragraph: Syrian refugees displaced by the earthquake in southern Turkey say they need water and more tents to keep their children warm.

headline: Fetterman Remains Hospitalized as Doctors Rule Out a Second Stroke
abstract: The first-term Democrat from Pennsylvania was admitted to a Washington hospital after feeling lightheaded.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator John Fetterman, the Pennsylvania Democrat who suffered a near-fatal stroke before winning his seat last year, spent a second night in the hospital on Thursday as doctors ruled out another stroke but monitored him for signs of seizure, his spokesman said.

headline: Man, 22, Fatally Shot Near Times Square During Rush Hour
abstract: The police were searching for two gunmen after the shooting on Eighth Avenue near 44th Street. The victim was not immediately identified.
lead_paragraph: A 22-year-old man was shot and killed near a Shake Shack in Midtown Manhattan during the evening rush hour on Thursday, and police were searching for two gunmen hours later.

headline: George Santos, Puppies and Bad Checks: How a Theft Charge Got Expunged
abstract: Mr. Santos was able to get a criminal theft charge in Pennsylvania dismissed, after he told the police that someone had stolen his checkbook.
lead_paragraph: A month after he declared his intention to run for Congress in 2020, George Santos asked an old lawyer friend to do him a favor. Police in Pennsylvania were seeking him on a theft charge, but it was all a mistake. Could she help clear things up?

headline: Striking HarperCollins Workers Reach Tentative Agreement With Publisher
abstract: After a three-month strike, the two parties reached a tentative deal that includes wage increases and a one-time bonus.
lead_paragraph: Three months since its members began to strike, the HarperCollins union on Thursday reached a tentative agreement with the publishing company that includes an increase in minimum salaries across an array of jobs and a one-time bonus of $1,500 to union members.

headline: Moshers in a Mosh Pit
abstract: Kavin Pawittranon and Nijah Morris make their New York Times Crossword debuts.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Review: How to Shoot Your Parents, in ‘Pictures From Home’
abstract: In a stage adaptation of Larry Sultan’s photo memoir, Nathan Lane stars as the father everyone’s aiming at.
lead_paragraph: Several weekends a month, from 1982 to 1992, the photographer Larry Sultan visited his parents in Southern California in search of a story. Was it a mark of his failure or his overachievement that, instead of one, he found many?

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon present a puzzle of romance, au naturel.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today’s particularly lovely passage, which is timed for the week of St. Valentine’s Day, is from a 2021 essay by Susan Milnius in the magazine Science News about reforestation and climate change. The essay focuses on Madagascar, whose staggering botanical diversity is the topic of the excerpt. Thousands of unique, endemic species of ferns, baobabs, orchids, palms and other plants mingle in vast forests there. They share pollen, set seed and absorb and exude tropical rains. It’s a verdant setting as sensual as a velvety boudoir.

headline: Joe Klecko’s Hall of Fame Election Recalls Bygone Jets Era
abstract: The Jets did not make a single playoff appearance in the 1970s, but Klecko, as part of a defensive foursome called the Sack Exchange, helped the team rise in the 1980s as its leader.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it will make Jets fans a bit happier. Perhaps it will evoke the good memories of the 1980s, the Era That Almost Was for this star-crossed team.

headline: As N.F.L.’s Quarterback Guard Changes, Patrick Mahomes Wins Second M.V.P. Award
abstract: Mahomes, Kansas City’s quarterback, won football’s top honor for the second time, establishing his place atop a new generation of passing talent.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the Super Bowl between Philadelphia and Kansas City.

headline: A Plot Fit for a Rom-Com
abstract: When Robert Minondo met Eileen Fitzpatrick two decades ago, they became fast friends and remained that way until one New Year’s Eve.
lead_paragraph: For 10 years, Eileen Patricia Fitzpatrick and Robert Mitchell Minondo refused to ruin their close-knit friendship. So they never even tested the waters of romance. But they could only hold out for so long.

headline: After 14 Address Changes, a Final Destination With Each Other
abstract: “We’ve learned that home is people,” Dr. Marc Beuttler said of his relationship with Matthew Davis, which began in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: From the moment Matthew Alec Davis and Dr. Marc Mahoney Beuttler first made eye contact, they each felt an instant attraction.

headline: The Beauty of Expiration-Date Dating
abstract: Falling for someone who’s leaving can be surprisingly liberating (and so much fun).
lead_paragraph: “So as a neurology nurse,” Finbar said, “what’s one thing you’ll never do?”

headline: Private Moments for a Very Public Couple
abstract: Cody Kolodziejzyk and Kelsey Kreppel have become famous for podcasting about their lives, but kept their proposal mostly personal — seal carcass and all.
lead_paragraph: In a relationship open to perusal by millions of followers, the podcasters Cody Michael Kolodziejzyk and Kelsey Lang Kreppel have made a practice of not letting their favorite moments turn into content.

headline: The Best Comes to Those Who Wait (By the Bar)
abstract: Angelique Velez Sina and José Cardona Crespo met while ordering post-golf drinks in Puerto Rico. Now they are partners in business, and in life.
lead_paragraph: After finishing up a game at the Punta Borinquen Golf Club in Aguadilla, P.R., Angelique Velez Sina went to a nearby bar and found herself the center of attention with a group of men who had been playing on the same course.

headline: With So Many Dead in Turkey, Families Forced to Rush Funeral Rites
abstract: The earthquake that hit in southern Turkey has killed more than 17,500 people there, overwhelming the traditional funeral process and accelerating how families say goodbye.
lead_paragraph: KAPICAM, Turkey — The mother wept next to the simple wooden slat that marked where her son had been buried in a long, thin mound of dirt that held dozens of others lost in the devastating earthquake that struck southern Turkey.

headline: ‘They’re Hunting Me.’ Life as a Ukrainian Mayor on the Front Line
abstract: Being the leader of Kherson may feel more like a curse than an honor. But one woman isn’t giving up, even though the Russians are sitting just across the river and shelling her city nearly every hour.
lead_paragraph: KHERSON, Ukraine — The little green van sped down the road, the Russian forces just across the river. Inside, Halyna Luhova, the mayor of Kherson, cradled a helmet in her lap and gazed out the bulletproof window.

headline: A Republican Takes Up the Fight for a Democrat’s Chief Judge Pick
abstract: Hector LaSalle, Gov. Kathy Hochul’s choice, was rejected by the State Senate Judiciary Committee. But now a member of the opposing party has gone to court on his behalf.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at a lawsuit about a disputed judicial nomination with a surprise twist: the plaintiff. We’ll also find out about new programs for students with dyslexia.

headline: Quake Death Toll Surpasses 23,000 Amid Struggle to Get Aid to Quake’s Victims
abstract: Only a trickle of humanitarian aid has reached the devastated parts of Syria because years of war have carved the country into zones of control that impede deliveries.
lead_paragraph: The death toll in Turkey and Syria from this week’s catastrophic earthquake surpassed 23,600 on Friday as relief organizations struggled to overcome an array of obstacles to deliver aid to survivors in both countries.

headline: What the Earthquake Destroyed in the Heart of One Turkish City
abstract: The Times identified nearly 200 buildings, many of them eight or more stories tall, in central Kahramanmaras that were damaged or destroyed.
lead_paragraph: The Times identified nearly 200 buildings, many of them eight or more stories tall, in central Kahramanmaras that were damaged or destroyed.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: A Turkish city lost in the earthquake.
lead_paragraph: The U.N. yesterday sent an aid convoy into opposition-controlled Syria, its first since a powerful earthquake hit the region three days ago, a natural disaster that has killed more than 20,000 people and left hundreds of thousands homeless across Syria and neighboring Turkey. As of yesterday, the death toll in Turkey exceeded the 17,600 mark. An additional 3,377 people are known to have died in Syria.

headline: The Australians in the Super Bowl
abstract: How Jordan Mailata and Arryn Siposs made it to the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: At least one, and possibly two, Australians will take the field in Arizona for the Super Bowl on Sunday night, before a television audience of hundreds of millions of people. With the game starting at 10:30 a.m. Monday Sydney time, relatively few Australians will be watching.

headline: Word of the Day: vitriol
abstract: This word has appeared in 124 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word vitriol has appeared in 124 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 28 in “Soledad O’Brien’s Painted Hardwood Floors Spark Debate on a New Trend” by Ronda Kaysen:

headline: ‘At Midnight’ Review: Running Out the Clock
abstract: A movie star and a junior hotel manager meet cute in Mexico in this ingratiating rom-com.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, a little-noticed indie called “Dating & New York” (2021) nudge-nudged viewers into noticing how it put a millennial spin on a timeworn rom-com formula. (You’ve heard of Instagram? Podcasts? So had the movie.) In that case, a likable cast helped hedge against clichés and the self-consciously peppy approach of the writer-director, Jonah Feingold.

headline: Late Night Is Still Concerned About That Balloon
abstract: “AT&T told their customers, ‘Relax, they can’t spy on you if you can’t get a signal,” Jimmy Fallon said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: U.K. Economy Sputters and Barely Avoids a Recession
abstract: Economic growth was unchanged in the fourth quarter, and only slow expansion is expected in the years ahead.
lead_paragraph: The British economy narrowly avoided a recession at the end of last year, data published on Friday showed, but it is still smaller than it was before the pandemic, and economists predict that it will take several years for Britain to make up that lost output.

headline: Young Love
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Can you write the beginning of a short story, personal essay or poem that uses at least three of the elements in the illustration above? You can use them as inspiration in any way you like, whether to invent a tale or to write about something they remind you of from your own life.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Oh, Football Is On? We’re Here for the Food.
abstract: Editors and writers for the New York Times Food and Cooking team share what they’re serving for Super Bowl Sunday, even if the game is not in their plans.
lead_paragraph: Journalists at The New York Times often joke that the holiday season is the Super Bowl for the Food and Cooking team. (There are many cookies that need baking, after all.) But what about the actual Super Bowl?

headline: Corrections: Feb. 10, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Feb. 10, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the French prime minister, Élisabeth Borne, incorrectly referred to Ms. Borne’s experience running the Paris subway system. She was the second woman to lead it, not the first.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a preview of Rihanna's Super Bowl halftime show.
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a preview of Rihanna's Super Bowl halftime show.

headline: Bing’s Revenge and Google’s A.I. Face-Plant
abstract: OpenAI’s chief executive, Sam Altman, and Microsoft’s chief technology officer, Kevin Scott, on an A.I.-powered Bing.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft’s release of a ChatGPT-powered Bing signifies a new era in search. Then, a disastrous preview of Bard — Google’s answer to ChatGPT — caused the company’s stocks to slide 7 percent. The A.I. arms race is on.

headline: The Tao of Rick Rubin
abstract: The legendary music producer shares practices for cultivating creativity and a more open mind.
lead_paragraph: Reading Rick Rubin’s production discography is like taking a tour through the commanding heights of American music over the past few decades. Jay-Z. Run-DMC. Beastie Boys. Slayer. The Red Hot Chili Peppers. Johnny Cash. Kanye West. Neil Diamond. Brandi Carlile. Eminem. Adele. And it’s not just his production credits: Rubin co-founded Def Jam Recordings and was a co-chairman of Columbia Records. What’s allowed him to work with so many different kinds of artists, across such a stunning range of genres, so successfully?

headline: In a Time of Endings, a Writer Finds Her Voice
abstract: Daisy Alpert Florin’s debut novel, “My Last Innocent Year,” is a coming-of-age novel set on a college campus near the close of the last century.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Group Text, a monthly column for readers and book clubs about the novels, memoirs and story collections that make you want to talk, ask questions and dwell in another world for a little bit longer.

headline: My Chinese Generation Is Losing the Ability to Express Itself
abstract: How can China’s people demand freedom if we can’t even say it?
lead_paragraph: One morning last November, I woke up to a stirring sight: video clips of young protesters in several Chinese cities singing, shouting and chanting for an end to the oppressive “zero Covid” policy that China had adhered to during the pandemic. I’m 31. Never in my life had I seen my fellow Chinese citizens stand up to the government on such a scale and with such determination.

headline: Do You Have a Family Motto or Creed?
abstract: What words, values or codes do you and your family live by?
lead_paragraph: How would you best sum up — in a word, phrase or saying — your family’s outlook on life?

headline: How to Prepare for a Possible Layoff
abstract: What you should do while you are still employed, how to retain important data and what you should be doing with your money.
lead_paragraph: Tech booms and busts are nothing new, so the recent layoffs at places like Facebook and Google may not be that surprising. The media industry is its own perpetual roller-coaster ride, so forced departures from NBC News and Gannett are understandable.

headline: Lois Lowry Breathes New Life Into a 2,000-Year-Old Child
abstract: “The Windeby Puzzle” begins in 1952, when a small, remarkably well-preserved body is unearthed from a bog in northern Germany.
lead_paragraph: Lois Lowry (a two-time Newbery Medalist, for “Number the Stars” and “The Giver”) has written about schoolgirls and church mice, the Holocaust and dream spirits, the bombing of Pearl Harbor and the private lives of toddlers. She is most famous for warmhearted comedies and dystopic fiction. Her style is transparent: graceful and direct, not attracting attention to itself but pulling the reader in. Her signature is compassion.

headline: Leave ‘I Love You’ to the Pros
abstract: Prewritten messages offered by flower-delivery services spare customers the hassle of having to put their feelings into words.
lead_paragraph: The note dangling from the bouquet of roses on your doorstep may have been composed by your crush. It also may come straight from the heart of a copywriter at 1-800-Flowers.com.

headline: I Love You, but I Don’t Want to Sleep With You
abstract: Snoring and conflicting schedules are top reasons couples decide to sleep in separate bedrooms. Sex therapists and marriage counselors have their doubts about the arrangement.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, as Valerie Weisler was preparing to move to New York City to live with her partner, she realized she wanted her own bedroom. She’d been living alone while in graduate school in Ireland, and the idea of sharing a bedroom, even with a partner, filled her with dread. But the alternative filled her with self-doubt.

headline: Psychedelics Are a Promising Therapy, but They Can Be Dangerous for Some
abstract: While drugs like ketamine and psilocybin are largely considered safe, here’s what to know about who should be cautious.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Charles Nemeroff first met his patient, the 32-year-old woman had already been to see several psychiatrists. Initially, the woman, whose identity has been concealed to protect her privacy, had experienced paranoid and racing thoughts, insisting there were listening devices in her phone and that people were watching her; she even sold her home in an attempt to get away from them. After being given antipsychotic drugs, her mania and psychosis abated, but they were replaced by debilitating depression.

headline: How to Stop Having Those Same Silly Fights With Your Partner
abstract: There are ways to meet somewhat near the middle, experts say.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I have had a recurring fight since the Clinton administration. He has a habit of shedding his socks and leaving them, like discarded snakeskin, near — but not in — the hamper. Sometimes a pile accumulates, and soon takes on a mulch-like quality. I ask why he can’t seem to reach the hamper. He wonders why I turn this trivial matter into an issue. Cue fight; repeat for decades. Another involves our divergent approaches to loading a dishwasher.

headline: When the Novel Swiped Right
abstract: Contemporary fiction writers have only just begun to address the dating app revolution, but when they do the results are often new, bold stories about human connection and desire.
lead_paragraph: A friend of a friend was heading back to New York on the train. He pulled out his phone and opened the Grindr app. He started chatting with a guy who, it turned out, was also on the train: the conductor. Shouldn’t you be focused on the road? he texted, flirtatiously. Last fall, a different friend matched on Tinder with the great-grandson of Eva Perón’s bodyguard. Another friend, who insists any app with a chat function can be a dating app, hooked up with the driver dispatched to bring him socks he ordered online after some DMing about delivery instructions got steamy. After he ghosted the guy, packages marked delivered never arrived.

headline: Hurts and Mahomes Show There’s More Than One Way to a Super Bowl
abstract: Philadelphia’s Jalen Hurts and Kansas City’s Patrick Mahomes played different styles successfully on the way to becoming the first two Black quarterbacks to face each other in a Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the Super Bowl between Philadelphia and Kansas City.

headline: There Is Glory and God in Our Struggles
abstract: We don’t need the Black Hebrew Israelites to invent our story.
lead_paragraph: Every February, Black History Month, Americans engage in a futile attempt to squeeze into 28 days the history of a people whose tribulations, contributions and successes are on every page of the American narrative. For African Americans, at least, the struggle to tell our story and make sense of our place in the American saga never recedes from view.

headline: Floodgates Open for Beer Ads During Super Bowl
abstract: For the first time in decades, Anheuser-Busch won’t be the only alcohol brand running national ads during the game.
lead_paragraph: Clydesdale horses. Spuds MacKenzie. Wassssuuuuuuup?!

headline: Life After Layoffs: A Financial Guide
abstract: How to get a handle on your finances after being let go from your job.
lead_paragraph: Losing a job ranks as one of life’s biggest stressors, something tens of thousands of workers have experienced in recent weeks, many for the first time.

headline: One Celebration the Super Bowl Will Lack: The Hiring of Black Coaches
abstract: For the first time, the starting quarterbacks are Black. And there has been a surge of Black team executives. But those milestones are overshadowed by a lagging record on hiring Black coaches.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the Super Bowl between Philadelphia and Kansas City.

headline: DeSantis, Aiming at a Favorite Foil, Wants to Roll Back Press Freedom
abstract: The Florida governor and possible presidential candidate is the latest in a string of Republicans to target the Supreme Court decision that has long protected journalists accused of defamation.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida convened a round-table discussion about the news media this week, he spared no effort to play the part, perching at a faux anchor’s desk in front of a wall of video screens while firing questions to his guests like a seasoned cable TV host.

headline: Big Shots Behaving Badly
abstract: “Unscripted,” an account by the Times journalists James B. Stewart and Rachel Abrams of the media titan Sumner Redstone’s final years, is a chronicle of corporate greed, manipulation, misogyny and sexual impropriety on a spectacular scale.
lead_paragraph: “Unscripted” is a model of how gracefully to tell the most grotesque of stories: that of the final years of Sumner Redstone. A self-made business titan, the founder of Paramount Global, whose holdings included Viacom and CBS, Redstone spent his 90s obsessively manipulating the people around him as they sought to manipulate him. The authors, the New York Times journalists James B. Stewart and Rachel Abrams, allow us to observe him from an almost uncomfortably intimate distance. (At times, I felt as if I were hiding in Redstone’s closet, peering out at the ugly absurdities unfolding.) The writing is elegant and the story so weird and compelling — I lost some sleep unable to put this book down — that the reader may be the only witness to this spectacle who never feels manipulated. It is hard, though, to imagine anyone who reads this book not coming to some clear conclusions: Wealth and power can metastasize until they become toxic, destroying families, companies and countless lives.

headline: Are Tiny Homes a Solution to the Housing Crisis?
abstract: At the International Builders’ Show, exhibitors offered mini prefab houses, kitchens ‘like Swiss Army knives’ and other strategies for dealing with a constrained market.
lead_paragraph: A tug of war is being waged over the size of the American home.

headline: Billy Crudup Makes the Sale in ‘Hello Tomorrow!’
abstract: The actor stars in this new series as a slickster hawking time-shares on the moon. Now in his 50s, Crudup is getting some of the best roles of his career.
lead_paragraph: Billy Crudup’s father, Thomas Henry Crudup III, was a gambler, a hustler, an occasional loan shark and a bookie of questionable gift. Sometimes on the way to his son’s weekend soccer practice, he would stop the car on an interstate shoulder and deal king crab out of the trunk. He sold red-and-white-striped umbrella hats, coffee additives, Farrah Fawcett posters, an inflatable ice chest.

headline: Caviar on Doritos? How a Delicacy Is Becoming a Cheaper Snack
abstract: Fancy fish eggs are no longer confined to snooty affairs. It’s being served at Super Bowl gatherings, game nights and tailgate parties.
lead_paragraph: Before going home to Philadelphia to watch the Super Bowl this Sunday, Cheyenne Corin, 27, a freelance journalist in Washington, D.C., texted her mother a special request: cheese steaks topped with caviar.

headline: At Hubbard Street Dance, Making a Place for ‘the Other Folks’
abstract: Linda-Denise Fisher-Harrell, the Chicago troupe’s new leader, wants to expand the voices in the company, coming this week to the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: In late 2020, Linda-Denise Fisher-Harrell was doing what many other dance instructors were doing: teaching all day on Zoom.

headline: There Is No Dignity in This Kind of America
abstract: The relentless attack on trans people is an attack on us all.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, we have seen a sweeping and ferocious attack on the rights and dignity of transgender people across the country.

headline: Fetterman, Recovering After Stroke, Labors to Adjust to Life in the Senate
abstract: The first-term Democrat, who was released Friday after two days in the hospital, is coping with the lasting effects of a near-fatal stroke last year, and Congress is adapting to accommodate him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At Senator John Fetterman’s desk in the Senate chamber, there is a newly installed monitor that rises or lowers, depending on whether he sits or stands, and provides closed captioning so he can follow the proceedings. At the center dais, a custom desk stand has been built to accommodate the same technology for when he takes his shifts presiding over the Senate.

headline: In Post-Roe World, These Conservatives Embrace a New Kind of Welfare
abstract: Some conservative thinkers are pushing Republicans to move on from Reagan-era family policy and send cash to families. A few lawmakers are listening.
lead_paragraph: Sending cash to parents, with few strings attached. Expanding Medicaid. Providing child care subsidies to families earning six figures.

headline: Why Does Eric Adams Fight City Hall Over Rats?
abstract: The mayor of the nation’s largest city is again immersing himself in contesting a mundane rat summons. His motivations may be both personal and political.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams’s voice was calm, his argument straightforward. The city — his city — was acting unfairly, he politely told a hearing officer on Thursday.

headline: When Did Hospitality Get So Hostile?
abstract: In a new era of rage, dining out has become downright volatile — with both customers and servers aggrieved.
lead_paragraph: HOSTILITY AND HOSPITALITY: how faint the line between them. The Latin hostis once meant “guest,” then became, through some shadowy slippage of language, the word for “enemy” — an etymological twist that might make some smile grimly, particularly those of us who have worked in restaurants as part of the so-called hospitality industry. For how else are we to think of the guests who flex their power from the moment they stalk into the dining room; who frown at the table they’re led to, aggrieved at the imagined underestimation of their status, and insist on moving to another, often identical table; who try to meddle with the kitchen, demanding that the chef subtract and substitute ingredients, to the point of creating entirely new dishes; who wrinkle their noses at a perfectly fine bottle of wine and declare it corked, just to pull rank on the sommelier; who snap their fingers at servers, leer, sneer or scream, “You can’t do your job,” a line attributed to the actor and late-night host James Corden last fall over a flubbed order at the downtown Manhattan brasserie Balthazar; who tip stingily or not at all, ignoring the fact that, in the United States, the federal minimum wage for tipped employees is only $2.13 an hour; or who book a table and then don’t bother to show up, as happens with as many as 28 percent of all reservations, according to a 2021 survey by YouGov and OpenTable, and which can cost a small restaurant hundreds and sometimes thousands of dollars, if not an entire night’s profit?

headline: Workers Fighting America’s Overdose Crisis Are ‘Hanging by a Thread’
abstract: President Biden has endorsed “harm reduction,” which aims to cut down on overdoses by encouraging safer drug use. But the organizations carrying out that strategy are severely underfunded.
lead_paragraph: OSCEOLA, Iowa — So many of Deborah Krauss’s friends and neighbors have died of drug overdoses during the pandemic that she said she felt as if she had been living inside of a dream. The longest she has gone without someone dying, she noted, is three weeks. Her calendar grew cluttered with funerals.

headline: Brad Pitt Is for Kansas City. Pink Is an Eagles Fan.
abstract: Both teams will have a lot of celebrity support when they square off at Sunday’s Super Bowl. Here is how the stars are aligned.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the Super Bowl between Philadelphia and Kansas City.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, February 10, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: The Mets Will Sell Themselves in a Super Bowl Commercial
abstract: A team that suddenly loves to spend money will have Francisco Lindor, Edwin Díaz and other Mets stars in a 30-second commercial during Sunday’s broadcast.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the Super Bowl between Philadelphia and Kansas City.

headline: How Twitter Changed the World, in 25 Tweets
abstract: The most important moments from 17 years of global conversation, ranked.
lead_paragraph: The most important moments from 17 years of global conversation, ranked.

headline: Oregon Liquor Officials Are Accused of Hoarding Rare Bourbon
abstract: An investigation found that six officials with the state’s liquor commission had diverted bottles of high-end alcohol for themselves, including Pappy Van Winkle bourbon.
lead_paragraph: Bourbon aficionados have watched over the years as Pappy Van Winkle Family Reserve bourbon has become a highly coveted luxury item — a status symbol, one whiskey expert said, akin to a Rolex watch, a Ferrari or a Birkin bag. The version that has been barrel aged for 23 years can sell for more than $5,000 a bottle on the secondary market.

headline: Linkin Park’s ‘Meteora’ Surprise: Unheard Chester Bennington Songs
abstract: A 20th anniversary edition of the band’s blockbuster second album will include a handful of previously unreleased demos and the completed track “Lost.”
lead_paragraph: Enough time has passed since his band’s first record that the Linkin Park singer Mike Shinoda has reached the stage of his career where his children’s friends are shocked to learn he was in one of the biggest bands of the 2000s. “The reactions are hysterical,” the musician, 45, said in a video interview from his home studio in Los Angeles.

headline: How Sports Betting Hit the Mainstream in America
abstract: A Times investigation looked into the risks and rewards of the fastest expansion of legalized gambling in U.S. history.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, one of the most watched sporting events of the year, the Super Bowl, will draw an estimated $16 billion in bets from Americans, more than double last year’s total.

headline: Romania says a Russian missile didn’t enter its airspace, countering a Ukrainian claim.
abstract: Ukrainian officials said that two Russian missiles crossed into the airspace of Moldova and Romania before entering Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Romania, a NATO member, said on Friday that a Russian missile had come within 22 miles of its border but that it did not cross into the country’s territory, countering a claim made by the Ukrainian military.

headline: China, Still Trying to Play Down Balloon, Finds It’s Getting Harder to Do
abstract: Beijing has accused the United States of waging “information and public opinion warfare.” But analysts say a lack of credible messaging from China is not helping.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Since the spy balloon saga started, China has tried to play down the incident, maintaining that the United States is overreacting and that the vessel is mainly for gathering meteorological data.

headline: Did He Say ‘Bird?’
abstract: We talk with Sam Altman, the C.E.O. of OpenAI, about the artificial-intelligence craze.
lead_paragraph: As President Biden was reciting a list of bipartisan accomplishments during his State of the Union address this week, he seemed to use a phrase that I had never heard before: toxic bird pits.

headline: Spring’s Hottest Shoes: Flamingo Heels, Crystalline Clogs and Anything Over-the-Top
abstract: Exuberant look-at-me footwear adds a bounce to your step and some fun to your wardrobe.

headline: Russia to Cut Oil Output in Response to Western Sanctions
abstract: The country’s announcement that it will reduce production by about 5 percent sent the price of oil higher.
lead_paragraph: Russia announced on Friday that it would cut its oil production next month by 500,000 barrels a day, or about 5 percent of its output — Moscow’s first substantive response to a wave of recently imposed sanctions on the country’s oil trade.

headline: The S.E.C. Signals a Crackdown on Another Crypto Practice
abstract: Cryptocurrency executives worry that charges against Kraken, a popular exchange, over the business known as staking would further chill their industry.
lead_paragraph: The S.E.C.’s decision to charge the crypto exchange Kraken with securities violations over a popular way for the industry to make money sent more chills down the spines of executives across the sector. At 7:40 a.m. Eastern, the price of Bitcoin traded at $21,757, down nearly 3.9 percent in the past 24 hours.

headline: Five Children’s Movies to Stream Now
abstract: Our inaugural list of picks include films about a shell dealing with loneliness, an adventure from the archives of Jim Henson and a singing crocodile.
lead_paragraph: If you’re one of the millions of humans who were charmed by Marcel when he made his debut on YouTube 12 years ago, it’s time to introduce your kids to this tiny talking seashell who wears pink shoes, has a pet ball of lint named Alan, and is now lonesome and living in an Airbnb with his Italian seashell grandmother, Nana Connie (voiced by Isabella Rossellini).

headline: The English Soccer Streak That Is ‘Just Statistically Ridiculous’
abstract: Bristol City has gone 65 games since its last penalty kick, a drought that has baffled the team and its fans. It has to end eventually, right?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Maybe it’s bad luck. Maybe it’s unconscious bias. Maybe it’s subpar skill. Maybe it’s conscious bias. Maybe a new strategy is needed. Maybe it’s a far-reaching conspiracy. Maybe the fates are cruel and unknowable.

headline: At Least 2 Dead as Driver Rams Bus Stop in East Jerusalem
abstract: A man drove a car into a group of civilians outside an Israeli settlement in what the police described as a terrorist attack. A 6-year-old was among those killed.
lead_paragraph: A man on Friday drove a car into a group of people at a bus stop outside an Israeli settlement on the northern edge of East Jerusalem, killing two people including a 6-year-old child, and wounding at least five others in what the police said was a terrorist attack.

headline: A New Option for Moving Retirement Savings When Switching Jobs
abstract: Three big 401(k) administrators are making it easier for workers with accounts of less than $5,000 to transfer the money to their new employers’ plans.
lead_paragraph: Moving retirement savings when switching jobs is about to get easier for millions of workers with small balances.

headline: Flaco, Central Park Zoo Owl, Tastes Freedom and Isn’t Rushing to Return
abstract: Not straying far from the zoo but not going back either, a bird of prey on the loose faces serious challenges to survival.
lead_paragraph: At around 10:30 Thursday morning, a half-dozen young women from Australia climbed a large rock outcropping near Central Park’s south end and began to snap pictures of one another with the skyscrapers of Billionaires’ Row as their backdrop.

headline: Why Are California’s Trees Dying?
abstract: Climate and human activities combine to make our forests vulnerable to fire and other plagues.
lead_paragraph: California’s iconic mountain forests are in serious trouble, according to a series of recent studies. The latest — an aerial survey of the state’s most forested regions — shows that a combination of drought and insect damage wiped out a startling 36 million trees between 2021 and 2022.

headline: Real Interest Rates Are Moving Up, but Don’t Celebrate Yet
abstract: While markets are predicting that inflation will fall further, savings rates still aren’t keeping up with the prices we’re paying.
lead_paragraph: Inflation is high, and interest rates have soared. How much further the Federal Reserve needs to raise rates, and whether the economy and the stock market can prosper as it raises them, are crucial questions without clear answers.

headline: Young Fathers’ Music Has Always Been Subversive. Now It’s Joyful, Too.
abstract: The Scottish trio has been making political, genre-blending songs for a decade. On a new album, the group embraces the elation of community.
lead_paragraph: When the Scottish band Young Fathers were partway through writing their new album, “Heavy Heavy,” Graham Hastings, known as G, played his brother-in-law a song called “Rice.” The track features cascading drums and bouncy, booming bass as the three-piece chant lyrics including “These hands can heal” and “See the turning tide.”

headline: E.U. Lawmaker Arrested in Qatar-Linked Corruption Inquiry
abstract: The detention of Marc Tarabella, who lost his immunity last week, is part of a long-running investigation into whether there were efforts to influence the European Parliament.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The Belgian authorities arrested a European lawmaker on Friday in connection with a sprawling cash-for-favors investigation, the latest figure to be detained in a scandal that has ripped through the European Parliament since it came to light in December.

headline: The prime minister of Moldova, a Ukrainian neighbor rattled by the war, steps down.
abstract: Natalia Gavrilita had been prime minister since 2021, when she took charge of the government after elections gave a strong majority in Parliament to pro-Western politicians.
lead_paragraph: The pro-Western prime minister of Moldova, a troubled Eastern European nation that borders Ukraine, resigned on Friday, buffeted by a severe energy crisis, soaring inflation and errant missiles as a result of the war raging next door.

headline: Putin used a secret decree to pardon an ex-inmate who joined Russia’s war effort, a document shows.
abstract: A copy of a prison release certificate reviewed by The New York Times offers evidence of what activists say is a mass pardon campaign to entice tens of thousands of inmates to enter battle.
lead_paragraph: A secret pardon granted by President Vladimir V. Putin to a Russian prisoner who fought in Ukraine shows that the former inmate received clemency on the day he left jail to join the war, an act that rights activists say short-circuits the existing legal process.

headline: The Students Quietly Kicked Out of Class
abstract: Students with disabilities face high suspension rates, leading to millions of lost class hours. But schools are also covertly removing children from class.
lead_paragraph: Students with disabilities face high suspension rates, leading to millions of lost class hours. But schools are also covertly removing children from class.

headline: Adidas Tumbles as Losses From Its Kanye West Venture Pile Up
abstract: Shares in the German sportswear brand fell sharply on Friday as the company grapples with a mountain of unsold Yeezy merchandise.
lead_paragraph: Bjorn Gulden has been chief executive at Adidas for just six weeks, and he’s already warning that Year 1 will be a mess.

headline: Celebrity ‘Queer Baiting’ and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Ronald S. Lauder Reaches Agreement on Klimt Painting With Jewish Heirs
abstract: Mr. Lauder agreed to the restitution and repurchase of the painting from the relatives of an art collector who fled Europe in 1943 to avoid Nazi persecution.
lead_paragraph: Ronald S. Lauder, the billionaire cosmetics heir and art collector, will continue to own a well-known painting by Gustav Klimt, which he has held for 50 years, after agreeing to the restitution and repurchase of the work from the heirs of a Jewish woman who had owned it before World War II.

headline: Biden and Lula Swap Insurrection Stories and Vow to Guard Democracy
abstract: President Biden hosted Brazil’s new president on Friday in a refresh of the countries’ relations. The two leaders agree on the Amazon but are split on Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When he hosts world leaders, President Biden typically exchanges thoughts on trade policy or national security and maybe swaps old election stories. But on Friday, for the first time, he welcomed a leader with whom he could trade notes about being on the receiving end of a violent insurrection.

headline: The War’s Violent Next Stage
abstract: Both sides are preparing to attack after months of slow-moving fighting. Russia is moving first. Here’s how each side is trying to shape the critical next few months in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Both sides are preparing to attack after months of slow-moving fighting. Russia is moving first. Here’s how each side is trying to shape the critical next few months in Ukraine.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a wry Bosnian coming-of-age film, a documentary about supernatural phenomena in Scotland and a drama about missing women in Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Bonnetta’s rapturous film opens with a remote shot of a dark, silhouetted figure setting up a boom microphone in a desolate landscape, while, in voice-over, a man describes the legend of “second sight” in the Outer Hebrides of Scotland: the supposed ability that some people have to see or hear things from elsewhere, be it the future, the afterlife or another realm. This connection between audiovisual technology and extrasensory experiences forms the spine of “The Two Sights.” On the soundtrack, various locals of the Hebrides describe strange incidents and encounters: a man who heard the radio years before its invention; a woman who saw a shadowy premonition of death; a fisherman who felt an unsettling communion with a beached whale. Onscreen, we see 16-millimeter images of unearthly beauty that complement — if not directly illustrate — these stories, with glimpses of craggy land and wooden boats and deep lakes all shimmering in fog and magic-hour light.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Chili, Moroccan nachos and more for the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Super Bowl LVII is on Sunday, Kansas City vs. Philadelphia, a proper feast for millions and millions of fans. Many of us will be stocking up on chicken wings or making chili on Saturday so that it cures into perfection for Sunday night. It’s a weekend for cornbread and jalapeño poppers, potato skins and queso, for cold beer and frozen fudge pops. Ribs for all!

headline: Cockatoos Know How to Pick the Right Tools for the Job
abstract: The job, in these experiments, was getting a cashew out of a puzzle box.
lead_paragraph: Cockatoos contain contradictions.

headline: A Duggar Revisits Her Religious Upbringing
abstract: Jinger Duggar Vuolo, who was one of 19 children on a popular reality show, becomes a powerful voice in a trend of young adults re-examining their own conservative Christian childhoods.
lead_paragraph: When Jinger Duggar Vuolo was about 14, her family piled into the family bus to drive to Texas from their home in Arkansas. They were headed to a conference for home-schooling parents and their children, an annual event that was one of the highlights of her year — and the rare place where very large families like her own felt normal.

headline: Harry Kane and the Power of Individual Achievement
abstract: Soccer prefers to recognize collective triumphs ahead of personal milestones as the true measure of success. But glory comes in many forms.
lead_paragraph: The record had, it turned out, been playing on Harry Kane’s mind. Players always insist that they are oblivious to these things, that they regard them as little more than statistical ephemera. Ordinarily, it is only once the achievement is banked and the challenge met that they will admit to the blindingly obvious.

headline: Lizzo and SZA Spin Up a Fresh ‘Special,’ and 7 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Luke Combs, Jessie Ware, Indigo de Souza and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: A Lawsuit Against Big Oil Gets Personal
abstract: An activist group is going after Shell’s board members in court. The suit could make life unpleasant for the people who oversee big polluters.
lead_paragraph: Is it risky to invest in oil and gas? Or is it risky not to?

headline: Story Collections to Take Readers Around the World
abstract: “Have Mercy on Us” moves from Greece to Kenya to California; “Call and Response” is set in Botswana; “Welcome Me to the Kingdom” explores Bangkok’s dark corners.
lead_paragraph: Many of the characters in Lisa Cupolo’s debut collection, HAVE MERCY ON US (Regal House, 117 pp., paperback, $17.95), are away from home; and even those not traveling seem somehow adrift. The stories traverse the world, leaping from a small Greek village to Alberta, Canada; Mombasa, Kenya, to Catalina Island, Calif.; but the struggles within are less “exotic” than familial, and painfully human. Some characters pay dearly for the poor life choices they make, while others suffer for someone else’s transgressions — a parent’s, a child’s, a lover’s.

headline: F.B.I. Found One Classified Document After Searching Pence’s Home
abstract: Aides to former Vice President Mike Pence agreed to the search after discussions with the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. found one classified document after searching the Indiana home of former Vice President Mike Pence for five hours on Friday, an adviser to Mr. Pence said.

headline: Maya Rudolph’s Super Bowl Challenge: Make M&M’s Sweet Again
abstract: Unpopular companies and brands in trouble go with a strategy of hiring a likable celebrity and hoping for the best. But they might be better off with a puppy.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the Super Bowl between Philadelphia and Kansas City.

headline: LaBolt to Replace Bedingfield as White House Communications Director
abstract: Kate Bedingfield’s departure is the latest turnover in the White House at the halfway mark of President Biden’s term.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kate Bedingfield, the White House communications director, is leaving her post and will be replaced by Ben LaBolt, a veteran press adviser to former President Barack Obama, the White House announced on Friday.

headline: As Federal Cash Flows to Unions, Democrats Hope to Reap the Rewards
abstract: In places like West Virginia, money from three major laws passed by Congress is pouring into the alternative energy industry and other projects. “I think it’s a renaissance for the labor movement,” said one union official.
lead_paragraph: BRIDGEPORT, W.Va. — In the mid-1970s, when Mark Raddish wasn’t more than 11 years old, his coal-mining grandfather picked him up from a mining camp and took him a thousand feet underground, to the cold darkness beneath West Virginia. There, he imparted a lesson.

headline: Electric Vehicles Could Match Gasoline Cars on Price This Year
abstract: Competition, government incentives and falling raw material prices are making battery-powered cars more affordable sooner than expected.
lead_paragraph: More quickly than seemed possible a few months ago, sticker prices for electric vehicles are falling closer to the point where they could soon be on a par with gasoline cars.

headline: Amsterdam Bans Marijuana Smoking on Streets of Red-Light District
abstract: The new regulations, which will take effect in mid-May, were introduced in response to complaints from residents about disruptive tourists.
lead_paragraph: Amsterdam will soon ban the smoking of marijuana on the streets of its popular red-light district, according to rules introduced on Thursday that are aimed at cracking down on the noisy tourists that local residents have long complained about.

headline: Can a Police Officer Accused of Spying for China Ever Clear His Name?
abstract: Federal prosecutors said Baimadajie Angwang was an agent for China who used his N.Y.P.D. job to report on Tibetans. Then, with scant explanation, they abandoned the case.
lead_paragraph: Now that he is no longer accused of being a secret agent for China, Baimadajie Angwang can start asking hard questions.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Recent releases include titles by Marlon James, Kristin Henning and more.
lead_paragraph: Recent releases include titles by Marlon James, Kristin Henning and more.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Rick Rubin
abstract: The Feb. 10, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Rick Rubin. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: How Will Humans and A.I. Get Along?
abstract: Readers express both fear and excitement about A.I.’s growing capabilities. Also: Slaughterhouse horrors; silencing filmmakers; what Manhattan needs.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How to Set Up a Standing Desk
abstract: You'll probably want to tinker with it a bit after installation.
lead_paragraph: You'll probably want to tinker with it a bit after installation.

headline: Fans at the Super Bowl Won’t Have to Go Far to Place a Bet
abstract: Legal betting on the Super Bowl will be available at the game for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the Super Bowl between Philadelphia and Kansas City.

headline: What We Know About the Earthquake in Turkey and Syria
abstract: As the death toll rises in the one of the deadliest quakes in decades, a global humanitarian aid effort faces deep challenges.
lead_paragraph: The 7.8-magnitude earthquake that struck southern Turkey and northern Syria in early February killed tens of thousands of people, flattened wide areas of cities and sent the region, which was already grappling with a refugee crisis and over a decade of war, into a monumental recovery effort.

headline: What ‘Tár’ Reveals About Wokeness in Hollywood
abstract: What movies define our political moment?
lead_paragraph: “Tár,” the best film of 2022 no matter which motion picture the Academy decides to honor, is a movie about contemporary culture wars that refuses to participate in them. It portrays the generation gap that yawns between liberal elders and progressive juniors in many cultural institutions, it illustrates the potent influence of cancel culture and #MeToo and it uses both forces in a believable (if hallucinatory or supernatural) way to propel the spiraling descent of its title character, Cate Blanchett’s fictional conductor, Lydia Tár. And it does all this in a spirit of controlled ambiguity, from a vantage point outside the forces it depicts — one that allows for varying judgments on the main character’s undoing, in the same way as comparable downfalls in real life.

headline: A Nun With Very Bad Habits
abstract: In the novel “Scorched Grace,” a tattooed, chain-smoking, swearing-prone nun turns out to be a crack detective.
lead_paragraph: Sister Holiday, the protagonist of Margot Douaihy’s showstopper of a series debut SCORCHED GRACE (Gillian Flynn Books/Zando, 310 pp., $27.95) isn’t what you’d imagine a nun to be like, even in laissez-faire New Orleans. “Not that I knew what to make of a nun like me — gold tooth from a bar fight, black scarf and gloves concealing my tattoos, my black roots pushing through badly bleached hair,” she says. Holiday longs for her married musician ex-girlfriend and her dead mother.

headline: Love and Scallops
abstract: Scallops may be a little fancier than most everyday ingredients, but Melissa Clark’s creamy preparation couldn’t be easier.
lead_paragraph: I sort of love Valentine’s Day and harbor no cynicism toward it: It’s one of the few days on the calendar devoted to being sweet to others. I know this makes me corny, and I simply do not care. The handmade card on construction paper, the freshly baked brownies, the bowl of spaghetti carbonara — adorable. Watching my 3-year-old adorn store-bought valentines with sparkly cat stickers melted my heart.

headline: What Are Your Favorite Wedding Songs? We Want to Hear Them.
abstract: Creating a great wedding playlist can be a challenging task. So we’re putting one together based on your input.
lead_paragraph: The dance floor is a hallmark of a wedding — it’s where guests can let loose and memories are often made.

headline: Mourning ‘Compassionate Conservatism’ Along With Its Author
abstract: The memorial service for Michael Gerson, a former speechwriter for President George W. Bush, came just before the 20th anniversary of the AIDS relief program they had conceived and initiated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the middle hour of their grief, they gathered in the majestic Washington National Cathedral, where presidents and cabinet secretaries and other titans of America’s ruling class are traditionally memorialized in the nation’s capital.

headline: Title Search: Can You Find These 14 Hidden Romance Novels?
abstract: This text passage contains a reading list of classic and contemporary titles. Ready to discover some books?
lead_paragraph: This text passage contains a reading list of classic and contemporary titles. Ready to discover some books?

headline: What Statistics Can’t Capture About the Global Baby Bust
abstract: Falling fertility has been hard to reverse, despite so many governments’ best efforts, because it’s not one thing, it’s everything.
lead_paragraph: It’s a story that you can almost set your watch by: Every few months, new data or a new report will show that the birthrate in a country or region is too low to sustain economic growth, and that efforts to convince people to have more babies have failed.

headline: Biden Shuns a Super Bowl Interview With Fox, After All
abstract: Dueling statements between the White House and Fox on Friday had generated confusion about the prospect of a pregame presidential appearance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It appears that President Biden will not be sitting down for a Super Bowl interview with Fox after all.

headline: Review: An Orchestra Falters in Schubert’s ‘Great’ Symphony
abstract: Bernard Labadie and the Orchestra of St. Luke’s returned to Carnegie Hall in a program that also included a Mozart piano concerto with Emanuel Ax.
lead_paragraph: Despite Schubert’s best efforts, his “Great” Symphony never received a performance in his lifetime. Initially considered overlong and unplayable, it took Mendelssohn, who gave its premiere, and Schumann, who wrote passionately of its glories, to bring it to light more than a decade after Schubert’s death. Now it’s a repertory staple.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: This week, the hosts focused mostly on the Chinese spy balloon that traversed the United States before being shot down, and President Biden’s second State of the Union address. Here's what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: This week, the hosts focused mostly on the Chinese spy balloon that traversed the United States before being shot down, and President Biden’s second State of the Union address. Here's what they had to say.

headline: Kenji López-Alt’s Family Loves This Soup. Here’s How He Made It Easier.
abstract: Roast the squash and aromatics in a Dutch oven, blend it all in the pot with stock and dinner’s done.
lead_paragraph: My family loves squash soup.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: How candy hearts explain the world. Also in this edition: the New York City mixtape and how SZA’s enigmatic music made her a megastar.
lead_paragraph: How candy hearts explain the world. Also in this edition: the New York City mixtape and how SZA’s enigmatic music made her a megastar.

headline: U.S. Shoots Down High-Altitude Object Over Alaska
abstract: The incident comes less than a week after a U.S. fighter jet brought down a Chinese spy balloon over the Atlantic during a diplomatic crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon said it shot down an unidentified object over frozen waters around Alaska on Friday at the order of President Biden, less than a week after a U.S. fighter jet brought down a Chinese spy balloon over the Atlantic in an episode that increased tensions between Washington and Beijing.

headline: How the Hasty Packing of Biden Papers Led to a Special Counsel Inquiry
abstract: Two aides played pivotal roles in how the classified documents appear to have gotten from the White House to a Biden think tank, where they were discovered years later.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, when the University of Pennsylvania opened the Penn Biden Center, a think tank for Joseph R. Biden Jr. to work out of in Washington following his vice presidency, the school gave the space a striking feature: an office that largely replicated the one in the West Wing that Mr. Biden had vacated the previous year.

headline: Warning Issued for Baby Trend Stroller After Death
abstract: Another baby was injured, leading the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission to warn about the risks of children getting trapped in the stroller’s front canopy if it isn’t properly used.
lead_paragraph: A baby was killed and another was injured after becoming trapped in Baby Trend strollers, prompting the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission on Thursday to warn customers about the potential dangers of some models.

headline: Brazil says it won’t be sending weapons to Ukraine, despite a U.S. push for more support for Kyiv.
abstract: The Brazilian leader, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, who met with President Biden at the White House, said he’s interested in helping negotiate a path to peace.
lead_paragraph: President Biden welcomed Brazil’s new president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, at the White House on Friday for a summit that was mostly about areas of cooperation between the countries. But when it comes to Ukraine, the two leaders disagree.

headline: Don’t Buy Biden’s ‘Buy American’
abstract: A stringent requirement is either harmful to taxpayers or superfluous.
lead_paragraph: I can’t say for sure, but I’m guessing that “drywall” was never an applause line in a State of the Union address before this week.
