headline: With Another Super Bowl Comeback, Patrick Mahomes Brightens N.F.L.’s Future
abstract: Capping a season plagued by shocking injuries and turnover among football’s most recognizable names, Mahomes, the Kansas City quarterback, dazzled in a Super Bowl win over Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — On Thursday night, Patrick Mahomes of the Kansas City Chiefs won his second N.F.L. Most Valuable Player Award, cementing him as the most accomplished passer of a new crop of young quarterbacks dominating the league. Three days later, he added the second Super Bowl victory of his career, throwing for 182 yards and three touchdowns to beat the Philadelphia Eagles, 38-35.

headline: A Jury in Manhattan Weighs a Matter of Life and Death
abstract: Sayfullo Saipov was convicted of killing eight people. A decision to execute him would require a unanimous vote of the 12 jurors.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at a question that federal prosecutors will put before a jury today — a question involving a punishment that hasn’t been imposed on a defendant in Manhattan in decades.

headline: The Eagles Came as Close as Close Can Get
abstract: Philadelphia quarterback Jalen Hurts scored four total touchdowns in a performance with only one blemish, but it was a big one: a fumble returned for a touchdown.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Sometimes, a team can win the regular season and lose the postseason. That’s what the Philadelphia Eagles learned on Sunday, when the Kansas City Chiefs and their hobbled yet transcendent quarterback, Patrick Mahomes, ripped the Lombardi Trophy out of their grasp and won their second Super Bowl title in four years.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Love Trip: Paris’ and American Idol
abstract: A new reality dating show set in Paris premieres on Valentine’s Day, and American Idol returns for its sixth season on ABC.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Feb. 13-19. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word of the Day: qualm
abstract: This word, including its plural form, has appeared in 88 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word qualm has appeared in 88 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 20 in “In ‘Reboot,’ Everything Old Is New, to Streaming” by Alexis Soloski:

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Reality Star Revisits Her Religious Upbringing
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 13, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “For a person to go through deconstruction, it often involves being rejected by your family and losing your entire social network.”

headline: Which Republicans Are Eyeing a 2024 Run?
abstract: For months, Donald Trump has been the only Republican in the 2024 race. But that's about to change.
lead_paragraph: For months, Donald Trump has been the only Republican in the 2024 race. But that's about to change.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: 10 Things You Might Have Missed During the Super Bowl
abstract: A coach wept. A tennis star hawked cognac and beer. Nobody tried to sell you cryptocurrency. Rihanna dropped in to sing and lived to tell about it. And Kansas City won a football game.
lead_paragraph: Forget Thanksgiving. Super Bowl Sunday is America’s true unleashing of its national id, the day the country gorges itself on beer and chicken wings, patriotism, pop culture, hero worship, machismo, fireworks, sanctioned violence and consumerist yearning.

headline: As Subway Ridership Rebounds, Some Women Are Reluctant to Return
abstract: Long wary on public transit, women who found other ways to get around New York during the pandemic could prove hard for the M.T.A. to win back.
lead_paragraph: Many women riding New York’s subway have stories of being leered at or harassed and have become used to raising their guard on public transit. Now, some women say safety concerns, which climbed among passengers during the pandemic, have pushed them to find other ways of getting around.

headline: How China’s ‘Gateway to Europe’ Began to Narrow
abstract: The Czech Republic, which once courted Beijing in the hope of attracting investment, has soured on China, as have many other countries in Central and Eastern Europe, partly over the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, the Czech president, on a visit to Beijing, offered his country as “China’s gateway to Europe.” But the entry ramp for an expected flood of Chinese investment has narrowed to a patch of muddy land on the edge of a tiny Czech village.

headline: Why Mississippi, a Covid Hot Spot, Left Millions in Pandemic Aid Unspent
abstract: Stop-and-go federal funding floods public health agencies with cash during crises but starves them of funds afterward. The coronavirus pandemic shows the pitfalls of that approach.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — When the coronavirus first scythed through the nation in early 2020, few places needed help fighting it more than Scott County, Miss., a rural patch of chicken processing plants and pine forests an hour east of the state capital, Jackson.

headline: No Corrections: Feb. 13, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 13, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Cambodia’s Leader Shuts Independent News Outlet Ahead of Election
abstract: The leader, Hun Sen, was not satisfied with an apology he received from the outlet after it wrote about his son, a lieutenant general.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia on Sunday ordered the shutdown of the Voice of Democracy, one of the country’s last independent news outlets, intensifying a long-running crackdown on the news media and political opposition as he consolidates his grip on power.

headline: The Origins of Valentine’s Day: Was it a Roman Party or to Celebrate an Execution?
abstract: Regardless of its origin, it’s a big deal now. An expert on the evolution of human sexuality says you have to “get out there” to make the holiday work for you.
lead_paragraph: Valentine’s Day is upon us again. It’s a time of candlelit dinners, heart-shaped candy boxes from the drugstore and (depending on your relationship status) watching old romantic comedies while you drink wine by yourself.

headline: A Valentine, from A.I. to You
abstract: We’re asking ChatGPT to try to capture that most human of emotions: love.
lead_paragraph: We’re asking ChatGPT to try to capture that most human of emotions: love.

headline: Write a (Bitter Valentine) to (Your Therapist) in the Style of (a Yelp Review)
abstract: We’re asking ChatGPT to try to capture that most human of emotions: love.
lead_paragraph: We’re asking ChatGPT to try to capture that most human of emotions: love.

headline: My Friend Won’t Leave Her Abusive Husband. What Do I Do?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the support we can give friends stuck in dangerous relationships.
lead_paragraph: I have a good friend whom I love and care about. She is married to a man whose alcoholism has gotten worse over the years; he is also both verbally abusive and controlling of her. They have a son who is 12. My friend participates in Al-Anon, a support group for friends and family of alcoholics, and is also going to therapy. We talk about once a week, and she tells me awful stories about her husband’s drinking and subsequent abuse. I have talked to her about leaving, and emphasized the support that I and other friends would give; she maintains that she is not ready to leave. (She has a good job with benefits and salary, so it’s not a financial issue.)

headline: Her Father Was a Drama Critic, Her Mother a Superstar Agent
abstract: In her memoir “The Critic’s Daughter,” Priscilla Gilman recounts her life with intensely intellectual — and very different — parents.
lead_paragraph: Priscilla Gilman’s new memoir, “The Critic’s Daughter,” is about her tangled relationship with her father, the critic Richard Gilman. By the end of the book, there’s a lot of blood on the floor, but it doesn’t belong to the author or her ostensible subject.

headline: Is It Possible to Wear Clothes From Other Cultures Without Appropriation?
abstract: A reader who is not Asian wonders whether it’s possible to participate respectfully in Asian sartorial traditions.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: In a Novel About Theater, the Most Fraught Dramas Are Offstage
abstract: Richard Bausch’s “Playhouse” follows a large cast of characters involved in a production of “King Lear.”
lead_paragraph: The “Cast of Characters” page at the start of Richard Bausch’s new novel, “Playhouse,” evokes the delicious anticipation a theatergoer might feel before the houselights dim, surrounded by the rustle of fellow audience members paging through their programs. It’s a fitting introduction to a novel about a theater company, yet it turns out to serve a practical purpose as well: The number of characters who populate the book exceeds the 35 listed up front, and keeping track of who’s who proves challenging.

headline: Do Social Media and Smartphones Make Your Friendships Stronger?
abstract: Does technology strengthen your relationships and make your friendships easier to maintain? Or does it do the opposite?
lead_paragraph: Do your friends know where you are at all times? Would you want them to? What about the other way around: Do you wish you could track your friends?

headline: Amrit Kaur of ‘Sex Lives of College Girls’ Runs on ‘Super Soul Sunday’ Podcasts
abstract: The actress, one of the stars of the HBO Max comedy, wakes up with elaborate chai rituals and unwinds with “90 Day Fiancé” episodes.
lead_paragraph: Amrit Kaur was glowing. “It’s like I’m doing a Pantene Pro-V ad,” the actress, freshly coifed, said with a flip of her shorter new ’do on a video call from her home in Toronto.

headline: In an Uncertain Job Market, How Can Companies Retain Workers?
abstract: Although some employees might decide to stick with their jobs when the market appears uncertain, work force reductions can, conversely, spur more quitting.
lead_paragraph: Reports of layoffs have cast a shadow over the recent surge in quitting. Tech behemoths like Amazon and Meta and, most recently, Dell and Microsoft have led the way in cutting jobs, along with companies like BlackRock and Goldman Sachs; layoffs are planned at McDonald’s, as well.

headline: I’m a Big Wave Surfer, and I’ve Never Seen Anything Like What I Saw This Year
abstract: Tyler Fox on what climate change is doing to his California coastal community.
lead_paragraph: SOQUEL, Calif. — Throughout my 20-plus years of surfing big waves, I’ve experienced some amazing moments in and around the ocean. I’ve witnessed carnage and chaos, joy and jubilation, events that have been seared into my subconscious and that I believe will stay with me until my dying day.

headline: Nikki Haley Threw It All Away
abstract: No political figure better illustrates the tragic collapse of the modern Republican Party than the former governor of South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: I remember the first time I saw Nikki Haley. It was in a high school gym before the 2012 South Carolina Republican presidential primary. Tim Scott, who was then a congressman, was holding a raucous town hall, and Ms. Haley was there to cheer him on. The first woman to be governor of South Carolina, the first Indian American ever elected to statewide office there, the youngest governor in the country. Whatever that “thing” is that talented politicians possess, Ms. Haley had it. People liked her, and more important, she seemed to like people. She talked with you, not to you, and she made routine conversations feel special and important. She seemed to have unlimited potential.

headline: A Hunger Strike Makes Headlines Before Milan Fashion Week Begins
abstract: Stella Jean, one of the few Black designers in Italian fashion, protests her industry’s lack of diversity and inclusion.
lead_paragraph: The designer Stella Jean has often cut a solitary figure.

headline: Marjorie Taylor Greene Didn’t Like What She Saw
abstract: Biden may be 80, but the real danger is the prepubescent opposition.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: So Bret, Joe Biden’s been on a roll. Economy good, State of the Union speech good — made even better by those Republican boobirds.

headline: ‘There’s No Spring Break Here’: Florida’s Gulf Coast Fights to Rebound After Hurricane Ian
abstract: Communities like Fort Myers Beach, Sanibel and Captiva, devastated by the storm, are struggling to rebuild the hotel rooms, restaurants and rental units that keep their economy alive.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 28, Hurricane Ian made landfall on Cayo Costa, a barrier island northwest of Cape Coral and Fort Myers, Fla., as a Category 4 storm with sustained winds of more than 150 miles per hour. Killing 149 people in Florida, it was the state’s deadliest hurricane since 1935. More than four months later, the storm’s extraordinary power remains evident: In Fort Myers Beach, multistory oceanfront apartment buildings are still just piles of twisted steel and concrete rubble, and massive shrimping boats sit tilted and smashed together like toys in the corner of a tub.

headline: $500 a Month, No Strings: Chicago Experiments With a Guaranteed Income
abstract: For recipients, it’s a lifeline. For liberal supporters, it shows how expanding government can make a difference. For conservatives, it’s a return to wasteful welfare handouts.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Christopher Ellington’s South Side photography studio crashed in 2020 with the onset of the pandemic. By March 2021, he was scraping by on a tax preparation and financial advice business when gunshots rang out one day as he was leaving work. Two bullets from a drive-by shooter pierced his head and left him permanently blind.

headline: Webb Telescope Spots a Distant Spiral Galaxy Like Our Own
abstract: LEDA 2046648 has an eerie resemblance to our Milky Way galaxy, but it lies a billion light-years away.
lead_paragraph: In the unfathomable darkness and time that is the universe, every star is an omen of hope, a promise of life and shelter, like the lights of a distant ship on a cold sea.

headline: She Left New York for a New Life, and Then Found It in the Bronx
abstract: A chef who had worked in many kitchens wanted to be her own boss. After a couple of detours, including on the Food Network’s “Chef Boot Camp,” Mott Haven beckoned.
lead_paragraph: In October of 2020, Covid was raging and Judy Anderson had a job she didn’t like. So, like a lot of pandemic-rattled workers, she quit.

headline: Have More Sex, Please!
abstract: America is in the midst of a loneliness epidemic. One solution: People should have more sex — as often as they can, as pleasurably as they can.
lead_paragraph: Sex is good. Sex is healthy. Sex is an essential part of our social fabric. And you — specifically — should probably be having more of it.

headline: Ron DeSantis Is Not Scott Walker
abstract: His support among Republicans at this early stage of the primary cycle puts him in rare company.
lead_paragraph: Is Ron DeSantis the next Scott Walker? It’s a question I’ve been hearing a lot lately.

headline: Two Women’s Basketball Coaches on the Future of the Sport
abstract: Cheryl Reeve, a three-time W.N.B.A. Coach of the Year, and Janice Washington, the new head coach at Lincoln University, discuss “the persistence of women in leadership who have pulled us forward.”
lead_paragraph: Janice Washington, head coach of the Lincoln University women’s basketball team, is hardly a newcomer to her field. Washington, 44, is in her 18th year of coaching, including stints at Daytona State College, Campbell University, Lackawanna College and Vicenza High School in Italy.

headline: Here Are the Big Themes to Look for in the Next N.F.L. Season
abstract: The Tom Brady era has ended as younger players like Patrick Mahomes make their mark, while injuries, diversity and other issues intensify.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — The N.F.L. strives to be a 365-day-a-year showcase.

headline: I Love You, Too, but Let’s Skip the Roses
abstract: The massive cut-flower industry — valued at $34 billion in 2019 — isn’t the most environmentally criminal of all commercial enterprises, but it’s far from benign.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — If you haven’t yet ordered flowers for tomorrow, you’ve likely waited too long. Valentine’s Day accounts for some 30 percent of annual cut-flower sales — more than the holiday season does, more than even Mother’s Day — so it’s very likely that all the florists in town are already booked. You’ll have better luck at your local grocery or big-box store, but you’re kidding yourself if you think this gesture won’t be recognized for what it is. Nothing says “I forgot Valentine’s Day” quite like a plastic-wrapped bouquet from a bucket by the checkout line at Target.

headline: Happiness or Success? Salesforce’s Marc Benioff Doesn’t Want to Choose.
abstract: The chief executive, under pressure from activist investors, seeks to do well and do good — but his options are narrowing.
lead_paragraph: Many years ago, Thich Nhat Hanh, the Buddhist monk and spiritual leader, posed a question to Marc Benioff, the co-founder and chief executive of Salesforce.

headline: George Santos and the Case of the Missing $365,000
abstract: Representative George Santos’s failure to account for hundreds of thousands of dollars in spending is part of a pattern of irregularities in the way his campaign handled its finances.
lead_paragraph: Representative George Santos has spent his campaign money in plenty of conspicuous ways, from lavish hotel stays in Las Vegas and Palm Beach, Fla., to an unusual slew of payments for exactly $199.99 — two cents below the threshold where receipts would be required.

headline: Beyond Silicon Valley, Spending on Technology Is Resilient
abstract: Despite an uncertain outlook, corporations plan to continue investing in their digital projects — a source of stability for the economy.
lead_paragraph: Johnson Controls traces its origin to the late 19th century in Wisconsin, where a clever teacher and inventor named Warren Johnson designed an early thermostat to turn the heat on or off in his classroom.

headline: ‘Our Losses Were Gigantic’: Life in a Sacrificial Russian Assault Wave
abstract: Poorly trained Russian soldiers captured by Ukraine describe being used as cannon fodder by commanders throwing waves of bodies into an assault.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — Creeping forward along a tree line late at night toward an entrenched Ukrainian position, the Russian soldier watched in horror as his comrades were mowed down by enemy fire.

headline: This Tool Could Protect Artists From A.I.-Generated Art That Steals Their Style
abstract: Artists want to be able to post their work online without the fear “of feeding this monster” that could replace them.
lead_paragraph: Robots would come for humans’ jobs. That was guaranteed. The assumption generally was that they would take over manual labor, lifting heavy pallets in a warehouse and sorting recycling.

headline: The College Board’s Rocky Path, Through Florida, to the A.P. Black Studies Course
abstract: The nonprofit met with Governor DeSantis’s state officials, who asked whether the course was “trying to advance Black Panther thinking.”
lead_paragraph: On the second night of Black History Month, a sparkling crowd of academics and teachers gathered at the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture to celebrate the unveiling of the first ever Advanced Placement course in African American studies.

headline: More Après, Less Ski
abstract: Conditions that are less than ideal (too little snow in some areas, too much in others) have left would-be skiers to find other forms of winter revelry.
lead_paragraph: Gregory DelliCarpini Jr. knew something was amiss as soon as he stepped off the train in Grindelwald, a village in the Swiss Alps.

headline: How Teens Recovered From the ‘TikTok Tics’
abstract: A wave of teenagers who developed tics during the pandemic has receded, illustrating the powerful influence of stress on the body and the resilience of adolescents.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The 25 Essential Dishes to Eat in Paris
abstract: We asked five chefs and culinary experts to determine the most delicious and memorable plates in the food-obsessed French capital. Here are the results.
lead_paragraph: There is perhaps no Zoom meeting less satisfying than one scheduled on a cold weekday morning to talk about food — specifically, the food that one ought to eat in Paris. We couldn’t gather in a great restaurant, for the people assembled were chefs and writers spread across continents, some racing from their kitchens, others dialing in after dropping off their children. The frenetic life we’d all once known was, in many senses, back. And so was the Paris culinary scene, driven by that thrilling hunt for places both new and old, French and not, an obsession among natives and tourists alike.

headline: China’s Top Airship Scientist Promoted Program to Watch the World From Above
abstract: Corporate records and media reports reveal an airship scientist at the center of China’s high-altitude balloon program. Companies he has founded were among those targeted by Washington.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, years before a hulking high-altitude Chinese balloon floated across the United States and caused widespread alarm, one of China’s top aeronautics scientists made a proud announcement that received little attention back then: His team had launched an airship more than 60,000 feet into the air and sent it sailing around most of the globe, including across North America.

headline: China Says U.S. Regularly Sends Balloons Into Its Airspace
abstract: The claim followed a weekend of aerial theatrics, with Washington and Beijing spotting unidentified flying objects in their airspaces.
lead_paragraph: In the latest jab over aerial surveillance, China said on Monday that high-altitude balloons from the United States had flown over Chinese airspace without permission more than 10 times since the start of last year.

headline: Russia tightens a claw around Bakhmut, as Wagner fighters claim another village.
abstract: Russian forces edged closer to Bakhmut on Sunday, claiming to capture a village on the outskirts of the strategic city in eastern Ukraine as they hammered nearby settlements with tank rounds, mortar fire and artillery shells.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces edged closer to Bakhmut on Sunday, claiming to capture a village on the outskirts of the strategic city in eastern Ukraine as they hammered nearby settlements with tank rounds, mortar fire and artillery shells.

headline: The Navy’s Very Expensive Mistake
abstract: Inside the move to retire a specific type of combat vessel.
lead_paragraph: Amid growing threats from rivals like China, the United States military is determined to invest in new forms of defense and abandon those that no longer meet its needs.

headline: Like Finland, Imagine Everything That Could Go Wrong
abstract: Natural disasters should get us thinking about how and why we prepare for the worst.
lead_paragraph: Each day, the reported death toll from the earthquake in Turkey and Syria grows. It’s not just a local tragedy killing people far away. Natural disasters have struck, and will strike, around the world — including in the United States. What are their repercussions? What lessons can be learned from them?

headline: The Next Phase in Ukraine
abstract: The war in Ukraine is entering a new phase. We explain each side’s strategy.
lead_paragraph: The war in Ukraine appears to be on the cusp of a new phase.

headline: The Artists Questioning Nostalgia for East Germany’s Past
abstract: Contemporary works are casting a new light on sentimentality for Communism.
lead_paragraph: WHEN THE ARTIST Henrike Naumann first saw “The Flintstones” on TV, she thought it depicted what life was really like in the United States. This was in 1990, when she was 6 and the Berlin Wall had just fallen, flooding Zwickau, the East German town where she was raised, with previously inaccessible Western media and products. For Naumann, the classic 1960s cartoon’s primitivist fantasy of consumer culture was foreign and exciting; revisiting the show more recently as an adult, she was shocked by its scenes of dinosaurs working as cranes and trash compactors, which the Marxist doctrine of the German Democratic Republic would have denounced as labor exploitation.

headline: A Timeline of the U.F.O.s That Were Shot Down
abstract: After a Chinese spy balloon was brought down this month, the U.S. shot down at least three unidentified flying objects.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. military shot down three unidentified flying objects over a three-day stretch this month after a Chinese spy balloon that had invaded American airspace was downed on Feb. 4, setting off a diplomatic crisis.

headline: See How Kansas City Secured Its Comeback With a 65-Yard Punt Return
abstract: In the fourth quarter, Kadarius Toney of the Kansas City Chiefs returned a punt to Philadelphia’s 5-yard line, setting up Patrick Mahomes’s third touchdown pass of the game.
lead_paragraph: In the fourth quarter, Kadarius Toney of the Kansas City Chiefs returned a punt to Philadelphia’s 5-yard line, setting up Patrick Mahomes’s third touchdown pass of the game.

headline: Shortages of Shelter and Medical Supplies Pose Dangers to Quake Survivors
abstract: A week after a powerful quake struck Turkey and Syria, the combined death toll surpassed 35,000. With more than a million homeless in Turkey alone, there is a desperate need for temporary housing.
lead_paragraph: A week after a devastating earthquake struck Turkey and Syria, with families crowded under tarps and cardboard shelters, a severe shortage of tents, housing and medical supplies is imperiling relief efforts, leaving survivors struggling amid ruins and in extreme cold.

headline: Giorgio Armani’s Life in Pictures
abstract: The Italian designer reflects on his career, from “American Gigolo” to his latest, samurai-inspired collection.
lead_paragraph: Giorgio Armani, arguably the most recognizable name in fashion, was born in 1934 in the northern Italian town of Piacenza, roughly 40 miles southeast of Milan on the swampy banks of the Po River. “As a child, and then as a teenager,” he says, “I wasn’t aware of the fashion industry, simply because the Italian fashion phenomenon had yet to happen.” Instead, Armani enrolled in 1953 at the University of Milan to become a doctor. He dropped out after three years to join the army and was later hired as a window dresser at the Milanese department store Rinascente. “One of my first fashion jobs was working alongside Nino Cerruti, who was a weaver who also had his own clothing line,” Armani says. It was there that he learned the intricacies of textile making, spending time in a weaving factory to improve his craft.

headline: The Winners and Losers from Super Bowl LVII
abstract: There were surprises on-field and off — from Rihanna’s halftime performance to Disney’s controversial ad splash.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. fans are still buzzing about the Kansas City Chiefs’ down-to-the-wire Super Bowl LVII victory, and the questionable defensive holding call that extended the game-winning drive. From Rihanna to Elon Musk, there were plenty more headlines to emerge from the game.

headline: Netanyahu’s Judicial Overhaul Sparks Huge Protests in Israel
abstract: As Benjamin Netanyahu’s government pressed ahead with plans to limit judicial influence, Israelis thronged to unusually large rallies.
lead_paragraph: A battle over the future of Israel’s judiciary — perceived by many as a fight for the soul of Israel’s democracy — grew more fraught and fractious on Monday as roughly 100,000 protesters from across the country filled the streets outside Parliament in Jerusalem in one of the biggest-ever demonstrations in the city.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of Feb. 6, 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.

headline: Wordle Wrap-Up: Feb. 6 to 12
abstract: A recap of the Wordle answers for the past week.
lead_paragraph: Hi Wordlers! Welcome to Wordle Wrap-Up, a reminder of which words were answers this week. For stories, stats and brain teasers, sign up for the Gameplay newsletter. For a daily reminder to play Wordle, sign up for reminders.

headline: $2.5 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Mediterranean-style house in the Hollywood Hills, a four-bedroom condominium in San Clemente and a Spanish-style home in Tustin.
lead_paragraph: This house is in the Hollywood Hills, about a mile from Mulholland Drive and less than a five-minute drive from Wonderland Avenue Elementary School, a highly ranked public school. It is also close to Fryman Canyon Park, where hiking trails offer sweeping views of the hills and the San Fernando Valley.

headline: Santa Cruz’s Waterfront Promenade Reaches an Inflection Point
abstract: After winter storms toppled bits of West Cliff Drive into the ocean, the seaside town grapples with how to fight erosion.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CRUZ — West Cliff Drive is not a typical neighborhood thoroughfare.

headline: Nausea, Wobbling, Confusion: Dogs Are Getting Sick From Discarded Weed
abstract: In places where recreational use is legal, dogs are getting sick from eating the remains of joints and other cannabis products, veterinarians and poison-control centers say.
lead_paragraph: On a recent weekend, Lola Star’s dog Dazzle, a mini goldendoodle just shy of 2 years old, ate a joint she found on the ground in Staten Island. It wasn’t the first or even the 10th time the dog had done this, Ms. Star said with a prolonged sigh.

headline: A Blueprint for Soccer’s Future Looks a Lot Like Its Present
abstract: Proponents of a European superleague do not lack for opposition. Those on the other side rarely have to explain why the status quo is worth saving.
lead_paragraph: The feedback to the latest proposal for a European soccer superleague could not exactly be described as positive. On Thursday, the so-called sports development company that has spent much of the last two years pitching the idea produced its latest vision of what European soccer could — no, should — look like.

headline: They Were Told Their Building Was Earthquake Safe. It Collapsed Anyway.
abstract: Some structures promoted as being built to modern seismic codes did not withstand the quake in Turkey. One upscale tower that fell may have had a design flaw, engineers said.
lead_paragraph: The upscale three-year-old housing complex of Asur in the Turkish city of Malatya, replete with chandeliers and marble floors, promised to be earthquake safe, built with the best materials to modern seismic codes. Residents in the middle-class neighborhood paid more for those assurances.

headline: Georgia Judge Will Release Parts of Report on Trump Election Inquiry
abstract: Releasing the introduction and conclusion of a special grand jury report could shed light on the extent to which Mr. Trump and others might face legal jeopardy in the case.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A Georgia judge said on Monday that he would disclose parts of a grand jury report later this week that details an investigation into election interference by former President Donald J. Trump and his allies, though he would keep the jury’s specific recommendations secret for now.

headline: Hot and Unbothered at ‘Magic Mike’
abstract: Watching the third installment of the cult-favorite dance film, with an enthusiastic crowd free to hoot and holler as much as they desired.
lead_paragraph: Excitement had been growing in the theater as 7 p.m. approached. Fake dollar bills with the words “In Abs We Trust” on one side and a photo of a man’s bare chest on the other were scattered across tables, perfect for throwing. By the time the “Warner Bros.” logo flashed across the screen, people were already erupting in screams.

headline: Searching for the Perfect Texture
abstract: Menudo, mochi brownies and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: People with different flavor obsessions tend to appreciate each other’s passions — lemon lovers understand chocoholics, and chile fiends click with squint-seeking sour-candy obsessives. But when it comes to texture, there can be a mutual incomprehension. I happen to love anything squishy, springy, chewy, wobbly or displaying the soft elasticity called Q or QQ in Taiwan, and I think everyone else should, too. My husband, however, just doesn’t understand my predilection.

headline: Rihanna at the Super Bowl
abstract: Were you watching last night? Are you a fan? What did you think?
lead_paragraph: A fashion critic from The Times’s Style section writes:

headline: At Stake in the Ukraine-Russia War
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay by Christopher Caldwell that blamed the U.S. for an escalation in the war. Also: Mask mandates; the next pandemic; YouTube.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Layoffs? Top Wall Street Traders Score Giant Paydays
abstract: Some large hedge funds that profited off the recent market volatility are wooing traders with tens of millions of dollars in guaranteed payouts.
lead_paragraph: As workers around the country frantically negotiate severance packages amid tens of thousands of layoffs, employees in a tiny, influential and often secretive corner of Wall Street are being promised some of their biggest paydays ever.

headline: SZA’s ‘SOS’ Is the No. 1 Album for an Eighth Time
abstract: The R&B singer-songwriter has matched Taylor Swift’s run with “Folklore,” the last time a female artist held the No. 1 spot on Billboard’s chart for eight weeks.
lead_paragraph: SZA is not done with No. 1 yet.

headline: Ted Lerner, 97, Dies; Developer Bought and Built Washington Nationals
abstract: A billionaire and Washington native, he gave the city its first baseball championship in 95 years, along with 20 million square feet of shopping malls and housing.
lead_paragraph: Ted Lerner, the billionaire real estate developer who bought the floundering Washington Nationals in 2006 and oversaw their thrilling rise to 2019 World Series victors, rewarding his native city with its first major league championship in 95 years, died on Sunday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 97.

headline: A New Kind of Food Candle Evokes Memories, and Garlic
abstract: A pantry’s worth of savory food scents, from burgers to croissants to latkes, are finding their way into luxury candles.
lead_paragraph: There’s a mild, wheaty aroma wafting from the host stand at the Midtown Manhattan pasta restaurant Jupiter. It’s not from the pasta. An herbaceous, vegetal smell fills the bathrooms at Horses, a high-end bistro in Los Angeles. It’s not from vegetables.

headline: A Vehicle for Social Justice, Bound for the Frieze Art Fair
abstract: With his family’s old tortilla delivery van and brightly colored tamale carts, Ruben Ochoa will highlight the economic challenges and harassment endured by Los Angeles street vendors.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — This beige 1985 Chevy cargo van has been around the block. When the artist Ruben Ochoa was young, his parents used it for selling tortillas on a route north of San Diego. As a graduate student in the early ’00s, he used it to commute from Los Angeles to Irvine. And during that time he also transformed it into a fly-by-night, no-rent art gallery, inviting other artists and curators to take it over, hanging paintings inside, plastering the back with bumper stickers or creating a halfpipe on the roof.

headline: What Does Jay Shetty Know About Love?
abstract: After bringing meditation to the online masses, the former monk wants to fix your relationships.
lead_paragraph: On a frigid February morning, Jay Shetty joined Drew Barrymore as a co-host on her talk show for an episode about love. “No one is smarter and better” at talking about love than him, Ms. Barrymore declared, before bringing Mr. Shetty to the stage.

headline: Two Years Since a Sudden Collapse, Keyontae Johnson Is Proving He’s OK
abstract: On Dec. 12, 2020, Keyontae Johnson collapsed during a game. Now, he’s a key member of the Kansas State men’s basketball team and on the watch list for the John R. Wooden Award.
lead_paragraph: One moment, Keyontae Johnson was soaring to the hoop to convert an alley-oop.

headline: After Four Turbulent Years, Lori Lightfoot Seeks a Second Term as Chicago’s Mayor
abstract: Elected in an upset four years ago, Lori Lightfoot is presiding over a bruised city, one wary in particular about crime.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Mayor Lori Lightfoot met recently with two dozen Chicagoans at a campaign event in a plush apartment building in the city’s affluent Lincoln Park neighborhood. Before long, she shifted into the rapid-fire mode that defined her career before City Hall, when she was a federal prosecutor known for her tenacity.

headline: Man in U-Haul Mows Down 8 People in Brooklyn ‘Rampage,’ Killing 1
abstract: Seven other civilians and a police officer were hospitalized after a man drove erratically through Bay Ridge and Sunset Park. The suspect was arrested several miles away.
lead_paragraph: A man driving a U-Haul truck cut a violent swath across Brooklyn on Monday morning, careening through Bay Ridge and Sunset Park, over sidewalks and into bicycles, killing one man before the police finally caught up with him.

headline: Did a Referee’s Call Unfairly Cost the Eagles a Super Bowl Win?
abstract: Philadelphia cornerback James Bradberry admitted he tugged on the jersey of a Kansas City receiver. But was it really a penalty? The answer depends largely on what colors you wear.
lead_paragraph: What’s the one play that is most remembered from a really big game? A ninth-inning strikeout from an ace reliever? A leaping save by a keeper? A powerful dunk in overtime?

headline: Teen Girls Report Record Levels of Sadness, C.D.C. Finds
abstract: Adolescent girls reported high rates of sadness, suicidal thoughts and sexual violence, as did teenagers who identified as gay or bisexual.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three in five teenage girls felt persistent sadness in 2021, double the rate of boys, and one in three girls seriously considered attempting suicide, according to data released on Monday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Review: Bach Collegium Japan Returns With Chamber Music
abstract: Players from the ensemble came to New York to perform works by Bach, Telemann and Johann Gottlieb Janitsch at the 92nd Street Y, New York.
lead_paragraph: At the 92nd Street Y, New York, on Sunday, Bach Collegium Japan — led by its founder and music director, Masaaki Suzuki — brought bold, brisk style to chamber works by its eponymous composer and his contemporaries.

headline: Ukrainians Demonstrate Training on Leopard Tanks in Poland
abstract: Kyiv’s troops are getting a crash course in using the German-made tanks, less than three weeks after Berlin agreed, under pressure from Poland and others, to let them go to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: SWIETOSZOW, Poland — One by one, Leopard tanks crewed by Ukrainian troops and their Polish instructors zipped up a muddy field, bouncing over deep ruts and cresting a low dirt berm. They stopped, fired smoke grenades, then raced back in reverse to their starting points.

headline: Ford Will Build a U.S. Battery Factory With Technology From China
abstract: Ford’s $3.5 billion plant in Michigan will draw on technology from CATL, a Chinese company that is the world’s No. 1 maker of electric-car batteries.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor said on Monday that it planned to build a $3.5 billion electric-vehicle battery factory in Michigan using technology licensed from a Chinese company that has become one of the most important players in the auto industry.

headline: Studies Show How Cupid Isn’t Fair
abstract: What the birds and the bees teach us about income inequality.
lead_paragraph: Birds do it. Bees do it. Even intertidal gonochoric prosobranchs do it. And human beings definitely do it. “It” is assortative mating, in which creatures tend to couple with those that are most like them. Case in point: One in four female physicians is married to another physician.

headline: Trugoy the Dove of De La Soul’s 10 Essential Songs
abstract: The Long Island rapper David Jolicoeur, known for his freewheeling rhyme style, has died at 54, just weeks before his trio’s catalog arrives on streaming services.
lead_paragraph: David Jolicoeur, best known as the rapper Trugoy the Dove of the climate-shifting rap group De La Soul, weathered decades of industry shifts with acerbic wit, oblique rhyme styles and intense bouts of self-reflection that flew in the face of hip-hop’s boast-centric bottom line.

headline: South Carolina Reasserts Itself Atop Women’s Hoops With L.S.U. Win
abstract: The undefeated teams played on Super Bowl Sunday, giving women’s college basketball its latest showcase game.
lead_paragraph: South Carolina Coach Dawn Staley was certainly dressed for a big game on Sunday.

headline: 15 Prompts for Talking and Writing About Friendship
abstract: Questions to help students reflect on the meaning of friendship in their lives
lead_paragraph: Who are your closest friends? How much do you share with them? Do you actually like your friends? What have you learned from them?

headline: How Students Can Cultivate Meaningful Friendships Using The New York Times
abstract: These practical strategies help educators reflect on their own social ties and support their students in building strong, healthy relationships.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 1, The Times’s Well section kicked off The 7-Day Happiness Challenge, which focuses on cultivating meaningful relationships. The author, Jancee Dunn, explains this choice, writing that from all the data on what makes a person thrive, one clear finding has emerged:

headline: 4-2 Game Rekindles Shot Clock Debate in High School Basketball
abstract: One of the two teams from Oklahoma, the Anadarko High School Warriors, passed the ball around for nearly the entire game in what an announcer called “stall ball.”
lead_paragraph: Something strange happened during a recent high school basketball game in Oklahoma.

headline: Why a U.S. Plane Shot Down an Object Over Canada
abstract: The plane was part of NORAD, a defense organization operated jointly by the U.S. and Canada.
lead_paragraph: In a move that may have confused Americans and Canadians alike, the second of the three unidentified flying objects shot down in the past few days was downed over Canada, on the orders of the Canadian prime minister — by a United States F-22.

headline: For Burt Bacharach, ‘Promises, Promises’ Was One Broadway Hit Too Many
abstract: The perfectionist composer was content with being a one-hit musical-theater wonder, calling the experience the hardest thing he had ever done.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1960s, when Broadway show tunes and popular music were veering in opposite directions, the producer David Merrick, one of the most hidebound curmudgeons on Broadway, reached out to one of the most successful American pop composers of the time: Burt Bacharach.

headline: Robert Geddes, 99, Transformative Architecture Dean at Princeton, Dies
abstract: As an educator, he worked to put architecture on an equal footing with other disciplines. As an architect, he was known for buildings at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton.
lead_paragraph: Robert Geddes, the transformative first dean of Princeton’s School of Architecture and an architect of elegant modernist buildings, many in New Jersey and his native Pennsylvania, died on Monday  at his home outside Princeton, N.J. He was 99.

headline: Biden Removes the Top Capitol Facilities Official Amid Allegations of Wrongdoing
abstract: After a damning report and a committee hearing in which lawmakers in both parties condemned his actions, the president ousted J. Brett Blanton, the architect of the Capitol, from his post.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Monday fired J. Brett Blanton, the federal official responsible for the maintenance and operation of the Capitol complex, amid bipartisan calls for his resignation after an investigative report accusing him of misusing his position and revelations that he avoided the Capitol during the Jan. 6, 2021, attack.

headline: After the Ohio Train Derailment: Evacuations, Toxic Chemicals and Water Worries
abstract: When a train derailed in the village of East Palestine on Feb. 3, it set off evacuation orders, a chemical scare and a federal investigation.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 3, a train carrying toxic chemicals derailed in eastern Ohio, igniting a fire that covered the town of East Palestine in smoke. Fearful of an explosion, the authorities carved out an evacuation zone and carried out a controlled release of toxic fumes to neutralize burning cargo inside some of the train cars.

headline: At Halftime, Patrick Mahomes Got a Little Tape and Gave a Little Talk
abstract: His ankle hurt after a hit in the second quarter of the Super Bowl, but mostly, he said, he wanted to fire up his teammates.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — It was right before halftime of Sunday’s Super Bowl, and Kansas City trailed Philadelphia, 21-14, when Eagles linebacker T.J. Edwards chased down Chiefs quarterback Patrick Mahomes and landed on his already-tender ankle.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Balloon Tensions Escalate
abstract: Diplomatic tensions between the U.S. and China escalated as the U.S. tried to explain its downing of three unidentified flying objects over the weekend and China accused the U.S. of sending its own unauthorized high-altitude balloons over Chinese airspace.
lead_paragraph: Diplomatic tensions between the U.S. and China escalated as the U.S. tried to explain its downing of three unidentified flying objects over the weekend and China accused the U.S. of sending its own unauthorized high-altitude balloons over Chinese airspace.

headline: That Bright Flash in the Sky Came From Space
abstract: An asteroid's explosion in the atmosphere lit up areas around the English Channel and as far away as the Netherlands on Monday.
lead_paragraph: An asteroid's explosion in the atmosphere lit up areas around the English Channel and as far away as the Netherlands on Monday.

headline: Top Oregon Liquor Official Resigns Amid Accusations of Bourbon Hoarding
abstract: An internal inquiry had found that Steve Marks, executive director of the Oregon Liquor and Cannabis Commission, and other officials had diverted bottles of rare bourbons so they could buy them in stores.
lead_paragraph: The executive director of Oregon’s liquor control agency announced his resignation on Monday amid a criminal investigation into accusations that top officials had hoarded bottles of top-shelf spirits including rare bourbons that can fetch more than $5,000 on the secondary market.

headline: United Flight From Maui Came Within 800 Feet of Striking Pacific Ocean
abstract: The plane, a Boeing 777-200, climbed to 2,200 feet on Dec. 18 before entering a steep dive and falling at a rate of nearly 8,600 feet per minute, according to flight data.
lead_paragraph: In December, about a minute after a United Airlines flight departed from Kahului Airport in Maui, the plane, a Boeing 777-200, entered a steep dive and came within 775 feet of the surface of the Pacific Ocean, according to flight data.

headline: Questions About Money to Ask While Dating
abstract: What should you ask a love interest and when? Lindsay Bryan-Podvin, a financial therapist, offers this timeline.
lead_paragraph: What should you ask a love interest and when? Lindsay Bryan-Podvin, a financial therapist, offers this timeline.

headline: Disney Toasts a Century as Business and Political Challenges Mount
abstract: The company is opening two exhibitions that will tour the globe until 2028. It comes at a moment when its formidable stature in the culture has shown a few cracks.
lead_paragraph: Walt Disney has been dead for nearly 57 years. In the coming weeks, however, he will begin greeting museum visitors on two continents.

headline: Choreographer Smears Dog Feces on Critic After Negative Review
abstract: Marco Goecke has been suspended from his position as ballet director at Hanover’s main opera house after he smeared excrement on a critic’s face.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, Wiebke Hüster, a German dance critic, was taking a break from watching a ballet program at Hanover’s main opera house when the choreographer Marco Goecke appeared in front of her.

headline: Share These Scandinavian Pastries for Carnival Season
abstract: Specialties from Scandinavia House and Ole & Steen, Kerber’s Farm comes to the West Village and more.
lead_paragraph: The celebration of Carnival — occurring this year just before Lent begins on Wednesday, Feb. 22 — is marked in Scandinavia with yeasted pastries variously called semlor (Swedish), fastelavnsboller (Danish) and laskiaispulla (Finnish), depending on the country. Made from cardamom-scented pastry, they’re split and overflowing with custard or whipped cream. In New York, Björk Café & Bistro in Scandinavia House will sell semlor all month, $8 each; and Ole & Steen, the Danish bakery with three locations in Manhattan and more to come, is also selling fastelavnsboller this month in vanilla, chocolate-raspberry, blueberry-hazelnut and coffee-caramel, $8.

headline: Champions League Failures Are ‘Wake-Up Call’ for Paris Olympics, Report Says
abstract: Investigators blamed UEFA for the security failures at last year’s Liverpool-Real Madrid final, and concluded it was only “a matter of chance” that no fans died.
lead_paragraph: A monthslong independent investigation into the dangerous overcrowding that jeopardized the safety of thousands of fans at last year’s Champions League final in Paris has placed the blame squarely on European soccer’s governing body, which organized the game. That no lives were lost in the crushes outside the stadium gates, the investigators’ harshly critical report concluded, was only “a matter of chance.”

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: G.O.P. Legislative Agenda Hits Snags Amid Party Divisions
abstract: Republicans have pulled back on legislation to crack down on unauthorized immigrants and support law enforcement as internal disputes conspire with a tiny majority to freeze them in place.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bill targeting progressive prosecutors whom Republicans have long considered too lenient is facing a wall of opposition from libertarian-leaning members of Congress.

headline: After Teen’s Suicide, a New Jersey Community Grapples With Bullying
abstract: Amid grief and outrage over the death of Adriana Kuch, 14, students have mounted protests, and a schools superintendent has resigned.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen-year-old Adriana Kuch told her father that she could not bear the humiliation after she was attacked by another girl inside her New Jersey high school and a clip of the assault was posted to TikTok.

headline: Flaco the Owl Caught on Camera After Leaving Zoo Enclosure
abstract: The Eurasian eagle-owl Flaco was spotted sitting atop a branch in Central Park after leaving his damaged enclosure in the park’s zoo.
lead_paragraph: The Eurasian eagle-owl Flaco was spotted sitting atop a branch in Central Park after leaving his damaged enclosure in the park’s zoo.

headline: Bally’s Casino Proposal May Hinge on Removal of One Word: Trump
abstract: With the Trump name mostly anathema in New York, Bally’s is pinning its hopes for a Bronx-based casino on a vow to sever Trump’s name from a golf course there.
lead_paragraph: For years, anyone going across the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge in New York has had to cast their eyes on former President Donald J. Trump’s surname, emblazoned in paving stones at the entrance to the public golf course he controls in the Bronx.

headline: Syria’s President Agrees to 2 More Border Crossings for Quake Aid
abstract: The decision is the first time that President Bashar al-Assad has agreed to the cross-border delivery of humanitarian aid to opposition-held territory since the civil war began.
lead_paragraph: Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, has agreed to the opening of two additional border crossings from Turkey into opposition-held territory in northwest Syria to allow the United Nations to deliver humanitarian relief to millions of earthquake victims, U.N. and Syrian officials said on Monday.

headline: Feeling Abandoned by the World in a Stricken Corner of Syria
abstract: Since a disastrous earthquake a week ago, little international aid has come to the hard-hit northwest of Syria, which is under the control of opposition forces.
lead_paragraph: AL-ATARIB, Syria — For years, northwestern Syria has been home to millions of people displaced by war, so many that neighbor no longer knew neighbor. And so when an earthquake struck last week and homes were reduced to rubble, many couldn’t say with certainty who had been accounted for and who was still missing.

headline: Carlos Saura, a Leading and Enduring Spanish Director, Dies at 91
abstract: Called “one of the fundamental filmmakers in the history of Spanish cinema,” he began making movies under Franco, often hiding his messages in allegory.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Saura, a Spanish director who began making films during the regime of Francisco Franco and was still making them at his death, exploring Spanish identity through allegory-rich storytelling and, later, vividly capturing flamenco and other art forms, died on Friday. He was 91.

headline: Bike-Path Terror Defendant Is Too Dangerous for Prison, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Sayfullo Saipov must die by lethal injection, they argue on the first day of his trial’s punishment phase.
lead_paragraph: A federal prosecutor told a Manhattan jury on Monday that Sayfullo Saipov, who drove a truck down a crowded West Side bike path in 2017, mowing down eight people without mercy in a terrorist attack, had “not abandoned his jihad, his fight.”

headline: The G.O.P.’s Long War Against Medicare and Social Security
abstract: Biden isn’t playing gotcha; there’s a lot of history here.
lead_paragraph: Politically, the most crucial moment in President Biden’s State of the Union address was his declaration that “some Republicans want Medicare and Social Security to sunset every five years.” Why did he say that? Maybe because Senator Rick Scott, when he was the chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, released a fiscal plan last year with the bullet point “All federal legislation sunsets in five years.”

headline: Ukraine Bars Aid Workers From Bakhmut as Russia Tightens Its Grip
abstract: With Moscow’s forces closing in, the besieged city is too dangerous for the volunteers, Ukrainian commanders said, in what could be a prelude to a Ukrainian withdrawal.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s military on Monday barred aid workers and civilians from entering Bakhmut, saying it was too perilous as Russian forces tightened their grip, in what could be a prelude to a Ukrainian withdrawal and the biggest tactical gain for the deeply troubled Russian invasion since July.

headline: Tensions Rise Over Spy Programs as U.S. Investigates Downed Craft
abstract: The Biden administration is looking into mysterious U.F.O. encounters and pushing back against China over accusations of widespread espionage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tensions between the United States and China escalated on Monday as the two nations traded fiery accusations over spying programs, in the aftermath of the U.S. downing of a Chinese spy balloon and three unidentified flying objects a week later over North America.

headline: A Left-Leaning College Didn’t Want to Offend, So It Closed Down Her Art Show
abstract: How have we forgotten that art needn’t defer to religion?
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL, Minn. — The work of the Iranian American artist Taravat Talepasand is cheeky, erotic and defiantly anticlerical. One painting in her new midcareer survey, “Taravat,” incorporates Iranian bank notes whose images of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini have been dosed with LSD. A graphite drawing, titled “Blasphemy X,” depicts a veiled woman giving the finger while lifting her robe to reveal high heels and a flash of underwear. There are sculptures of women in niqab face coverings with enormous exposed breasts. On a gallery wall, “Woman, Life, Freedom,” the slogan of Iran’s recent nationwide protests against the morality police, is written in neon in English and Persian.

headline: Packed With Tourists, Japan Returns to Economic Growth
abstract: The modest expansion in the fourth quarter of 2022 was driven by a recovery in private consumption, as well as spending by visitors.
lead_paragraph: After more than two years under some of the world’s tightest border controls, Japan is once again open for business. Tourist spots are packed. Hotels are booked out well in advance. And it’s getting harder to get a seat at many of the country’s best restaurants.

headline: A Surprise Pick to Lead the Bank of Japan Faces a Wrenching Choice
abstract: Kazuo Ueda is set to replace the longtime governor who helped put the country on an unorthodox monetary path. Will he change course?
lead_paragraph: Over the last several months, many people were mentioned as possible replacements for Haruhiko Kuroda, the long-serving governor of the Bank of Japan, who has captained the country’s decade-long experiment with ultra-easy money and rock-bottom interest rates.

headline: Second Sight
abstract: Ella Dershowitz’s tasty theme may have you experiencing a bit of déjà vu.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Shooting at Michigan State University Adds to Death Toll on Campuses
abstract: The biggest mass shooting on a college campus was at Virginia Tech in 2008, where a gunman killed 33 people.
lead_paragraph: The violence at Michigan State University on Monday was the latest episode in a string of mass shootings on college campuses in the United States over the past few decades.

headline: At the Oscar Nominees Luncheon, a Crowd in Cruise Control
abstract: The “Top Gun: Maverick” star and producer is mobbed as Austin Butler, Angela Bassett, Ke Huy Quan and others angle to chat with him.
lead_paragraph: For the privileged few embarking on an Oscar campaign, the path to a nomination asks you to hobnob with so many of the same people that over the course of many months, your competitors can begin to feel like classmates.

headline: Secretive Network Rescues Russia’s Antiwar Dissidents in Nick of Time
abstract: Hundreds of people facing long prison sentences are being spirited out of the country by groups that arrange daring escapes, with one trip using six different cars over more than 4,000 miles.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Protests over proposed judicial changes in Israel.
lead_paragraph: As a battle over the future of Israel’s judiciary — perceived by many as a fight for the soul of the country’s democracy — intensifies, roughly 100,000 protesters filled the streets outside Parliament in Jerusalem yesterday. Carrying Israeli flags, megaphones and banners, they chanted for democracy, freedom and judicial independence.

headline: Want to Live on the McGraw-Hill Building’s 32nd Floor?
abstract: The Landmarks Preservation Commission is considering an application for mixed use at the exuberant Midtown skyscraper.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at a new plan that would bring apartments to a landmark Art Deco office building in Midtown Manhattan. We’ll also look at how a typographical error is complicating the road toward life after prison for some felons in New York.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Teen Girls Report Record Levels of Sadness
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 14, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Young people are telling us that they are in crisis.”

headline: Corrections: Feb. 14, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Feb. 14, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about Turkey’s detention of building contractors as the earthquake death toll grows misstated the action taken by the Turkish government against more than 100 contractors in connection to buildings that collapsed in Monday’s earthquake. Warrants were issued for their arrests. They were not all detained.

headline: The Striker Who Waited for the Champions League to Find Him
abstract: Eric-Maxim Choupo-Moting was never a can’t-miss talent. But as he leads Bayern Munich against P.S.G., he has proved he belongs right where he is.
lead_paragraph: There were always plenty of things about Eric-Maxim Choupo-Moting that caught the eye. The scouts dispatched to watch him tended to find that his build grabbed their attention first: tall but not rangy; broad-shouldered and muscular but lean. What held it, though, was everything else.

headline: Word of the Day: adamant
abstract: This word has appeared in 166 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word adamant has appeared in 166 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 30 in “Creating the Exiled Sea Creature of ‘Avatar: The Way of Water’” by Carlos Aguilar:

headline: Late Night Recaps Rihanna’s Super Bowl Halftime Surprise
abstract: Jimmy Kimmel called the pop singer’s pregnancy reveal “the biggest ‘we’re expecting’ announcement in the history of the world.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Picture Prompt: A ChatGPT Valentine
abstract: Play with The Times’s A. I. valentine generator and see what you think of the results.
lead_paragraph: Note to teachers: Please preview this tool to make sure it is appropriate for your students.

headline: Binge Drinking May Be Curbed With a Pill
abstract: A recent study suggested the use of a decades-old medicine taken before imbibing could reduce the amount of alcohol consumed.
lead_paragraph: Ever wake up regretting the last round of drinks from the previous night? There’s a medicine that might help.

headline: In the Archives, Finding Love (Stories)
abstract: Journalists have always ventured into the shifting world of romance.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, ’80s and ’90s, New York Times articles slowly, and painfully, updated the rules of courtship. To have success dating in New York City, don’t order a sandwich at dinner and pick a restaurant with candlelight. (Otherwise, you might look “embalmed.”) Women are allowed to date men who are shorter — gasp — and even younger than them. A woman could indeed pick up the check. (Though some women, instead of putting their credit cards down at the table, preferred to slyly offer it to the maître d’hôtel before the meal to not bruise their dates’ egos.) There was even hope for single women over 35, according to one author of a book on marriage — if only they outgrow their “fantasies of knights in armor.”

headline: The Changing Online Language of Hearts
abstract: How to show a heart — the universal symbol of love — has shifted on the internet over the years, driven by new technology.
lead_paragraph: Take your middle fingers and bend each down at the bottom knuckle at a steep angle. Then take your index fingers and arch them down to touch. The rest of your hands curl out of sight.

headline: Fear Gripped Michigan State University as Gunman Roamed Campus
abstract: Students and nearby residents waited anxiously for hours as the police searched for the 43-year-old gunman. He later died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound.
lead_paragraph: EAST LANSING, Mich. — Jane Nodland had just arrived at the Michigan State University Union, a four-story gathering space with meeting rooms, a restaurant and a small store, to do homework on Monday night with her boyfriend.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Guided Missile Killed U.S. Aid Worker in Ukraine, Video Shows
abstract: A Times analysis suggests that an intentional strike, not an indiscriminate attack, most likely killed Pete Reed. It is unclear whether the attackers knew he was with a group of aid workers.
lead_paragraph: Roughly a minute after an American paramedic, Pete Reed, and a team of aid workers began tending to a wounded civilian in the Ukrainian city of Bakhmut on Feb. 2, they were attacked. Mr. Reed, a former U.S. Marine volunteering on the war’s front lines, was killed, and several of his colleagues were wounded.

headline: China Tries to Depict Furor Over Spy Balloon as Sign of U.S. Decline
abstract: Ignoring charges of spying, Beijing says Washington’s “overreaction” is a symptom of the country’s broken politics.
lead_paragraph: While many in the world see the Chinese spy balloon as a sign of Beijing’s growing aggressiveness, China has sought to cast the controversy as a symptom of the United States’ irrevocable decline.

headline: A Brief History of Hating My Face
abstract: “It’s really, really hard to live when you’re constantly focused on how you look.”
lead_paragraph: “It’s really, really hard to live when you’re constantly focused on how you look.”

headline: What Rom-Coms Teach Us About Love, Life and Meg Ryan’s Hair
abstract: A quiz about familiar (and troubling) romantic-comedy cliches.
lead_paragraph: A quiz about familiar (and troubling) romantic-comedy cliches.

headline: What the World Can Learn From Gay-Straight Friendships
abstract: These relationships can help us be more free to be you and me.
lead_paragraph: At around midnight in a sweaty crowd at Crews & Tangos, one of Toronto’s popular L.G.B.T.Q. bars, I watched my friend hop onstage to rip a shot of tequila with Jada Shada Hudson, our favorite drag performer, as Nicki Minaj’s “Super Bass” pulsated through the venue.

headline: Can One City Be a Microcosm of Everything That’s Wrong?
abstract: In his new book, “Palo Alto,” Malcolm Harris makes the case that the story of his hometown represents way more than you might expect.
lead_paragraph: Malcolm Harris’s “Palo Alto” starts with a grim reality: a spate of youth suicides in the titular small city where he spent much of his childhood. Many of the young people who killed themselves stepped in front of the CalTrain, a railroad formerly owned by the Southern Pacific, the once all-powerful monopoly co-owned by Leland Stanford, the founder of Palo Alto and Stanford University. “We have a word for idyllic towns where the youth suicide rate is three times as high as it’s supposed to be: haunted,” Harris writes, by “the kinds of large historical crimes that, once committed, can never truly be set right.”

headline: How the $500 Billion Attention Industry Really Works
abstract: Your attention is constantly being bought, packaged and sold. Tim Hwang explains how.
lead_paragraph: For most of us, seeing an advertisement pop up while we’re scrolling on Instagram or reading an article or watching a video is the most banal experience possible. But in the background of those experiences is a $500 billion marketplace where our attention is being bought, packaged and sold at split-second speeds virtually every minute of every day. Online advertising is the economic engine of the internet, and that engine is fueled by our attention.

headline: A Brief History of Hating My Face
abstract: “It’s really, really hard to live when you’re constantly focused on how you look.”
lead_paragraph: Shaina Feinberg feels horrible about how she looks. This anguish has consumed an incalculable amount of her life. She classifies her self-loathing as body dysmorphic disorder, a condition in which people fixate on perceived flaws in their appearance, causing significant emotional distress.

headline: No More Spring Trainings
abstract: John Jaso walked away from Major League Baseball at 34, potentially leaving millions of dollars on the table. The sea was calling.
lead_paragraph: John Jaso knew he wanted to retire, so he started shopping for sailboats. It was the 2017 season, and Jaso, the Pittsburgh Pirates’ first baseman, would spend his downtime at home browsing on boat websites. And when the Pirates visited a team near a body of water, he would wander the marinas and imagine himself on the open water.

headline: A Secret for Falling Asleep So Good It’s a British National Treasure
abstract: Tune into serenity with the BBC Shipping Forecast, a weather report from deep in the analog era.
lead_paragraph: Most nights I don’t sleep well, so to relax, I often listen to audiobooks or the radio. Other people’s words keep me from sliding into the canyon of doom, where all around shouts of “you’re screwed” reverberate. For many months I put on murder mysteries, but in an effort to embrace a more soothing sort of rest, I have started listening to compilations of the Shipping Forecast, a BBC Radio 4 production that is no fancier than its name suggests: It is, simply, a program featuring weather reports that narrate the gales and tides around the British Isles. If some people doze off to the sound of rain, I fall asleep to broadcasters announcing the rain that is to come.

headline: Portrait of the Artist as a Young Chambermaid
abstract: “The Applicant,” a debut novel by Nazli Koca, features a worldly-wise 20-something Turkish writer who works as a cleaner at a Berlin hostel while struggling to figure out what kind of life she wants to lead.
lead_paragraph: About halfway through Nazli Koca’s debut novel, “The Applicant,” the narrator, 26-year-old Leyla, finally reads “My Brilliant Friend.” She’d found a copy of the book two months earlier, during a shift at the Berlin hostel where she works as a cleaner, but her attempts at starting it had failed; the fictional childhoods of Elena Ferrante’s characters Lila and Elena reminded Leyla too much of her own unhappy childhood in Turkey.

headline: Twitter’s Glitches Are Taking a Toll on Chinese Activists
abstract: As the Elon Musk-owned social media service encounters interruptions and bugs, Chinese dissidents and activists said they feared they were being muzzled.
lead_paragraph: In November, Bao Pu, a veteran human rights activist who was visiting Beijing, posted videos on Twitter of university protests against China’s tough coronavirus lockdown orders. He gained over 10,000 followers in subsequent weeks.

headline: Two Novels Confront Violence Against Women
abstract: Two new books — “Brutes,” by Dizz Tate, and “On the Savage Side,” by Tiffany McDaniel — challenge and reshape the way stories about abused and murdered women are told.
lead_paragraph: A preacher’s daughter disappears in the swamplands of Florida. An empty bedroom, a ripped window screen, a small town in panic. A chorus of echoes asking: Where is Sammy?

headline: Democrats Meddle Again in a G.O.P. Primary, This Time Down-Ballot
abstract: In a race for a State Senate seat in Wisconsin, Democrats are replicating their midterm strategy of elevating far-right Republicans in hopes of beating them in the general election.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Democrats spent millions of dollars elevating far-right candidates in Republican primary contests for governor and Congress — betting, it turned out correctly, that more extreme opponents would lose general elections.

headline: Is It a Campus or a Powder Keg? In This Novel, It’s Both.
abstract: In her new novel, “The Laughter,” Sonora Jha satirizes academia by following an older, white male professor who is lusting after his younger, Pakistani colleague, all while a student protest brews.
lead_paragraph: The campus novel is a well-worn genre. We’ve already read about the hapless white men in their early middle age, navigating the politics of uptight English departments and falling hopelessly in love with bewitching undergraduates. Each of these academics has his arcane specialization, and each laments the rising tide of social consciousness among his students: Will the forces of cultural relativism not stop until every university, every haven of logical thought and rational inquiry, is burned completely to the ground? Unfortunately for the men in Sonora Jha’s new novel, “The Laughter,” the answer may very well be yes.

headline: Let Us Eat Lungs
abstract: The Department of Agriculture’s ban on the organ makes no medical sense.
lead_paragraph: Federal policy in the United States allows butchers to sell virtually every part of an animal’s body as human food, with one notable exception: the lungs. In 1971 the Department of Agriculture declared animal lungs unfit “for use as human food” and banned them from the commercial food supply.

headline: What Is Something You Want to Try, Even Though Others Might Think It’s Weird?
abstract: The New York Dippers Club meets every morning to plunge into icy cold water. Is that something you would want to do?
lead_paragraph: What’s one experience — that might be considered strange or extreme to some — that you would want to have? Perhaps plunging into ice-cold water, bungee jumping or sand surfing? Or competing in a chili pepper eating contest, an all-night dance-a-thon or an ultramarathon? What is it about the activity that appeals to you?

headline: Why Do I Feel Butterflies in My Stomach When I’m on a Date?
abstract: Sometimes your gut seems to have a mind of its own — and in a way it does.
lead_paragraph: Q: What is the biology behind the butterflies sensation people get when they’re excited about dating someone new?

headline: Long Before RuPaul, Doris Fish Wore the Wig. Fiercely.
abstract: In “Who Does That Bitch Think She Is?” Craig Seligman resurrects the life and fabulousness of a drag queen who flourished in AIDS-era San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: From wee-hours cabaret to prime-time reality TV to fiercely contended children’s story hour at the local library, the American drag queen’s journey has been a long and bumpy one.

headline: Food Prices Weigh on Seniors’ Savings, Health and Even Social Ties
abstract: As costs rise, many older Americans have changed the way they shop and eat out. For some, it could affect their health or leave them feeling isolated.
lead_paragraph: For the better part of the past year, Marilynn Miller stretched her food budget.

headline: How Do You Solve a Problem Like the Rom-Com? Three Comedians Try.
abstract: In the podcast “Let’s Make a Rom-Com,” the hosts attempt to put the spark back into a familiar and underrated genre.
lead_paragraph: Mark Chavez thought that it would be so simple. Chavez, a Vancouver-based actor and comic, had seen plenty of romantic comedies. He understood the deep structure of the genre, the various story beats that pushed a couple from meet cute to final clinch.

headline: Sarah Huckabee Sanders Has a Funny Idea of What the Republican Party Should Be
abstract: The G.O.P. does not seem to care much about winning over a majority of voters.
lead_paragraph: The most striking thing about the Republican response to President Biden’s State of the Union last week, delivered this year by Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders of Arkansas, was that it wasn’t actually pitched to the American public at large.

headline: Flaco the Owl Spreads His Wings, Devours Rats and Learns to Survive
abstract: An eagle-owl out of the zoo and loose in Central Park shows he can hunt, prompting officials to pause and re-evaluate recovery efforts.
lead_paragraph: Halley Barton was at a dinner party with friends on Saturday night when someone in the group shared the news that the Eurasian eagle-owl Flaco had coughed up a pellet of animal matter — rat fur and bones — in Central Park.

headline: DeSantis’s Latest Target: A Small College of ‘Free Thinkers’
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis’s plan to transform New College of Florida into a beacon of conservatism has left students and faculty members at the tight-knit, progressive school reeling.
lead_paragraph: SARASOTA, Fla. — After her son began attending New College of Florida, Dr. Sonia Howman felt a pang of fear about the future of the small, little-known public liberal arts school on the shores of Sarasota Bay.

headline: How to Find a Fancy Vintage Purse
abstract: What’s a good deal? Where should you look?
lead_paragraph: The ubiquity of certain “it” handbags on social media can create a feeling of snow blindness when you’re scrolling online. If you want to break out of that trend cycle, the solution is obvious: Get a vintage bag.

headline: Italy’s Hard-Right Leader Vexes Europe by Playing Nice, Mostly
abstract: Some still fear an authoritarian turn, but Giorgia Meloni has surprised many by showing a pragmatic streak since coming to power. Now Europe is not sure what to do.
lead_paragraph: ROME — In the weeks before Italy elected the hard-right leader Giorgia Meloni, the left sounded “the alarm for Italian democracy.” The European Union braced for Italy to join ranks with members like Hungary and Poland who have challenged the bloc’s core values. International investors worried about spooked markets.

headline: Under Trump, Barr and Durham Made a Mockery of the Rules I Wrote
abstract: Merrick Garland needs to remind Americans what independent investigations and decision making look like.
lead_paragraph: The recent revelations about the special counsel John H. Durham’s investigation of the origins of Robert Mueller’s Russia inquiry paint a bleak picture — one that’s thoroughly at odds with governing law. Those rules, called the special counsel regulations, contemplate someone independent of the attorney general who can reassure the public that justice is being done.

headline: Aggressive New York Housing Plan Borrows Ideas From Other States
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s proposal to step up housing construction is likely to face opposition in Albany, especially from Long Island legislators.
