Since then, Ernest has done spirit fingers in the attic of a cartoonishly spooky three-story Queen Anne, although the creepiest thing about him is his combover.

headline: Just for Kicks
abstract: Margaret Seikel and Sophia Maymudes team up for a Friday themeless that sparkles.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon make order from chaos, as usual.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today’s puzzle concerns a complex subject and is an appropriately sprawling solve, with clues that draw from a multitude of topics. The resulting passage is an excerpt from a 2018 book called “The Disordered Mind” by Dr. Eric R. Kandel, who received a Nobel Prize in Medicine or Physiology in 2000 for his discovery of molecular processes that are associated with learning and memory.

headline: U.S. Unseals Terrorism Charges Against Men Identified as MS-13 Leaders
abstract: The indictment detailed the gang’s operations in El Salvador, Mexico and the United States. Three of the men will be transferred to New York to face federal charges.
lead_paragraph: Three men accused of being high-ranking leaders of the transnational criminal gang MS-13 were arrested in Mexico on Wednesday and will be sent to New York to face charges, the Justice Department announced on Thursday.

headline: How Could I Deny Him Fatherhood?
abstract: He wanted children. I didn’t. What happened next was completely unexpected.
lead_paragraph: When we found out the pregnancy was ectopic and life-threatening, my husband vowed to never ask me to have children again.

headline: Getting a Charge Out of a Drone Instructor
abstract: Austin Brown taught Chelsea Wilson how to fly a drone while she was charging her phone. Love took flight later.
lead_paragraph: Chelsea Anais Wilson was on her way to meet her cousins at a magic show at Illusions Bar & Theater in downtown Baltimore in May 2019 when her phone ran out of juice.

headline: Home is Where Their Hearts (and Careers) Are
abstract: Alison Zhuk and Jay Parker first met during a real estate transaction. Years later, the housing market reunited them.
lead_paragraph: The first time Alison Brooke Zhuk encountered Jay Phillip Parker, in 2004, he was a disembodied voice on a speaker phone in a Miami conference room, ready to close a deal.

headline: He Even Recommended a Dentist
abstract: When Cat Lukaszewski and Steven Whalen met in Los Angeles, she was new to the city and he was lost in his hometown. Then they found each other.
lead_paragraph: Catherine Ann Lukaszewski was on a small side street in Los Angeles, looking for the Saint Sophia Greek Orthodox Cathedral, when she met Steven James Whalen who was looking for the same.

headline: Among the Ruins of a Hurricane, Love Thrives
abstract: When they fell in love on a Florida island, Beth Sharer and Jay Goad couldn’t imagine that months later it would be devastated by Hurricane Ian, throwing their wedding plans into the winds.
lead_paragraph: As each day passed on the beaches of Sanibel Island, Fla., Beth Ann Rueter Sharer and Jay Goad fell more deeply in love.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Science Fiction Magazines Battle Flood of Chatbot-Generated Stories, and They’re Not Very Good
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Feb. 24, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t want to read bot stories. I want to read stories that come out of actual imagination and experiences.”

headline: Corrections: Feb. 24, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Feb. 24, 2023.
lead_paragraph: A headline with an article on Wednesday about Saudi Arabian authorities meting out harsh punishments to citizens who criticize the government overstated the impact of posting a single tweet. A man was sent to prison for multiple social media posts and possessing what the government viewed as an insulting picture of Prince Mohammed bin Salman, not for a single tweet.

headline: MacDowell Names Chiwoniso Kaitano Its Next Executive Director
abstract: Kaitano, the first Black person in the role at the artists’ residency, will focus on identifying underrepresented artistic voices and intensifying outreach.
lead_paragraph: MacDowell, a prestigious artists’ residency program in New Hampshire, announced on Friday that Chiwoniso Kaitano would be its next executive director. The appointment of Kaitano, who was previously the executive director of Girl Be Heard and the Ifetayo Cultural Arts Academy, is part of the program’s push toward greater diversity and equity.

headline: Europe Has Weathered an Energy Crisis, for Now
abstract: Worries about gas and oil supplies have greatly eased. But reverberations from the war in Ukraine continue to cloud longer-term forecasts.
lead_paragraph: Within months of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine last year, there was near panic in Europe over energy supplies. Mainstay flows of natural gas through pipelines from Russia were dwindling to a relative trickle, pushing wholesale prices up more than 10 times the level of a year earlier. Oil prices were high. Lawmakers warned of fuel rationing and rolling blackouts, and winter loomed.

headline: Shattered Homes and Lurking Disease: Quake Hardships Pile Up
abstract: Hundreds of thousands are sheltering in tents, breathing air thick with pollutants unleashed from tombs of rubble, fearful that a new disaster could strike at any moment.
lead_paragraph: After powerful earthquakes struck southern Turkey, Eylem Sahutoglu and her family endured two weeks of freezing nights under a blue tarpaulin. Then word came from government engineers who had inspected their building: They could return home.

headline: Stained Glass With an Unsettling Backstory
abstract: The windows at Old First Reformed Church in Brooklyn were donated by families whose ancestors had owned slaves. And inmates at Sing Sing have a disturbing tale of brutality by guards.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll see what a venerable Brooklyn church discovered when it dug deep into history. We’ll also look at allegations that corrections officers at the Sing Sing maximum-security prison stripped and beat inmates in November.

headline: Giant Winter Storm Sweeps the U.S.
abstract: Heavy snowfall caused power outages and treacherous travel conditions across several states.
lead_paragraph: Heavy snowfall caused power outages and treacherous travel conditions across several states.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: The war in Ukraine, one year in.
lead_paragraph: One year after Russia’s invasion, virtually no one in Ukraine has avoided the violence, destruction and bloodshed of the war, which has killed tens of thousands, left millions homeless and turned entire cities into ruins.

headline: Yellen Confronts Russian Officials at G20 Meeting
abstract: In a private session, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said the Russians were “complicit in Putin’s atrocities,” according to remarks shared by a U.S. official.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen directly confronted senior Russian officials during a meeting of finance ministers of the Group of 20 nations on Friday, calling it a “moral imperative” to end the war in Ukraine.

headline: This War May Be Heading for a Cease-Fire
abstract: The Korean War shows that a frozen conflict can be preferable to the alternatives.
lead_paragraph: After a year of brutal fighting, in which thousands of lives have been lost, civilian infrastructure destroyed and untold damage caused, the war has reached a stalemate. Neither side will countenance a negotiated settlement. On the battlefield, battered armies contest small strips of territory, at a terrible cost. The threat of nuclear escalation hangs in the air.

headline: Word of the Day: ingratiating
abstract: This word has appeared in 13 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word ingratiating has appeared in 13 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 26 in “‘Shotgun Wedding’ Review: ‘Die Hard’ With Refreshments” by Calum Marsh:

headline: That Mystery Orb on a Japanese Beach? It Was Just a Buoy. (Sorry.)
abstract: Experts said the sphere that washed ashore, leading to speculation about espionage, was nothing special. “Maybe everybody is paranoid because of balloons,” one said.
lead_paragraph: Not every unidentified spherical object in sight is a spying device, people.

headline: Children and a Year of War
abstract: On this anniversary of the war in Ukraine, what do you notice and wonder about the lives of young people there?
lead_paragraph: Note to teachers: We will be publishing more resources for teaching about Ukraine in coming days.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Ahead of Crucial Election, Security Crises and Kidnappings Plague Nigeria
abstract: Nigerian voters say that insecurity is the most important issue in this week’s presidential election. One man who was kidnapped said, “You can only survive on your own in Nigeria.”
lead_paragraph: A 61-year-old civil engineer was supervising a digging project on a farm in southern Nigeria when five young men carrying AK-47s stormed the place and dragged him into the bush.

headline: Fashioning a Future in the Face of War
abstract: A year after Russia began its invasion of Ukraine, four figures from the Kyiv fashion scene reflect on a year of personal and professional survival.
lead_paragraph: It has been 12 months since Russia began a brutal invasion of Ukraine, forcing millions to flee the country and devastating the local economy, including the budding Kyiv fashion scene.

headline: In ‘The Coldest Case in Laramie,’ a Journalist Returns Home
abstract: For a new podcast, the reporter Kim Barker traveled to Laramie, Wyo., a town she lived in as a teen, to revisit a murder case from 1985.
lead_paragraph: In January 2021, Kim Barker, an investigative reporter at The New York Times, was looking for her next story idea. Quarantining at home, she found that inspiration was hard to come by. So, she dipped into the past. On Google, she entered a name she had first heard nearly four decades earlier: Shelli Wiley.

headline: ‘It’s Complicated’: How Biden and Zelensky Forged a Wartime Partnership
abstract: The relationship between the two leaders has become critical to the future of the international order.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After Russia invaded Ukraine last year, President Biden reflected privately on his long-distance conversations with President Volodymyr Zelensky. He did not know the man well — and might never get to. It was chilling, several people remember him observing grimly, to think that he might be talking with a dead man.

headline: Our Photographers in Ukraine on the Images They Can’t Forget
abstract: In a year of war, New York Times photographers have reported from the front line, from cities and villages and in the footsteps of refugees. These pictures stayed with them.
lead_paragraph: New York Times photographers were on the ground in Ukraine even before Russia invaded in February 2022. Over the course of the year, they have documented every aspect of the conflict that journalistic effort could reach: drone bases and sites of atrocity, packed subways and deserted villages, funerals and joyful crowds, missile paths and refugee routes, front lines and wrecked living rooms.

headline: How Should Fans Feel About Newcastle United?
abstract: Saudi money has revived a Premier League soccer team and sent it to a cup final on Sunday. Those cheering say they shouldn’t have to answer for the source of its recent success.
lead_paragraph: NEWCASTLE-UPON-TYNE, England — As he walked out of the tunnel and onto the field at St. James’ Park, Eddie Howe paused for a beat. Much of the time, Newcastle United’s manager makes a conscious effort to maintain the distance between himself and the effects of his work. It is a natural instinct, a self-defense mechanism.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a preview of the Metropolitan Opera's new staging of "Lohengrin."
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a preview of the Metropolitan Opera's new staging of "Lohengrin."

headline: Cancel a Flight, Ding the ‘Completion Factor’
abstract: Airlines plan out flights months in advance. But how do you know whether you can count on a carrier to stick to its published schedule?  One way is to take a look at its “completion factor.”
lead_paragraph: Airlines plan out flights months in advance. But how do you know whether you can count on a carrier to stick to its published schedule?  One way is to take a look at its “completion factor.”

headline: If You Could Change the Laws of Nature, What Would You Change?
abstract: Would you want to be able to time travel? To be in two places at once? To predict whether someone would laugh at your joke? Share your wildest ideas.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever wished you could do something that is physically impossible in our current reality?

headline: Kevin Killed Sydney, and Reddit’s C.E.O. Defends Section 230
abstract: And what Meta’s new paid verification program means for the future of social media.
lead_paragraph: Bing AI isn’t sentient. But it’s more than glorified autocomplete. How do we talk about — and understand — the power of today’s large language models? Then, Reddit’s C.E.O., Steve Huffman, on Section 230 and why the future of the internet lies with the Supreme Court.

headline: The Real Reason North Dakota Is Going After Books and Librarians
abstract: As a gay young person, I found refuge in libraries. Now in my state and others, they are under attack.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, I was the keynote speaker at the North Dakota Library Association’s annual conference. The theme was “Libraries: The Place For Everyone.” There were rainbow flags, paper-link chains and multicolored glitter scattered across tables. It was the safest I have ever felt back home as an out, gay man. When I was a young person, libraries were where I went to find stories that made me feel I could fit in, not only in North Dakota, but in the wider world. But two pieces of legislation that may soon be signed into law in North Dakota would make it possible to restrict libraries and, in some cases, to imprison librarians.

headline: Sizzling Hot Books for Cold Winter Days
abstract: Cozy up with one of the four new books recommended by our romance columnist.
lead_paragraph: Writers adore putting writers in their fiction, and romance is no exception. This month’s books feature modern fantasy novelists, fairy scholars, historical reading clubs and rakes turned art critics.

headline: Marjorie Taylor Greene Has a Dream
abstract: Her plans for a “national divorce” are very revealing.
lead_paragraph: Marjorie Taylor Greene, now one of the most influential Republicans in the House of Representatives, says it is time for Americans to consider a national divorce.

headline: Wine, Wine and More Wine: The Latest Amenity for Luxury Condo Owners
abstract: Over the past couple of years, residential developers have increased their wine programs, hiring specialists, hosting private tastings and even providing ritzy storing options to house one’s elaborate collection.
lead_paragraph: When Cat Stephani receives a text, there’s a good chance it’s from a wine-enthused resident at 180 East 88th Street who’s in need of a unique buttery French Burgundy, or who has an uncorking question before the guests arrive. Ms. Stephani, a fine wine sales associate at Sotheby’s Wine, an arm of the well-known auction house, is also the building’s resident wine specialist, a new position that started last March.

headline: Inside the Minds of Spiders, Octopuses and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: The science fiction writer Adrian Tchaikovsky explores what an explosion of A.I.-produced content would mean for human society and the human spirit.
lead_paragraph: Adrian Tchaikovsky’s “Children of Time” is about an advanced civilization built by sentient spiders. A sequel, “Children of Ruin,” is about a society run by superintelligent octopuses. I love these books. They’re remarkably serious about their premises, and by the end, it’s human civilization and our limited sensorium that come to seem strange.

headline: Two Caldecott Medal-Winning Illustrators Tell Their Own Stories
abstract: Dan Santat and the late Jerry Pinkney draw from life (literally) in their memoirs for young readers.
lead_paragraph: According to an apocryphal story, the 19th-century French illustrator Gustave Doré was already so famous for his prodigious artistic talent by the age of 6 (circa 1838) that during the processions on feast days little Gustave was carried aloft through the streets of Strasbourg, drawing all the while and tossing his sketches into the upraised hands of the cheering crowds.

headline: The Fury-Paul Fight: YouTube Boxing Meets Saudi Money
abstract: Tommy Fury and Jake Paul have been trading verbal jabs for months. After being postponed twice, their fight on Sunday is being staged in Saudi Arabia, and ESPN is streaming it.
lead_paragraph: The lead-up to Sunday’s fight in Diriyah, Saudi Arabia, between Tommy Fury and Jake Paul looks as if it were ripped out of boxing’s oldest playbook.

headline: Want to Put Something in Writing? Read These Books.
abstract: Getting words onto a page can be a painful process. Authors of all abilities, help is within reach!
lead_paragraph: “Writing is easy,” the sportswriter Red Smith famously said. “I just open a vein and bleed.” As annoying as I find writers who dramatize their craft, the guy had a point. Every ink-stained wretch will tell you about the skills he’s developed in order to avoid the blank page. Because I have to turn this column in by tomorrow, for example, my house is spotless, there is a pork roast in the oven and I am killing it with 20 strangers on Words With Friends.

headline: ‘Party Down’ Gets It: Food Service Is No Party
abstract: The Starz sitcom about the mundane lives of L.A. cater waiters is a smart, funny antidote to the shows and films that focus on chefs and glamorize the business.
lead_paragraph: In their baby-pink bow ties and crumpled white shirts, the catering crew on the Starz series “Party Down” works event after wretched event across Los Angeles: dismal rich-kid sweet 16s and backstage parties for jaded superstars, awkward and unsuccessful suburban orgies, singles seminars for seniors, bland corporate retreats.

headline: The E.S.G. Fight Has Come to This: Bankers Suing Lawyers
abstract: Kentucky passed a law targeting banks and their climate policies. Bankers sued the attorney general. Whose definition of investment risk should prevail?
lead_paragraph: Bow-tied bankers do not often sue a state’s lawyer in chief. So when it does happen, it’s time to pop the popcorn and gather around to watch.

headline: A Publishing Superstar Whose Memoir Shuns Glitz to Explore Private Torment
abstract: In “The Absent Moon,” Luiz Schwarcz, a legendary Brazilian publisher and global tastemaker, shares little of the glamorous life, focusing instead on the lifelong pain of clinical depression.
lead_paragraph: Kazuo Ishiguro called him “lovely.” Andrew Solomon said he “raises the level of discourse across the country.” Salman Rushdie, who has not been in the habit of giving interviews while recovering from an attack, made an exception, calling him “a warm and deeply emotional human being” whose “cultural span is broad and deep.” He added, “I love him very much.”

headline: Mike Pence’s Dangerous Ploy
abstract: The former vice president is injecting campaign-style politics into the special counsel’s inquiry and risks doing real damage to his reputation.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence recently announced he would challenge Special Counsel Jack Smith’s subpoena for him to appear before a grand jury in Washington as part of the investigation into former President Donald Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 presidential election and the related Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol. Mr. Pence claimed that “the Biden D.O.J. subpoena” was “unconstitutional” and “unprecedented.” He added, “For me, this is a moment where you have to decide where you stand, and I stand on the Constitution of the United States.” Mr. Pence vowed to take his fight all the way to the Supreme Court.

headline: Kids Buying Weed From Bodegas Wasn’t in the ‘Legal Weed’ Plan
abstract: The rollout of legal marijuana in New York has been a slow and laborious process. The corner stores aren’t waiting.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, a mother in Westchester learned from her teenage son that he and his friends had gone to a nearby bodega and bought weed. She understood — they were kids, stifled and robbed by the pandemic of so many opportunities for indulging the secretive rituals of adolescence. Their parents only got through it all on Barolo and “The White Lotus.”

headline: You Don’t Have to Be a Skier to Dress Like One (From the ’80s)
abstract: Neon and metallic designs have become so popular among skiers and nonskiers seeking “the vibe” that they’ve become hard to find.
lead_paragraph: Once a month during the winter season, Laura McDonald, owner of Rad Max Vintage, hosts a pop-up shop at a bar named Le Chamois, at the base of Palisades Tahoe, a ski resort in Olympic Valley, Calif. The crowd there — a mix of skiers and nonskiers — comes to party, dancing to classic tunes and taking “shotskis.”

headline: On Broadway, ‘Bad Cinderella’ Is a Rebel With a Brooklyn Accent
abstract: Linedy Genao brings her whole Latina self to Andrew Lloyd Webber’s new musical, which also stars the stage veteran Carolee Carmello as her evil stepmother.
lead_paragraph: Linedy Genao vividly remembers the first time she saw herself represented on Broadway: “In the first couple of lyrics, Usnavi says, ‘Dominican Republic! I love it! Jesus, I’m jealous of it’ — and I almost jumped out of my seat in tears,” Genao said of seeing “In the Heights” as a high school student in 2009. “I was like, ‘They said Dominican Republic on Broadway! I didn’t know that was allowed!’”

headline: Don’t Let Politics Cloud Your View of What’s Going On With Teens and Depression
abstract: Josh Hawley may be right about this one thing.
lead_paragraph: Last year, a study came out showing that left-leaning adolescents were experiencing a greater increase in depression than their more conservative peers. Indeed, while girls are more likely to be depressed than boys, the study, by a group of epidemiologists at Columbia, showed that liberal boys had higher rates of depression than conservative girls.

headline: East Palestine Crisis Tests a Trump-Backed Senator
abstract: J.D. Vance, the freshman senator from Ohio, is in the spotlight for the first time in his tenure as he responds to the train derailment and its aftermath.
lead_paragraph: EAST PALESTINE, Ohio — As Donald J. Trump criticized the federal response to the train derailment that has shaken this Ohio town, there was one leader in Washington he praised repeatedly — the man he helped propel to Congress, Senator J.D. Vance.

headline: ‘Magic’ on the Slopes: In Vail, 2,000 Black Skiers Celebrate a Milestone
abstract: The National Brotherhood of Skiers recently observed 50 years of camaraderie on the slopes with parties, parades, s’mores and, of course, skiing and snowboarding.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks leading up to my February trip to snowy Vail, I was told by several people — promised, really — that I would “feel the magic” of the 50th anniversary gathering of the National Brotherhood of Skiers before I even arrived in Colorado.

headline: Inside New York City’s Nastiest (and Smallest) Newspaper War
abstract: A crusty publisher. A “guerrilla” litigator. An ambitious caregiver. Has the news of Greenwich Village ever been more fun?
lead_paragraph: They say that print is dead and local news is dying. But in the small patch of Lower Manhattan that is Greenwich Village, there are four local newspapers vying for supremacy. Here, print is very much alive.

headline: Digital Clutter Can Be Overwhelming. Here’s How to Clean Up.
abstract: Hint: Tackle your photos last.
lead_paragraph: My sister Heather, a fourth-grade special education teacher, maintains a hyper-organized system on her work computer. All students have their own folders, labeled with their initials and neatly filed away. So pristine is Heather’s desktop that aside from a handful of icons, all that you see is her screen background — a shot of her current class, every smiling face clearly visible.

headline: Delbert Anderson’s Mission: Putting ‘Native Sound Back Into Jazz’
abstract: The trumpeter’s trio takes inspiration from traditional Navajo songs. Its work has stirred up global interest, as well as conversations about the responsibilities of Indigenous artists.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The French Like Protesting, but This Frenchman May Like It the Most
abstract: Jean-Baptiste Reddé has hoisted his giant, colorful signs in nearly every street protest for over a decade, embodying France’s enduring passion for demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: A human tide swept through Paris last month for the type of event France knows only too well — a protest. Union leaders led the march, awash in a multicolored sea of flags. Demonstrators shouted fiery slogans. Clashes with the police erupted.

headline: Where New York’s Sick Sea Turtles Go for Rehab and Squid Snacks
abstract: At New York State’s only sea turtle rehabilitation center, workers are nursing a record number of sick patients back to health.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Thursday morning, Maxine Montello was at work making breakfast for 48 hungry diners.

headline: Forget About Jazz Hands, This Fosse Show Is About Dancin’
abstract: “Bob Fosse’s Dancin’,” revived by the director Wayne Cilento, is back on Broadway. Its stars? An eclectic cast of dancers who are anything but machines.
lead_paragraph: Karli Dinardo never imagined that, at 5 foot 5, she was tall enough to be a Fosse dancer. The Broadway veteran Dylis Croman was introduced to the Fosse style by Ann Reinking, one of his most influential dancers, when she was just 14 at a summer dance program in Florida; she thought, “Where has this been all my life?”

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, February 24, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Fear, Anger, Love: See Ukrainians’ Texts From the First Hours of War
abstract: On Feb. 24, 2022, many people in Ukraine were awakened by explosions, and others by the pings of anxious or supportive messages. Their exchanges that morning are a snapshot of a turning point in modern history.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 24, 2022, many people in Ukraine were awakened by explosions, and others by the pings of anxious or supportive messages. Their exchanges that morning are a snapshot of a turning point in modern history.

headline: Rare and Dangerous: Southern California Faces Floods and Blizzard Conditions
abstract: Snow, high winds and intense rain hit parts of the state Friday. Los Angeles was under a flash flood warning early Saturday, and blizzards were expected in nearby mountains.
lead_paragraph: Whiteouts in the Tehachapi Mountains. Flooding in and around Los Angeles and record rainfall across the Central Valley. Snow in places that had not seen it for decades.

headline: The Times invites readers to reflect on the war in Ukraine.
abstract: Share your reactions and observations about the conflict.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Feb. 24, 2022, Russian forces began shelling Ukrainian cities. Ground troops invaded shortly thereafter.

headline: Letting Go of Her Ballet Dream
abstract: A writer confronts her “Nutcracker” childhood and the unforgiving culture that went with it.
lead_paragraph: One recent Saturday morning at Steps on Broadway, a rehearsal studio on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, ballet dancers pirouetted to recordings of classical piano music while an instructor guided them.

headline: A Year of War in Ukraine
abstract: Ukrainians discuss how their lives have changed since Russia invaded their country.
lead_paragraph: The war has already done untold damage. By some estimates, tens of thousands have died on both sides, and the country has sustained tens of billions of dollars’ worth of damage that has left cities flattened. But Ukraine has also largely stopped the offensives of its much larger and better-armed neighbor and has regained some captured land.

headline: Living Small: 450 Square Feet in the West Village
abstract: When he found his dream home, he wasn’t expecting it to be tiny. Here’s how he made the most of every square foot.
lead_paragraph: When he found his dream home, he wasn’t expecting it to be tiny. Here’s how he made the most of every square foot.

headline: A Serene Oasis in the West Village, in Just 450 Square Feet
abstract: When he found his dream home, he wasn’t expecting it to be quite so small. Here’s how he made the most of every square foot.
lead_paragraph: Many people are looking for the biggest home they can afford. But not Michael Ingram Jones.

headline: A United Front
abstract: Western unity could have consequences beyond Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin was counting on this winter — with its potential for cold weather and high energy prices — to fracture the West’s alliance over Ukraine. He hoped that Americans and Europeans would ask: Is refusing Russian oil and gas really worth it?

headline: Six ways the war changed the world.
abstract: The ripple effects of Russia’s invasion have reordered lives and upended economies. Here are some of the consequences.
lead_paragraph: A year of war in Ukraine has reshaped the world in ways few had predicted. Far beyond the front lines, the ripple effects of Russia’s invasion have reordered lives and upended economies.

headline: Glenn Close: Let’s Hold Our Leaders Accountable
abstract: The actor recalls Richard Nixon’s history and applies a lesson to Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Toward a New Uniform, at Prada
abstract: Miuccia Prada and Raf Simons elevate the everyday, while, at Fendi, Kim Jones splits the suit.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — The Prada show invitation did not arrive alone. It came with a delicate calla lily, rolled out of starched white cotton and ready to be pinned to a lapel. Also a door stopper of a 550-page monograph titled “Recycling Beauty” and chronicling the current exhibition at the Fondazione Prada: an examination of the way in which themes and materials (and ideas) are reused and reinvented over time.

headline: Their Retirement Plan Did Not Include Being Forced to Sell Their Condo
abstract: An investor-owner took over a condo board, terminated a condo declaration and is now requiring a couple to sell their condo in what one expert called “a private form of eminent domain.”

headline: Tell Us What’s Wild Around You
abstract: We’d love to hear about the wildlife in your life, especially if you live in a city.
lead_paragraph: Cities are, by definition, human inventions. But there are all kinds of wild creatures that have adapted themselves to urban life.

headline: Tracking the California Blizzard
abstract: A rare snowstorm could bring several feet of snow to mountains near Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Portions of California are expected to receive snow measured in feet and winds gusting to near hurricane force (74 miles per hour or greater) into Saturday, leading to blizzard conditions. Some mountains in Southern California could see rare snowfalls of up to seven feet, while other areas may get the first measurable snow in decades.

headline: Remembering Thomas H. Lee, a Veteran of Private Equity
abstract: The financier, who died at 78 years old, was known for prominent takeovers of Snapple and Warner Music.
lead_paragraph: Thomas H. Lee, a pioneer in the trillion-dollar business of private equity, has died, his family confirmed yesterday. (The New York Post reports that he was found dead in his Manhattan office of what appeared to be a self-inflicted gunshot wound.)

headline: The Fed’s Preferred Inflation Gauge Sped Back Up
abstract: Inflation is down from its peak last summer, but recent readings have shown substantial and surprising staying power.
lead_paragraph: There was a moment, late last year, when everything seemed to be going according to the Federal Reserve’s plan: Inflation was slowing, consumers were pulling back and the overheated economy was gently cooling down.

headline: ‘Bursting Proud’: Ireland Cheers Paul Mescal for Embracing Irish Language
abstract: On the red carpet for the British Academy Film Awards, the Oscar-nominated actor gave an interview in Ireland’s national language.
lead_paragraph: Paul Mescal, the Irish actor nominated for an Oscar for his performance in “Aftersun,” is a familiar figure on red carpets. But on Sunday at the British Academy Film Awards, he did something he had never publicly done before: He spoke Irish.

headline: Finding Hope in a Ballroom Dance Scene Torn by Tragedy
abstract: Monterey Park has a tight-knit world of passionate dance students who are determined to carry on after the mass shooting in January.
lead_paragraph: It has become a tragic routine: A mass shooting draws attention to an area, thrusting it into an unfortunate spotlight. Suddenly we want to learn the intricate details of a community that had always been in our midst.

headline: Tina Barney: The Photographer’s Origin Story
abstract: With a show at Kasmin and a new book of rediscovered photographs, both called “The Beginning,” the ethnographer of the elite reflects on finding her voice.
lead_paragraph: Tina Barney was home alone in Watch Hill, R.I., during 2020 and needed a Covid quarantine project. While many were cleaning their closets, the acclaimed photographer exhumed about 1,000 35-millimeter negatives shot in the late 1970s and early ’80s, when she was learning the basics of her craft at the Sun Valley Center for the Arts in Idaho and turning a lens to rituals and relationships among her affluent circle of friends and family.

headline: Murdaugh Hammered by Prosecutor Over Where He Was on Night of Killings
abstract: The intense cross-examination of Mr. Murdaugh, who is charged with killing his wife and son, came as he concluded his testimony in his own defense.
lead_paragraph: WALTERBORO, S.C. — After five weeks of trial, the murder case against Alex Murdaugh narrowed on Friday to the question of what happened in a critical few minutes after the prominent South Carolina lawyer went down to his family’s dog kennels where his wife and son were found shot to death later that night.

headline: His Shows Take On Big Issues. They’re Also Good Yarns.
abstract: The British writer and director Alexander Zeldin is bringing “Love,” a European hit set at a temporary-housing facility, to the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: Because his shows are based on research and interviews, and are grounded in pressing social issues, the British writer and director Alexander Zeldin is often said to practice docu-theater.

headline: In ‘The Quiet Girl,’ an Irish Loneliness Rarely Seen Onscreen
abstract: The first Irish-language film to be nominated for an Oscar, directed by Colm Bairéad, tells a gentle story of cultural reticence.
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for the film “The Quiet Girl.”

headline: U.S. Eyes Trade Deals With Allies to Ease Clash Over Electric Car Subsidies
abstract: The Biden administration has faced backlash in Europe and Asia over its plans to bolster electric vehicle and battery production.
lead_paragraph: BENGALURU, India — The Biden administration hopes to reach limited free trade agreements with countries in Europe and Asia that would not require congressional approval as it looks to ease allies’ concerns about legislation that President Biden signed into law last year, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said on Friday.

headline: Ricardo Darín: Argentina’s Lucky Charm at the Oscars
abstract: When the country has a nominated film, it has usually starred this veteran. But the actor says other people have believed in his talent more than he has.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Fortune has long favored Ricardo Darín. More than the subjective concept of talent, it is providence, manifested as other people’s unwavering confidence in his abilities, that the actor credits for his storied career as Argentina’s most celebrated film star internationally.

headline: ‘Radical Care’ for the Beings Around Us
abstract: Here’s what the people who nurture wild animals can teach us about life in the era of climate change.
lead_paragraph: Birds of prey have preoccupied me lately.

headline: When to Replace 5 Household Essentials
abstract: Nothing lasts forever.
lead_paragraph: Nothing lasts forever.

headline: Cosori Recalls 2 Million Air Fryers After Reports of Fire and Burn Risk
abstract: A faulty wire connection caused some air fryers to overheat and catch fire, causing at least 10 minor injuries.
lead_paragraph: Cosori is voluntarily recalling more than two million of its air fryers after a fault was discovered that created fire and burn hazards, the U.S. Consumer Product Safety and Commission announced on Thursday.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Adrian Tchaikovsky
abstract: A conversation with science-fiction writer Adrian Tchaikovsky.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Adrian Tchaikovsky. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: What I’m Watching, Weimar Noir Edition
abstract: “Babylon Berlin” is the TV show I can’t stop thinking about.
lead_paragraph: This week I’ve been watching “Babylon Berlin,” a television show about detectives in Weimar Germany, which has so captivated me that I barreled straight through the new season and then started rewatching the whole series from the beginning.

headline: Former Jail Guard Union Chief Wins Early Release From Bribery Sentence
abstract: Norman Seabrook took kickbacks in exchange for placing most of the union’s pension in a risky hedge fund. It lost $19 million of the $20 million investment.
lead_paragraph: Norman Seabrook, the former longtime leader of the New York City correction officers’ union who in 2019 was sentenced to nearly five years in prison for taking a bribe, was granted release on Friday by a Manhattan judge who noted an “unjust disparity” between his sentence and that of the businessman who had paid him off.

headline: On Reading ‘A Wrinkle in Time’
abstract: Sarah Lyall discusses reading Madeleine L’Engle’s classic novel at a pivotal moment in her childhood, and the lessons she has extracted from the book throughout her life.
lead_paragraph: Some books find us at the right age and in the right frame of mind to lodge an enduring hold on our imagination; these are the books we turn to again and again, which become the cherished classics of our personal canon.

headline: A Common Sight on U.S. Campuses: The Rest of the World’s Female Olympians
abstract: A federal law opened doors for millions of American women. It also made the United States an incubator for women’s national teams worldwide.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Sini Karjalainen could have played ice hockey closer to home.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Good morning. The weather’s mild and the ground spongy where I stay these days, and if the trees aren’t budding, there’s still a faint springlike balm in the air. It’s fool’s gold, perhaps, the weathered mica of hope. March could yet bring some corker storms and real snow. So this weekend, I’ll be cooking shoulder-season food: recipes to welcome where we’re going, and others to acknowledge where we are.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The weather’s mild and the ground spongy where I stay these days, and if the trees aren’t budding, there’s still a faint springlike balm in the air. It’s fool’s gold, perhaps, the weathered mica of hope. March could yet bring some corker storms and real snow. So this weekend, I’ll be cooking shoulder-season food: recipes to welcome where we’re going, and others to acknowledge where we are.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: From rousing war films to gory massacres, this month’s action picks are bloodier than usual.
lead_paragraph: Similar to Robert DeNiro’s sports-betting character in “Casino,” the protagonist of the “The Last Deal,” Vincent (Anthony Molinari), begins with a workmanlike voice-over in this crime thriller from the writer-director Jonathan Salemi, explaining how he rose from a weed grower to a top distributor only to fall on hard times. A dubious friend of Vincent’s, Bobby (Mister Fitzgerald), has a lifeline: Some Armenians want to sell cheap product to them that can be flipped for five times the price. It seems too good to be true.

headline: Some People on Ozempic Lose the Desire to Drink. Scientists Are Asking Why.
abstract: As the diabetes drug gains more attention, a surprising side effect has emerged.
lead_paragraph: At what Eva Monsen calls the height of her drinking — during the long slog of the coronavirus pandemic — she drained around half a bottle of wine each day. Ms. Monsen, 46, wasn’t a regular drinker before the pandemic, but she grew to rely on several glasses of wine to help her relax and soften the tension of life during and after lockdown.

headline: ‘Cocaine Bear’ Review: She Never Forgets Her Lines
abstract: The greatest joke of this blood-spattered horror-comedy from Elizabeth Banks is that it exists.
lead_paragraph: When you were in high school or college, did you know someone who would stay up late, get stoned and wonder what would happen if you got a pet high? That person went to Hollywood. How else to explain “Cocaine Bear,” a chaotic, blood-splattered major studio horror-comedy whose greatest joke is that it exists.

headline: Vice C.E.O.’s Departure Signals Fallen Hopes for Digital Media
abstract: Nancy Dubuc is leaving the media company, which is exploring a sale of some or all of the business, after nearly five years there.
lead_paragraph: When Vice Media named Nancy Dubuc as its new chief executive in 2018, her contract hinted at one of her missions. Sell the company — at the time a darling of the media industry — and she could cash in on a big stock grant, according to a copy of the contract obtained by The New York Times.

headline: BASF to Cut 2,600 Jobs After a Year of High Energy Costs
abstract: The German chemical giant blamed a drop in profits on stubbornly high natural gas prices and shifting global demand.
lead_paragraph: The chemical giant BASF announced plans on Friday to cut 2,600 positions, mainly in Germany, as it reported a slide in earnings that it attributed to shifting global demand and a loss of the cheap Russian natural gas that has served as a backbone for the company for decades.

headline: The Oligarchs’ Derby
abstract: When the top teams in Greece meet, the story lines, and the rivalries, regularly extend far beyond the soccer field.
lead_paragraph: Olympiacos called it the Match for Peace. On April 9 last year, a little more than a month after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the Greek club staged a friendly with Shakhtar Donetsk. It was a heartfelt, poignant sort of occasion, the first game Shakhtar had played since it had fled a war in its homeland.

headline: U.S. Girls’ Luxuriously Absurd Disco, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Gracie Abrams, Ashley McBryde and Skrillex.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Obie Awards Honor ‘English’ as Best New Play
abstract: A ceremony for the awards, celebrating work Off and Off Off Broadway, will be held Monday, but organizers decided to announce the winners in advance.
lead_paragraph: The Obie Awards, back on track after a lengthy pandemic hiatus, are naming “English,” an acclaimed comedic drama set in an Iranian test-prep classroom, the best new American play staged Off Broadway over a two-year period.

headline: M.L.B.’s New Rules Are All About Action
abstract: A pitch clock, no defensive shifts and larger bases represent some of the largest single-season rule changes in major league history.
lead_paragraph: A pitch clock, no defensive shifts and larger bases represent some of the largest single-season rule changes in major league history.

headline: Stocks Sink for Third Straight Week
abstract: A turn in the market has eroded the sharp rally at the start of the year, as investors have fretted about recent signals suggesting a resurgence in inflation.
lead_paragraph: Stocks slumped Friday to cap their worst week of the year, as investors balked at fresh government data that added to a flurry of signals showing a resurgence in inflation.

headline: A Dave Brubeck Cantata Boasts Star Soloists: His Sons
abstract: “The Gates of Justice,” a large-scale 1969 choral work about relations between Black and Jewish Americans, is being performed in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Want to give us a blast?” the bassist Chris Brubeck asked the young woman in a music studio at the University of California, Los Angeles, on Wednesday morning.

headline: What Sounds Did Dinosaurs Make?
abstract: A new study of a fossilized ankylosaur suggests it could have uttered birdlike calls.
lead_paragraph: In the next generation of dinosaur-based blockbuster films, some of the star creatures could perhaps sound more like a bird and a little less like a roaring lion.

headline: The Perfect Retirement Investment Nobody Wants, Part 2
abstract: It doesn’t exist, but could it?
lead_paragraph: Readers were intrigued by my newsletter last Friday, “The Perfect Retirement Investment Nobody Wants.” It was about a concept, never realized, for a hybrid product combining long-term care insurance with an immediate annuity — a stream of monthly payments that begins right away and lasts as long as you live.

headline: These Veggies Are Sneaky
abstract: Ali Slagle’s recipe for salad pizza with white beans and Parmesan will get you to eat your greens.
lead_paragraph: Hello, Five Weeknight Dishers! It’s Krysten, this newsletter’s editor, stepping out from behind the curtain while Emily is out.

headline: Nigerian Politician Arrested With Nearly $500,000 on Eve of Election, Police Say
abstract: For years, Nigerian politicians have been accused of buying votes. The lawmaker, the police say, was caught with dollar bills and a list of possible recipients.
lead_paragraph: A Nigerian politician was arrested on Friday with nearly $500,000 in U.S. bills in his car and a list of possible recipients for the money, the police said, announcing his detention on the eve of a closely watched presidential election in which vote buying has worried officials.

headline: Right Wing or Woke? The Complicated Politics of ‘Yellowstone.’
abstract: Patriarchy and pantheism in the American West.
lead_paragraph: I wrote a little bit about “Yellowstone” after my family’s cross-country road trip last summer, linking the hit soap opera to ongoing debates about land use and development and conservation in the American West. My column described the series as very “red state” and cited a very blue-state essay in which the author, Vulture’s Kathryn VanArendonk, described being drawn into the show almost in spite of herself. With its portrait of an embattled but sympathetic white male patriarch defending a cowboy way of life against coastal money and Californian transplants, it didn’t seem controversial to present the show as leaning rightward.

headline: The Prospect Park Gator Was Not the First. Here Are Other Urban Gators.
abstract: A brief history of New York City alligators.
lead_paragraph: An emaciated alligator found in Prospect Park last week was the latest in a long line of saw-toothed reptiles found all over New York City, raising several obvious questions: What? How? And why does this keep happening?

headline: Love Letter: A Decade-Long Negotiation
abstract: He wanted children; she didn’t. How could they move forward?
lead_paragraph: After growing up with a tumultuous family life, Rachel Heng decided that she did not want children. However, her husband desperately wanted to become a father.

headline: Zelensky answers reporters’ questions for hours, expressing confidence in Ukraine’s eventual victory.
abstract: On the anniversary of Russia’s full-scale invasion, Mr. Zelensky offered a broad overview of where the war stood, the challenges Ukraine faced and the opportunities in the months ahead.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — In a wide-ranging, hourslong news conference in a basement in the heart of Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, President Volodymyr Zelensky said Friday that he was confident his country could win the war this year, expressed hope that China would not provide lethal military aid to Russia and implored Israel to get off the fence and side with his nation.

headline: China Reprises Old Themes in Ukraine Plan, Casting Itself as Neutral
abstract: A year after Russia’s invasion, Beijing released a paper declaring its position on the war: It called for an end to the fighting but avoided demands that could hurt its ties with Russia.
lead_paragraph: After a drumroll of diplomatic activity suggesting that China was poised to play a more energetic role in seeking peace in Ukraine, Beijing issued a paper on Friday that reprised its established views on the war, calling for an end to fighting while avoiding demands — or words like “invasion” — that could hurt its ties with Russia.

headline: Spencer, the Dog for Whom Boston Marathoners Happily Stopped, Dies at 13
abstract: The golden retriever drew hugs and selfies as the official dog of the Boston Marathon, and was “too good not to share,” his owner, Rich Powers, said.
lead_paragraph: Spencer, a golden retriever who became the Boston Marathon’s official race dog, died at home in Holliston, Mass., on Feb. 17. He was 13 years and 6 ½ months old.

headline: ‘The Consultant’ Review: When Your Start-Up Goes to Hell
abstract: Christoph Waltz plays a very, very bad boss in a dark tech-industry satire from Amazon Prime Video.
lead_paragraph: “The Consultant,” an amusing trifle on Amazon Prime Video that burns through most of its dark-comic capital before its eight episodes are up, is set during a critical moment at a tech company: when new, “competent” management takes over for the brilliant but callow founder.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: This week’s suggestions include a reprint of Nora Ephron’s first novel, Tolkien’s final writings on the world of “The Lord of the Rings” and more.
lead_paragraph: This week’s suggestions include a reprint of Nora Ephron’s first novel, Tolkien’s final writings on the world of “The Lord of the Rings” and more.

headline: Stop Policing Language on College Campuses
abstract: Responses to columns by Pamela Paul and Nicholas Kristof on language changes. Also: A family’s journey with cancer; Yiddish; protecting grizzly bears.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: My Friend Is Dating a Murderer. Should I Do Anything About It?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what to do when a roommate is in a relationship with a convicted killer.
lead_paragraph: I have a childhood friend who recently moved into my home. Everything has been going well, except she is dating an inmate who was convicted of murdering one of his family members. This inmate is somebody we knew when we were younger; our friend group was very affected by the murder. I have my own personal trauma with the inmate, and I know my roommate does as well. He is really not a great guy. But my roommate is convinced the inmate has changed. She tells me details about their relationship, as friends do. It’s clear to me he hasn’t changed much. I avoid talking about him as much as possible and change the subject if he is brought up. Although he still has 11 years left on his sentence, he is trying to appeal for a lesser term. I am hopeful their relationship will end before he is released. Otherwise, I fear for her safety; I can see the red flags every day. What do I do to help? My family tells me that if I try to talk to her about it, I will just push her away. But I’m having a hard time just standing by. — Name Withheld

headline: Wonking Out: Conservatives Face a Rude Fiscal Awokening
abstract: They can’t actually find much wasteful spending to cut.
lead_paragraph: The Republican response to President Biden’s suggestion that they want to cut Medicare and Social Security has been basically that of the Monty Python knights to the Killer Rabbit of Caerbannog: “Run away, run away!” But many in the party still appear to hope that they can make big spending cuts without hurting anyone they care about.

headline: Snow in California Surprises and Delights
abstract: Whiteout conditions shuttered roads in the mountains, while a dusting of snow on beaches brought residents out to marvel.
lead_paragraph: A rare and powerful winter storm sweeping the West Coast is battering areas unaccustomed to snow and wintry mix, bringing parts of Portland, Ore., to a halt before moving south toward California. The varied precipitation, ranging from rain to snow to graupel, a slushier version of snow, was met with a mix of distress and marvel: Whiteout conditions shuttered roads in the mountains and stranded drivers, while beaches in areas like Santa Cruz, Calif., received a light dusting.

headline: Revenue Grew at Condé Nast Last Year, but Shy of Target
abstract: The chief at Condé Nast, which only occasionally discusses its financial results, said ad revenue grew year over year, while subscriptions and e-commerce fell short of goals.
lead_paragraph: Roger Lynch, the chief executive of Condé Nast, the publisher of Vogue, The New Yorker and Vanity Fair, said in an interview on Friday that the company’s business grew last year, but narrowly missed its revenue target.

headline: In the Wild Tale of ‘Cocaine Bear,’ an Apex Predator Is the True Star
abstract: The horror-comedy is based on a real story from 1985, but the director Elizabeth Banks and writer Jimmy Warden gave their furry lead a different ending.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Warden wanted his bear to have its full 15 minutes of fame — while it was still alive.

headline: How Well Do You Know These Page-Turners Set in Washington, D.C.?
abstract: Along with its memorials and monuments, the nation’s capital has been a frequent location for many spine-tingling novels. Take this week’s quiz to see how many plots and places you recognize!
lead_paragraph: Along with its memorials and monuments, the nation’s capital has been a frequent location for many spine-tingling novels. Take this week’s quiz to see how many plots and places you recognize!

headline: Spring Comes Early With This Bright, Cozy Dinner
abstract: A mustardy beet salad, a creamy chicken main and a warm lemon pudding: This menu from David Tanis looks ahead in all the right ways.
lead_paragraph: Spring may not be here quite yet, but I’m more than ready for it. Ready for lighter, brighter colors and flavors. Ready for clear skies. Ready for a dinner that tastes like spring, verdant and hopeful.

headline: ‘All Quiet on the Western Front’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Edward Berger narrates a sequence from his Oscar-nominated film.
lead_paragraph: The director Edward Berger narrates a sequence from his Oscar-nominated film.

headline: Watch a Harrowing Battle Scene in ‘All Quiet on the Western Front.’
abstract: The director Edward Berger narrates a sequence from his drama, nominated for nine Academy Awards and winner of best film at the BAFTAs.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: In Town Where Train Derailed, Lawyers Are Signing Up Clients in Droves
abstract: Lawyers have poured into East Palestine, Ohio, since the derailment that led to a burn-off of toxic chemicals, filing more than a dozen lawsuits so far on behalf of local residents.
lead_paragraph: EAST PALESTINE, Ohio — In the three weeks since a freight train derailed in East Palestine and released more than 100,000 gallons of toxic chemicals, lawyers have poured into the little town, signing up clients, gathering evidence and already filing more than a dozen lawsuits in federal court on behalf of local residents.

headline: Review: He Needs Your Help. And She’s Trapped Under a Mound.
abstract: In Dean Moss’s “Your marks and surface,” at Danspace, images of softness and struggle coexist.
lead_paragraph: So many potent images linger in the aftermath of Dean Moss’s “Your marks and surface,” a spare yet dense and delicately layered work that had its premiere at Danspace Project on Thursday. One moment that keeps replaying in my mind: the choreographer asking for assistance.

headline: Canada Saw a Deadly Derailment. A Decade Later, Little Has Changed.
abstract: When a runaway train loaded with oil jumped the tracks in Lac-Mégantic, Quebec, 47 people died in Canada’s worst rail disaster in nearly 150 years.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Its nearly silent approach belied the fiery death it was bringing.

headline: Russia, Ukraine and the West Vow to Fight On, in a War With No End in Sight
abstract: Moscow and Kyiv face daunting challenges in moving forward, with no clear sense of what an attainable victory might look like.
lead_paragraph: At the one-year mark of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin and President Biden both insisted this week that they were committed to the fight. Mr. Putin prepared Russia for a long war to be waged “step by step,” while the American president said “we will not tire” in the quest to ensure a democratic Ukraine.

headline: An Office in Which Screaming Is Encouraged
abstract: At the Berlin headquarters of the art magazine Blau International, editor in chief Cornelius Tittel doubles as an instructor of Kundalini yoga classes.
lead_paragraph: On a Sunday afternoon in January, high-pitched shrieks and deep howls could be heard emanating from an elegant Art Deco building in Berlin’s Charlottenburg neighborhood. Their source was the third-floor office of Blau International, a large-format art magazine whose contributors include the French interiors photographer François Halard, the French fashion stylist Marie Chaix and the German astrologer Alexander von Schlieffen. Published twice a year in English by the German media group Axel Springer and overseen by founding editor in chief Cornelius Tittel, 46, the nine-year-old magazine has recently run such stories as an essay by the Austrian novelist Peter Handke about the 17th-century French artist Nicolas Poussin and one by Tittel himself on the psychedelic work of the young Parisian painter Pol Taburet.

headline: Former Soldier Is Charged With Killing Pregnant Army Private 2 Decades Ago
abstract: Private Amanda Gonzales, 19, was on her first assignment in the Army when she was killed on a military base in Germany. A former soldier, arrested on Thursday, has been charged with her murder.
lead_paragraph: Several months into her U.S. Army service in Germany, Private Amanda Gonzales called her mother back home in Texas and told her that she was pregnant. She was only 19 and on her first assignment in the Army. She was excited and planned to name the child Alicia Marie, her mother, Gloria Bates, recalled.

headline: What the HBO Show ‘South Side’ Teaches Us
abstract: Black people are entirely comfortable with “details.”
lead_paragraph: Sometimes a very special sitcom that has nothing to do with school nonetheless gets you thinking about education and learning. In the case of HBO Max’s treasure “South Side,” it has also gotten me thinking about race, culture and even our current notions of alternative forms of objectivity.

headline: Twin Brothers Face Prosecution as Manhattan Cracks Down on Wage Theft
abstract: Prosecutors say Lulzim and Gzim Shabaj stiffed day laborers on construction sites for thousands of dollars. When one worker complained, he was punched bloody, they say.
lead_paragraph: A week after the Manhattan district attorney’s office announced a new unit to prosecute wage theft, it is accusing a pair of twins of stealing construction workers’ money — and charging one with assaulting and threatening two day laborers.

headline: 5 New(ish) Australasian Books for Your Reading List
abstract: Great reads you might have missed.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to Australia and New Zealand would do well to carve out some time for their independent bookstores. A few immediate standouts: Unity Books in Wellington, Time Out Bookstore in Auckland, Readings in Melbourne (the Carlton branch is particularly good) and Gertrude & Alice in Sydney.

headline: 12 States Sue F.D.A., Seeking Removal of Special Restrictions on Abortion Pill
abstract: The suit argues that rules applying to mifepristone unnecessarily limit patients’ access to medication abortion.
lead_paragraph: The attorneys general of a dozen Democratic-controlled states sued the Food and Drug Administration on Friday, asking a judge to remove special restrictions that the federal agency has long applied to the first of two drugs used in medication abortion.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: This Year, the Berlin Film Festival Sparkles
abstract: After two years of pandemic disruptions, the festival returns in full, with Kristen Stewart as the jury president and gems like Celine Song’s “Past Lives.”
lead_paragraph: In February, when the Berlin International Film Festival takes place, the German capital is reliably what meteorologists term “bloody cold.” The overriding fashion aesthetic is puffer jackets, the puffier the better, accessorized with a scarf and a scowl.

headline: Thomas H. Lee, Pioneer in Leveraged Buyouts, Is Dead at 78
abstract: Born into wealth, he became a billionaire in founding an aggressive Boston private equity firm. He was remembered as a “kinder, gentler” corporate raider.
lead_paragraph: Before the era of swashbuckling corporate raiders rained riches and fear on Wall Street, there was Thomas H. Lee.

headline: ‘Mama, I Want to Sing!’ Returns for 40th Anniversary
abstract: Gospel soul returns to the stage as the long-running musical is revived for Black History Month at El Museo’s El Teatro.
lead_paragraph: Ahmaya Knoelle Higginson first appeared onstage before she was even born. Her mother, Vy Higginsen, a co-writer of the gospel musical “Mama, I Want to Sing!,” was pregnant with Higginson in 1983 as she performed in the show about a preacher’s daughter who becomes a pop sensation. When Higginson was a toddler, she waddled backstage during the musical’s international tours, and at the age of 10 she joined its choir for performances at Madison Square Garden. Then as a teenager, she stepped into the lead role of Doris Winter.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Cash Crunch in Nigeria Causes Chaos Before an Election
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, February 23, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “We’ve been in hell, serious hell. It’s choking — as if they are pressing my throat.”

headline: Raymond Trollat, Who Took a Hilly Wine Region to New Heights, Dies at 91
abstract: Few knew the Northern Rhône Valley when he began growing grapes and making wine in the 1940s. By the time he retired, the region, and his wines, were world famous.
lead_paragraph: Raymond Trollat, a storied grape grower and winemaker who embodied the spirit and history of France’s Northern Rhône Valley and its area known as the St.-Joseph appellation, died on Sunday in Lyon, France. He was 91.

headline: Doctor Describes and Denounces C.I.A. Practice of ‘Rectal Feeding’ of Prisoners
abstract: In a hearing at Guantánamo Bay, an expert gave a graphic public depiction of torture after the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks.
lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — Over the years, the Central Intelligence Agency’s use of waterboarding and other forms of torture in its secret overseas prisons after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks has been revealed in government leaks, testimony and a damning Senate investigation.

headline: Robert Hébras, Last Survivor of a 1944 Massacre in France, Dies at 97
abstract: Dead bodies shielded him as the Nazis killed 643 people in Oradour-sur-Glane. He spent his life keeping the memory of the slaughter alive.
lead_paragraph: Robert Hébras, who, shielded under dead bodies, survived an infamous 1944 massacre in which members of an SS Panzer division killed almost everyone in the village of Oradour-sur-Glane in France, died on Feb. 11 in a hospital in Saint-Junien, not far from Oradour. He was 97 and the last survivor of the massacre.

headline: Biden Reaffirms Support for Ukraine Amid Concerns About Russia-Iran Ties
abstract: The Biden administration announced new measures targeting Moscow and supporters of President Vladimir V. Putin’s war.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden marked the start of a second year of war in Europe on Friday by announcing billions of dollars in additional military aid for Ukraine, imposing more sanctions on those helping President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and delivering a grim warning about an alliance between Russia and Iran.

headline: Prosecutor Questions Alex Murdaugh in Murder Trial
abstract: Mr. Murdaugh testified that he had cooperated with the police during the investigation of the deaths of his wife and son, despite having lied about his whereabouts on the night of the murders.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Murdaugh testified that he had cooperated with the police during the investigation of the deaths of his wife and son, despite having lied about his whereabouts on the night of the murders.

headline: First At-Home Combination Test for Flu and Covid Is OK’d by the F.D.A.
abstract: But the company that created the 30-minute, over-the-counter test has filed for bankruptcy, so the product’s eventual availability to consumers remains unclear.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration issued an emergency authorization for the first over-the-counter, at-home combination flu and Covid test on Friday, just two days after the company that makes the test announced that it had filed for bankruptcy protection based, in part, on the agency’s lengthy approval timeline.

headline: Protests and Defiance Mark a Year of Russia’s War on Ukraine
abstract: On the anniversary of the invasion, Volodymyr Zelensky held a marathon news conference and vowed victory if Ukraine’s allies remained united like a fist.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine marked the anniversary of the Russian invasion on Friday with a show of defiance, as anti-Kremlin protests took place around the world and the United States made a significant commitment of new weaponry to the country.

headline: Snow? Graupel? Whatever Is Falling, It’s Making Californians Giddy
abstract: A cold storm has created winter wonderlands in unusual California spots that almost never see snow.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Stay in, the meteorologists had said. Historic blizzards are coming to California. There will be snowplows.

headline: ‘Everything Good?’
abstract: Trent H. Evans makes us hustle up the stairs in his Saturday debut.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a quirky challenge from a constructor I didn’t recognize at first, Trent H. Evans. It’s his Saturday debut after creating grids for Mondays, Tuesdays and Fridays, and I had to look back in the archives to remember his last puzzle for The Times. It was one I loved (a circle-shaped Friday themeless, with SPACECAMP at its north pole and SPINCLASS in the south).

headline: With a Quick Violation, M.L.B.’s Pitch Clock Era Begins
abstract: Manny Machado was issued a strike for not being ready in the batter’s box as baseball got its first look at a sped-up game.
lead_paragraph: PEORIA, Ariz. — In the first inning of a spring training game against the Seattle Mariners here on Friday, San Diego Padres third baseman Manny Machado placed his left foot in the batter’s box, tapped his bat on home plate and twirled it around before coming set. It is a routine he has done countless times.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Marathoners Mourn Spencer, a Race Fan Who Inspired Boston
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 25, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Everyone claims to have the best dog and no one is wrong. Spencer did not know he was as special as he was.”

headline: Corrections: Feb. 25, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 25, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about a new olive oil coffee line at Starbucks in Italy misstated Howard Schultz’s role at Starbucks. He helped build the company in leadership roles, but he is not a founder.

headline: What Fox News Hosts Said Privately vs. Publicly About Voter Fraud
abstract: Dozens of private messages, released as part of a lawsuit against Fox, revealed what was said behind the scenes.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of private messages, released as part of a lawsuit against Fox, revealed what was said behind the scenes.

headline: Why Investing at the Last Moment Can Hurt Your Returns
abstract: You can still put money in an I.R.A. for 2022, and that’s better than not investing at all. But an early start would have given you a great advantage, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: If you haven’t put money into an individual retirement account for 2022, do it before the April deadline. That’s a standard tax tip for investors this time of year.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: They Went Viral and Made Money. Now They Owe Taxes.
abstract: Many content creators who earned money for the first time on platforms like TikTok, Instagram and YouTube are figuring out what a 1099 form is and what they can write off.
lead_paragraph: Fortunes can ebb and flow substantially on social media platforms, with content creators reaping riches from viral videos one month — and making little the next. Influencers may also receive lavish gifts, one-off checks and direct tips from loyal viewers.

headline: What You Need to Know for the 2023 Tax Season
abstract: Doing taxes in 2023 feels a lot like it did before the pandemic. Still, there are some meaningful changes to keep in mind.
lead_paragraph: The 2023 tax filing season is probably most notable for what’s missing: After three years of stimulus payments and pandemic tax breaks, nearly all of those extra benefits have faded away — and tax refunds are likely to shrink as a result.

headline: The Salton Sea, an Accident of History, Faces a New Water Crisis
abstract: The vast California lake relies on runoff from cropland to avoid disappearing. But as farmers face water cuts due to drought and an ever drier Colorado River, the Salton Sea stands to lose again.
lead_paragraph: BRAWLEY, Calif. — The drought crisis on the Colorado River looms large in California’s Imperial Valley, which produces much of the nation’s lettuce, broccoli and other crops, and now faces water cuts. But those cuts will also be bad news for the environmental and ecological disaster unfolding just to the north, at the shallow, shimmering and long-suffering Salton Sea.

headline: After 8 Lost Years, a Wide-Open Election in the Giant of Africa
abstract: In Nigeria’s presidential election on Saturday, voters were desperate to elect a leader who can unleash their youthful country’s potential and chart a new course after years of dashed hopes.
lead_paragraph: After Nigeria won independence from Britain in 1960, thousands of Nigerians watched as their new green and white flag was raised over the capital at the time, Lagos, at midnight. As fireworks lit up the streets, hope and promise filled the air.

headline: Exploring the Wilds: Magical Marshlands, Nascent Planets
abstract: New books by Frances Hardinge, Annalee Newitz and Freya Marske.
lead_paragraph: A new Frances Hardinge novel is always cause for celebration, and UNRAVELLER (423 pp., Amulet, $19.99) is no exception. In the country of Raddith, people live in complicated relation to the Wilds: magical marshlands full of dangerous gifts and beautiful threats. Among these are the Little Brothers, spiderlike creatures who, out of sympathy for the angry and suffering, grant some people the ability to curse others. A curse might make a wicked man’s hands weep blood, turn a woman into a harp or children into birds, all depending on the grief and fury of the curser.

headline: Give Your Heirloom Jewelry a Modern Makeover
abstract: Couples looking to add a personal touch to their weddings are reimagining jewels passed down through generations and recasting them into new creations.
lead_paragraph: As more couples seek to make their weddings more meaningful, repurposing family jewelry to create new pieces that can be worn as engagement or wedding jewels has become a popular way to infuse tradition into a modern celebration of love.

headline: How the Fed Opened Pandora’s Box
abstract: Jerome H. Powell’s no-holds-barred response to the pandemic was made possible by history. It raises questions about the future.
lead_paragraph: It was July 2019 when Representative Rashida Tlaib, a Michigan Democrat, asked Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, whether he would use the central bank’s powers to help state and local governments during the next recession.

headline: Unlikely Rebels With a Very Good Cause
abstract: Kate Zernike’s “The Exceptions” tells the infuriating, inspiring story of the sexism faced by female scientists at M.I.T. — and how they fought back.
lead_paragraph: The word “exception” implies rules, and as we know, rules are made to be broken. But in real life, it can be a frustrating business — especially if you’re a woman in science, especially in the decades leading up to the 21st century and especially if you’re not the rule-breaking type.

headline: Take Water. Add Sodium Chloride. Chill and Squeeze Into Salty Ices.
abstract: The lab-created compounds — never seen before — might exist naturally on icy moons in the outer solar system.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have discovered two new forms of salty ice that probably do not exist naturally on Earth but might be found on icy moons farther out in the solar system.

headline: How Bjarke Ingels, Architect, Spends His Sundays
abstract: The Dane is into cargo bikes, making pancakes and spiffing up the mysterious top floor of an Art Deco hotel.
lead_paragraph: After Bjarke Ingels left Copenhagen for New York City in 2010, his first project in Manhattan was a real humdinger: The stark and pyramidal Via 57 West, an apartment building with a not-small hole sliced down the middle, allowing for a courtyard.

headline: A Video-Gaming School Stumbles on a Way to Get Dropouts Back in Class
abstract: Japan’s first e-sports high school thought it would turn out pro gamers. Instead, it attracted an unexpected demographic.
lead_paragraph: Wataru Yoshida had had enough. He wasn’t going back to school.

headline: Ephemeral Tattoos Were ‘Made to Fade.’ Some Have a Ways to Go.
abstract: The temporary tattoo company updated its product description after customer complaints about persistent tattoos.
lead_paragraph: In May 2021, Claudia Mangione got a tattoo of a match on her rib cage. Ephemeral, the studio that tattooed her, had just opened in the Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn, and its draw was a trademarked tattoo ink that was advertised as “made to fade” nine to 15 months after application.

headline: Their Hair Long and Flowing or in Ponytails, Women in Iran Flaunt Their Locks
abstract: Defiant resistance to Iran’s mandatory hijab law has exploded across the country after nationwide protests that erupted last year.
lead_paragraph: An engineer strode onstage at an event in Tehran, wearing tight pants and a stylish shirt, and clutching a microphone in one hand. Her long brown hair, tied in a ponytail, swung freely behind her, uncovered, in open defiance of Iran’s strict hijab law.

headline: In a California Town, Farmworkers Start From Scratch After Surprise Flood
abstract: Planada residents spent decades building their lives in the Central Valley community. A brutal series of storms destroyed what they had.
lead_paragraph: PLANADA, Calif. — Until the floodwaters came, until they rushed in and destroyed nearly everything, the little white house had been Cecilia Birrueta’s dream.

headline: Where’s the Snow? Snowboarding Brands Are Trying to Find Out for Themselves.
abstract: Brands are changing their strategies and entering policy debates, as climate change continues to upend the snowfall calendar.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 1, 2021, during the biggest blizzard to hit New York City in five years, snowboarders turned city spots into their playground. Hollis DuPre, 23, grinded rails at 30 Rockefeller Plaza. Jayell White, a 30-year-old Bronx native, popped off a brick wall in Battery Park.

headline: The Furniture Hustlers of Silicon Valley
abstract: As tech companies cut costs and move to remote work, their left-behind office furniture has become part of a booming trade.
lead_paragraph: Brandi Susewitz touched the curved stitching on a pair of bright red Arne Jacobsen Egg Chairs and announced they were worth around $5,000 each. The chairs were in pristine condition, perched in the reception area of the software company Sitecore’s office in downtown San Francisco.

headline: Alone and Exploited, Migrant Children Work Brutal Jobs Across the U.S.
abstract: Arriving in record numbers, they’re ending up in dangerous jobs that violate child labor laws — including in factories that make products for well-known brands like Cheetos and Fruit of the Loom.
lead_paragraph: It was almost midnight in Grand Rapids, Mich., but inside the factory everything was bright. A conveyor belt carried bags of Cheerios past a cluster of young workers.
